column2: Carlos L. Henriquez 3d's bulldog, Ch. Basford Milk Meat, scored an impressive victory yesterday when he was named best-in-show in the Brooklyn Kennel Club's tenth annual fixture.
Four men and their Air Force plane have been down on a remote Antarctic island for more than a week. They have tents and food for four months.

A respected, impartial, experienced fact-finding panel has decided in favor of an industry-wide representation election for employes of the New York City Transit Authority. It thus supports the position of the Transit Authority, and the Transport Workers Union as well,...
COLORADO SPRINGS, Dec. 1--Baseball men converged today on this picturesque metropolis nestled under snow-capped Pike's Peak for the annual winter conclaves of the major and minor leaguers. It could
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1--A chief spokesman for American Protestantism singled out tonight man's distrust of man as the costliest of "all the failures and weaknesses of the Christian Church."
HONOLULU, Dec. 1 (UP)-- Hurricane Nina churned toward the Hawaiian Islands today on a course that would vent the full impact of its 100-mile-anhour winds on the populous island of Kauai.

BACK in September, when Western Electric Company let on that it had bought the Broadway block between Fulton and Ann Streets for a new office building, sculptors and artists in town started to worry about the old St....

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1-- President Eisenhower's illness has produced two quite contradictory reactions in the capital. In fact, not since just before the Suez war have official opinion and well-informed private opinion been so far apart.

COME 5 o'clock these December evenings and many a home cook is too exhausted from the hustle of holiday preparations to undertake an elaborate dinner. Today's recipes for two casseroles that can be pre
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 1-- Duffy Stables' foxchaser, Tourist's Encore, was among the victors as the thirty-third Boulder Brook Club two-day fall horse show ended late tonight.
Senator Jacob K. Javits urged yesterday that President Eisenhower delegate the dayto-day functions of his office to Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
LONDON, Dec. 1--President Eisenhower's illness had only a slight effect on the stock markets here last week.
Dealings in the principal currencies were active during the past week. British pound sterling had a very steady undertone while the Canadian dollar continued soft.
A dismal steamship charter market marked time last week. The net result of some slight rate losses and compensating gains in some commodities left the market just about where it was a week ago.
Forty hours of devotion to the Blessed Sacrament began yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
THE newest American pastime is rubbernecking in other peoble's houses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1-- There's talk that Donald A. Quarles, Deputy Secretary of Defense, may resign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The National Science Foundation announced today that 108 institutes would be held next summer all over the country to train about 5,000 high school and 250 college teachers in science and mathematics.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 1-- In a mood of elation, Colombians voted today on a governmental plan designed to end the na-, tion's traditional political strife. A heavy affirmative vote was believed certain.

U.N. Secretary General Hammarskjold arrived in Jordan yesterday morning to stop a little blaze before it becomes a big fire. It is not of much importance whether or not Jordan permits the Israelis to take gasoline into their isolated position on Mount Scopus adjacent to...
RINGOES, N.J., Dec. 1-- Consistency under all circumstances made the Berol Lodge Kennels' F.T. Ch. Berol Lodge Glen Garry from Chappaqua, N.Y., the national cocker spaniel field trial champion today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 1 --Security personnel pressed the search today for the perpetrators of an attempt last evening to assassinate President Sukarno.

Renata Tebaldi, soprano, has made no decision as yet on whether she will make further appearances in the United States this season. The soprano has remained in seclusion since the death of her mother Saturday morning.
The National Committee for Labor Israel yesterday started a two-year drive to raise 10,000,000 to finance welfare, cultural and youth projects in Israel.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec 1-- Masten Gregory of Kansas City, rated twelfth among the world's Grand PriX auto racing drivers, set a blazing pace today to win the feature contest at the opening of Nassau's fourth annual sports car speed week.

The forty-first annual convention of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards will open Wednesday at the Traymore Hotel in Atlantic City. About 1,800 real estate men are expected to attend the meeting.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 1 --The United States is expected to put its first earth satellite into orbit with a rocket fired from Cape Canaveral this week.
Twenty-seven business and civic leaders have been chosen for a fund campaign for the Lincoln Square arts project.

More than half a century ago, at a meeting of social reformers, a young college sophomore was fired with enthusiasm for change. Yesterday, reveiewing the progress he had seen and helped to make since undergraduate days, Dr. Harry W....

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 1-- The wave of local government borrowing that has been ranging between $5,500,000,000 and $6,900,000,000 since 1953 is likely to last indefinitely, according to projections made at the Investment Bankers Association convention here today.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Dec. 1 --About thirty merchants in this Middlesex County city kept their business establishments open today for Sunday shoppers.

Peter McArdle, the New York Athletic Club's Irish import, turned in his second straight impressive victoiy yesterday, winning the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 1--Two men, one with a police record, were found shot dead in a parked car here at 2:20 P.M. today.

LONDON, Nov. 29--As a tooland-die maker, James Kerr O'Hagan is earning above-average pay for a British factory worker. But he thinks the standard of living among those in the United States doing work similar to his is far higher.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 --Jeff Chandler is close to signing with A.A.P., Inc., of Hollywood and Hammer Films of London to head the cast of "6 to 1." The film about a group of Nazi soldiers assigned by the Allies to detonate unexploded
When last seen, the Giants were still alive in the National Football League's Eastern Conference race, but they were breathing ever so faintly. That
AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 1-- Dag Hammarskjold arrived here today and immediately plunged into talks with Jordanian officials on the operations of the truce with Israel.
Cotton futures prices were mostly lower last week on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Jean-Paul Sartre's "Kean," a Parisian hit of 1954, has been acquired by Huntington Hartford. The leading role, that of Edmund Kean, one of the great actors of the nineteenth century, appeals to Orson Welles, who also may undertake the direction.
Three of the nation's top medical and scientific research organizations disclosed yesterday they would finance privately a housing project on the East Side for which they failed to obtain public aid.
An experiment during a Forty-Niners' practice last week turned into a play that added a titter to the last laugh the San Franciscans enjoyed at the favored Giants' expense yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1 --Scientists at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory received no evidence today to shake their theory that the rocket of the first Soviet earth satellite had ended its spin through space.

MAX LERNER'S "America as a Civilization: Life and Thought in the United States Today"* is a massive and monumental book. There is reason to believe that the creeping price inflation that was the outstanding characteristic of the American economic scene from mid-1955 to mid1957 has finally been arrested, for the time being at least.
The meeting of the fifteen nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Paris Dec. 16 is one of the most critically important steps that has to be taken to secure the peace of the world.

Soccer with an international kick: That could well have been the theme of the recently completed season at the New Hampton (N.H.) School. Seven students from foreign countries helped the team capture the New England Lakes Region championship.
A proposal that school children be prepared for their eventual adult roles in the redevelopment of New York City was made yesterday by the Citizens Housing and Planning Council.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 1 (AP)-- Lenny Moore got away for three touchdowns today to carry the Baltimore Colts to a 31-14 victory over the Los Angeles Rams before 52,060--biggest crowd for a pro football game in the city's history.
MADRID, Dec. 1--Reports from military sources today indicated that Spanish forces were in command of the situation in the Spanish territory of Ifni.
Some of the most ancient art on this continent--rock carvings called petroglyphs--are now submerged in a reservoir on the Columbia River, between Oregon and Washington.

The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham's New York Crusade was evaluated as "a genuine success" by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell in a sermon yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)--Americans will buy about the same volume of goods this month as they did last December, but they will pay $600 million more for it, the
A special rackets grand jury may be convened upstate to question the thirty-six New York State residents who attended the Apalachin gang's meeting Nov. 14.

Minstrels again are wandering the hills and valleys that range away from New York City. But the musical instrument that once was on their back is carried now in a station wagon, a sports car or a limousine with a uniformed chauffeur at the wheel.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 1 (UP)-- Tommy O'Connell threw two touchdown passes and set up a third as the Cleveland Browns downed the Chicago Cardinals, 31--0, today to increase their lead to one and one half games in the National Football League's Eastern conference.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 1--There will be a small increase in steel production this week follawing last week's Thanksgiving Day curtailments at several plants. But the rise will not signify any change in the slow downward trend of production.

DESIGNER EVELYN GATES does not keep her finger on the public pulse. Her collections of custom-made clothes reflect rather her own taste and the pattern of a busy, decidedly gay Long Island life. She is not a
In the murk and the mud of a rain-drenched field as the college football season ended, Navy's defense prevailed over Army's running attack to establish the midshipmen as the East's best team.

NATHAN MILSTEIN has been playing so well in recent years that he could coast if he chose. But he has done nothing so complacent. For a great performer there is always a higher prize: to reach ever more deeply into the heart of music.

The carnival air that has prevailed in the past at Thanksgiving week-end college jazz concerts at Carnegie Hall was missing this year. So was the customary parade of enthusiastically haphazard Dixieland bands.
The threat of a bolt of 3,000,000 building trades unionists from the merged labor federation began to peter out last night.
SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Dec. 1--Rockland County, home of many theatrical, literary and musical people, has two organized outlets for its amateur musicians and singers.

BARABOO, Wis., Dec. 1 (AP) --Harlan W. Kelley, who made the Presidential nomination speech for General of the Army Douglas MacArthur at the 1948 Republican convention, died today at his home here. His age was 54.
"CONQUEST," which made its debut yesterday aft ernoon on Channel 2, is a new filmed series dealing with progress in the world of science. The premiere was in

The Standard-Vacuum Oil Company announced over the week-end that it had suspended oil exploration activities in Sumatra. The company said the suspension resulted from its inability to obtain permission from the Indonesian Government to explore and develop new areas.

When Elizabeth Bishop first went to Brazil in 1952, she inquired about Brazilian books that she should read. Among the suggestions was the diary of a young girl that had first been published privately in a small edition in 1942 and is now considered a classic.
A fact-finding panel recommended yesterday a oneunit, system-wide election among Transit Authority employes to decide which union should represent them.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 1--The recent speech by Dr. Marius W. Holtrop, president of the Netherlands Bank, before the Association for Political Economy in which he said that neither a compensatory anti-cyclical bud
When a group of teen-agers here shouts, "Blast off!" it's the real thing and not just a popular expression picked up from comic books or television programs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The chairman of the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee called today for a reappraisal of United States policy on atomic power development. He said it was "not adequate" to compete in the race for world leadership in this field.
Media, agencies and advertisers are rallying to fight moves by cities to tax advertising.
PARIS, Dec. 1--Rene Billeres, Minister of National Education, threatened tonight to resign if spending for education was cut too far next year.

A year ago today one of the strangest and most romantic episodes in Cuba's colorful history began. On Dec. 2, 1956, a band of eighty-two Cuban youths, headed by a 30-year-old law graduate, Fidel Castro, landed on a marshy strip of beach in Oriente Province at the eastern end of the island.

One of the most provocative thinkers this country has ever produced. Thorstein Veblen, would probably derive great satisfaction from the current national discussion about science were he alive today. As long ago as 1906, in his famous essay, "The Place of Science in Modern Civilization," he called at-...
DETROIT, Dec. 1 (UP)--The New York Rangers broke their four-game losing streak tonight and ended the Detroit Red Wings' five-game unbeaten string with a 5-1 victory.
LAST night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center was made up entirely of ballets by George Balanchine to music of Igor Stravinsky.
A 100-member Citizens Council to spur traffic safety action is being set up by Governor Harriman.
Additional alterations in the changing corporate picture of Loew's, Inc., were made over the week-end.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 1 --The Indonesian Government announced today a twenty-four hour strike against Dutch enterprises throughout the country.

The low-cost service being offered to American industry by inland water carriers is enabling the barge and towing vessel industry to grow in the over-all traffic pattern, according to the American Waterways Operators, Inc.

New materials, instruments and processes used in the rocket and nuclear engineering fields will be among the displays of 550 exhibitors at the twenty-sixth exposition of Chemical Industries, opening at noon today at the New York Coliseum.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday that "just putting a policeman in the school" did not provide either an "immediate or a long-range" answer to juvenile delinquency.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1-Secretary of State Dulles will be happy to talk with Foreign Minister Mahmoud Fawzi of Egypt if the latter wants to see him, State Department officials said today.
Isador Lubin, State Industrial Commissioner, said yesterday that unemployment was rising in the state and that the economic situation "will get worse before it gets better."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1-- Some military officials, particularly in the Army, are criticizing the "stampede" to produce long-range ballistic missiles and other weapons designed for nuclear warfare.
MOSCOW, Dec. 1--Soviet specialists expect to be sending space ships with human beings aboard on flights "in the next few years."

The United States was the first nation to "dangle the hope of freedom" before the Iron Curtain countries, the Very Rev. James A. Pike said yesterday. But now, he added, this country "ranks thirteenth in meeting the needs of those who sought their freedom."
NEWARK, Dec. 1--Neither 10-year-old violinists nor other amateur musicians have chipped away at the professional standards required by local orchestras throughout New Jersey.
The rate of increase in heavy industrial production in the Communist bloc nations appears to have been smaller this year than in any year in the last decade.
One of Japan's traditional products--her artistic home furnishings--is about to be "Americanized."

Former President Herbert Hoover led a tribute yesterday to a scientist, Josiah Willard Gibbs, and an inventor, George Westinghouse. Busts of both men were installed in the Hall of Fame for Great Americans.

LONDON, Dec. 1--George F. Kennan asserted tonight that the existing military tension in Europe would be seriously increased if Western continental nations were supplied with strategic or tactical atomic weapons.
ZURICH, Dec. 1--Trading in Interhandel shares was the outstanding feature of Stock Exchange business here last week.
The New York Knickerbockers snapped a three-game home losing string last night by checking the Detroit Pistons, 109 to 102, in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden.
ISAAC STERN, violinist, played a recital at Hunter College Auditorium on Saturday evening as the third event of the Hunter College Concert Series.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 1 --Samuel Hazard Gillespie, a retired exporter and importer, died here today at his home, 25 Ogden Place. He was 79 years old.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1--The top-seeded California contract bridge team captained by Lew Mathe of Los Angeles tonight continued to lead in the men's team-of-four championship, opening event of the thirtyfirst annual winter championships of the American Contract Bridge League.
Many neighborhoods in big cities have become segregative devices to increase social distances, a community relations specialist contended last night.
Complete harmony now exists among the seagoing unions on the Pacific Coast, a condition sought by maritime labor leaders there for decades.
WARSAW, Dec. 1--For the first time since the war, leading Polish Communists are taking a fresh look at the West.

American Judaism, an architect said yesterday, has embarked on an "adventure in architecture" Contemporary design, he noted, predominates in synagogues that are being built at the rate of about thirty a year in the New York area.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Marion B. Folsom, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, has assumed an attitude of righteous resistance to Budget Bureau cuts in his department's programs.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1-- Argentina's oil enterprise, Yacimentos Petroliferos Fiscales, will attempt to lure the savings of small depositors into oil investments.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1-- Miss Mary Ellen Flynn of Peabody, Mass., and Jaime PenaVera of Mexico City, who met in Switzerland, were married here last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1-- James G. Cross, president of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union, has warned locals opposing his administration that secession may cost their members pensions--and health and welfare benefits.
THE launching of the sputnik appears to have sent Amer ican educators back to the drawing boards.
The National Broadcasting Company is shopping for a filmed television program that might be suitable as a replacement for "Sally" later this season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)-- The Amateur Athletic Union voted today to allow its district associations to decide whether boxers at A.A.U.-sanctioned tournaments should wear head protectors.

Sydney S. Baron, who resigned under pressure last July as the public relations consultant to the New York Democratic organization, was praised in glowing terms last night by Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Foreign policy is neither abstract art nor science. Its aims and methods must continually adjust to changing world conditions. This is especially true in a democracy where each Administration is bound by commitments of its predecessors and, in turn, obligates its own successors.

PARIS, Dec. 1--The Government of Premier Felix Gaillard is preparing a three-part plan that seeks, among other objectives, to prepare for FrenchUnited States negotiations on a loan of between 100 and 200 million dollars.
HAVANA, Dec. 1--Four rebels were killed in an encounter with Government troops at a point between Agua Reyes and Mar Verde in the Sierra Maestra, according to Cuban Army Headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The Administration is running into some almost insuperable obstacles in its search for major savings in the nondefense part of the budget.

The leader of the thirteen rank-and-file drivers who are seeking to have James R. Hoffa legally barred from assuming the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters promised yesterday there would be "no deals" with the Hoffa forces.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 1-- As a measure of the devotion of Fairfield County residents to their symphony orchestras, consider the case of Iden Kerney of Darien.
PARIS, Dec. 1--A group of forty-five prominent European advocates of closer cooperation in Western Europe recommended today the concentration of European institutions in a single place.
ROME, Dec. 2 (UP)--Italy's highest court has ruled that special protection granted the Roman Catholic Church as the state religion is not inconsistent with freedom of religion.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.-- Miss Gloria Addae, attractive young member of Ghana's United Nations delegation to the current General Assembly, would like to destroy the idea that all Africans are savaged spear-throwers or docile burden--
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 (AP) --The National Football League owners today unanimously granted all the demands of the Players Association--exhibition pay, minimum salary, injury
LONDON, Dec. 2--The British Petroleum Company will float on Thursday a 41,000,000 ($114,800,000) issue of 6 per cent convertible debentures, due 1976-80, at a 1 per cent discount.
The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation plans to acquire the 40 per cent minority interest held by the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company in the National Petro-Chemicals Corporation.
Jack Oakie, Rudy Vallee, Earl Holliman and Virginia Gibson will star in "The Battle for Wednesday Night," a television drama about two competing shows.
Faced with declining demand, the steel industry last week reduced production to 1,846,000 net tons, representing operations of 72.1 per cent of the nation's rated capacity. Except
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 2-- Policies of the Civil Aeronautics Board are crippling the aviation industry financially, a team of eight investment banning specialists charged here today.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 2-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, recovering from influenza at his home in Rhoendorf, resumed a limited work schedule today. His recovery is taking a "normal" course, the Government's spokesman said at a news conference.

Final plans are being made for the benefit performance on Thursday of "Rumple" at the Alvin Theatre. Proceeds will aid St. Barnabas House, temporary shelter for women and children of the Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP)-- Rumors that Senator William E. Jenner may resign this month instead of waiting for the end of his term early in 1959 led to brisk speculation about a successor today.
QUINCY, Mass., Dec. 2--The free world's first nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed surface warship began to take shape here today.
The annual auction of the Irvington House Thrift Shop, known as the Famous Designers and Artists Auction, will be held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, on the evening of Dec. 17.
The recommendation of a factfinding panel that Transit Authority employes vote for one union to represent the entire city transit system produced the expected reactions yesterday.

Although he has had many exciting moments during his ten-year career as a professional sports broadcaster, Chris Schenkel got his biggest thrill from telecasting a high school football game Thanks giving Day.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2--An enthusiastic audience of 2,000 persons hailed the Soviet debut here tonight of Blanche Thebom, American mezzo-soprano.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 --Stanley Kramer is looking ahead to a new and busy program of films for independent production. The producer-director was back at his office today in the California Studios and, for a change, his mind was note on "Pride and the Passion."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--A union truck driver testified today that his Denver local had disregarded democratic processes in sending delegates to the convention that elected James R. Hoffa president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 3-- The Japanese Ministry of Justice decided today not to appeal the suspended sentence given Specialist 3/c William S. Girard of the United States Army for killing a Japanese woman last Jan. 30.

Auburn, the unbeaten, untied giant of the Southeastern Conference, yesterday became the first winner of The Associated Press national football championship trophy. The Tigers, whose sturdy defense yielded only four touchdowns in ten games, drew a landslide vote in the final poll of the season.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2-- American cities were advised today to be choosy about the industries they encouraged to settle within their borders.
Among the many problems that will confront the Paris "summit" meeting of the North Atlantic alliance two weeks hence there are two which imperil the internal cohesion of the alliance itself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) --Representative H.R. Gross said today that the Eisenhower Administration had designated Vice President Richard M. Nixon to lead a "propaganda campaign" for another "big foreign handout program."

SHIPPINGPORT, Pa., Dec. 2 (AP)--Scientists today started the atomic furnace at the country's first full-scale civilian nuclear power station--fifteen years to the day since man achieved a chain reaction in a reactor.
The fighter who has won the most bouts at the St. Nicholas Arena this year won another there last night.
James R. Hoffa had the phones of his union subordinates tapped to find out what they were telling official racket investigations, a jury was told here yesterday.

It's a good thing, a commuter's wife might say, that she does not have to put up preserves, fill kero sene lamps, bake bread, run a spinning wheel or get water at the well or spring as her sisters once managed to do.
FISHERS ISLAND, L.I., Dec. 2--The Coast Guard cutter Mariposa and two rescue craft scurried through calming seas here this afternoon rounding up forty-foot sections of pontoonequipped pipeline.

Marshaling arguments in elaborate brochures is old hat for Robert Moses, chairman of the State Power Authority, but the one he released yesterday to quash opposition in a little upstate town tops anything yet seen.
Larger staffs, better salaries and less crowded facilities are needed at state training schools for juvenile delinquents, according to a survey made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--Dr. Ernest O. Lawrence, director of the University of California's radiation laboratory at Berkeley, received today the Enrico Fermi Award for contributions in the development of atomic energy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--The Administration's program to increase the nation's output of scientists, engineers and mathematicians is beginning to take final shape.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2-- About 300,000 Los Angeles commuters were without their usual transportation today because of a strike against four companies that operate buses and trolley cars.
Republican Assemblymen demanded yesterday that Governor Harriman appoint a special rackets prosecutor and convene an extraordinary grand jury to investigate gangster operations.
Sales of major department stores in the metropolitan area last month were about even, on the average, with those of November, 1956, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec, 2-- The merged labor federation prepared today to give its blessing to a strike against the Montgomery Ward mail order chain. The pre-Christmas strike by 4,000 members of the Retail Clerks International Association is expected to begin next week.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 2-- The controversy over the Westport Woman's Club abated considerably today at its annual Christmas meeting. Club officers rejected several charges made against the organization by Mrs. Lewis E. Welsh.
SOMETIMES the difference between a drawing and a painting is like the difference between a banquet and a luxuriously casual sunday breakfast.
LONDON, Dec. 2--Britain's Conservative Government defended its integrity today against Labor party charges that a Cabinet secret had been leaked to interested financial circles.
munists in the Electrical Trades Union are waging a bitter but apparently losing fight to end the thirteen-year Communist domination of their organization.

Brooklyn College's basketball team probably has more know-how than any squad Coach Placido (Tony) Gomez has had in the past five seasons, but the pilot of the Kingsmen would be more at ease if he had additional height and bench strength.

The dismissal of Dr. Warren B. Austin, suspended City College professor, was recommended yesterday by a trial committee of the Board of Higher Education. Dr. Austin was charged with swearing falsely that he had never been a member of the Communist party.

BONN, Germany, Dec, 2-- The West Germans have turned down unofficial French suggestions for the formation of a Continental European bloc in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as a counterweight to the United States and Britain.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Dec. 2--That much-awaited hunting jamboree in New York State--antlerless deer day--starts at dawn tomorrow. And don't think that natives of Sullivan County aren't worried.

The Hudson Pulp and Paper Corporation in the fiscal year ended on last Aug. 31. exceeded the record sales and production achieved in the previous fiscal year. Earnings were lower than the year before, but were 21 per cent better than the average for the last five years, the report notes.

The news from Colombia, where the plebiscite for internal peace was voted overwhelmingly on Sunday, is that the Colombian people are elated. They have reason to be, and so have all friends of Colombia and of democracy in Latin America.
TOKYO, Dec. 2--Japan must sell more to the United States or risk economic death, Foreign Minister Aiichiro Fujiyama told a gathering of leading American business men today.

ALBANY, Dec. 2.--A bill that would give school districts higher-than-normal state aid in spite of absences caused by disease or bad weather was filed today for introduction in the 1958 Legislature.

The State Attorney General undertook the second of a series of court actions yesterday "to break the grip of racketeers and hoodlums" on the private garbage collection industry in the metropolitan area.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 2--A record budget of about $1,640,000,000 was presented to Parliament tonight by the government of Premier Adnan Menderes.

The balance of world power is still on the side of the United States, Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther said last night. He is president of the American Red Cross and former Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Manufacturers who continue to refuse to sell to discount houses and other "unorthodox" retailers face extinction, Stephen Masters declared yesterday.
The New York Central Rail road went to court yesterday to seek a full 6 per cent return in fares on $60,000,000 it says it has invested in commuter facilities in the metropolitan area.

HONOLULU, Dec. 2 (AP)-- Hurricane Nina moved northward today after having battered the Hawaiian Islands with winds up to ninety-two miles an hour. Some areas were deluged with two feet of rain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--Who invented the phantom Egyptian ship bearing arms to Tunisia? Was the State Department misinformed about it? If so, by whom? Or was an Egyptian arms ship diverted from Tunisia at the last moment?
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Dec. 3--The State Labor Department was accused of unfairness today in its continued prosecution of a company that processes radioactive materials here.
Snowflakes began falling on the metropolitan area last night. The season's first measurable snow was expected to reach one to three inches in depth in some places, particularly in the suburbs.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3-- The leader of 15,000,000 American workers acknowledged to day that disclosures of labor corruption had seriously hurt the trade union movement.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 3 --The deputy director of Project Vanguard said today it was "probable" that the United States' test satellite would go into orbit after being fired tomorrow in a three-stage rocket.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3-- An agreement to eliminate conflict between the merged labor movement's two major maritime unions was announced here today.
BERNARDO SEGALL returned to Town Hall last night with a program devoted to several of the more popular pieces in the piano repertory. They were Haydn's E flat Sonata, Beethoven's...
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 3--Tax reform has not been made a dead issue by Russia's success with space satellites, the Investment Bankers Association convention was told
THE man with the decorating assignment of 1957-58 is Peter Harnden, whose task it is to fit all America into a building the size of Rome's Colosseum.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The Administration advised Congressional leaders today that it would ask $520,000,000 more for military pay next year to recruit and keep scientists and technicians in the armed services.
JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), Dec. 3--Mr.Hammarskjold flew here from Amman this morning and immediately entered the Israeli Sector through the Mandelbaum Gate.
WARSAW, Dec. 3--West Germany and Poland agreed today to extend their trade pact into the first three months of 1958.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)-- Conflicting proposals for a revision of the United States' foreign trade program were urged on Congress today by a panel of economists and trade spokesmen.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3-- The president of the American Medical Association described as "socialized medicine" today plans to provide hospital and medical benefits for the aged under the Social Security program.
"EVERY color goes with every color," says Clare Potter adding a qualifying, "if you know the right nuances to use."

The Sibelius Memorial Scholarship Fund, established for the furtherance of cultural understanding between the United States and Finland, will be augmented as a result of a concert in Carnegie Hall at 5:30 Sunday afternoon.
The wife of Cornelius Vanderbilt (Sonny) Whitney, millionaire turfman and movie backer, today blocked his plans to get a Reno divorce, at least temporarily.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS N.J., Dec. 3--Mr. and Mrs. William N. Shafer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Shafer, to Michael Stephen Denci, son of Miehael Denci of Wallington and the late Mrs. Denci.
ONE of New York's lushest men's shops has opened its doors just in time for Christmas. Richard Cheatham's "salon for gentlemen," at 16 East Fifty-fifth Street, occupies a
AGAIN, Tyrone Guthrie has decided to do things the hard way. Having selected a difficult script, he has proceeded to make it interesting and theatrical.
Four Americans stranded or a remote Antarctic island are well and may be relieved within a few days when fuel is delivered for their Air Force plane.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--It would be a sharp blow to the Allied cause if President Eisenhower were unable to attend the NATO meeting in Paris. The alliance's immediate future may depend heavily upon the judgment of White House doctors.
The Air Force has spent more than $100,000,000 so far in trying to prevent structural damage to jet airplanes from noise and vibration, it was reported here yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3-- From George Meany down, the leaders of major labor organizations repudiated today a proposal that unions forego wage increases for one year to check inflation. The proposal had been made by Richard J. Gray, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3-- The World Bank is host, mentor and laboratory here for twenty-two economists and financial officials of eighteen countries. They are being prepared by six months of seminars, field trips and...
From now on, the unusually long title of "Who was That Lady I Saw You With?" will identify Norman Krasna's comedy, formerly called "My Wife and I,"
MINEOLA, L.I, Wednesday, Dec. 4--Vincent J. Squillante and five other men were indicted late last night by a Nassau County grand jury investigating racketeering in the carting business.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The Eisenhower Administration gave Congressional leaders a fivehour briefing today on its plans for meeting Soviet military and scientific challenges in the space age.
Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Zionist Organization, appealed last night for an agreement between the Western powers and the Soviet Union to remove the "cold war" from the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The Department of Health, Education and Welfare was called on today for detailed answers to charges that it has failed tomake a continuing study of advances in Soviet education as requested by the Department of Defense.
RABAT, Dec. 3--The outlawed Moroccan Communist party came out today in support of the nationalists fighting in Ifni.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3-- President Eisenhower will ask Congress next month for authority to share nuclear weapons secrets with this country's allies.
McGregor-Doniger, Inc., sportswear manufacturer, will move its advertising account to McCann-Erickson, Inc., effective July 1.

ATLANTIC CITY, Wednesday, Dec. 4--The merged labor federation decided late last night to proceed with the longexpected ouster of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the country's biggest and most powerful union.
Public and private bus lines and railroads yesterday prepared to handle extra passengers after subway motormen threatened to strike.
TRENTON, Dec. 3--Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared today that, if the 1958-59 New Jersey budget is to be balanced, existing state taxes must be increased or new levies adopted before June.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3--A psychiatrist warned today against accepting slum clearance as a cure-all for city ills Dr. Leonard J. Duhl of the National Institutes of Health
Representative Abraham J. Multer of New York called on the Army yesterday to institute the competitive sealed-bid system in purchasing fresh fruits and vegetables.
Two 16-year-old high school students were at arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday on charges of sending a threatening letter to their social studies teacher.
Navy used a forward-lateral pass play against Army that was eye-catching enough to rate post-game analysis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UP) --A teamster official from Yonkers testified today that James R. Hoffa had used hand signals to mastermind the Miami Beach convention that elected Hoffa as president of the union.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 4-- The revolt of the building trades unions against the merged labor movement sputtered out today.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4-- Precise information on the dangers of exposure to radiation is not available, a professor of genetics said today.
Fourteen young scientists and engineers rented a room at the Statler Hotel yesterday and invited potential employers to come hire them.

Governor Harriman will ask the next Legislature to strengthen and clarify the law regulating installment buying. Of this further measure to protect consumers in a time of inflation, he said yesterday:
MIAMI, Dec. 4 (AP)--Counter Spy, a 2-year old colt owned by the Wheatley Stable and trained by Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, galloped to an easy victory in the feature today at Tropical Park.
The development of a digital computer that is small enough for use in an aircraft was announced yesterday by the Hughes Aircraft Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP)-- A leading foreign trade economist today proposed limiting United States tariff rates to a ceiling of 20 or 25 per cent. He described tariff protection as an outdated instrument of economic policy.
MOSCOW, Dec. 4--Two missile specialists hinted today that the Soviet Union had developed a rocket that could be fired from a submerged submarine at a target 750 miles away.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--Adlai E. Stevenson has urged the Administration to enlist the cooperation of the other North Atlantic Treaty powers in a new effort to negotiate a general political settlement in the Middle East.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4--One hundred and fifty-six qualifying contract bridge pairs out of a starting field of 276 pairs began play tonight in the final session of the 1957 Master Mixed Pairs Championship.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The Treasury announced today that all investors except commercial banks would be allowed to buy Series E and H Savings Bonds after Jan. 1.

Two six-story apartment buildings are planned to replace Oceantide Baths at Coney Island. Oceantide, on the Boardwalk and West Thirty-sixth Street, is assessed at $140,000. The property was sold by Lendy Baths to a client of Rand Eisberg, attorney. The seller was represented by David Leavenworth. Harold L. Rockmore was the broker in the transaction.
Mrs. George Richard (Helen Menken) has announced plans for the second in a series of small benefits for the American Theatre Wing, of which she is president.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 4--Republican legislative leaders challenged Governor Harriman today to join them in authorizing a $500,000 campaign against racketeers.
Two women employes of James R. Hoffa and Owen B. Brennan testified against the men yesterday at the union leaders, wiretap conspiracy trial.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP)--Joe Brown cut loose with a violent flurry in the eleventh round to stop Joey Lopes on a technical knockout in the third defense of his world lightweight title tonight at Chicago Stadium.
There will be a Santa Claus at longshore Local 791's Christmas party this year, but it won't be the same for the kids.
LONDON, Dec. 4--Small price falls predominated in the principal sections of the stock market today. Trading volume, at low ebb, barely tested prices.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Thursday, Dec. 5--The first United States launching of the Vanguard space rocket with a satellite in its nose cone was called off last night after many delays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--Attorney General William P. Rogers filed today a civil antitrust action against Volkswagen of America, Inc., and its fourteen United States distributors. The suit charges illegal price-fixing in the sale of Volkswagen automobiles in this country.

Norman Mailer, whose first novel, "The Naked and the Dead," proved to be one of the most controversial and popular books to come out of World War II, has completed his first work for the Broadway theatre.

A strike of subway motormen, scheduled to start at 5 A.M. yesterday, failed to materialize. But a high official of the Motormen's Benevolent Association declared that a unionauthorized walkout would be called in the next eleven days.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4--Two Administration officials sent up today what welfare leaders regarded as trial balloons on where Federal welfare spending might be pared because of increased defense costs.

LONDON, Dec. 4--Sir John Braithwaite, chairman of the London Stock Exchange, said today that he had heard of nothing that could be called a leak of the Government's intention to raise the bank rate Sept. 19 from 5 to 7 per cent.

From its perch in the crow's nest of the economy, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York foresees only mild adjustments before the nation's business spurts ahead again. In its latest monthly review the bank says ...

Another "little war," centered around some African fishing villages but involving the future of Spanish and French possessions with their prospective mineral wealth, has been raging between Moroccan nationalists and Spanish troops.
LONDON, Dec 4--At least fifty persons were killed tonight in the wreck of two London commuter trains.
College football enjoyed another banner season at the gate this year.

LONDON, Dec. 4--The British Government has abandoned hope of obtaining what it regards as equitable settlement with West Germany on the question of money to maintain British forces in the Federal Republic.

A new biography of Lord Nelson is planned for publication Jan. 30 by Atlantic-Little, Brown. Written by Oliver Warner, the volume gives details of Nelson's great naval victories and his contribution to naval strategy.

DALLAS, Dec. 4--With play of exceptional brilliance, Bent Larsen of Copenhagen defeated Larry Evans of New York in twenty-eight moves today and retained first place in the international chess masters tournament.
ALBANY, Dec. 4 (AP)--Shootings and heart attacks killed fifteen hunters during New York's big game season, which ended yesterday with deer of either sex fair game.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4-- The American Municipal Association ended its thirty-fourth annual congress with adoption today of a program to resist deep slashes in Federal programs for urban areas.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3--A tanker-freighter crash, explosion and fire in which ten seamen died on the Delaware River last March 7 was attributed today to improper navigation by both vessels.

Development of smaller-- rather than larger--jet engines was described here yesterday as "imperative" to insure aviation advance. The declaration was made by Louis W. Davis of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, Deer Park, L.I.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 4--Conditions in Indonesia have reached a stage of crisis.
Officials of Pan American World Airways yesterday took time out to sip champagne with a steady customer at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Dec. 4-- Harry F. Randolph of 282 Forest Avenue, general manager of receiving tube operations at the Radio Corporation of America plant in Harrison, died last night of a heart attack at the Lackawanna railroad station in Harrison. He was 57 years old.

The scheduled arrival of Foreign Minister Giuseppe Pella in Washington this evening for two days' talks at the State Department emphasizes a rather curious aspect of our foreign relations. One need only think of how little has been published about Italy in recent years, and yet Italy is one of the most important of our allies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 (UP)--The Pacific Coast Conference voted unanimously today that penalized seniors at Southern California and the University of California at Los Angeles could play in half their schools' football games next year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 --Warner Brothers has more than passing interest in William Inge's new play, "The Dark at the Top of the Stairs," which opens tomorrow night on Broadway.

SATURDAY, 11 A.M. (and 1:30 P.M.: Three free films will be presented at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. They are "Freight Stop," "Misfit" and "Hare and Tortoise." Miss Janet Pinney will tell stories and entertain the children between films. For information call LEhigh 4-1672.
St. Francis College of Brooklyn has a balanced starting five, but the Terriers' basketball team lacks reserve strength and a well-knit defense.
Donald A. Quarles, Deputy Secretary of Defense, urged last night that the free world's military and scientific assets be "more effectively pooled for the common good."

NOW that the season for counting the days until Christmas is here, it is an excellent time to browse through a few of the current year's harvest of books on food and drink and note a few that seem particularly suitable as Yule gifts.

King Hill of Rica, Dick Christy of North Carolina State, Jim Pace of Michigan and John Crow of Texas A. and M. compose the backfield of the 1957 Associated Press All-America football team announced yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points off to 13 points up yesterday.
Americans are drifting into "absolute regimentation of their daily lives," Ernest G. Swigert, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared yesterday.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., Dec. 4--There's no doubt about it. The anticipated slaughter of does on "antlerless deer day" failed to materialize in Sullivan County yesterday. But it was no fault of the hunters. They showed up on schedule. The does, in most cases, didn't.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 4-- Sixty planning, zoning and administrative representatives from Wilton, Ridgefield, Weston, Danbury and Redding met last night with state officials in the Ridgefield Town Hall to hear a report on long-term planning for a new link in U.S. Route 7.
Frank Erickson was taken into custody by the police yesterday and questioned for an hour about the Albert Anastasia slaying. It proved to be a one-sided inquiry.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 4 --Using a fast break to good advantage, Army crushed Yeshiva, 98 to 67, today in the cadet basketball team's opening game of the season.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 4--A bumper crop of Republican candidates for the Senate seat of William E. Jenner appeared in prospect for Indiana today. Gov. Harold W. Handley and others announced or hinted their availability for the job.

The Family Part of the Supreme Court in New York County has been made permanent, it was announced yesterday by David W. Peck, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, First Department.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 4 --Workers sought to interfere with Dutch banks today in the anti-Netherlands campaign.

The proceeds of a theatre party on Jan. 8 will contribute to the general support of the New York Botanical Garden. Mrs. Robert A. Lovett and Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell, chairman and vice chairman of the benefit committee, have announced that that evening's performance of "The Music Man" ...

A two-way radio is being used to direct the movement of industrial trucks in new warehouse and shipping facilities that have just been put into operation by the Federal Pacific Electric Company at its integrated manufacturing operation in Newark, N.J.

PARIS, Dec. 4--Paris' concierges, who are the combined door-keepers, guardians of morals and police auxiliaries of the capital's dwellings, are such important citizens that they have not had a day off in 140 years.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 4 (AP)-- Relicensing of "undesirables" by some state racing commissions spells trouble for horse racing in this country, the convention of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations was told today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--Adlai E. Stevenson has met all the reasonable obligations he assumed when he accepted the invitation of the Administration to review and comment on its agenda for the forthcoming Paris conference of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Future prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, hides, rubber, zinc and copper advanced; wool cocoa and potatoes declined, and price movements for sugar, coffee, soybean oil and lead were mixed.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 4-- By the end of this year, new sales of mutual investment company shares will have outstripped shares redeemed during the year by a rate of more than three to one, according to estimates made public today at the Investment Bankers Association's convention here.
Two first-run movie theatres are due for a change in management in the near future, it was learned yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 4-- The merged labor federation offered today to call off its planned expulsion of the huge International Brotherhood of Teamsters if James R. Hoffa would quit as an international officer.

AMONG the intellectuals who helped to spark last year's abortive uprising in Hungary were a number of artists from the Budapest theatre, a source from which has sprung considerable talent well known on Broadway and in Hollywood.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4--Israel and the Arab states along her borders must assume the "primary responsibility" for the fate of 900,000 Arab refugees from Palestine, a United States representative told the United Nations today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The Administration appeared ready today to ditch the major farmsurplus reducing feature of the multi-million-dollar soil bank.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 4 (AP) --Navy's Cotton Bowl game against Rice on Jan. 1 probably will be its last post-season football appearance "for a good many years," Capt. Slade Cutter said today.
Cal Ramsey, New York University's 6-foot 4-inch junior, last night scored 26 points and led the Violet Vikings to an 84-to-64 triumph over Roanoke at Alumni Gymnasium.
The pay rises proposed for City Councilmen could be expected to add appreciably to the city's pension costs, he Citizens Union declared yesterday. Larger pensions, the civic group ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--A third congressional inquiry into the United States defense program was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--Manufacturers' inventories declined in October, the Department of Commerce reported today. Their sales, after allowing for normal October trends, declined for the third month in a row.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (AP)-- Petitions for a referendum on the real estate deal between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the City of Los Angeles were officially approved today.
Ohio awarded $25,000,000 of capital improvement construction bonds yesterday to an investment banking group headed by the Bankers Trust Company, New York.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 4 (AP)--Harry H. Rogers, a past president of Rotary International and of the International Convention of Christian Churches (Disciples of Christ), died yesterday at the age of 80.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz yesterday urged member of a special grand jury investigating lawlessness in the Brooklyn public schools to subpoena education officials. He said they Should be asked to explain why juvenile misfits were allowed to attend school with law-abiding children.

Thomas Dimock Leonard of 65 Central Park West, who was active in real estate here from 1898 to his retirement in 1950, died yesterday at the Easton (Md.) Memorial Hospital after a short illness. His age was 85.
The Stanley Warner Corporation and its subsidiaries achieved record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31, according to the annual report of Simon H. Fabian, president, issued today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 4 (AP)--Two assistants to Coach Paul Bryant on the Alabama football staff were named today by Bryant at College Station, Tex., where he is preparing the Texas A. and M. team for the Gator Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The Eisenhower Administration advised Republican Congressional leaders today that it hoped to maintain a balanced budget, but could give no assurances of success. The leaders spent a long and inconclusive day at the White House seeking ways to reduce costs of domestic civilian programs ...

James L. Fri, president of the Upholstery and Drapery Fabric Manufacturers Association, predicted yesterday that business activity in 1958 would be at about the same level as this year. He added that manufacturers "must learn to make a profit" on that basis.

The new $30,000,000 passenger terminal at New York International Airport to be dedicated today and then opened to public service is a significant milestone for air travel, an improvement appropriate to the city's position as a crossroads of the world and one of the Port Authority's finest products.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (UP) --The Baltimore Colts, first in the National Football League's Western Conference, also lead in total yards gained, yards gained by passing, total scoring and in defense against rushing.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 --The television audience, rarely consulted in the selection of new programs, will have an opportunity, at least in Los Angeles, to make known its feelings about a new half-hour film series developed by Jack Webb's Mark VII, Ltd.
PEIPING, Dec. 4 (Reuters)-- China's grain harvest, the foundation of the country's economy, has increased in 1957 compared with 1956. But 1957 grain output is far short of the year's goal.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 4 --Simplification of the United States defense system was recommended here today by William C. Foster, former Deputy Secretary of Defense.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The Air Force announced plans today to construct four launching sites for Bomarc long-range anti-aircraft missiles. The cost will be $46,000,000.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 4 --Although the first United States satellite is considered a scientific problem, the launching site at the Air Force Missile Test Center on Cape Canaveral is under strict military security.
The first severe snowstorm of the season disrupted all forms of travel in the metropolitan area yesterday. Travel Is Snarled as Season's First Severe Snow Blankets the Metropolian Area
Senator Thomas Carey Hennings Jr. of Missouri collapsed with "a mild cerebral spasm" yesterday while presiding at a long public hearing in the United States Court House here.
The stock market edged up yesterday with some smart gains for a few favorite groups. Aircraft-missile, shipbuilding, metal and high-energy fuel issues received much of the play.
An extensive campaign for El Al Israel Airlines will begin tomorrow. Advertisements will call attention to the company's new turbine-propeller plane service across the Atlantic, starting Dec. 23.

FOLLOWING two gala preview evenings a large part of the collection of paintings assembled by Stavros Niarchos, operator of a huge fleet of merchant marine vessels, will go on view to the public today at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East FiftySeventh Street.
PARIS, Dec. 4--The necessary Parliamentary approval of the treaties for a European nuclear pool and a European common market was completed today.

RUDOLF SERKIN, who generally confines himself to the piano music of the German and Viennese masters, came up with a novelty in his Carnegie Hall recital last night. He played the first performance of Bohuslav Martinu's Sonata No. 1.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 4-- Emphasizing Turkey's determination to remain a free country in the community of free nations, Premier Adnan Menderes delivered today his Administra tion's declaration of policy to Parliament.

TED CONNOLLY, the injured guard of the Forty-Niners, sat contentedly in the press box at Yankee Stadium last Sunday, and thoroughly enjoyed his sabbatical as the San Franciscans upset the Giants, 27 to 17.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Dec. 4 (AP)--The major league player representatives joined the fast growing bandwagon for the repeal of the controversial bonus rule today.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 5 (AP)--The United States took a commanding 2--0 lead over the Philippines in their interzone Davis Cup final today by sweeping both singles matches.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 4--A new five-year economic plan that promises a steep and steady rise in the standard of living was adopted today by the Yugoslav Parliament.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Dec. 4--The major league trading mart, which rolled into action late last night when the White Sox and Baltimore Orioles closed a six-player swap, continued to be active today as Frank Lane, baseball's intrepid trader, made his first deal since becoming the general manager of the Cleveland Indians.

It's getting so the New York Rangers would prefer to play all their National Hockey League games away from home. The Broadway Blues skated against the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night and the Black Hawks won, 2--0.
HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 4 (UP) --The Senate Democratic Leader, Lyndon B. Johnson, proposed tonight a five-point program to speed the United States into "the world of space."
THE lamp bulb manufacturers, who for year concen trated on good, clear light to illuminate the dim corners of America's homes, have gone theatrical.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4--A new effort to work out a compromise resolution on the Algerian question collapsed tonight when France rejected the proposed text.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 4-- The president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards today endorsed government efforts now underway to reduce "top heavy Federal activity" in certain areas.
The Long Island Rail Road won at least a silver star yesterday for its "considerably improved" mechanical condition.
Leather tanning, one of the oldest of arts, is undergoing technological changes. Improvements in footwear and other leather products have resulted from advances in processing in recent years.
PARIS, Dec. 4--There is one Paris concierge who plans to celebrate her first official day off in twenty-two years by the unheard-of luxury of staying in bed.
Governor Harriman told a Senate investigating committee yesterday that the state was giving "serious consideration" to excluding trouble-makers from public schools.

The attention of the nation has been centered these past few days on Cape Canaveral, where preparations have proceeded for the effort to send the first United States test satellite into orbit. This attention has symbolized the great importance we now attach to the conquest of space, an age-old dream of humanity which has now come practically into the agenda of humanity.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UP)-- The Treasury was swamped today with protests against an economy move calculated to save taxpayers about $150,000, a year.

GUATEMALA, Dec. 4--A Congressional investigating committee tonight charged that the Dominican Military Attache had participated in the murder of a Guatemalan truck driver Oct. 20 on the outskirts of the capital.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4-- President Eisenhower put in another busy day at the White House. And his press secretary reported today that the President's physicians had said he was "fine."
Four trains of the Far Rockaway branch of the IND subway in Queens, which uses a windswept trestle across Jamaica Bay, were marooned last night for more than three hours by the snowstorm.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 4--American Protestantism is moving "slowly but surely" toward the goal of a nonsegregated church, it was reported here tonight.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4--Two Israeli oil corporations got their first day in court today to argue a breach of contract claim. They began it with a complaint that they had been given a legal run-around in Moscow.
Geore F. Kennan, an authority on Soviet affairs, will dis cuss "Russia, the Atom and the West" in a series of six lectures to be presented by the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, November 27:
SEATTLE, Wash., Dec. 4-- Dave Beck faced late today a jury box filled with five housewives and seven men.

New issues of corporate securities amounting to more than $36,000,000 are being offered to investors today. The issues include utility bonds, the equipment trust certificates of two railroads and stock. They are:

A capital budget of $614,122,110 for 1958 was adopted by the Board of Estimate yesterday. It was $23,007,562 less than the City Planning Commission's proposed budget of... $637,129,673, which included $626,686,573 of city funds and $10,443,099 to be obtained from Federal, state and private sources.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The Eisenhower Administration has decided to urge Congress again to clear up what should be done when a President is unable to perform his duties.

"CARMEN" can be a plum for the conductor as well as the leading lady. In his first opportunity to conduct Bizet's irresistibly fiery opera at the Metropolitan last night Thomas Schippers behaved as if he appreciated the gift.
The American Rocket Society has put before President Eisenhower a space-flight program aimed at satellites carrying four to ten men and moon expeditions within twelve to twenty-five years.
The nation's gasoline stocks increased 1,715,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
Flames billowed four stories high at Broadway and Fortieth Street yesterday afternoon in a spectacular gas main fire that illuminated the snow-darkened area for ninety minutes.

Today, on its second anniversary, the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations meets in Atlantic City in a convention that rivals the original merger in its importance to labor and the nation. Seldom in their turbulent history have unions faced so hostile a public--due, of course, to the McClellan committee exposures of some of their officers' wrongdoing.
FLINT, Mich., Dec. 4--A vice president of the General Motors Corporation predicted today that the 1958 automobile market would be a good one.

WALT DISNEY presented on Channel 7 last night a new film of timely appeal-- a study of man's perennial curiosity about the possibility of life on Mars and, more particularly, his chances of completing a trip to the neighboring planet.

THE Bach Aria Group, which began giving con certs ten years ago, opened its new season last night, with the first of three concerts at Town Hall. Despite the all-day snow, there were 1,300 listeners who greeted the performers like old friends.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--A Federal court jury this afternoon started considering the case of John Joseph Frank, a Washington attorney, accused of acting illegally as an agent for the Dominican Republic.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz recommended yesterday that New York hold its primaries and state nominating conventions in the spring instead of the fall next year.

PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 5-- Any failure of the Atlantic alliance to defend its members' interests around the world could wreck the pact and lead Europe toward neutralism, Premier Felix Gaillard said last night.

Directors of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York authorized yesterday the payment of an extra dividend of 80 cents a share on Jan. 15. This is in addition to the fourth quarterly dividend of 80 cents a share on the capital stock payable on the same date.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 4 (Reuters)--Lieut. Gen. Sir John Dudley Lavarack, who inflicted a defeat on German Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Afrika Korps at Tobruk Lybia, in World War II, died today. He was 71 years old.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 4--The most immediate threat to peace in this area was removed tonight when arrangements were made to resume the Israeli convoy to Mount Scopus.

WAS THE Allied invasion of North Africa a springboard or a couch? This is the central question examined in "Winston Churchill and the Second Front," a searching study by Trumbull Higgins of strategy against totalitarians that silhouettes the dilemmas that the free world finds itself facing today.
When New York is struck by a major snowstorm, the 12,000man Sanitation Department becomes the "Department of Snow Removal."

Harold B. Simpson, a partner in Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co., accountants, died Saturday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals after a short illness. His age was 57. He lived at 1255 North Avenue, New Rochelle, N. Y.
TOLEDO, Spain, Dec. 8-- Reuters)--The Roman Cath olic Primate of Spain today laid down rules for modesty in dress for women and told them they must wear stockings.
Michael J. Quill, head of the Transport Workers Union, said last night that the strike voted by subway motormen was "a bluff" and predicted that the subways would run on schedule today.

Men's, women's and children's apparel, toys, dolls, houseware and other articles will be on sale at the annual bazaar of the Cardiac Children's Welfare League at Flatbush Terrace, 1475 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, on Dec. 16 from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. Proceeds will aid in the support of a camp for underprivileged cardiac children.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--Vice President Richard M. Nixon urged the American people today to abandon their "weeping walls" and "get behind our missile people."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 8--Icy Lure, with Jimmy Moore at the helm, finished 1, 2, 1 to score 4 points and take first place in the weekly series of frostbite dinghy races at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (AP) ----John Brodie, the San Francisco Forty-Niners' rookie quarterback, threw a 14-yard touchdown pass to Hugh McElhenny with 46 seconds remaining today, enabling the Forty-Niners to gain a 17-13 victory over the Baltimore Colts.

TOKYO, Dec. 8 (UP)--Japan today ignored the sixteenth anniversary of Pearl Harbor. Newspapers made no mention of it, but a Tokyo movie theatre billed "From Here to Eternity," withp osters reading "Dec. 8, Day of Destiny. Dramatic Love Ends with Pearl Harbor."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 8 (AP)--Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina drove his 3000 C. C. Maserati to victory today in the Gran Premio of Rio.
"Modern scientific power has nothing to offer in comparison with the healing power implicit in one's discipleship with Jesus Christ," the Rev. Edward Winckley declared in a sermon yesterday.

Marcel Marceau, mime extraordinaire, has been persuaded by the City Center to play a four-week return engagement there starting Jan. 21. His run will end on Feb. 16, when he is scheduled to begin an extensive tour of the United States.

POTTSDOWN, Pa., Dec. 8-- The national council of the American Youth Hostels at its annual meeting here today elected Henry W. Trimble of Montclair, N.J., as national president for a one-year term. Mr. Trimble is secretary of International Business Machines.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Dec. 8 (UP)--The sailing of the Queen Mary for New York was postponed today until 11:30 A. M. (6:30 A. M. Eastern Standard Time) tomorrow because of high winds.

FREDONIA, N.Y., Dec. 8-- Dr. Robert S. Thompson, dean of the State University Teachers College here, announced at a faculty dinner tonight that he would retire at the end of the month. He came to the college in 1930 as head of the Department of Education and Psychology and seven years later was made director of training. He was appointed dean in 1949.

Events tonight: Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera, 8 o'clock; Guy and Monique Fallot,' cellist and pianist, Town Hall; Manja Mourier, Danish ballads, songs and drama, Carnegie Recital Hall, and opera and song program, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, all at 8:30.
Directors of the BristolMyers Company have elected Frederic N. Schwartz as president to succeed Lee H. Bristol who was elevated to the chairmanship.

The Gold Medal of the Mining and Metallurgical Society of America this year has been won by Donald M. Liddell of New York. The award was for "unusual contribution to the art of non-ferrous metallurgy and research."
Industry and union representatives have been summoned to a meeting this afternoon in the city's effort to end the strike by 1,600 private garbage men.
Keeping olive oil cruets sweet and clean is a simple chore but one that should be done regularly according to Edward Nurses, president of the Olive Oil Association of America.

TEHRAN, Iran, Dec. 8 (UP)-- Foreign Minister Aligholi Ardelan said today Iran would "take all relevant steps" to convert the British-protected Sheikhdom of Bahrein into an Iranian province. He told Parliament Iran regarded the oil-rich island in the Persian Gulf as a province.
TOKYO, Dec. 8 (AP)--The Japanese Agriculture-Forestry Ministry predicted today that Japan's 1957 rice harvest would reach $29,036,160 bushels--the largest in the nation's history.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Dec. 8 (AP) ----The Batavia Daily News today said its price would be seven cents a copy beginning tomorrow--an increase of a cent. The afternoon daily said the increase was dictated by rising costs of newsprint and supplies.
The Ray and Charles Newman Memorial Foundation at 233 Broadway has given $750,000 to charities since its establishment after Mr. Newman's death in 1950.
Rainy weather over the past week-end once again has brought that old question-- should artificial rinks be covered or not?
Christmas lights glow on Fifth Avenue pavement. They lure children, their parents arid grandparents to gay shop windows. Soon Park Avenue's Yuletide trees will break into nocturnal splendor.
The sudden wildcat strike of subway motormen on June 14, 1956, tied up a large part of New York's subway system. It lasted for nine hours.

CEDARHURST. L.I., Dec. 8 --The miniature gold racquet went to Calvin MacCracken of Englewood, N.J., for the second time today. MacCracken, the winner of the Gold Racquet squash racquets tournament in 1949, repeated against 22-year ...
BOSTON, Dec. 8--A 14-year-- old Idaho boy died at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital today despite a kidney transplant made in an effort to save his life.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--The Supreme Court will be the scene tomorrow of an opening skirmish in that interesting rarity, a suit between states.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 8 (UP)-- The nation's first all-purpose military jet transport has been test-operated successfully at near-sonic speeds from conventional airports and will be ready for the Air Force in January, it was announced today.

TRENTON, Dec. 8--A longrange plan to reclaim for park and recreational purposes 150 acres of submerged and marsh lands in Jersey City was outlined today by State Senator James F. Murray Jr. of Hudson County.
HAVANA, Dec. 8 (AP)--Al Balding, a Canadian playing out of Miami Beach, today won the Havana open golf tournament after a sudden death play-off with Al Besselink of Grossinger, N.Y.
MOSCOW, Dec. 8 (AP)--Trofim D. Lysenko, controversial Soviet biologist, backed up agricultural theories of his supporter, Nikita S. Khrushchev, in a newspaper article today.
The Motormen's Benevolent Association went on strike on the subways and elevated lines at 5 o'clock this morning.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Dec. 8--The beginnings of formal political life were seen in the Belgian Congo today, under the firm control of a cautious Government.

PARK FALLS, Wis., Dec. 8 (AP)--Eight children, ranging in age from 1 to 10, perished today as a fire engulfed a three-room cottage three miles west of this north woods community while their parents were away.
Dr. Bernard Bandler was chosen yesterday as presidentelect of the American Psychoanalytic Association. He will take office in May 1959.

The Zionist Organization of America yesterday called on the United States Government to fulfill this country's "moral commitments to assure Israel's security against aggression." It cited Israel's recent reaffirmation of its adherence "to the cause of the free world."

The Cerebral Palsy Center at 652 West 170th Street will benefit from a cocktail party to be held Feb. 13 in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Mrs. Gordon C. Forbes is chairman of the Auxiliaries of the Committee for the Rehabilitation of Crippled Children, the group sponsoring the fete.

On Saturday evening Puccini-lovers had one of their extremely rare opportunities to hear the composer's first opera, "Le Villi," presented in concert form by the Columbia University music department at the McMillin Theatre.

Two charming young ladies named Frances Archer and Beverly Gile delighted a Town Hall audience with a program of folk songs late yesterday afternoon.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 7-- Democratic deputies and some members of the Administration are considering plans to restrict news coverage of proceedings in Turkey's Grand National Assembly.
Fame is not important enough as a goal to be either sought after or scrupulously avoided, the Rev. Hugh McCandless declared in a sermon yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 8--Miss Saralta Padawer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Padawer, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Laurence Loeb. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman K. Loeb of Brooklyn, New York.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Dec. 7 --The latest developments in Icelandic politics indicated today that Communist-supported ministers belonging to the Labor Alliance would remain in the Government.

SEIGNIORY CLUB, Que., Dec. 8 (AP)--W.H.A. Short's Seigniory Club rink today won the eighteenth annual International Friendly Games curling event, finishing three rounds of play undefeated with 23 points.
PARIS, Dec. 8--A picture of French youth romantically happy in its personal life but passive, skeptical and detached in its political outlook was unveiled here last week.
The president of Fordham University reported yesterday that the school had been advised that its participation in the city's Lincoln Square project was "completely proper and legitimate."
MOSCOW, Dec. 8.--The Soviet Union began today to make full propaganda use of the United States failure to send up and earth satellite.

Americans, long used to fresh citrus fruits, lettuce and even strawberries during the winter, are taking an increasing year-around supply of foods from all parts of the world.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8--At the close of this afternoon's semi-final round in the 1957 Open Pairs Championship Lew Mathe and Ed Taylor, both of Los Angeles, continued to lead a field of 156. They had a three-session score of 483 points.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8--(Reuters) ----The shortage of cemeteries in Moscow has led to a black market in burial space, the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia said today.

The Bakelite Company division of the Union Carbide Corporation has decided that the market future of reinforced plastics lies largely outside polyesters. It announced over the weekend that it was withdrawing from the manufacture and sale of polyester resins, effective Jan. 1.

THE first performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" this season at the Metropolitan Opera furnished another demonstration of the strength of the company's roster and efficiency of managerial planning.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 8-- Turkey's Hall of Parliament, which is still under construction, will be used for the first time in January for a meeting of the Baghdad Pact Organization, it was announced today. Preliminary sessions will begin Jan. 12. The organization's council will meet beginning Jan. 27.
The "night people" who follow the radio broadcasts of Jean Shepherd assembled Saturday at midnight at Loew's Sheridan Theatre to hear a jazz concert presided over by their leader.
