LONOKE, Ark., Dec. 8 (UP)-- Chief of Police L.D. Rainey said today that this town had not had a traffic fatality in 5,848 days. He believes the town of 2,068, situated twenty-four miles east of Little Rock, holds some sort of national record for deathless days. The last death was recorded Dec. 8, 1941.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--Authority to cut tariffs 25 per cent below present levels over a fiveyear period will be sought by the Eisenhower Administration as part of a foreign trade program to be put before Congress in January.

WARSAW, Dec. 8 (Reuters) --Only 3 per cent of the persons imprisoned in Poland are political offenders, A. Walczak, Deputy Minister of Justice, said yesterday. Forty per cent of the common criminals now in Polish jails are under the age of 25, M. Walczak disclosed. He gave no indication of the total number of prisoners.

Dr. Timothy W. Costello, Professor of Psychology at New York University, yesterday received the Humanitarian Award of the Staten Island Lodge of B'nai B'rith. The award is presented annually for outstanding service in human relations.
William Z. Foster, American Communist leader, has reassured the Soviet Union that it need have no fears about American Communists' "cooperation" or about any "revolt against Moscow."
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, yesterday assailed the emphasis on crash programs in scientific and technological education at the expense of the social sciences and humanities.

Opposition to the addition now of any new schools for disturbed children was voiced yesterday by two members of a committee appointed by Superintendent of Schools William Jansen to survey such schools.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 8 (AP)--Ron Sobie scored 32 points and Ken Sears 25 as the New York Knickerbockers defeated the St. Louis Hawks, 113--110, for their fourth straight National Basketball Association victory today.

Dr. Reuben Fine gave an exhibition of chess play while blindfolded yesterday at the Brooklyn Chess Club. Playing against six members of the club, Dr. Fine had a 6-0 score after two and a half hours of continuous play.

AT least one badge being worn nowadays by the badge-conscious younger set can't be had in exchange for a couple of cereal boxtops or a candy-bar wrapper. Its wearers have sampled a different sort of fare: food for thought. And in most cases the first tentative taste has proved habitforming.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 8 --There is the strong likelihood that the Air Force is preparing to fire another Atlas missile within the next seven days.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 (AP)--Billy (Sweetpea) Peacock, dropping back to his own weight class after five successive losses, scored an eighth round technical knockout last night over Frankie Campos for the vacant California bantamweight crown.

Miss Mona Kassel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kassel of Brooklyn, was married last night to Richard Dinaburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Dinaburg of Jamaica, Queens. Rabbi Joseph I. Singer performed the ceremony in the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 (AP)--Governor Harriman's secretary took issue today with a Republican leader's statement that the underworld had grown "bolder and bolder" in New York since the Democratic Governor took office.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 8 (UP)--Demonstrators stoned former Prime Minister Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy and members of his Awami League party yesterday during a state byelection at Rangpur, East Pakistan, it was reported here today.
Dr. Jerry Graham and Danny McShain will engage Antonino Rocca and Miguel Perez in a tag-team match featuring the exhibition wrestling program tonight at Madison Square Garden.
The Symphony of the Air, under the direction of Jonel Perlea, played a Carnegie Hall concert last night. The soloists were Licia Albanese, soprano, and a 24-year-old baritone, Guy Richard Gordon.

AN audience of 2,700 filled Carnegie Hall late yes terday afternoon for the Sibelius memorial concert that was given there under the auspices of the Finlandia Foundation and Unisomi, Inc., an organization fostering the ideals of the United Nations through music.

ATHENS, Dec. 8--The police were taking extra precautions today to protect the British, Turkish and United States embassies, consulates and outlying properties on the eve of the United Nations debate on the Cyprus issue.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 8 --It is possible for Southern leaders who favor desegregation to speak out and still continue in their positions of leadership, if their positions were previously secure, a Princeton University study asserted today.
Measures to supplement the city's basic traffic-relief program have been recommended to the City Planning Commission.

Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange showed mixed trends last week. Distant months gained and nearer deliveries eased.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 8-- Advocates of rigid religious observance of Judaism opened a campaign today to deny Conservative Judaism a foothold in Israel.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 8 ----A memorandum of agreement on reparations issues was signed today by the Indonesian and Japanese Governments.
The steamship charter market last week suffered its fourth consecutive weekly setback as grain and coal rates continued to drop.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 8-- Turkey, with assistance and cooperation of the United Nations Children's Fund, will establish thirty rural health centers in the coming year. By the end of 1959 there will be 135 such centers.
The campaign to ward off a 6 per cent tax on advertising in St. Louis is said by a trade executive to have taken "an encouraging turn."

Roman Catholic laymen--as members of "the priesthood of the laity"--were told yesterday that prayer and theological study would best prepare them for their roles in "this time of acute crisis for civilization."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 8 (UP)--Albert Thomas, a 22year-old Sydney runner, bettered John Landy's Australian three-mile record by 1.5 seconds today, winning the event in 13 minutes 25.9 seconds during a dual meet between New South Wales and Victoria.

The Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo has been given approval by the State Banking Department to increase its capital stock from 1,885,898 to 1,896,398 shares of $5 par value each. The Liberty Bank of Buffalo also has been given approval by the department to increase its capital stock from 275,000 to 343,750 shares of $10 par value.
The Commercial State Bank and Trust Company of New York has been granted approval by the State Banking Department to increase its capital stock from 87,532 to 89,283 shares of $25 par value each.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 8-- Prof. Peter H. Odegard said today he would seek the Democratic nomination for United States Senator next year.

The marriage of Miss Shirley Louise Jaye to Daniel Neale Hoffman took place yesterday afternoon in Earl Hall at Columbia University. Rabbi Isidor Binswanger Hoffman, counselor to Jewish students at Columbia and father of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.
E.J. Korvette, Inc., a department store chain, has opened its first Connecticut unit. The ninestory building is at 909-939 Main Street, Hartford.
ROME, Dec. 8--Italian communism has lost 15 per cent of its organized strength in 1957.
RUMSON, N. J., Dec. 8--The Junior Service League of Red Bank will hold its tenth annual charity ball on Friday at the Rumson Country Club. Mrs. Robert Nicholas of Red Bank is general chairman.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 8 --Dr. Charles A. Richardson of 384 High Street, Closter, a physician, died late last night at Englewood Hospital, after a long illness. His age was 82.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 8-- Sir Hugh Foot, the new Governor of Cyprus, made a surprise broadcast today in which he promised the people of this troubled island a new year of hope.
The Rev. Edward O. Miller questioned yesterday whether modern Americans were making good use of the Bible, "for which martyrs galdly paid the price."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Monday, Dec. 9 (AP)--The Indonesian Army's only ammunition depot and small arms factory was destroyed by a tremendous series of explosions during the night.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 8 (AP) ----French military sources said tonight that French forces had killed 227 Algerian nationalist rebels in a series of widely scattered actions over the weekend.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 8-- The Istanbul police smashed a narcotics smuggling ring yesterday. They arrested three alleged leaders and seized drugs valued at $322,000. The police said the ring had customers in the United States and Greece.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP)--Willie Galimore raced 67 yards for a touchdown that launched the Chicago Bears to a 14-to-6 vic tory over the Chicago Cardinals before 43,735 at Comiskey Park today.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Dec. 8 (AP) --Frank Broyles, who yesterday quit Missouri to become football coach at Arkansas, tonight announced he was taking two members of the Missouri staff, Jim Mackenzie, line coach, and Merrill Green, backfield coach.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., Dec. 8-- Bob McCullough won three races with Scotch Cooler today for a perfect score of 39 points in the season's second frostbite dinghy regatta at Riverside Yacht Club.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 --Frank Sinatra and Peter Lawford will co-sponsor independent production of a movie about Las Vegas in which neither actor plans to appear before the cameras.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 8, --Miss Gail Panfiel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip S. Panfiel, and Pfc. Richard D. Hoffman of the Army, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Hoffman of Larchmont, were married here this afternoon in the Panfiel residence.
MADRID, Dec. 8--Spanish troops have withdrawn from three army posts under pressure from Moroccan tribesmen in Ifni, according to a communique issued here today.

Dr. Stephanie Haas of 17 East Ninety-sixth Street, senior clinical assistant, in obstetrics and gynecology at Mount Sinai Hospital, died Saturday at her home after a long illness. Her age was 58. She was the wife of Dr. Edward Kronold.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 8--Philadelphia defeated Boston in the final of the Payne Whitney intercity court tennis doubles tournament today by taking two of three matches at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club.
NORTH PELHAM, N.Y., Dec. 8--Sister M. Simplicia began her fiftieth year of parochial school teaching today, still "unable to see anything bad in kids."
BALTIMORE, Dec. 8--The appointment of William McChesney Martin Jr. as a trustee of the Johns Hopkins University was announced today. Mr. Martin is chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 8-- Stirling Moss of England and a 3.5 Ferrari from Italy swept the honors today, the final day of racing in Nassau's fourth annual, international sports car speed week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--The chiefs of government will find themselves completely disagreed upon one vital issue at the NATO summit meeting. This is whether the partners should support each other's global interests or limit mutual obligations to the area defined in the North Atlantic Treaty.
A one-year pilot operation aimed at reducing the heavy volume of stock certificates processed daily in the financial district will begin today.

MIAMI, Dec. 8 .(AP)--Three University of Michigan players today accepted invitations to play on the North team in the annual North-South charity football game here Christmas Night. They were James Van Pelt, a quarterback; Lawrence Faul, a guard; and Jerry Goebel, a center.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 8 (UP)--Ken Rosewall defeated Lew Hoad today in a professional tennis match, 5--7, 6--2, 6--3. Frank Sedgman scored a 6-4, 6-0 victory over Pancho Segura. Hoad and Rosewall defeated Sedgman and Segura in doubles, 6--2, 6--4.
MARSEILLE, France, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Alphonse Halimi of France, the world bantamweight champion, outpointed Tanny Campo of the Philippines in a nontitle ten-round bout at the Sports Arena today.

Western civilization needs "first-rate minds" in theology as well as science to survive, the Rev. Dr. Hampton Adams said in a sermon yesterday at the Park Avenue Christian Church, at Eighty-fifth Street.
KETTLEWELL, England, Dec. 8 (AP)--Six college students, two of them girls, were missing tonight in a deep network of caves beneath the lonely Yorkshire moors.

Robert D. Levitt has resigned as president of California National Productions, Inc., a National Broadcasting Company subsidiary. The company produces and syndicates television films. H. Weller Keever, vice president of N.B.C. Television Films, a C.N.P. division, has been named acting head.

Frankie Ryff and Frankie Ippolito, Bronx lightweights, will meet in the ten-round main bout tonight at the St. Nicholas Arena. It will be the second meeting between the borough rivals. Ryff took a ten-round decision from Ippolito on Oct. 22, 1956.

A car and a taxicab collided on the Grand Central Parkway Extension in Elmhurst, Queens, last evening, killing a woman in the car and injuring her husband. Olin Meadows, 30 years old, of 722 Dale Place, Uniondale, L.I., was thrown from his car and was in serious condition in Queens General Hospital. His wife, Geraldine, 29, was killed.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP)-- Spokesmen for the Congregational Christian Churches and the Evangelical and Reformed Church announced further steps today toward unification.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)-- Bowdoin College's Polar Bears national champions, won the eleventh annual frostbite sailing regatta today.

THE Agrupacion Coral de Pamplona, a group of nine young women and six men from Spain, which is making its first tour in this country, gave a program last night at Town Hall. It was led by its founder-conductor, Luis Morondo.

Joseph S. Stern of Cincinnati has been named chairman of the board of trustees of the National Shoe Institute. He was elected during the Popular Price Shoe Show of America held last week in New York. He is chairman of the United States Shoe Corporation. The vice chairman will be Gilbert Hahn of Hahn Stores, Washington, D.C.

Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, 14-year-old national open chess champion, yesterday defeated Arthur Feuerstein at the Manhattan Chess Club in the first game of the tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 (UP)-- Norm Van Brocklin passed for four touchdowns today to lead the Los Angeles Rams to a 42-17 victory over the Green Bay Packers. The National Football League game drew 70,572 fans.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 8-- Leaders of the merged labor federation made secret plans here tonight to give the scandaltainted Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union a three-month stay of execution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)-- The Agriculture Department said today that horses were Ireland's largest single dollar earnings export. United States imports of race horses, jumpers and hunters from Ireland during the first eight months of the year totaled seventy head, but were valued at more than $507,000.

TORONTO, Dec. 8 (Canadian Press)--Sir Edmund Wyly Grier, first Canadian to receive a knighthood in recognition of his work as an artist, died yesterday at the age of 95.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 8-- The Lebanese Army was reported today to have taken over the border zone of the northeast where raiders from Syria looted a gendarmerie post Friday night.

The New York Telephone Company reported last night that it had an option on a fleet of more than thirty buses to get its employes to work in the event of a subway strike.
BARRINGTON, Ill., Dec. 8-- James R. Cardwell, a Chicago industrialist and inventor, died early today in his home here. He was 84 years old.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews has named John F. Brosnan its New York chairman for the annual observance of Brotherhood Week, Feb. 16-23. Mr. Brosnan is Chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents and a leading Catholic layman.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8 (AP)-- The Pittsburgh Steelers tonight signed Larry Krutko, a fullback from West Virginia University, their No. 2 choice in last week's National Football League draft. Krutko will report for the 1958 season.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 8--Ch. Merrymorn Lita, a blackcoated toy poodle owned by Mrs. Milton Erlanger of New York, was selected best in show today at the Camden County Kennet Club's twenty-sixth annual all-breed event. A field of 744 dogs competed at Convention Hall.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 8-- For the first time since Morocco became independent, capital appears to be moving from France into this former protectorate.
There may be a moral for parents as well as teachers in an incident reported at a recent conference of the Yorkville Youth Council.
The Police Department set up a clearinghouse at midnight last night to answer questions from the public concerning the threatened strike of motormen against the city's rapid transit system.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP)--The grain futures markets followed an erratic pattern on the Board of Trade last week.

The Police Department further tightened provisions yesterday for obtaining a pistol permit. It will now be necessary for each of the three persons sponsoring an applicant to fill out a questionnaire containing forty-nine parts.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 8-- The merged labor movement has made a start toward resolving differences over foreign activities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--On election night last year President Eisenhower was sitting before a television screen in a hotel suite with members of his official family, waiting for Adlai E. Stevenson to concede.

Emma Lazarus' reference to "the wretched refuse of your teeming shore" has been deleted in the excerpt of her famous Statue of Liberty poem that now adorns the new terminal building at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

The La Guardia Memorial Association, 100 East Fortysecond Street, announced yesterday that its seventh annual La Guardia Award would be given to Omer Carmichael, Superintendent of Schools of Louisville, Ky., for "the out...
The successful launching of the Russian satellites has made closer scientific ties among the Western allies imperative, the New York Times Youth Forum was told yesterday.
The Police Department, to cope with possible violence, ordered 7,500 policemen to emergency duty last night after the subway motormen threatened to strike.
BUFFALO, Dec. 8 (AP)--The former chief of Nazi Germany's missiles research says that the United States public should not be unduly dismayed by Friday's failure of the Vanguard rocket.
America is living dangerously. Every time a car is driven, a coal fire is made, a meal is cooked with natural gas, a tin can is thrown away, something is gone forever.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 8-- West German cotton importers have placed $25 000,000 worth of orders with the Soviet Union.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 8 (UP.)--Turkey and Belgium played a 1-1 tie today in an international soccer match.

DETROIT, Dec. 8 (UP)--Dickie Moore fired his twelfth and thirteenth goals of the season tonight to lead the Canadiens to a 3-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings, adding 2 points to Montreal's National Hockey League lead over New York.

The third lecture in the current series for the laity at the New York Academy of Medicine will be given by Dr. James R. Hundley of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. It will be delivered Wednesday at 8:30 P. M. at the academy, 2 East 103d Street. Dr. Hundley will speak on "The Future in Nutrition."
DETROIT, Dec. 8 (UP)--The Detroit Lions today beat the National Football League's Eastern Conference champion Cleveland Browns at their own game --defense.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $75,854,693,501.

A statement by a spokesman for the City Planning Commis sion after a public hearing on Nov. 27 was erroneously attributed in The New York Times the following day to Robert A. Low, a representative of the Thirtieth Street Association.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 (AP)--The State Thruway served as an emergency airplane landing strip today for the second time in two days. Harry W. Clark, 26 years old, of Troy, brought his single-engine Skyhawk down on the center mall south of Albany today. He said the...

The American Academy of Dental Medicine was told yesterday that programs to rehabilitate the maimed, injured and sick abroad could become an effective instrument of United States international relations.
OPP, Ala., Dec. 8 (UP)--A high speed head-on collision to day killed five persons, including a civilian motorist and four airmen, the state Highway Patrol reported.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 8 (AP)--Edward Cayea of Syracuse, formerly of Malone, died here yesterday at the age of 109.

After the Motormen's Benevolent Association staged its nine-hour wildcat subway strike on June 14, 1956, the Transit Authority obtained an injunction in the State Supreme Court against another walkout.
The global migration and resettlement program of the United Hias Service will gain from the proceeds of the preview performance of "The Music Man" on the night of Dec. 18 at the Majestic Theatre.

JOHNSON AIR FORCE BASE JAPAN, Dec. 8-- (UP)--The Johnson Air Force Base Vanguards upset the Marine Corps' Sukiran Streaks from Okinawa, 6--0, today to win the twelfth annual Rice Bowl football game and the Far East service championship.
King Mohammed V of Morocco was joined in New York by his four daughters yesterday. They were not included in original plans for his eighteen-day official visit to this country ...
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (AP) --The Philadelphia Daily News has been sold to Walter H. Annenberg, editor and publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirer and head of Triangle Publications, Inc.
Two trustees of Beth-El Hospital, Brooklyn, were honored last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 8--John F. Crossin, a management consultant and former industrial executive, died today in New Rochelle Hospital. His age was 63.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8-- James Gallagher, a former United States representative who was an original supporter of the plan to have the Independence Hall area designated as a national shrine, died today at his home here. He was 90 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--Nuri as-Said, grand old man of Arab politics, is in Washington this week-end urging a Western initiative toward solving ArabIsraeli problems and more vigorous support of the Baghdad Pact.
ONE of the largest investments made annually by the American family is for electrical equipment and appliances for the home.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 8--AntiDutch measures and riots in Indonesia largely dominated sentiment on the stock market last week.

DALLAS, Dec.8--Fredrik Olafsson of Iceland today upset Laszlo Szabo of Hungary in the seventh round of the international chess masters tournament. The talented expert from Reykjavik pinned the first defeat on Szabo.
The Government's plan to publish annual volumes of recent Presiden tial papers is good news indeed for students of the Presidency.
Morton S. Kline, a Trenton realtor, has been elected the forty-second president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Dec. 8--(UP)--The University of North Carolina suffered the third major loss from its National Collegiate basketball championship squad today when x-rays showed Danny Lotz suffered a broken foot in yesterday's game. Lotz will be out of competition for several weeks.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8--Steel operations this week will feel the full effects of year-end, seasonal and inventory-cutting influences. These factors show that consumption is at a high level, that inventories are being pared to a low level and that steel companies are pushing harder for sales.
MEDFORD, Wis., Dec. 8 (AP)--The Duncan rink of Wausau, Wis., won the All-America Trophy at the Midwest Curling Association bonspiel today, trimming the Kleffman Rink of Hibbing, Minn., 11--7.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 8 --Foreign Minister Subandrio said today that the door still was not closed to a peaceful settlement of the Dutch-Indonesian dispute over West New Guinea. However, he added that Indonesia would not take the initiative in seeking a solution.

"Off Broadway Revitalizes the Theatre" is the subject to be discussed Thursday at 8 P.M. by the Dramatists' Forum at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West Fifty-third Street. Participating will be Day Tuttle, William Landis, Dorothy Raedler and Robert Kamlot. Ray Yates, chairman of the forum, will act as moderator.
Home ice contests continue to be too hard for the New York Rangers. They skated against the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison. Square Garden last night, but they couldn't so much as tie the visitors.

Ninety new walk-in trucks, costing a total of $275,000, have been added by the Curtiss Candy Company to its route sales fleet. The trucks are designed for 40 per cent greater load capacity to meet the company's expanding truck route requirements, according to William C. Jakes, president.

Food Fair Properties, Inc., is offering to stockholders of record of last Friday, rights to subscribe to an additional share of common stock at $2 a share for every two shares held, the company announced over the week-end. The subscription offer will expire Dec. 20.
Bus and railroad companies made hasty arrangements last night to provide additional service to the city after the subway motormen decided to strike.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 8 --Tony Ziluca sailed Hiccup to victory today in the fourth regatta of the frostbite championship season at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8-- Reginald Sheffield, an actor who had been in the entertainment field since he appeared in "Peter Pan" in England in 1913, died today at his home here. He was 56 years old.
Dr. Nanette Kass and Dr. Julius Wenger, both physicians, were married last night in the Park Avenue Syagogue by Rabbi Judah Nadich.

A Professor of Inorganic Chemistry at the University of Illinois has been elected president of the American Chemical Society in a nationwide mail ballot of the society's 82,000 chemists and chemical engineers. He is Dr. John C. Bailar, Jr.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) --The Washington Redskins crushed the Philadelphia Eagles today with their biggest scoring show of the season, a 42-7 victory at soggy Griffith Stadium.
Nine new films are slated to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
The American Research Bureau, which compiles television program ratings, is experimenting with a new electronic system that can report almost instantaneously what programs are being watched.
A REALISTIC appraisal of the scientific assets and liabilities of the United States was offered yesterday during an excellent ninety-minute telecast on "Wide Wide World" over Channel 4.

FLORENCE MONT, soprano, proved herself a singer of substantial promise when she presented a program of Italian, German, French and Spanish songs, as well as a group of spirituals, at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Jonathan Brice was the accompanist.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 8 --Miss Louisa Sewall Cheever, retired associate professor of English literature at Smith College, died today in Newton Centre, where she had been in a nursing home for a year. Her age was 89.

BOSTON, Dec. 8--A young woman Congregational missionary, who helped with the translation of the New Testament into the Kusaien language, is returning to Micronesia to fulfill a promise to an island king.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 8-- Donald Lawder Jr. has been appointed director of information services for the Educational Testing Service. This was announced today by Dr. Henry Chauncey, president of the educational measurement research organization. For the last eight years, Mr. Lawder held the same position at the Menninger Foundation, nonprofit psychiatric center at Topeka, Kan.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 8 ----Two new buildings were blessed on the campus of Marymount College this afternoon preliminary to the opening of Marymount's golden anniversary celebration.

WILTON, Conn., Dec. 8.--A recital of works by Beethoven, Bach and Brahms was presented here this afternoon by David M. Keiser, president of the New York Philharmonic, at the piano, and Aldo Parisot, Brazilian-born American cellist.
Judah Louis Buchman of 4710 Beach Forty-seventh Street, Sea Gate, Brooklyn, a retired vintner, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn. His age was 77.
All television and radio stations in the metropolitan area suspended normal operations early today to participate in a Conelrad test. Regular programs were off the air from 1 to 1:30

LONDON, Dec. 8 (Reuters)-- The Moscow radio said today that work done in the first five months of the International Geophysical Year had enabled Soviet scientists to forecast magnetic storms and the disruption of the normal transmission of radio waves connected with them.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8-- Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Rossner Graham have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Carolyn Graham, to William Frederick Stifel 2d. He is the son of Dr. John L. Stifel of Toledo, Ohio, and the late Mrs. Stifel.

A large turnout from the Comoedia Matinee Club will be present at Wednesday afternoon's performance of "Rumple" at the Alvin Theatre. Before the matinee, the members will hold a luncheon meeting in the Sheraton-Astor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (AP)--A shoving and yelling me lee erupted today at Kezar Stadium as 4,800 general admission seats for the sell-out Baltimore Colts-San Francisco Forty-niners football game went on sale.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--A national farm program, paralleling the Administration's approach to agriculture problems, was advanced today by the Committee for Economic Development.
United Nations Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, returning from a week's mission to the Middle East, was able to report on Saturday that he got what he "hoped for."

ZURICH, Dec. 8--Argentine stocks provided last week's most spectacular recovery here. The market showed great buoyancy, with prices mounting by jumps and volumes being substantial. All Argentine shares traded in Zurich improved considerably from the extremely depressed level long prevailing.
A day of rain "probably becoming mixed with or changing over to snow during the day and ending late" tonight was forecast by the Weather Bureau.

"Desire Under the Elms," Don Hartman's production for Paramount of the Eugene O'Neill play, will have its local premiere at the newly renamed Odeon Theatre, formerly the Central, at Broadway and Fortyseventh Street.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 8 (AP)--An Air National Guard jet trainer crashed near Niagara Falls Airport this afternoon killing one man and injuring another. Killed was Capt. Lloyd L. Arsenault, 36 years old, of Buffalo, a combat veteran of Korea. Injured was Lieut. Thomas R. Healy, 29, also of Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)-- Thomas E. Murray said today he was not switching his position when he said earlier this month that he saw "no objection" to reopening the security case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer.
AGOURA, Calif., Dec. 8 (AP) --A sports car road racer was killed today on the two-mile Paramount ranch track. It was the second fatality at the track in two days.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 8 (UP)--More than 190,000 European cars worth $400 million have been sold to American buyers in 1957, an export magazine reported today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 8-- Brazil must carry a heavy burden in the next three years in order to pay interest on a bond issue recently approved by Congress.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 8 (AP)-- Xavier University presented its annual St. Francis Xavier Medal awards today to a professional baseball player, an education leader and a priest.

Members of the New York Typographical Union 6 who have attained fifty, sixty and seventy years of continuous membership were awarded gold membership buttons yesterday in ceremonies at the Martinique Hotel. Francis G. Barrett, president...
LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP)--The Soviet travel agency Intourist announced today that foreign tourists might now go to Siberia.
Following up an earlier study of the farm problem, issued in January, 1956, the Committee for Economic Development has just released its second report covering the same economic area.

York Avenue between Eightyfourth and Eighty-fifth Streets was closed to traffic yesterday as a result of a water main break. Although the surface of the street was unbroken, the police feared that it might have been undermined by the break, which was discovered at 3:50 A. M.

CAIRO, Dec. 8 (AP)--Three members of the American Gen eral Federation of Women's Clubs talked for an hour today with President Gamal Abdel Nasser. All three agreed after the meeting that President Nasser was a "charming man."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 7--President Tito of Yugoslavia has again assured the United States that his country stands apart from the Soviet bloc and intends to pursue a fully independent foreign policy.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec. 8 (AP)--Fire swept through three buildings in the warehouse district of Charleston's west side early today, causing about $150,000 in damages. No injuries were reported. The cause was not determined.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Dec. 8 (AP) --A default in the final enabled Edgar Yeomans, 47, Los Angeles, to take the national hard court senior tennis championship today at the La Jolla Beach and Tennis Club. William Robertson, Los Angeles, defaulted.

The American Trust Company, New York, has been named a member of Cadena Internacional, a new organization headed by Banco Internacional, Mexico City. It is made up of fifty Mexican banks and financial institutions.
John T. McHugh has announced his resignation as president of the Joseph Katz Company, after twenty-four years with the agency.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP)--The young Aga Khan, leader of the world's 10,000,000 Ismailis, said tonight he planned a vast Moslem educational program to enable his followers to catch up to Christian levels of learning.

The General Electric Company has announced a price reduction of about 4 per cent on pole-type distribution transformers. Effective last Saturday, the reduction was said to be the first sizable cut in distribution transformer prices since 1938.

The nation's banks will be able to meet the credit needs of a growing economy only if they can continue to earn enough to attract new capital, Prof. Marcus Nadler of New York University, consulting economist to the Hanover Bank, warned yesterday in a letter entitled "The Outlook for Banking."

NEWARK, Dec. 8--Miss Reva Schapira, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Schapira of West Orange, was married this evening to Harold Isen, son of Mrs. Nathan Isen of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Isen. The ceremony was performed in the Essex House Hotel here. Rabbis Eli Pilchik and David Goldstein officiated.
ON a March morning forty one years ago Charles B. Phelps, a farmer at West Shelby in upstate New York, and Margaret Wolcott, his housekeeper, were found shot dead in the Phelps farmhouse.
New York Airways announced yesterday that it was considering replacing its present fleet of single-rotor helicopters with a tandem-rotor type, the Vertol 44-B.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 8-- The rain and the White House staff have played hand in hand with the doctor's orders this week-end, making it one of the quietest that President Eisenhower has spent since taking office.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8 (AP)-- The fifty-six-day strike that tied up Pittsburgh's largest mass Transit system ended tonight with union and management acceptance of a two-year contract.

VIENNA, Austria, Dec. 8-- Anglo-American companies that, after pioneering the development of Austrian oil fields, were expropriated first by the Nazis and then by the Russians, will be permitted to participate in their further development. This was announced here today in a radio talk by Chancellor Julius Raab.

Riders stranded by the subway strike poured into Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station during the evening rush hour yesterday seeking transportation to the Bronx, lower Westchester County and Queens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--A Congressional statute providing for deportation of aliens for past membership in the Com munist party was construed by the Supreme Court today as requiring proof of "meaningful association" with the party.
SEATTLE, Dec. 9--The state rested its case in the Dave Beck grand larceny trial this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)-- The Administration today urged a five-year renewal of President Eisenhower's authority to cut tariffs and make foreign trade agreements, saying this was a vital tool in the economic cold war with Russia.
"Paths of Glory," the film version of Humphrey Cobb's novel about a doomed regiment during World War I, starring Kirk Douglas, will open Christmas day at the Victoria Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--The Supreme Court held unanimously today that wiretapping by New York State law enforcement officers, although authorized by the State Constitution and statutes, violated Federal law.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9-- President Tito has asked the United States to terminate its dwindling military assistance to Yugoslavia.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9--A Syrian spokesman charged here today that the disintegration of friendly relations between the United States and the Arab countries had been caused largely by distortions in the United States Press.
HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Dec. 9 (AP)--Dr. Wernher von Braun said today that during the postWorld War II years his missile operations for the Army were restricted.
Eager bidding by investment bankers yesterday caused new AAA-rated utility bonds to be priced beneath a 4 per cent yield level for the first time in more than a year.
King Mohammed V of Morocco blamed Spain last night for the new fighting in North Africa.

RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 9-- King Mohammed V told the Moroccan people in a message that their "wisdom and restraint" had gained "the sympathy of all states that condemn any aggression of which we might be victims."
C.P. Snow, probably the only living author who has been knighted for his achievements in public affairs, will have his new novel, "The Conscience of ...

BONN, Germany, Dec. 9--The West German Government has informed the North Atlantic Council of the subjects it wants to discuss at the forthcoming Paris meeting of the Council.
The State of New York plans to resume long-term financing for the New York Thruway by the sale of state-guaranteed bonds next month.

PARIS, Dec. 9--There were signs today that some European members of the Atlantic alliance might raise the question of who pulled the trigger on intermediate-range missiles at bases the United States intended to establish on the Continent.
JAMES PRIDEAUX may be the only man in history who begged women to complain to him twenty-four hours a day.
Luncheon meeting, Association of Reform Rabbis of New York City and Vicinity, 838 Fifth Avenue, noon. Speaker: Dr. Emil Fackenheim.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--A long dispute over railroad freight rates for iron ore entering through the ports of New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore was sent back to the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Supreme Court.
The longest subway strike in the city's history, inconveniencing thousands of riders, took place on the Interborough Rapid Transit System in 1926 from July 6 to July 23.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9--J.G. Tolpin, a lecturer at Northwestern University, said tonight that the Soviet Union was using women to incerase technological development.
ALBANY, Dec. 9--Governor Harriman's two chief economic experts joined today in painting a gloomy picture of the state's business and employment prospects.
The Yale Alumni Association of Long Island, of which Harvey McClintock is chairman, is sponsoring the Yale Glee Club concert at the Glen Cove (L.I.) High School on Friday at 9:30 P.M.
Since his team holds a commanding lead in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association, Red Auerbach, Boston Celtics' coach, can afford to be generous in praising rival clubs.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 9-- Tea authorities here have warned that world producers will face a crisis within two years unless immediate steps are taken to keep production in line with consumption.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9-- Secretary of State Dulles has assured Premier David BenGurion of Israel that, in the absence of a formal treaty, "substance and not form" will govern United States-Israeli relations.
ALBANY, Dec. 9--Governor Harriman named today an eight-member committee of legal and psychiatric experts to study the definition of criminal insanity used in New York courts.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 9-- The merged labor movement agreed today to raise $1,000,000 in the next three years to be spent on foreign projects.

The strike led against the New York City subway system by the Motormen's Benevolent Association is a flagrant violation of state law. It is contemptuous of court order.
Representatives of 1,600 striking garbagemen voted unanimously last night to turn down a management proposal for a settlement.
ALBANY, Dec. 9 (AP)--President William S. Carlson of the state University today warmly defended a controversial report that recommended a central campus for the widely scattered University units.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)-- The 1957 cotton crop was estimated by the Department of Agriculture today at 11,010,000 bales.
The United States is neglecting its bright students, a panel of high school boys and girls agreed yesterday. A wide program of Federal scholarships was urged.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 9--Attorney General William P. Rogers indicated today a shift in Administration legal arguments concerning the claim of Texas to offshore oil exploitation rights extending 10 miles into the Gulf of Mexico.
NORMAN, Okla., Dec. 9 (AP)-- Don Schwall, a University of Oklahoma basketball star, today quit the Sooner team and said he would sign a contract with a major league baseball team "within a week."
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9--California's top-ranking contract bridge pair, Lew Mathe and Ed Taylor, won the Open Pairs Championship early this morning.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 9 (UP) --The United States Trotting Association directors today approved rule and by-law changes
Held that wiretapping by New York State officials pursuant to New York law violated Federal law and that evidence so obtained was inadmissible in Federal criminal trials.
"Assignment: Southeast Asia," a documentary film with narration by James A. Michener, will be televised by the National Broadcasting Company on Sunday, Dec. 22, from 2:30 to 4 P.M.
The litigation between the States of Virginia and Maryland that was brought before the Supreme Court yesterday is technically described as Virginia v. Maryland.
Battle lines were being drawn yesterday over the question of federal charters for savings banks.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9--Greece accused Britain today of holding Cyprus under colonial repression.
GIFTS for the home--be it a Connecticut mansion or a city walk-up--are often more appreciated at Christmas than clothes in the wrong size, style or color.
The operating rate of the nation's steel industry is expected to fall below 70 per cent of rated capacity this week.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 9 (UP)--Mrs Eisenhower drove into town today and bought seventy-two picture postcards of the Presidential farm.

The general situation on travel routes in the five boroughs follows. Persons who want more detailed information can obtain it by calling the Police Department at these numbers: Manhattan--WOrth 6-1910; Brooklyn--JAckson 2-2400; Queens --JAmaica 3-4199; the Bronx-CYprus 4-1610.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--A Senate committee piled up more evidence today of unpunished assaults, dynamitings and sabotage visited on Tennessee employers who had refused to take orders from local officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9--A group of LatinAmerican, Western European and Asian delegates worked out a compromise resolution on the Algerian question tonight.
ROCHESTER, N.Y. Dec. 9 (AP)--The will of Frank E. Gannett, publisher, filed for probate today, divided personal estate estimated at $3,000,000 among relatives, friends and the Gannett Foundation.
TOKYO, Dec. 9--The Japanese Cabinet approved today the $800,000,000 reparations formula for Indonesia worked out by Premier Nobusuke Kishi ...
DETROIT, Dec. 9 (AP)--The auto industry is continuing its drive for a 6,200,000 car output this year.
The catalogue of human suffering recorded Sunday, when details of the Neediest Cases of 1957 appeared in this newspaper, has drawn a swift response to the individual cases of hardship.
The Board of Education has scheduled a special meeting tomorrow afternoon to elect Dr. John J. Theobald Superintendent of Schools.
NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 9-- The State Water Resources Commission refused today to approve a proposed boat channel and bathing-beach project near the Shorehaven Golf Club here.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that the 1958 legislative program of his office would be keyed to greater protection of the buying public.
DALLAS, Dec. 9--Significant changes occurred in the standing of the players in the international chess masters tournament today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 9-- The merged labor federation expelled the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union tonight.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 9 (AP)--Co-Captain Alan Seiden scored 19 points to pace St. John's University of Brooklyn to a 78-66 basketball victory over Bridgeport tonight.
The Bell and Howell Company of Chicago, announced yesterday the purchase of the Inserting and Mailing Machine Company of Phillipsburg, N.J., for an undisclosed amount of cash.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--A State Department spokesman said tonight that J. Gordon Main, director of the department's Office of Southwest Pacific Affairs, left yesterday by plane for Jakarta.
Guy and Monique Fallot, a French brother and sister team, 'cellist and pianist, made their New York debut last night at Town Hall.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--Vice President Richard M. Nixon linked traffic safety and the Soviet earth satellite today as major problems for the nation.
HAVANA, Dec. 9--Circulars calling on the people of Cuba to stage a general strike to overthrow the regime of President Fulgencio Batista are being circulated in Havana.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)-- A spokesman for British woolen and worsted mills called today for a lowering of tariffs on woolen fabric imports into the United States.

Yale, which finished third behind Princeton and Dartmouth in the Ivy League football race this season, placed four players on the All-Ivy eleven yesterday. The team was selected by the eight league coaches.
Despite the fact that it lacks height and depth, Long Island University's sophomore-studded basketball team has the potential for a winning season.
BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Dec. 9 (UP)--William Rooe Simpson, a pawnbroker who once wrote pawn tickets on the Hope diamond, died at his home here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 60 years old.
The New York State Pharmaceutical Society condemned yesterday "false and misleading advertising containing unsubstantiated claims for drug products."

An unhappy debate which can only increase tensions within the North Atlantic alliance and bring joy to the Communists has begun before the United Nations General. Assembly over the problem of the British Crown Colony of Cyprus.
George A. Hopkins of 620 West 116th Street, a lawyer with an office at 233 Broadway, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. His age was 75. He had been ill since Friday.
LONDON, Dec. 9 (Reuters)-- World-wide laughter at its rocket failures may be what the United States needed to goad it to success, a leading columnist wrote today in The Daily Mirror.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 9 (AP)--The State Racing Commission today suspended for life four jockeys and a trainer from Kentucky tracks.
The legislative watchdog committee announced yesterday that it had served three more subpoenas on delegates to the Apalachin gang meeting, calling for their appearance in Albany on Thursday.
Because of the Soviet Union threat, Americans must put new goals ahead of an ever-higher standard of living, a leading economist warned yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 9--Stock market trading continued at low ebb today. Most industrial groups had small irregular movements.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--The Supreme Court vacated a 1938 Michigan murder conviction today on the ground that the defendant had not had counsel when he pleaded guilty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)-- A former Supreme Court law clerk said today that "unconscious slanting" of material that clerks provide to the justices might influence which cases the court decides to consider.

TRENTON, Dec. 9--The Republican majority in the State Assembly today blocked a Democratic effort to extend rent controls beyond Dec. 31. The extension would apply to the thirty-five municipalities in which controls still exist.
Madison Square Garden's first wrestling program since the riot of Nov. 19 was a success in every way but one--financial.
Capt. Sigurd Staalesen, charged with negligence by the Coast Guard in the grounding of a Norwegian freighter off Newport, R.I., last September, testified at a hearing here yesterday.
MILAN EFFECTS as colorful and amusing as baubles on a Christmas tree enlivened a recent mid-season showing of high-fashion apparel by Biki.

IN the days ahead, many a visiting youngster can be counted on to transform a festive holiday home into a Roman ruin.
The Esso Standard Oil Company expects to put two huge caverns, cut out of solid rock, into use next year for the storage of liquefied petroleum gas.
"Who," asked King Hill, Rice Institute's quarterback, "is going to win the Cotton Bowl game in Dallas?"

The Ford Foundation and the Rockefeller Foundation have made initial grants to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts of $2,500,000 each.
Today's representation election among 32,500 hourly rated Transit Authority employes will disclose, among other things, the actual strength of the Transport Workers Union.

IT was a game that meant nothing in the standings. The Cleveland Browns had already clinched the Eastern Conference championship when they squared off against the New York Giants at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 15-- There is a mood of expectancy here that the next few months may produce some important developments in the thirtyseven-month-old Algerian rebellion.
Just short of a month ago the New York Rangers won a game at Madison Square Garden. The Broadway Blues showed that it was no fluke, for they won again on their home ice last night.
The National Industrial Advertisers Association has dropped plans to publish a Media Data File. When announced earlier this year, the project set off a sharp controversy.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon last night graded the nation's parents on the state of the public school system, and flunked them.
THE bright array of intriguing dishes that covers a smorgasbord table is never too much for Swedes at home or abroad. But American appetites are less hearty, Mrs. Charlotta Morner has found.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 15 (UP)--A missiles expert, alarmed by several recent accidents from homemade rockets, issued a list of don'ts for amateur rocketeers today.

Francis A. O'Neill of 33-19 Twenty--fourth Avenue, Astoria, Queens, a detective on the main office squad of the Police Department for nineteen years before his retirement in 1943, died yesterday in his sleep. His age was 60.
POMONA, N.Y., Dec. 15-- Rockland County's new $1,600,000 Welfare Home and Admin istrative Office was dedicated here today, with more than 3,000 persons visiting the red brick structure.
Mayor Wagner told the striking subway motormen last night that the city would not let itself be "blackmailed" into acceptance of their demand for separate bargaining representation.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 15-- President Eisenhower has assured the Arab states that no decisions affecting their vital interests will be taken at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization conference without their being consulted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UP) --Senator Ralph E. Flanders said today the United States' allies should have "possession" of any atomic missiles sent to Europe by this country to counter the Soviet Union's rocket threat.

The full draft of a proposed international code to safeguard foreign investment from nationalization or expropriation was made public here today by a West German sponsoring organization, the Society to Advance the Protection of Foreign Investment.
Ross H. Smith of Cornell was elected president of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association as the organization's seventy-fifth annual convention ended yesterday at the Hotel Statler.
THE New York City Ballet ushered in its fifth annual presentation of "The Nutcracker" with four performances over the week-end at the City Center.
LONDON, Dec. 15--The stock markets here were helped last week by the encouraging November trade figures, but business remained slow.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 (UP)--Brian Cullen, assisted by brother Barry, scored a late third-period goal to help the Toronto Maple Leafs gain a 3-1 victory over Boston tonight. The Leafs tied the Bruins for third place in the National Hockey League.
LONDON, Dec. 15--Michael Sadleir, author, bibliophile, publisher and student of Victorian literature, died Friday at the age of 68.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (UP)--Tobin Rote sparked the Detroit Lions to two touchdowns in the third period today as Detroit overcame a 10-point Chicago Bears' lead and posted a 21-13 triumph before 41,088.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 15--The Netherlands diplomatic mission here announced today an accelerated program of evacuation by ship for Dutch nationals in Indonesia.

IN midsummer heat last July, Willard K. Denton, head of the Manhattan Savings Bank, dreamed a Christmas dream. He thought he had built an ice pond in the bank's lobby at Madison Avenue and Forty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15-- Support is growing in Congress for a more powerful missiles chief to take over all programs.
Nikita S. Khrushchev's policy has been bolstered by last weekend's abolition of four Soviet military production ministries.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 15--Developments in Indonesia and some trade pessimism last week dominated a stock market already suffering from low blood pressure.

Cotton prices in the domestic market fluctuated widely last week, and all active months made new life-of-contract highs. Prices closed at higher levels.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15--An ambitious production program of twelve motion pictures has been announced for 1958 by the Hecht-Hill-Lancaster company.
PARIS, Dec. 15--The meeting of the North Atlantic Council at the level of heads of government will open tomorrow.

PARIS, Dec. 15--President Eisenhower asserted today that a world-wide ban on future nuclear weapons testing, without other measures, might increase rather than diminish the threat of aggression and war.

Extra nonsubscription performances of "Don Giovanni" on Friday evening and "Carmen" Sunday evening will be highlights of the Christmas week schedule of the Metropolitan Opera. Carlo Bergonzi will sing Don Jose in "Carmen" for the first time at the Met.

It is hard to overestimate the impact of basic research on the nation's way of life. Almost every product the consumer uses today had its genesis in the "pure" research laboratory. And the list is growing rapidly.

It took a champion team, the Cleveland Browns, to reel off what many considered the best and most smoothly executed running play of the football season at Yankee Stadium.

The strike of some hundreds of motormen against the New York subways has ended eight days after it began.
LONDON, Dec. 16--The seventeen Asian member nations of the Colombo Plan continued to make progress in economic development in the last year despite increasingly adverse trade balances.

Sales of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation this year would reach a company record of about $2,000,000,000, Gwilym A. Price, president and chairman, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The Secretary of Labor said today that the nation's economy faces a "cyclical adjustment" in 1958 but "not one which will cause us any serious concern."

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Dec. 19--Dr. Michael H. Lucey of Lake Grove, retired principal of Julia Richman and Forest Hills High Schools in New York and Queens, respectively, died here yesterday in Mather Memorial Hospital after a short illness. His age was 83.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 19 (AP)--Louisiana State thrashed heavily favored Lafayette, 80-- 72, tonight to join two other Southeastern Conference teams and Louisiana Tech in the semifinals of the Carrousel basketball tournament. L.S.U. meets Alabama, and Tennessee plays Louisiana Tech tomorrow night.
Jimmy Archer, a Bronx welterweight, will engage Gale Kerwin of Valley Stream, L.I., in the principal ten-round fight at Madison Square Garden tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 19 (UP)--The Moscow radio quickly threw cold water tonight on the West's offer to make a new start at disarmament through the twenty-five-nation United Nations Disarmament Commission.
UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 19 --A tentative agreement has been reached under which France would present the compensation claims against Egypt by the old Suez Canal Company.
New York City is planning to borrow $25,500,000 in the public market on Jan. 15 to finance its 1957 contribution to the social security fund for city employes.

Bob Hope's second television show for Plymouth has been scheduled for Friday, Jan. 17 from 8 to 9 P.M. There is still the question, however, of whether the automobile company will be a co-sponsor of three additional programs starring the comedian.
The final audit of the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham's New York Crusade yesterday showed expenditures of $2,632,412.91 and income of $2,850,030.91.
Fernando Previtali conducted the New York Philharmonic in a largely Italian program last night in Carnegie Hall opening the third and last week of his current guest appearance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The latest United States intelligence information indicates that the Soviet Union has sharply slowed construction of conventional submarines.
The trial of James R. Hoffa and two other men on wiretap conspiracy charges ended in a disagreement early today.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 19 --Preliminary details of a new system of photography were presented today to a meeting of the American Physical Society at Stanford University.
The locked door with a peephole leading to the Bureau of Planning and Operations at Police Headquarters was removed yesterday. The order came shortly after news

BOSTON, Dec. 19 (UP)--Larry Hillman, a defenseman, blasted in a 30-footer during a finalperiod scoring flurry to draw the Boston Bruins into a 3-3 deadlock with the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- Fifteen member countries of the Inter-American Economic and Social Organization opposed today an increase in United States tariffs on lead and zinc.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation plans to close one of the eight potlines --or series of production units --at its Mead, Wash., smelter today.
ALMOST everything on wheels, except full-sized motor cars, comes to Harold Robert Semerau's dark loft in the Salvation Army warehouse at 540 West Forty-sixth Street, down near the North River.
Directors of the National Supply Company of Pittsburgh will consider today a merger offer from the Armco Steel Corporation, Arthur W. McKinney, president, confirmed yesterday.
Picketing of vessels of the Moore-McCormack Lines and those of its Robin Line Division by the National Maritime Union was partly effective yesterday.
In an atmosphere charged with the expectancy of an Irish sweepstakes, a group of city high school students yesterday drew lots for twenty balcony seats to Broadway's biggest musical hit.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Grain futures ended irregular on fairly active dealings on the Board of Trade today.

The French budget, which at least gives hope of political and economic stability, has now won first-round parliamentary approval. The budget is by no means ideal, but time has been gained and a crisis avoided.
LONDON, Dec. 19--A wish by the late George Bernard Shaw that part of his estate be used to finance development of a phonetic alphabet is to be carried out.
DOLLARS to doughnuts, Meredith Willson dotes on brass bands.

The year-end upsurge in business borrowing at the larger New York City banks increased $182,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Arthur B. Bisguier, the defender, defeated William Lombardy, the world junior champion, in the second round of the United States championship tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.
The merged labor federation will send out formal orders today for the expulsion from state and city central bodies of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and two other orphaned unions.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 (UP) --Jim Smith, chairman of the Coliseum Commission, today proposed a formula under which the Los Angeles Dodgers would be permitted to play in the stadium rent-free for two years on a temporary basis.

LONDON, Dec. 19--The Government made it clear today that it had no intention of altering the system under which the Bank of England operates, at least until it gets a report from a tribunal investigating allegations of a bank rate leak.
PALEMBANG, Indonesia, Dec. 19--The tensions and excitement of the acts against Dutch enterprises in Jakarta are absent in this provincial capital of South Sumatra.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 19-- R. Ford Hughes, Suffolk County Republican leader, was dismissed by the county's special grand jury today without being questioned. He refused to sign a waiver of immunity.

A gift of $400 for the Neediest came yesterday from one of their regular benefactors, Cardinal Spellman Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New Yrok.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 19-- Premier David Ben-Gurion's coalition of pro-Western and neutralist parties apeared to be breaking up tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 19-- The use of armed deputy sheriffs as guards on trucks serving struck newspapers of the Westchester County Publishers, Inc., was protested today at a meeting of the Westchester Board of Supervisors.

Holiday parties for the city's sick and unfortunate continued merrily yesterday. Toys were handed out until Santa's pack was empty; but new collections were being made to fill it again for celebrations still to come.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- The United States is prepared to increase its purchases of military equipment in Europe and to finance production there of new weapons for North Atlantic Treaty members.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 20 --The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors today unanimously approved the appointment of a seven-man commission to study the need for colleges in the county.
DETROIT, Dec. 20--Temporary lay-offs affecting about 90,000 auto workers are planned during the holiday season as a result of sluggish auto sales and mounting dealer inventories.

WARSAW, Dec. 18--A leading Communist journalist asserted today that Poland's signing of the Moscow declaration of the twelve ruling Communist parties in no way affected the independence wrested from the Soviet Union in October, 1956.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 (AP) --The Coliseum Commission early tonight voted against adopting a new proposal to permit the Los Angeles Dodgers to use the stadium as a ball park.
Walter Page, widely known jazz bass player who helped Count Basie to bring hot music from the Midwest to New York in the Nineteen Thirties, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital. He was 57 years old.

LONDON, Dec. 20--Peter Thorneycroft, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today that an impending increase in the bank rate was not mentioned when he briefed newspaper men and others on anti-inflationary measures planned by the Government.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 20-- Adnan Menderes, Premier of Turkey, is under fire in the Middle East because he did not discuss Palestine in his speech at the North Atlantic Council meeting in Parish Tuesday.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 21 (UP)--Gardnar Mulloy, the 44-year-old tennis player from Miami, bounded back into the Davis Cup picture today.
LONDON, Dec. 20--The British Government's support for the rearmament of Western Europe with United States nuclear weapons survived its first major political test today.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 20 (AP)--Jim Pace will get a hero's welcome from members of his race when the Negro halfback returns to his home town for the holidays Dec. 30.

Gale Kerwin, Valley Stream (L.I.) welterweight; scored an upset victory over Jimmy Archer of the Bronx in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
Futures trading, on the New York exchanges yesterday closed generally irregular. Trading in most markets was featureless. Evening of positions prior to the Week-end accounted for most of the volume.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture today announced 1958 sugar marketing and import quotas based upon an estimate that national requirements for the year would be 8,800,000 tons.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20--The United Nations Special Committee on Hungary expressed "concern" today over reports that leaders of the 1956 anti-soviet uprising were on trial in Budapest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The National Education Association urged today a program of permanent Federal aid to education that would cost more than $1,100,000,000 in the first year and rise to $4,600,000,000 within five years.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 20 --Motorists may get picked up by radar for speeding here during the holiday period, but they will not be arrested.
PALTO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 20--The creation of an Institute of Public Enlightenment to serve as a "management consultant firm" for the American public was proposed tonight.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad announced plans yesterday for dropping 30 per cent of its long-distance passenger train service, beginning Jan. 2.
LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, Dec. 18--The Soviet Union's expedition headquarters said tonight that it planned to extend the oceanographic survey of the icebreaker Ob halfway around the Antarctic.
CAMERON, La., Dec. 20 (AP) --Christmas came to crippled Cameron today, bringing toys to the children and new pride to everyone else.

LONDON, Dec. 20--The stock market ended the week on a better note. A more optimistic interpretation of America's economic outlook checked recent selling and with continued selective buying raised prices in nearly all sections.
The murder suspect slain Thursday night in a police chase along Fifth Avenue was identified by his parents yesterday as 17-year-old Lawrence Boos.
An Army bear that apparently became nervous in the service in Berlin arrived here yesterday en route to Washington for reassignment.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- Bennett H. Griffin, an early trans-Atlantic flier, will retire on Feb. 1 as director of Washington National Airport. He has held the post for ten years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 (AP)--Both the Detroit Lions and San Francisco Forty-Niners were unhappy today about the National Football League's "sudden death" play rule should their title match in Kezar stadium Sunday be tied at the end of the fourth quarter.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 (AP)--Governor Harriman called today for strict state restrictions on food additives--chemicals to preserve food or drink or to improve flavor and color.

Between forty and fifty antiBatista Cubans tried to storm an East River pier last night to free a Cuban rebel who was being held prisoner aboard a freighter.

NEWARK, Dec. 20--Newark's urban renewal plan suffered a major setback today, The prospective sponsors of a $17,620,000 middle-income housing and commercial project announced their withdrawal because of their inability to obtain financial support from the Federal Housing Administration.

On a roof twenty-three stories above the southwest corner of Forty-second Street and Madison Avenue is a laboratory that has been testing the corrosion rate of various alloys for a quarter of a century.
"Overwhelmed" is the word John Frederick Dugan uses to describe his reaction to his selection as the first all-American in the fifty-year football history of the University of Dayton.

The National Music Council, as reported in this newspaper, is interested in efforts now being made to "tidy up" the national anthem. The Library of Congress and the Department of the Army are helping.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20 (AP)-- The Armco Steel Corporation and the National Supply Company today disclosed plans to merge. Armco, the nation's seventh largest steel producer, would be the surviving organization.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20-- The Columbia Broadcasting System has purchased the radio and television facilities and real estate of Station WCAU for $20,000,000.
Following is the text of a statement issued yesterday by the Transit Authority in behalf of Chief Thomas J. O'Rourke of the authority's police force:
The sole juror who stood out for acquittal in the Hoffa wiretap conspiracy trial explained yesterday that he believed the Government had failed to prove conspiracy.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 20-- West Germany will not "go it alone" in talks it plans to hold soon with the Soviet Union, a Government Spokesman said today.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 20--The City Commission at a special meeting today unanimously passed a local rent control law that will be in effect through 1958.

The machinery for distributing new issues of securities is grinding more slowly as the year-end holidays approach. In most bond houses there would be a complete shutdown in such activity until Jan. 7 were it not for the $245,000,000 issue to be sold next week by Public Utility District 1 of Chelan County, Wash.

A group of junior high school boys in an East Harlem neighborhood have for weeks been saving pennies, nickels and dimes. The money was to be spent for grab-bag prizes at their Christmas party yesterday. However, by a unanimous vote they decided to send the savings--$2.97--to New York's Neediest Cases.
This is to report on the restoration of plane N-90407.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Dr. Simon L. Ruskin, a New York physician and chemist, was awarded a patent this week for synthetic chocolate. The proper chemical mixtures, he says, can simulate the aroma, flavor, feel, color and nutritional values of natural chocolate.
Stocks were off on a modest but pleasant advance yesterday morning when word reached Wall Street that Chrysler would halt car assemblies for varying periods.

ALBANY, Dec. 20--Three men who attended the Apalachin, N.Y., gangland convention last month swore before the Legislature's watchdog committee toddy that their presence in Apalachin had been accidental and not by invitation.

THE bane of existence for many homemakers is pol ishing brass. And yet the reward is worth it since nothing imparts a warmer glow to holiday guests than a front door gay with Christmas garlands and bright glistening brassware.
Yesterday, the start of the last week-end before Christmas, was the busiest day of the season for airports and railroad stations here. Heavy rain added to the jams.
MOSCOW, Dec. 19--Georgi M. Malenkov appears destined to go down in Soviet history as an "anti-person."
Three gunmen escaped with $250,000 in jewels yesterday in a daylight robbery in a Queens parking lot. The thieves, all described as six feet tall, fled in a Volkswagen.

PALEMBANG, Indonesia, Dec. 20--In the commissaries that the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company runs for its 6,000 Indonesian, American and Dutch employes here certain items such as tissues, canned foods and packaged cereals have recently become virtually unsalable.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The Administration plans to ask Congress for an additional $1,000,000,000 to rush development and production of missiles and other weapons.
OTTAWA, Dec. 20--Rising unemployment dominated the proceedings in Parliament all this week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- The Consumer price, Index for the United States has resumed its climb after a one-month pause. The index reached another record in November, the Labor Department reported today.
Rain forced many pre-Christmas festivities indoors yesterday, but it failed to dampen the ardor of children who went to scores of parties in the city.

Ted Williams, the most robust 39-year-old baseball player in the history of the game, was, besides being the batting king of the American League, its slugging champion. The official figures were released yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 20 (AP)-- Louisville turned back Army, 66--61, tonight in the first round of the Blue Grass Festival basketball tournament before a crowd of 8,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 20 --"The Man in the Net," a mystery novel published last year by Simon Schuster, has been acquired for filming by the Mirisch Company. It was written by Hugh Wheeler and Richard Webb under the psuedonym of Patrick Quentin.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 20-- Supreme Court Justice Frank H. Coyne ruled tonight that a cr che depicting the birth of Christ may be placed on the lawn of the Ossining High School for the yuletide season.
The fumes given off by the country's Diesel buses have long been a problem to the transit companies as well as pedestrians.
A threatened strike on the Long Island Rail Road appeared to have been headed off yesterday before it started.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 20 (AP) --North Carolina, paced by Pete Brennan and Lee Shaffer, survived numerous Minnesota threats tonight to gain a 73--67 basketball victory in the opener of the University of Kentucky invitation tournament.

New York could do more to lower borrowing costs for school construction by setting up a state marketing authority than by putting the full faith of the state behind bonds of local issue, the Governor's Committee on Marketing School Bonds said yesterday.
MADRID, Dec. 20--Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Generalissimo Francisco Franco conferred here for two hours and fifteen minutes today.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, B.W.I., Dec. 20--The framework of a new Western Hemisphere nation will be dedicated here within two weeks. But in this city, which will be the national capital, there is not much enthusiasm for it.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP)-- Paced by new crop wheat, grain futures ended mostly lower on the Board of Trade today.
Vessels of the Moore-McCormack Lines returned to normal operations last night after the issuance of a Federal Court order barring picketing by the National Maritime Union.
New Yorkers were called upon yesterday by the city's Protestant Council to take "a mature approach" to Christmas.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 20 (AP)--Pennsylvania, citing its l63-year-old law against Sunday business, moved today to force a large retail discount chain out of the state.

LAST night's du Pont monthly attraction, "Junior Miss," was billed as a musical production derived from the Sally Benson, stories. The program hardly so qualified because there was only one fleeting number of consequence. As a play, the acting generally was not much more than routine.
An angry Mayor Wagner moved swiftly yesterday to avert a New Year's Day subway strike--and to smash one if it took place.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Republicans got some good farm news today after a week of politically explosive developments.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 20 --Appeals were made to the Government today to act to avert a rice famine.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20-- St. Asaph's Protestant Episcopal Church, Bala-Cynwyd, was the setting this afternoon for the wedding of Miss Helen Lyons Clothier to William Farnham Hoffman.
Gerard Kantarjian, violinist displayed a dual personality at his Town Hall recital last night.
MOSCOW, Dec. 20--The leader of the Soviet Union's scientific community warned today it would be "most harmful" to overestimate Soviet scientific achievements.
Robert Goldsand gave a piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall. He was in good form, his program was cannily selected, and it was an evening of sound, dependable and often exciting piano playing.
Law schools have been warned against eagerly assuming and executing "any and all research projects."

COCOA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP)--The Air Force disclosed tonight further plans to tighten security restrictions around the area where America's big missiles are launched and to prevent close-up photographs.
The twenty-second annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball last night, held in a pink and silver setting, was a delicate confection for 109 young women to savor and remember.

MADISON, N.J., Dec. 20-- Grenville T. Anderson of 58 Prospect Street, a circuit-design engineer at the Bell Telephone Laboratories in Murray Hill, near Summit, died of a heart attack yesterday near his office. His age was 61.

The New York State Banking and Insurance Departments completed public hearings here yesterday on proposals to bring under state supervision pension funds administered exclusively by employers or by labor unions.
A production model of the Boeing 707, this nation's first commercial jet airliner, made its first test flight yesterday. The pilot termed it a success.
PARIS, Dec. 20--In the vertiginous Himalayan summits there is rumored to exist a creature known as the Yeti, or Abominable Snow Man. All that has ever been found of him are footprints.
Rain-laden winds lashed New York last night, soaking package-burdened Christmas shoppers and slowing traffic.
The Atlantic alliance conference that ended Thursday was another proof of the adage that actions speak louder than words.

Directors of the Callahan Zinc-Lead Company and the Vulcan Silver-Lead Corporation have appointed committees to study the advisability, of merging, Joseph Hall Callahan, president announced yesterday.

Fordham University's radio station has applied to the Federal Communications Commission for permission to use a new technique that would enable it to broadcast two programs at one time.

An announcement more welcome than a Christmas bonus was made to employes of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company yesterday. Instead of moving out of the state, as had been planned, the company said part of its plant would be moved to a site on Long Island and the rest would remain in Brooklyn.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 20 (AP)-- A strike by sixty-four mailers kept The Dayton Daily News from publishing today. It also prevented the company's morning paper, The Journal Herald, from publishing its Saturday editions. Members of some craft unions declined to cross picket lines.

SEATTLE, Dec. 20 (AP)--Jack Regas became the first man to crack the 200-mile-per-hour water barrier in a propeller-driven boat when he piloted the Hawaii Kai III in a speed test here Nov. 29, a timer, Andy Joy, said today.
FOR its Christmas group show of contemporary American painting and sculpture, the Leo Castelli Gallery, 4 East Seventy-seventh Street, has adopted the novel idea of making it a collectors' choice.
Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries yesterday reported consolidated net income for the three months ended Oct. 31 at $9,606,219, after taxes and all charges.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 20 (AP)--An Ohio buckeye tree against an Oregon fir tree is the wager between the Governors of the two states on the outcome of the Rose Bowl football game Jan. 1.
