NEW HAVEN, Dec. 25--The Yale University Library opened today an exhibition commemorating the 100th anniversary of the birth of Joseph Conrad, the author.
After an interval of two days, play will be resumed tonight in the United States championship chess tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club.
SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Dec. 15 --Robert Henry Gittins, a retired New York corporation lawyer who had served in Congress and the State Senate, died today in Tuxedo Memorial Hospital. He was 87 years old.
DETROIT, Dec. 25 (AP)--There is a lot of optimism around the offices of American Motors Corporation.

The National Broadcasting Company radio network will avoid international headaches New Year's Eve, but will do a round-up that has the makings of an international hang-over.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 25 (UP) --Ed Conlin missed a shot that would have won in regulation time, but netted 6 points in an overtime period tonight to give a 134-130 victory to the Syracuse Nationals over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

Outstanding loans to business of the large New York City banks dropped $70,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, as wholesalers and retailers and food, liquor and tobacco companies made substantial repayments on seasonal borrowings.

Carter L. Burgess has resigned as president and a director of Trans World Airlines, Inc., effective Jan. 1, because of a "disagreement over airline policies." T.W.A. is the nation's fourth largest airline.

TOKYO, Dec. 26 (UP)--A Chinese Communist official has reported the spread of "dangerous" nationalism in Sinkiang, the strategic border province linking China with Asian Russia, the Peiping radio said today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 26--The Soviet Union has intensified its campaign to attract the sympathies and cooperation of nations in Asia and Africa.
VENTURA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP)--Pfc. Ted Julian Jr. got home for Christmas, he said today, because a Nevada man went out of his way--by something like 1,500 miles.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26-- Directors of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania approved today the issuance of $50,000,000 of debentures, subject to the necessary regulatory approvals.
The Better Business Bureau of New York City, Inc., added two vice presidents to its roster yesterday. They are George L. Fichtenbaum and Arthur Startz.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26-- Mouse genetics, which has been growing in scientific stature since 1900, is likely to decline for a lack of mouse geneticists.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26-- Robert H. Brigham, an authority on probate law, died yesterday at his home in suburban Villanova. He was 58 years old.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 26-While Canada's economy is strong, there is little evidence of forces "which would quickly generate new strength" in exports or investment, Gordon Churchill, Minister of Trade and Commerce, said today in a survey of 1957 and a forecast for 1958.
AURORA, Ill., Dec. 26 (AP)-- A tour of Stateville prison was ordered today for seven boys, 12 to 16 years old. The police said the youngsters had been looting homes here.

WEST NEWTON, Mass., Dec. 26--Mr. and Mrs. Frank Barry Maher of West Newton, formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Denise Carroll Maher, to John Richard Dunne. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Dunne of Garden City, L. I.

POMONA, Calif., Dec. 26 (UP) --Top 2-year-olds from the estate of the late Louis B. Mayer will be among fifty-nine head of breeding and racing stock to be sold at the Los Angeles County Fairgrounds on Jan. 6.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 26-- William E. Selby Sr., vice president in charge of the trust department of the Federal Trust Company in Newark and for more than thirty-five years Mayor of Allenhurst, died today in St. Barnabas Hospital, Newark, after an operation. He was 72 years old.
SHIRLEY BOOTH, whom everyone loves, is appearing in another play that it is difficult to like--"Miss Isobel," which opened at the. Royale last evening.

TOKYO, Dec. 28 (Reuters)-- The Soya, the Japanese Antarctic Expedition's 2,700-ton ice-breaker, is trapped in pack ice in the Indian Ocean off the Prince Harald Coast of the Antarctic continent, the expedition headauarters said here today.
The Aro Equipment Corporation, Bryan, Ohio, announced yesterday the election of E.L. Jackson and F.A. Stockwell as vice presidents. Mr. Jackson is manager of the industrial division.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 26-- The New York State Council of Churches has announced receipt of a grant of $10,000 to produce a film on its activities.
ALBANY, Dec. 26--Sometime this week 1,000 persons sat down at their typewriters or filled up their pens to write to one man.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) --Everett D. Green, 67-year-old rooming house operator, was freed today after a court fight of four and a half years during which he was convicted twice of murder and once of arson.
Prisoners at the Penitentiary of the City of New York on Rikers Island gave 165 pints of blood yesterday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) The Labor Department said today fewer workers had been made idle and less time had been lost because of strikes in 1957 than in any other postwar year.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 26 --The Industrial Science Achievement Award of the American Association for the Advancement of Science was presented here last night to the P.R. Mallory Co., for a new technique in powder metallurgy.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 26 (AP)--The adjoining city of Allentown opened its water lines today to the residents of Bethlehem, plagued for the last week by muddy drinking water.

MAHWAH, N.J., Dec. 26-- The Mayor and the Township Engineer submitted their resignations tonight to a meeting of the Town Council. The resignation of Mayor Thomas J. Ackerson was accepted "with regrets;" that of Frank E. Harley, the engineer, was "filed for later consideration."

CHICAGO, Dec. 26--Dr. Herbert L. Anderson, a physicist who helped to develop the atomic bomb, was named director today of the Enrico Fermi Institute for Nuclear Studies at the University of Chicago. Dr. Anderson, 43 years old, succeeds Dr. Samuel K. Allison, who resigned as director to devote more time to research.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) --High-tariff advocates opened a campaign today against President Eisenhower's request for a five-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Program, which will expire June 30.
HONOLULU, Dec. 26 (UP)-- A destroyer and two helicopters searched the Pacific off northern Oahu today for seventeen missing navy airmen, but little hope was held for success.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 26 (AP)--Niagara led by Alex Ellis, who scored 38 points, upset Western Kentucky with a 77-74 overtime victory in the first round of the all-college basketball tournament today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP)-- Frank Leahy entered Passavant Hospital tonight, 99 per cent willing to take the Texas A. and M. football coaching job but trying to get medical approval for the other 1 per cent.

HONG KONG, Dec. 26 (AP)-- A sudden typhoon overturned 900 fishing boats in the East China Sea Dec. 12, the Hsinhua (New China) news agency said today. The loss of life was believed heavy, but Communist officials followed their usual policy of refusing to give details of fatalities.

Samuel Reshevsky, international chess master, gained his third consecutive victory last night when play was resumed in the United States chess championship tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald trophy.

The election of Dominic S. Lepore as vice president of manufacturing of McGregorDoniger, Inc., has been announced by William N. Doniger, president. The company is a leading manufacturer of men's and boys' sportswear. Mr. Lepore was formerly in charge of the shirt division.

RICHMOND, Ind., Dec. 26 (UP)--A father relented at the last minute tonight and gave permission to physicians to perform an emergency appendectomy on his 11-year-old daughter. She was rushed to a hospital.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that Police Department officials had assured him "it is not their, policy" to use hidden microphones and that "they will adhere to this policy."

The wooden deck scow Steers No. 74, the last of a string of six gravel-laden barges being towed down the East River, capsized yesterday afternoon near Seventy-second Street. Ernest Johnson, barge captain, was removed safely to another barge in the tow.
Boston College, which traditionally regards hockey as its major winter sport, suddenly has become acutely conscious of basketball.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Dec. 26 (Reuters)--Charles Pathe, French movie pioneer, died here yesterday on the eve of his ninety-fourth birthday.
HOUSTON, Dec. 26 (AP)-- Texas Tech extended its undefeated streak to seven games today while making its debut as a Southwest Conference member by defeating Southern Methodist, 72--70, in overtime.
To retain the fine glossy appearance of marble surfaces, the following advice is offered by Miss Gena Thames of the extension service of Rutgers University.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 26 (AP)--President Carlos Ibanez del Campo, who is 80 years old, has recovered from a brief illness, officially described as a stomach upset, and was back at work today in the Government palace.

Bernard Gordon, realty operator, has resold his contract for the purchase of the apartment house for sixty-five families at 55 Sheridan Avenue, Mount Vernon, in Westchester County. The property is 200 by 240 feet and was sold subject to mortgages amounting to $352,000. The Wishnow Horowitz Real Estate Company was the broker.
Gerald Sarracini, 30-year-old romantic lead of the Broadway comedy "Romanoff and Juliet," died yesterday morning in Roosevelt Hospital of head injuries he received in a fight early on Christmas Day.
CLINTON, N. Y., Dec. 26 (AP) --The Clinton Comets outskated New Haven, 5--3, in an East ern Hockey League game tonight.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics decreased to 84.7 on Tuesday, from the revised figure of 84.8 on Monday. The figure for Dec. 26, 1956 was 92.6.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 26(AP) Nationalist Chinese warships sank three out of four Communist gunboats in a ten-minute engagement off the Red China coast today, Navy headquarters reported. It said the action had started off Tsinkiang Bay, forty-five miles north of Quemoy.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 26 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Cecil A. Daley of Bronxville and Cutchogue, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Elizabeth Daley, to Frederic DeGraw Schuh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick. C. Schuh of Teaneck, N. J.

Stockholders in the Bergen Trust Company of Jersey City have approved a change in the par value of shares from $25 to $5 to provide for a five-for-one split, and the payment of a 50 per cent stock divident. The move increases capital from $200,000 to $300,000.
MOSCOW, Dec. 26--The Soviet Union vaguely described today successful tests of a to type for mechanisms that eventually would permit the vertical take-off and landing of large planes.

A syndicate managed by First Boston Corporation and Kidder, Peabody Co. yesterday announced that it would offer on or about Jan. 8 $50,000,000 of Commercial Credit Company twenty-year senior notes. The securities will mature Jan. 1, 1978, and will not be redeemable before 1963.

The Flatbush Savings Bank has announced the election of Crawford Young as president. He succeeds John S. Roberts, who was named chairman. Mr. Young joined the bank in 1922 and was elected executive vice president and a trustee in 1941. He is a director of the Flatbush Chamber of Commerce.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hirshon of New York and Glen Cove, L. I., gave a supper dance in the River Club last evening to present Mrs. Hirshon's laughter, Miss Hilary Paley, and Mr. Hirshon's niece, Miss Evelyn Hirshon.

The Southern Pacific Company experienced a $3,252,362 drop in gross revenues last month to $52,019,843, but reported a gain in earnings of $519,261 above the 1956 level. Net income was $3,869,944, up from $3,350,683 in November, 1956.
PARIS, Friday, Dec. 27 (AP)-- Two days of heavy snow and rain have caused damage in wide areas of south and central France. A snowstorm paralyzed transportation in the Auvergne region.

Seven members of the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission met for two hours yesterday in executive session.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 26 (AP) --Wilt Chamberlain score 41 points and hogged the rebounds as Kansas defeated Oklahoma, 68--50, in the opening game of the Big Eight Conference basketball tournament tonight.

THE lull between Christmas and New Year's can be an exasperating one for the family cook who is trying to tempt holiday-jaded palates. Because of the predominance of such seasonal specialties as turkey, capon, goose, duck, roast suckling pig or ham, ordinary fare like hamburger appears uninviting.

BILOXI, Miss., Dec. 26 (AP)-- The forty-four-man Texas football team arrived today for final workouts for its Sugar Bowl football game against Mississippi next Wednesday. Optimism prevailed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with the result that almost $1,900,000,000 was added to market values. It was the largest gain in a week.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 26 (UP) --Llangollen's Nashville today raced to a length and a quarter victory in the $23,350 Palos Verdes Handicap at the opening of Santa Anita Park's fiftyfive-day meeting.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Dec. 26--A heroic woman and two of her granddaughters died today after a fire swept a four-story tenement at 51 Forty-seventh Street here early this morning. The police said that nine others were injured.

Sidney Kingsley, holder of the Pulitzer Pize as well as the award from the Critics Circle, is writing a drama, the working title of which is "Ghost Dance." He promised yesterday that it would be ready for rehearsals in September or October.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), Dec. 26 (UP)--The United Nations Mixed Armistice Commission announced today it was investigating a Syrian complaint that Israelis fired at a Syrian border post yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) --President Eisenhower, Vice President Richard M. Nixon and six Cabinet members will initiate the Republican party's 1958 Congressional election campaign Jan. 20 at fund-raising dinners.

A NEW clock with four dials took over the task last night of measuring time in the Marble Collegiate Church tower at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street. The old one had stayed faithful for, roughly, 100 years. It started to run down about two years ago, when the church was 101 years old.

The Simmons Company, world's largest producer of mattresses and other sleep equipment, will introduce next month an "orthopedic" mattress, Grant G. Simmons Jr., president announced yesterday. He said it was developed with the aid of leading orthopedic surgeons.
Dr. Donald A. Covalt and Dr. Claude Edwin Heaton have been appointed professors at New York University College of Medicine.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) --London's Tottenham Hotspurs today shut out Wolverhampton, 1--0, to snap the Wanderers' eighteen-game streak without a defeat in English League soccer.

ATHENS, Dec. 26--Four young Cypriotes are reported to be held for questioning in connection with explosions here Dec. 13. One of the blasts, caused by a time bomb, severely damaged the United States Information Service Library, and the others affected United States Air Force installations.

The Textile Machine Works of Reading, Pa., yesterday announced that Louis R. Thun had been named chairman. He was formerly executive vice president and treasurer. El Roy P. Master, formerly secretary, was elected president. Frank B. Hower was named secretary and Robert J. Ryan treasurer.

TORONTO, Dec. 26 (UP)-- Approaches to a $150,000 bridge were built backward because an expert hired as a consultant got his directions confused, W. A. Clarke, chief engineer of the Ontario Highways Department, said today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Dec. 27(AP)--Australia swept to its third straight Davis Cup victory and its seventh over the United States in the challenge round in the past eight years when Mal Anderson and Mervyn Rose scored a 6-4, 6-4, 8-6 doubles triumph over Vic Seixas and Barry MacKay today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 (AP) --Dick Gray signed his 1958 contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers today. The infielder from Jefferson, Pa., hit .297 in 153 games for St. Paul in the Class AAA American Association last season. He led the league in runs batted in with 111.

Thornton Wilder revealed yesterday that the opera he had been working on emanates from a play of his authorship called "The Alcestiad." In an interview in May, 1955, the recipient of three Pulitzer Prizes said that the libretto would deal with a contemporary American theme.

Daniel J. Ferris said yesterday that the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States had not been "too successful" in obtaining acceptances from foreign athletes to compete in indoor track and field meets in this country this winter.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday directed that Paul Schmittman be removed as superintendent of highways in Putnam Valley, N.Y., even though his term expires today at midnight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Individuals' net savings rose by $4,900,000,000 in the third quarter of this year. This was substantially above the gains for the previous quarters of 1957 and the third quarter of last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

A threatened strike by the Transport Workers Union against the city-owned transit system has been avoided. In a sense, reason has prevailed. But the greater credit for a settlement must go to the offer of a good, stiff wage increase by the Transit Authority.
Louis Minsky of 115-25 Metropolitan Avenue, Kew Gardens, Queens, managing editor of Religious News Service, died yesterday at his home of a heart attack. His age was 48.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) --The Senate Small Business Committee today said the Defense Department again showed "lethargy, inaction and procrastiation" last year in programs designed to aid small contractors.
The New York Times repudiated yesterday an attack made by Michael J. Quill of the Transport Workers Union against A.H. Raskin, labor reporter for the newspaper.

"The Bridge on, the River Kwai" yesterday carried off a majority of the awards in the twenty-third annual balloting conducted by The New York Film Critics.
Tax-loss selling dominated an exceedingly active market yesterday. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 3,750,000 shares--the highest since Oct. 24--compared with 2,620,000 on Friday.

Hosts of bemused children and deluded grown-ups are swallowing a depressing lot of nonsense.

Edwin Seymour-Bell, general manager in this country for the Cunard Line, has announced the appointment of Elven S. Sheahan as assistant manager and the promotion of John S. Quinn to the newly created position of deputy general passenger manager. Both men take up their new duties today.

Ernest Shackleton (1874-1922), the English explorer, spent the last twenty-two years of his life investigating the great unknown region of Antarctica. A biography of him is planned for publication next year by Houghton Mifflin entitled "Shackleton and The Ant-Arctic."
A State Supreme Court justice yesterday permanently enjoined a union from taking reprisals against 2,800 members who did not support a 1956 strike.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 31 -- Foreign Minister Samir el-Rifai said today that Jordan would need an average of $50,000,000 a year in United States aid for the next five to ten years to help finance her economy and armed forces.

Contract negotiations between two major networks and the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians will begin Monday in Boston. The New England city was selected as a "neutral' site for the bargaining sessions, which may continue for several weeks.

But neither has been true of Harold Arnoldus SStevens, who yesterday became the first of his race to be named an associate justice of the Appellate Divi sion of the State Supreme Court.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 31 -- President Theodor Heuss urged tonight a return to diplomatic channels in dealing with the Soviet Union.

Supreme Court Justice Harold A. Stevens was formally inducted yesterday as an associate justice of the Appellate Division, First Department. He is the first Negro in the state to hold such a high judicial office.

For his second week with the New York Philharmonic, on Jan. 9 through 12, Leonard Bernstein has programed the first performance here of Alexei Haieff's "Ballet in E." Also listed are first Philharmonic performances of David Diamond's Symphony No. 4 and Teo Macero's "Fusion."
WASHINGTON, Dec 31 (AP) -- The Army claimed today new helicopter altitude records.

The Tennessee Valley Authority ended its twenty-fourth fiscal year with more than half its output going to the Atomic Energy Commission and other Federal Government defense agencies; with more than two-thirds of that output being developed in steam instead of waterpower plants; and with a total installed capacity of about ten million kilowatts, or about 8 or 9 per cent of the national total. T. V.

Robert F. Wagner was sworn in for a new four-year term as New York's 102d Mayor last night at Gracie Mansion. Judge Adrian P. Burke of the Court of Appeals administered the oath in the presence of the Mayor's family and many friends.
Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack said yesterday that a prime objective of his second term in office would be the widening of all crosstown streets from Twenty-third to Fifty-ninth Street.
The Mayfair Assembly, held at the Ambassador last night, honored twenty-four of this season's debutantes. The eighteenth annual dinner dance was arranged by Miss Clementine Miller.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 31 -- The accepted dates and sequence of events in the last week of Christ's life on earth and his crucifixion were brought under questioning today by scholars of the Society of Biblical Literature and Exegesis.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Mr. Donmar closed strongly from fifth position on the backstretch to annex the featured seventh race today at Tropical Park.
The Rev. Dr. Edwin T. Dahlberg, president of the National Council of Churches, warned yesterday against retrenchment in religious services for the armed forces.

Having had many years of experience in the public utility labor-management field, may I be permitted to suggest that the repressive and political approach to the solution of our transit labor problems makes no sense at all.

Sales of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company for 1957 may be off about 10 per cent from 1956, but they will be about five per cent above the average for the last five years, John D. Biggers, chairman, and George P. MacNichol Jr., president, said yesterday.
The General Services Administration has leased 80 per cent of the ground floor and all of the mezzanine floor in the former Wanamaker store building at 770 Broadway, between Eighth and Ninth Street.
PARIS, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- New Year's Day marks a historic date in Europe -- the official birth of the six-nation European Economic Community and the European Atomic Energy Community.

Fluctuations of the New York Stock Exchange may be said to express the hopes and fears of the people who trade in securities. I have traded continuously and actively on the New York Stock Exchange for forty-nine years. Thinking back over these years,
CAIRO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The United States, Britain and France were pictured as villains today in repeated denunciations of "imperialism" at the Asian-African Peoples Solidarity Conference.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Governor Harriman agreed today to meet with the Governors of New Jersey and Connecticut to discuss New York's nonresident income tax.

ONE hundred twenty-five million wall calendars printed in the United States will have been distributed by this morning to count the days in 1958. They will include farm calendars with rural scenes, calendars of the different religious faiths with pictures from Scripture, Boy Scout and safety prints, and calendars that glorify the American girl.

Universal Pictures Company has entered into an agreement with Hearst Metrotone News, effective today, under which the Universal - International Newsreel will utilize Hearst's worldwide news-gathering facilities, according to a company announcement.

CAIRO, Dec. 31 -- Neutral Asian diplomatic sources said today that Egypt and the Soviet bloc had achieved their separate but parallel aims at the nongovernmental conference of Africans and Asians here.

The election of Michael Rapuano as the fifth president of the American Academy in Rome was announced yesterday. Mr. Rapuano is a partner in the firm of Clarke Rapuano, consulting engineers and landscape architects here. He will assume office today, succeeding James Kellum Smith, a New York architect.

EL PASO, Tex., Dec. 31 (AP) -- United States District Judge R. E. Thomason today dismissed the Government's case against Clinton E. Jencks, former union official once convicted of filing a false non-Communist affidavit with the National Labor Relations Board.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Adlai E. Stevenson declared today that the United States must emphasize its "basic peaceful purpose."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 30 -- Indonesia's bid to buy arms from the United States gives new urgency to the question of Washington's policy toward this troubled island republic.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -- Mike Wallace, leading exponent of the catch-as-catch-can school of television interviewing, is preparing to expand his activities with a filmed dramatic series.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (UP) -- The Mississippi Rebels flew in today for the Sugar Bowl game and Coach Johnny Vaught said they would go right back to the air when they meet Texas tomorrow before 80,000.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- Bus service between Stamford, Conn., and New Rochelle, N. Y., came under new management tonight. But the bus service ended on eight shortlines that had linked the mainline to railroad stations and business centers in various communities.

The Transit Authority -- relieved of the threat of a New Year's Day subway and bus strike -- began yesterday to consider ways of maintaining the 15-cent fare. Two conclusions were speedily reached. First, the present fare is safe for 1958.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -Senator James E. Murray, Democrat of Montana, reported today that the Soviet Union and Red China were outstripping the United States "in the vital area of river development."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- The United Nations Children's Fund, said today in a year-end report that it extended its welfare work in 1957 to assist a total of 45,000,000 children and mothers. This was 50 per cent more than the number assisted in 1956.

The response to the appeal for the Neediest is keeping close to the pace of the last two Christmas seasons as the New Year begins. There have been more than 10,000 donations amounting to nearly $400,000.
BAYONNE, N. J., Dec. 31 -- More than 800 workers at the Esso Standard Oil Company refinery -- 50 per cent of its working force -- will be laid off Jan. 17.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Postal officials are considering rejecting all the candidates for Postmaster of New York, leaving the vacancy temporarily unfilled.

Robert E. Gross, chairman of Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, said yesterday that missiles accounted for 8 per cent of the company's record total of more than $900,000,000 in sales for 1957. He predicted that the proportion would rise to 20 per cent this year, al-through over-all sales would drop to about $750,000,000.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 31 -- President Eisenhower closed out formal 1957 business shortly after noon today. He and Mrs. Eisenhower devoted the remainder of the day to a granddaughter's birthday party and an informal New Year's Eve dinner at their farm.

Net income of Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries declined 30.5 per cent in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 from the year before. Sales were off 2.9 per cent, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Proposals to permit the dissolution of mutual savings banks and the purchase of their assets by commercial banks have been withdrawn from the agenda of a joint legislative committee studying revision of the New York State Banking Law.

FIVE or six years ago Eugene Ormandy began giving to Philadelphia a special type of program on or around New Year's Eve. Taking his cue from Vienna, he made it a Viennese program. Philadelphia responded enthusiastically, and last night he and the Philadelphia Orchestra brought the program to New York to see how this city would respond.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The stock market closed firm today although business volume remained small and the demand for industrial shares continued selective.

In honor of the Princess Franz Josef of Liechtenstein, who will be guest of honor at the third annual Imperial Ball, a pageant of Imperial Favorites will be presented instead of a bal de tete, as had been planned originally.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A special advisory committee recommended to President Eisenhower today an expanded and vigorous Government research program into how to control or modify the world's weather.
EL PASO, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Louisville was rated a 3-to-7-point favorite over Drake as both teams staged their final workouts today for tomorrow's Sun Bowl game here.
Price changes of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were irregular yesterday. The close was 14 points higher to 6 points lower that on Monday.

Through the painstaking reporting of The New York Times we learn another person has been killed, this time an 11-year-old boy, by a nighttime hit-run driver who could not be identified because his license plate was not lighted.
Greetings ranging from raucous celebration to quiet prayer were extended throughout the world last night to the new year.
HAVANA, Dec. 31 (AP) -- President Fulgencio Batista promised today freedom for Opposition political parties and urged Cubans to settle their political differences in the general elections June 1.

The collapse of a retaining wall between Wadsworth Avenue and Wadsworth Terrace is a consequence of past mistakes in the laying out of streets and poor zoning laws. Fort George not only abounds in unusually high retaining walls, dangerous in themselves and also shutting out light from abutting apartments, but also has the steepest streets in the city.

Joseph L. Ennis Co., realty operators, have resold the four-story vacant dwelling at 232 East Seventy - second Street that they bought a month ago. The property is 18 by 102 feet and is assessed at $48,000. The buyer was a client of John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker in the deal.

MIAMI, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Ralph Lowe's Gallant Man, one of the top 3-year-olds of 1957, is responding "remarkably well" to treatment for an infected forefoot, Johnny Nerud, his trainer, reported today. Nerud thus scotched rumors that Gallant Man would be retired.

IT has been pretty well established that hunters and fishermen make more New Year's resolutions than anybody. The Outdoor Sports Division of the Institute for Advanced Trendular Studies (est. 1957) has determined that a fisherman or hunter is one and five-eighths times more likely to resolve than a bowler who owns his own ball.

The all-night bargaining session at City Hall that prevented a threatened strike against the city-owned transit system also delivered an extremely generous pay rise to labor. The Transport Workers Union, led by Michael J. Quill, walked out into the dawn with a bundle that means 32 1/2 cents an hour in increased wages and benefits over a two-year contract period. Small wonder that Mr. Quill said he was "satisfied."
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 31 -Iranian official circles were jubilant today at the news that Secretary of State Dulles would visit Iran en route to the Baghdad Pact meeting in Ankara, Turkey, in January.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 30 -The director of the United States aid mission said today that while Iran would eventually be capable of standing on her own feet financially, technical aid would be needed for some time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Fewer than 5 per cent of the scientists and other skilled persons permitted to enter this country annually under special immigration provisions actually came in as immigrants during 1957.

Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the national open champion, yesterday held Samuel Reshevsky, international grand master, to a draw in their adjourned game from the third round of the United States championship for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations president, George Meany, said today America's main job in the new year was to strengthen her defenses. "American workers are prepared to shoulder their just share of that cost," he said.
A 35 - year - old British peer, whose songwriting activities and jazz playing in smart cafes have more than once raised eyebrows in the House of Lords, has agreed to appear in a Broadway play.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Dec. 31 -- The Luzerne County Board of Assessors rejected today a request of the Glen Alden Corporation, a leading anthracite producer, for a cut of $16,000,000 in valuation of its coal properties.

Thoroughgoing court reorganization is a New Year's resolution that should be solemnly taken by the people of this state. This goes especially for those who represent us in the Legislature. Their dereliction in refusing to act on court reform last spring makes their action this year an overriding obligation.
A hearing on one phase of an antitrust suit brought by the National Hockey League Players Association against hockey club operators and others was adjourned yesterday until Feb. 18.
Trans World Airlines and Northwest Orient Airlines will link their routes today to provide around-the-world air service.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 31 -- President Eisenhower gave tentative approval today to a record peacetime budget.

Harold Callender, for thirteen years chief of the Paris bureau of The New York Times, will take over his new post today as The Times' European economic correspondent. Robert C. Doty, a member of the bureau staff, will assume the duties of Paris bureau chief.

Representative Ludwig Teller characterized the Eisenhower Administration's educational program yesterday as "a tangential and niggardly approach to an enormous problem that affects our national security."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, today asked the Justice Department and Federal Communications Commission to investigate the "dictatorial and arbitrary" decision that kept Detroit television viewers from watching the Lion-Cleveland Browns game for the National Football League championship Sunday.
MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Plans to open four new Air Force finance offices to serve contractors in heavily industrialized areas were announced today by officials of the Mobile Air Materiel area.

ROME, Dec. 31 -- Italian communism ordered its intellectuals today to study "Anglo-Saxon culture" so they could fight it better. They were warned, however, not to fall victim to the lures of Western philosophy, literature and art.
MIDWAY through 1957 there was a tremendous hubbub made about a new look in fashion; this was the chemise, or relaxed silhouette.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Nine officers of the Nicaraguan National Guard were convicted today by a court-martial on charges of plotting to overthrow President Luis A. Somoza and establish a military junta.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Atomic scientists and animal lovers, lawyers and a lighthouse keeper, poets, politicians and a prize-fighter are among the 2,200 persons on Queen Elizabeth's New Year honor list. It will be published tomorrow.
AUSTIN, Minn., Dec. 31 (UP) -- Eleven high school boys and a Roman Catholic nun finally managed to fire their rocket today, but with an artificial mouse.

Bobby Joe Morrow, who claimed there was "no accounting for my speed" and who then went on to take three sprint gold medals in the 1956 Olympic Games, won the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy yesterday as the outstanding amateur athlete of 1957.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved agreements today under which railroads in the West and South will get about $12,300,000 a year in additional Government payments for carrying mail.

TRENTON, Dec. 31 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared today that White House plans to aid education might induce New Jersey to revise upward the $82,550,000 expansion program recently demanded by the State Board of Education.

VIENNA, Dec. 31 -- The Czechoslovak Government has establish a commission to censor its press. It also has charged a dismissed minister who advocated a hard line with the task of censoring scientific and philosophic literature.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 31 -- President Tito called this evening for a fresh start toward disarmament through "a broad meeting at the highest level."
TOKYO, Dec. 31 -- Japan and Korea signed today an agreement on the release of each other's imprisoned nationals and prepared the way for other negotiations.
In one of a series of silver loan repayments by Pakistan, a shipment of 15,519,360 fine ounces of the metal has arrived here aboard the Isbrandtsen Company cargo liner Flying Cloud.

Factory volume of the electronics industry last year reached a record total of more than $7,000,000,000, according to Dr. W. R. G. Baker, president of the Electronic Industries Association. This was a substantial gain above 1956 sales of $5,900,000,000.
HAVANA, Dec. 31 -- Six bombs exploded late today in Havana as the public prepared to celebrate New Year's Eve.

New financing in December declined sharply below the November level. Public offerings of new bonds here dropped to the lowest level of the year, and stock flotations were the smallest for any month since February, 1951.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 31 -- A sentence of death has been passed on a 35-year-old "holy man" who captured the minds and faith of a north Indian village and carried it to murder and destruction.
Nevada, a town in Central Iowa, produces a good deal more than the corn for which the area is noted. It is also the world's direct-mail advertising capital.
West Virginia, idle since Dec. 21, still is the No. 1 college basketball team in The Associated Press poll, but the list of the first twenty is expected to be shuffled next week.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 31 -- Kent Fitzgerald, president and general manager of the Illinois Transit Company, was found dead of a gunshot wound in the basement of his home here today. He was 58 years of age.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 31 -- According to unofficial reports, the first oil from the Sahara is on its way north to light the lamps of France and fuel her industries.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Premier Willem Drees, in a New Year's Eve broadcast today, told Dutch citizens fleeing from Indonesia that a warm welcome awaited them in the Netherlands.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board confirmed today that airplanes were safer than automobiles.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 31 -- Six of Suffolk's ten townships will start 1958 with structural changes in government designed to meet the needs of booming population growth.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -Taxpayers had better start tomorrow to keep closer tab on how much they get from their bosses in expense - account money.
Michael J. Quill repeated before a television audience last night his charges of a "press conspiracy" against the Transport Workers Union.

Selling to establish losses for income tax purposes met buying by bargain hunters in a turbulent session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The result was a market turnover of 5,073,730 shares, the heaviest for any Dec. 31 since The New York Times began to keep such records in 1911.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The British Government rejects as too risky proposals for a meeting of the heads of governments of the Soviet Union and the leading Western powers.

NASHVILLE, Dec. 31 -- Jack Norman Sr., Nashville attorney who long has specialized in criminal law, was appointed today special state attorney to direct the investigation of Criminal Court Judge Raulston Schoolfield of Chattanooga.
WARSAW, Dec. 31 -- Poland is again under heavy attack within the Communist bloc.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31 -- The Soviet Union ended the year 1957 today with a glowing review of its scientific achievements.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 31 -- Mexico is finishing the year with food reserves of more than 1,000,000 tons. This was announced by Julian Rodriguez Adame, director of the Compania Exportadora y Importadora Mexicana, the governmental farm products sales and purchasing agency.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- A cluster of privately financed wildlife preserves in this region of Westchester County and adjacent Connecticut will be increased tomorrow when the new Westmoreland Sanctuary is opened.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Dec. 31 -- A 10-year-old school boy who wrote Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff that he had "helped to build" the $464,000,000 Connecticut Turnpike will attend the highway's opening Thursday as the Governor's guest.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Senator Charles E. Potter said today a toll-free St. Lawrence Seaway would constitute a "breach of faith" although he would prefer it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The National Society of Professional Engineers criticized today the Eisenhower Administration program to promote the education of more scientists and engineers. The society said it would put a crushing burden on the nation's colleges.

WHAT'S ahead in 1958 for the family? Shades of sputniks all around us, will life be so different in the days to come? Only time and vital statistics will tell whether the recent trend toward larger families will continue.

CANNOBIO, Italy, Dec. 31 -- It is an amazing coincidence that Capt. F. R. Nekrasov and private soldiers D. I. Smirnov and A. I. Korol, all three of the 294th Guards Infantry Regiment and all three stationed on sentry duty inside Moscow's State Mausoleum, the Lenin-Stalin tomb, should all three at the same midnight instant have been overcome by sleep.

The New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America had its greatest year of activity in 1957. National and regional races were run at Thompson and Lime Rock, Conn., at Montgomery and Bridgehampton, N. Y. Numerous rallies were conducted, including two outstanding nationals, the Rip Van Winkle and the Appalachian Mountain events.
Eighty-four persons have been approved by the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange for admission to partnership in member firms.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- A 185-foot section of the closed and partly demolished Chestnut Street bridge over the Schuylkill collapsed today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- France, despite her near-empty treasury, made a payment today of approximately $35,000,000 due the Export-Import Bank.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Montgomery Ward Co. announced today the filing of unfair labor practices charges in thirteen regional offices of the National Labor Relations Board against sixty-two locals of the Retail Clerks International Association.

During the twelve months that came to a close at midnight last night the peoples of the free world, and particularly of the United States, have involuntarily gone through a reappraisal as illuminating as it is agonizing.
The executive committee of the New York Chamber of Commerce has urged that the Federal Reserve Board equalize the reserve requirements of New York City banks with those in other large cities.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Fourteen states join tomorrow in a unified system of collecting divorce statistics.

THERE'S going to be a lot of room for decorating in 1958. About three million persons, it is estimated, are going to be married and set up housekeeping, some of them in the 950,000 new dwelling units, including apartments, that will be built this year.

In a rough-and-tumble year-end session shares on the New York Stock Exchange rose about $1,900,000,000 in market value. Gains ran through the entire list, but were trimmed in the final forty-five minutes of trading.

Bonds called for redemption in December before maturity rose to $13,040,000 from $7,687,000 in November, but the total was the smallest for any December in thirty-one years. A year ago, $16,421,000 was redeemed in the month.

MIAMI, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Carl Dodd's twisted ankle appeared fully healed today and the Oklahoma Sooners were solid 10-point favorites to whip Duke's Blue Devils in tomorrow's twenty-fourth annual Orange Bowl football game.

MONTREAL, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Henri Richard of the Montreal Canadiens kept the lead in the National Hockey League scoring race with 40 points today. But a team-mate, Dickie Moore, was only a point behind.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 31 (AP) -- President Eisenhower abolished today the Clemency and Parole Board for Japanese war criminals subject to United States jurisdiction. The Japanese Government henceforth will assume most of the board's former responsibility.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Dec. 31 -- Dr. James S. Coles, president of Bowdoin College, announced today that Lady Oakes, of Nassau, Bahamas, had given to Bowdoin her property at Bar Harbor, Me., known as the Willows.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A flying boat of the Argentine airlines crashed and sank in Buenos Aires harbor today and nine of the fifty-one persons aboard were reported missing tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- A jury in an inquest into the death of ninety persons in or after the Dec. 4 train crash in suburban London returned a verdict today of "accidental death due to gross negligence."
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- A move is under way to permit municipalities to levy an admission tax at bingo games as they become legal in the state.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- Miss Diana Dorrance Strawbridge, daughter of George Strawbridge of Happy Hollow Farms in Malvern and the late Mrs. Margaret Dorrance Strawbridge, was honored here this evening at a party in the Bellevue Stratford Hotel.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Hard-hitting Ohio State and speedy, deceptive Oregon meet in the forty-fourth edition of the Rose Bowl football game tomorrow, with the Buckeyes from the Big Ten favored by three touchdowns.

The Minneapolis-St. Paul Metropolitan Airports Commission, Minnesota, raised $13,000,000 for airport development on Monday by the sale of bonds due from 1961 to 1988 to the Investors Syndicate of America, the only bidder, at an interest cost of 2.69372 per cent.
UPTON, L. I., Dec. 31 -- The Brookhaven National Laboratory quietly observed a milestone today in its burgeoning peacetime research into nuclear and related sciences.
Governor Harriman was reported yesterday to have picked Dr. Finla G. Crawford, vice chancellor of Syracuse University, to replace John E. Burton as a member of the State Power Authority.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Troops returned to Little Rock Central High School today as the holiday recess drew to a close. Classes will resume tomorrow.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Willie Passmore hustled Pine Echo to the front quickly today and the 5-year-old bay sprinter led all the way to win the $11,400 New Year's Handicap at Tropical Park.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The official Pacific Coast Conference football schedules for 1961 and 1962 were released today and included the three schools that have announced they were withdrawing from the loop -- California, the University of California at Los Angeles and Southern California.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 1 (AP) -- President Sukarno vowed in a New Year's speech today that Indonesia would continue fighting until she had acquired Netherlands New Guinea.

Paul Keres of Russia and Olof Sterner of Sweden were the winners in the third round of the international masters tournament at the annual chess congress of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club yesterday.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 1 (UP) -- The mother of one of the San Antonio boys said today that her son left a good-by note.

BERLIN, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Otto Winzer, East German Deputy Foreign Minister, said today that a forthcoming journey by United States Ambassador David E. K. Bruce from Berlin to West Germany would not be made a visa test case.
The National Association of Manufacturers warned yesterday that continued inflation would mean "general economic catastrophe."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A Government rule barring reinstatement of alleged security risks who waited more than eighteen months to challenge their dismissals in the courts has been struck down by the United States Court of Appeals here.
ROSLYN, L. I., Jan. 1 -- David Fleming's chances of recovery from a burst aorta rose to 90 per cent yesterday, thirty-six hours after he had undergone a rare operation.
TENANTS take note: You are in the same boat as your landlord. Each of you is in doubt with respect to the ownership of your bookshelves, among other things.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Scotland's soccer program today was played under tricky conditions on icy ground, but did not produce any freak results.

It came to light at City Hall yesterday that Mayor Wagner's 11-year-old son, Duncan, erred slightly Tuesday night in his identification of one of the Gracie Mansion guests at the Mayor's New Year's Eve oath-taking.
James M. Ovens, for twenty-three years manager of the Phoenix, Ariz., branch of E. F. Hutton Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, will retire today at the age of 68.

Of all your editorials on world affairs and American understanding and policy orientation pertaining thereto in recent months I have felt never so puzzled as I do about the two appearing side by side in your usually enlightening editorial page on Dec. 26. I am speaking of "Two Worlds at Cairo" and "The Gaither Report."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 1 -- A motel, costing $2,000,000 and to be operated by American Hotels Corporation, will be constructed on Revell Highway in Maryland on the western approach to the Chesapeake Bay Bridge.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Colonial Secretary Alan Lennox-Boyd said today that "not far short" of 1,000,000,000 ($2,800,000,000) had gone from Britain to her colonies since the end of World War II.
DALLAS, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Wayne McKee, a senior Navy end from Pittsburgh, fractured his left forearm today while tackling Buddy Dial of Rice on a pass play in the third quarter of the Cotton Bowl game.

The nation's shippers, who normally have a habit of over-estimating their freight car requirements in fear of being stranded without the necessary rolling stock in case "something turns up," have given the railroads some bad news.

MIAMI, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Oklahoma, paced by David Baker, turned the Orange Bowl game before 76,318 fans into a 48-21 bout of Duke today. The Sooners scored three touchdowns in the first seven minutes of the final period.
The American Viscose Corporation will move its advertising account from N. W. Ayer Son on March 31 to another Philadelphia agency, Arndt, Preston, Chapin, Lamb Keen, Inc.

THE poets and historians of Greece never recorded any fishing or hunting prophecies from Delphi. Divine oracles are no fools and they don't go around predicting what everybody knows is going to happen; they stick to deep, enigmatic stuff.

ISLAMORADA, Fla., Jan. 1 -- Three armed teen-agers commandeered a forty-foot yacht last night for a flight to Cuba or Mexico. They set out with a family of six as hostages on a voyage that ended today in a sea chase and capture by a sheriff's speed boat.
A policeman was charged yesterday with felonious assault. He was accused of having shot and critically wounded a youth while off duty early yesterday.
A pension plan covering artists performing in radio and television went into full effect yesterday.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The two-day celebration of the twentieth anniversary of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will begin tomorrow with the dedication of a Polio Hall of Fame.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Norma Talmadge, star of the silent screen, left the bulk of her estate, valued at a total of more than a million dollars, to her two sisters, Constance and Natalie Talmadge. Norma Talmadge died here Dec. 24 at the age of 60.
DESPITE her manifold attainments, Gypsy Rose Lee hardly can be expected to be convincing in the part of a sentimental, guileless theatrical agent.
OSWEGO, N. Y., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Vincent A. Corsall took office as Mayor of Oswego today. He faced the prospect of losing his job as a high school teacher tomorrow.
The Transport Workers Union will start planning today for a secret ballot to ratify new labor contracts with the Transit Authority and eight private bus lines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Some state and local governments might be able to share in President Eisenhower's proposed new billion-dollar educational program without spending an additional nickel of their own.
DETROIT, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Most of the auto industry's assembly lines will be back in operation next Monday for full-time operations after holiday shutdowns.

The stock market had its good days and its bad days in 1957, but no one can say it didn't bring the year to a close on a spectacular note. In volume Tuesday's session was the heaviest last-day-of-the-year trading since the New York Times began keeping a day-to-day statistical record of its behavior, almost a half century ago, with a turnover of 5,073,730 shares.
A WOMAN with any spunk at all has already included a diet in her 1958 resolutions. But until calorie counting pays off, a sturdy foundation garment may permit her to follow fashion into a chemise.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A 23-year-old woman of Euclid, Ohio, has been awarded $70,000 for the mental anguish she has endured since the sinking of the Andrea Doria, which she survived.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Congress will be asked to provide $100,000,000 this year to modernize the New York Post Office, which postal officials call the "No. 1 bottleneck" in the nation's mail system. The modernization would require five years.
Secretary Benson's pronouncement concerning lower price supports for milk products April 1 seems to imply that the dairyman is guilty of overpricing at the farm.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 1 -- Provisional President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu has told the nation that it is up to the citizens to prevent Argentina from falling under the sway of an alliance of neo-Peronist parties.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 1 -- Rum Dum from the Larchmont Yacht Club, with Jack Sutphen as skipper, retained her laurels in the twenty-seventh annual frostbite regatta with a three-day score of 43 points in Manhasset Bay today.

THE most incomprehensible maneuver in recent football history was the wild gallop of Frank Leahy in the direction of the Texas Aggie coaching job only to have the doctors whistle the play dead because of an obvious offside. Everything about the action defied logic. Everything about it was completely out of character for Leahy.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 1 -- President Eisenhower will interrupt a year-end work holiday at his farm near here tomorrow for a twenty-four-hour business trip to the White House.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Half of the projects under the Federal Government's three-year program of enlarging and modernizing medical laboratories will be under construction this year.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 1 -- Following are the texts of a New Year's message to President Eisenhower from Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, Soviet Chief of State; Premier Nikolai A. Pulganin and Nikita S. Khrushchev, first secretary of the Soviet Communist party, and of the President's reply, addressed to Marshal Voroshilov.
About 800,000 persons, or at least 10 per cent of the city's population, had Asian influenza in the epidemic last fall, the Department of Health reported yesterday.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- New Zealand's new Labor Government imposed import licensing controls today in an effort to save falling exchange reserves.
Unlike most city and suburban gardeners, Louis Martini ignored the cold this week to work his privately maintained gardens in Central Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Zora Folley, a heavyweight contender, registered his seventeenth consecutive victory tonight by flooring Garvin Sawyer twice and easily outpointing him in a bout at the new Capitol Arena.

It's a curious fact that negative acts usually fail to inspire enthusiasm. Negative acts are thought of as those based on fear, resentment or jealousy and, by intent, impede constructive works, continue injustices and attempt to turn back the clock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The Rural Electrification Administration financed rural power systems in 1957 that brought light and energy to 102,000 additional farm consumers.

As the old year closed a new Administration was inaugurated in the Philippines. The year had been one of tragedy and stress. In March Ramon Magsaysay, the beloved President and inspirational national leader, was killed in a plane crash. A tumultuous political campaign to name his successor followed. The year ended with a new "regime of austerity," designed to meet the crisis of a depleted balance of foreign reserves.

Negotiations for a long-distance telephone labor contract made "some slight progress" yesterday, according to a spokesman for the Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
HOUSTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Prairie View A. M. College and Texas Southern University battled to a 6-6 deadlock today before 5,000 fans in the thirtieth annual Prairie View bowl game.

ALTHOUGH oysters have been in season for the last four months, many who fancy these prize products from cold coves, frigid bays and estuaries, contend that they have never been juicier nor better flavored than now.

EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Louisville University, its ground star put out of action in the first period, beat Drake University, 34 -- 20, today with a passing attack before 12,000 fans in the Sun Bowl.
A weedkiller in this country is stimulating growth in the Far East. It is 2-4-D, a chemical used by gardeners to kill dandelions and other broad-leafed weeds.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Tall Chief II, a 6-year-old gray horse owned by W. G. Gilmore of San Francisco and bred by the late Aga Khan, won the $29,200 San Gabriel Handicap at Santa Anita Park before a crowd of 39,000 today. He out-finished the favored Ekaba by a head.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- More than a million persons turned out today for the Tournament of Roses parade.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The House of Representatives will get off to a fast start on investigations in the new session of Congress. Five separate hearings are scheduled for the opening week.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Raymond Brown's bruising runs and deft passes powered mighty Mississippi to a 39-7 Sugar Bowl football victory over Texas today before 82,000 fans.
The Penn-Texas Corporation has sold "certain assets" of a subsidiary, the Liberty Aircraft Products Corporation of Farmingdale, L. I.
A driver for the Fifth Avenue Coach Company used his changemaker as a weapon and routed two teen-age boys who attempted to rob him last night.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- Rockland County opened its first Bureau of Identification here today to expedite the identification of criminals.

The tragic events in Indonesia are appalling to anyone familiar with the strategic importance of that nation and with the acute suffering of the Indonesian people in some areas. The loss of this land to the West would be a terrible one. And the effect on the 80,000,000 Indonesian victims would be worse.
TEANECK, N. J., Jan. 1 -- Television and automation, twin giants of electronics, have helped transform tenpin bowling from a backward child to a robust adult in the family of sports.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The wets gained ground over the drys last year despite 358 elections throughout the nation to determine if distilled spirits could be legally sold.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- Secretary of State Dulles and Dag Hammarskjold had a two-hour discussion today on United Nations problems.

The best New Year's resolution that could be made -- and kept -- in the field of foreign affairs is suggested by the remarks of Theodor Heuss, President of West Germany, in his New Year's Eve message to the German people.
MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- Mr. Khrushchev and other Soviet leaders welcomed in the new year at a Kremlin party with repeated wishes for peace in the world and for agreement with the United States.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 1 -- Ski Sketch: There's a new note of gaiety in this pretty Green Mountain Village. It's being provided by Louis Weissman, talented musician, ski enthusiast and local motel director.

John Patrick, known to theatregoers as the adapter of the Pulitzer Prize play "The Teahouse of the August Moon," and Paul Gregory are at odds. The disagreement involves Mr. Patrick's dramatization of Marjorie Housepian's well-received novel "A Houseful of Love."

Robert Zaborowski has been elected president of the Thompson-Starrett Company, builders and engineers. He succeeds John E. Kalinka, who has retired. Eugene V. Kipp has been elected executive vice president.

SCOTT BASE, Antarctica, Jan. 1 -- Deep snow repeatedly brought tractors of the New Zealand Antarctic expedition to a halt on the polar plateau last night. The party, headed by Sir Edmund Hillary, left behind food, kerosene and other supplies to lighten the loads of tractor-drawn sledges.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Premier Einar Gerhardsen said tonight that the Western democracies "should not place a lop-sided emphasis on military strength."
A court order has prevented the 1958 officers of the Long Island Home Builders Institute from taking office. The officers were chosen in a disputed election last Nov. 20.
Gay and hectic weeks of parties that many a 1957 debutante will long remember drew to a close last night.

DALLAS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Navy, piloted by the brilliant Tom Forrestal and powered by the tremendous running of Ned Oldham, Harry Hurst and a second - stringer, Roland Brandquist, whipped Rice, 20 -- 7, in the Cotton Bowl football game today.
JAKARTA, Jan. 1 -- The State Palace, where the Indonesian Government does its entertaining, was today a happy babel of "Happy New Years."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- More than a third of the members of Congress traveled abroad last year.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The stock market was quiet and firm today. Prices responded to steady demand in a market where offerings were weak, although net gains generally were small.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported over the holiday a record net income of $19,209,548 for twelve months ended Nov. 30. This was a gain of 19.1 per cent above the level of the preceding period and was the ninth consecutive month that system earnings had increased by at least 15 per cent on the twelve-months basis.
The National Audubon Society turned to Congress, Governors and conservation leaders yesterday in its campaign to stop mass spraying or dusting programs using super poisons.

GEN. MARCOS PEREZ JIMENEZ, President of Venezuela, who had to cope yesterday with a military uprising, is a shy, retiring and hard-working dictator. Unlike most of his colleagues in Latin America, he abhors bombast and ostentation.
Donald Rubell of Brooklyn won the junior singles title of the Eastern indoor junior and boys' tennis championships at the 102d Engineers Armory, Manhattan, yesterday.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, urged today that United States service men overseas "think always of God and your country." He officiated at two New Year's Day masses, greeted hundreds of G. I.'s and dined with President and Mme. Chiang Kai-shek at their home, where he is staying as a house guest.
Mayor Wagner formally opened his new four-year term yesterday with an announcement that he would ask the 1958 Legislature for machinery to revise New York City's Charter.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Dr. Douglas M. Kelley, chief psychiatrist during the Nuremberg Nazi war crimes trials, collapsed and died in his home today. The Berkeley police said that he had committed suicide by taking poison.

Mrs. Agnes E. Meyer charged yesterday that the city Board of Education's integration program "has been worked out with complete disregard of the effect it would have upon the learning process and the orderly administration of the school system."
The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power is planning to sell $9,000,000 of waterworks revenue bonds on Jan. 29.

THE series of television feuds between rival attractions appearing on the air at the same time was the theme of "The Battle for Wednesday Night," last night's play on the "Kraft Television Theatre" over Channel 4.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 1 -- President Eisenhower assured the leaders of the Soviet Union today that the United States would do all in its power this year to bring the peoples of the two countries closer together in understanding and goodwill.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Deborah Kerr, winner of the New York Film critics best-actress award, has agreed to co-star with Yul Brynner in "The Journey." The story, set against the background of the anti-Communist uprising in Hungary, is due to go before the camera in Paris next month. Mr. Brynner and Anatole Litvak, the director, have signed a contract to produce the drama independently for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 1 -- A revolt broke out against the Venezuelan Government today.

Samuel Reshevsky, an international grand master, last night took the lead in the United States championship tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club. He won two games, including the one with Atilio Di Camillo of Philadelphia, deferred from the first round.

Although it has no cracker barrel to dip into, today's supermarket is, consciously or no, merchandising a highly attractive commodity -- a community's social life. The bigger and brassier a supermarket grows, the more it resembles, at least in a customer's social habits, the old general store.
The Maritime Administration has issued a pamphlet history of the American merchant marine in connection with its annual poster contest for students.

One of the most respected old-timers in public service has said his retirement good-bys at the New York City Transit Authority. William Jerome Daly, a former newspaper man himself, is 70 years old this month and is the dean of departmental secretaries.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 1 -- Bus drivers in the United States are neat, courteous and cooperative. Their passengers, who ride in fine, comfortable vehicles that are rarely overcrowded and always run on time, are models of decorum and honesty.

Conrad Aiken, poet, novelist and critic, has been awarded the 1957 Fellowship of the Academy of American Poets, a $5,000 prize. The fellowship is the largest award made to poets in this country. Mr. Aiken's poetry has won him four previous prizes.
The return of Democratic control in Queens was marked yesterday by promises of "courtesy and service for all."

A. H. Raskin, labor reporter for The New York Times, declared yesterday he would welcome a Senate inquiry into his "sources of income," as advocated by Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- A patient stand of 189 runs by Jim Burke helped place Australia in a good position on the second day of the second cricket test against South Africa today.
Telephone contact with Venezuela was cut yesterday as the Caracas regime tightened censorship. Persons attempting to call Caracas were informed that no calls to Venezuela were being accepted.
Big industry in the Buffalo-Niagara Falls area strongly urged yesterday that State Power Authority plans for the $600,000,000 Niagara power project be approved "promptly without modification."

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Ohio State, outplayed most of the game by an inspired Oregon team, today eked out a 10-7 Rose Bowl victory on a fourth-period field goal by a substitute halfback, Don Sutherin.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Neal Hinson's 31-yard field goal in the final period enabled East Texas State to rally and defeat Mississippi Southern, 10 -- 9, tonight in the twelfth annual Tangerine Bowl football game before 10,500 fans.
Following is the text of Mayor Wagner's inaugural speech at City Hall yesterday:

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 1 -- Executives of the International Commission of Jurists will leave tomorrow on a tour of fifteen countries, mainly in Asia. The trip is in preparation of a human rights conference to be held in 1959.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- The exclusive group of British tradesmen entitled to display the royal crest and the words "By Appointment, Suppliers to H. M. the Queen" were joined today by reed thatchers, bagpipe makers, coach hirers, frozen food suppliers and machinery manufacturers.

TEL, AVIV, Israel, Dec. 29 -- Changes in United States development aid policies have had a marked impact upon Israel's economy. Israel has depended heavily on United States subsidies for dollars to buy raw materials as well as for funds for her development budget.
CAIRO, Jan. 1 -- The Asian-African Peoples Solidarity Conference closed today with a decision to set up what had every appearance of becoming a "little Cominform" of the Eastern World.

ATLANTA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A Negro leader challenged the Government today to "stop talking about cooling off and put the heat on those who are trying to destroy our Government from within by sabotaging free elections."
" HAVE you read the new Freudian biography of Sitting Bull by Pottawatomie Jones of Lewis Nichols University?"

BOSTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Claude Provost's third-period goal with Boston short-handed, his second tally of the game, enabled the league-leading Montreal Canadiens to gain a 4-3 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Albanian fighter aircraft forced down a British freight-carrying airliner yesterday. The downed plane was charged with having violated Albanian airspace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- High officials of the Justice Department denied today that their decision to abandon prosecution of Clinton E. Jencks had been based on a reluctance to disclose reports of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Until recent years the "weather man" has been intent on predicting, as best he could, what the weather will be like tomorrow and the next day. City folk depend on his reports -- in spite of their undependability -- to help decide what to wear and whether to go to the country for the week-end.
NEWARK, Jan. 1 -- The advantages and disadvantages of Newark Airport will be argued here in a court action Jan. 14 in the Federal District Court.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 1 -- David Ben-Gurion formally agreed today to establish a new government.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon is preparing to use jet air transport -- a travel advantage that has been denied President Eisenhower, at least for the time being.
The world whirled into 1958 yesterday with prayers, family dinners and hangovers.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith yesterday hailed the Eighty-fifth Congress for having enacted what it termed "the first bright chapter in civil rights legislation since the Reconstruction Era."
BOSTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Fires in the United States last year set a record loss of $1,275,000,000 in property and killed 11,300 persons.
HAVANA, Jan. 1 -- A series of small bombs exploded last night in Havana and its suburbs as the public celebrated New Year's.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 1 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru is pressing urgently for the quick release of Sheikh Abdullah, a political prisoner in Indian Kashmir for more than four years.
Columbia University announced yesterday the selection of twenty-two editors and a cartoonist as jurors for the 1958 Pulitzer Prizes.

Wanted: An electronic "wizard" that knows all and tells all -- instantly -- about prices, space and sales on an airline flying to eighty-two cities on six continents. This is the substance of a call that has gone out from Pan American World Airways.
A major effort is being made by the city schools to strengthen and expand science education on all levels. The change could effect most of the nearly 1,000,000 pupils and teachers in the system.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A party-loving ambassador from one of the smallest nations became dean today of one of the world's largest diplomatic corps.
