New York City was asked yesterday to recognize the public's "right to know" by giving it more information about city affairs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Secretary of Commerce predicted today a "mild dip, then climb" for the economy in 1958.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 1 -- The new year ushered in an "atomic-age program" at the University of Tennessee. Research laboratories equipped for experiments with isotopes from near-by Oak Ridge were opened. The laboratories are in the new $6,000,000. Memorial Research Center and Hospital in Knoxville.

A shopping center, consisting of ten stores and off-street parking space for 100 automobiles, is to be built in Merrick, Nassau County, L. I. The sponsors are clients of J. Yudell Realty, Inc., of Forest Hills, Queens.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 -- A gain of $350 million in savings deposits last year -- more than $1 million a day -- was reported here today by the Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, the world's largest bank.
HARTFORD, Jan. 1 -- The Connecticut Turnpike, under construction for almost four years, will be opened to traffic tomorrow afternoon.
Charles Beattie has been elected president of E. Robison, Inc. Eben Robison, founder and former president, has been elected chairman of the board, a new post.

Three American mothers began an air journey to Communist China yesterday to visit imprisoned sons they have not seen for five to eleven years. They departed at noon from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. er of New Britain, Conn. Mrs. Downey is the widow of John Downey, who was a probate judge and an uncle of Morton Downey, singer and actor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Donald A. Quarles, Deputy Secretary of Defense, said today that the results of research in weapons would begin to show in the nation's defenses in 1958.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Sir Hugh Foot, Governor of Cyprus, began discussions today with members of the Cabinet on the political future of Britain's island colony in the Mediterranean.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Earl Buchholz of St. Louis defeated Bill Heyck of Tampa today, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0, in the third day of the Dixie tennis tournament.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Ed Litzenberger scored twice tonight, his first goals in fifteen games, to help the Chicago Black Hawks post a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.
Venezuela has had another record year in the production of crude oil and the extension of proven reserves. H. W. Haight, president of the Creole Petroleum Corporation, said in his year-end review.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- The Public Housing Administration announced today that it would sign contracts soon with the Philadelphia and Pittsburgh Housing Authorities for more than 1,500 low-rent homes.
TOKYO, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Japanese housewives were thrown into confusion today as the nation's storekeepers began using a uniform system of metric weights and measures.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 1 -- Baltimore's new city taxes on advertising started today, despite fifteen pending injunction suits. The suits deny the validity of the taxes. The administration is confident that the taxes will be sustained.

The appointment of Eli E. Cohen as executive secretary of the National Child Labor Committee, 419 Fourth Avenue, has been announced by Dr. F. Ernest Johnson, its chairman. Mr. Cohen went to the fifty-four-year-old social agency from Executive Job Counselors, Inc. here.
A letter from the House of the Holy Nativity, Bay Shore, L. I., explained a gift of $10 to the Neediest yesterday.

WARSAW, Jan. 1 -- The Verification Committee was in session last week at a Warsaw factory. Its job, ordered by the ruling Communist party's Central Committee, was to check on the doubters among the factory's Communists and decide who should remain in the party.

We wonder whether Governor Harriman, with his sympathy for "the little man," is aware that it is the comparatively little man that would be most hurt by a refusal to reform the New York State income tax law as it affects the non-resident taxpayer who lives in New Jersey or Connecticut.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 1 -- Iran is in a state of discontent that is dangerous to her internal security and to the stability of the Middle East.
BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- Massachusetts' fiscal condition and mass transportation are the state's two most critical problems, Gov. Foster Furcolo warned today in his annual message to the 1958 Legislature.

The Maryland Shipbuilding Drydock Company has added two new men who will divide the duties of Charles F. Willis, chief engineer. Mr. Willis is retiring for reasons of health. He will continue to serve Maryland, however, as a consultant pending the completion of certain engineering projects currently under way.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 1 -- The Moroccan Government moved today to lessen Spanish influence in the northern zone of this kingdom by abolishing the peseta as the official medium of exchange in Tangier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Navy today awarded a $100,000,000 contract to Chance Vought Aircraft, Inc., of Dallas, for the production of a new line of carrier fighters. The planes are designed to fly twice the speed of sound. Sound travels about 700 miles an hour.

Since November, 1948, when he seized power in a bloodless coup, Marcos Perez Jimenez has ruled Venezuela with one of the toughest, harshest military dictatorships in the Western Hemisphere, a dictatorship that was threatened by yesterday's uprising.

The New York colleges, which have produced more than their share of track and field stars, will be represented by an exceptionally promising group of youngsters tomorrow night at the 102d Engineers Armory in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union championships, which open the 1958 indoor track campaign.
A closed circuit television broadcast yesterday featured admission to New York Stock Exchange trading of Siegler Corporation stock, first new listing on the Big Board this year.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The pound sterling continued to rise today. The pound closed at $2.81 1/16, for a rise of one-eighth of a cent on the day and one-sixteenth of a cent below the day's top price.

A steady stream of public utility financing and borrowings by local governments lie ahead for the bond market this year, but money requisitions from other sources will likely decline, according to the annual survey of the bond market published today by the Chicago bond house, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

The State of the Union message that President Eisenhower is to deliver at the Capitol next week will set the Administration's tone for the coming twelve months. This speech is likely to be listened to by Congress, the nation and the world with more attention than most such speeches have received in recent years.

The nine-story apartment building at 125 East Sixty-third Street has been purchased by a corporation representing a group of the tenants, including Lawrence Hoguet, Leon R. Spear, Mrs. Buell Hollister, Miss Thayer Gibbons and Judge Simon H. Rifkind.
Many Wall Street investment banking and New York Stock Exchange firms revised their partnerships yesterday to admit new members and accept retirements.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Government, accepting a new legal standard for obscenity, decided today to let the Kinsey Institute import some concededly pornographic pictures, books and other objects.

Boat racing history may have a page added to it any day now. Danny Foster, now of Detroit, heretofore known for his daredeviltry in mammothsized inboard craft (he has won the Gold Cup twice) has been lured back to outboards which he first raced as a teen-ager around his native Oakland, Calif.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers hunt for a place to play baseball was kept as high in the air as ever today in action by both the City Council and the Memorial Coliseum Commission.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial "Moscow's Peace Program" again emphasizes the crucial need for a more vigorous American peace program -- if, indeed, it can be said we now have one. This, as you note, must originate from more imaginative and insightful leadership in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -M/Sgt. Roy A. Rhodes, who admitted selling United States military information to the Russians was ordered today to face a general court-martial on spying charges.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Carl Braun and Willie Naulls combined for 52 points tonight to lead the New York Knickerbockers to a 131-98 National Basketball Association victory over the Syracuse Nationals at Convention Hall.

ROME, Friday, Jan. 3 -- The gala opening of the 1958 Rome Opera season broke up in tumult shortly before midnight last night as the prima donna Maria Callas refused to continue her performance after the first act of Bellini's "Norma."

YONKERS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Good Time Park, a mile harness track in Goshen, N. Y., home of the Hambletonian trot from 1930 through 1956, has been sold to a realty corporation headed by Alfred Tananbaum, chairman of the board of directors at Yonkers Raceway.

Stocks moved diffidently into 1958 yesterday, with volume on the New York Stock Exchange falling away to 1,800,000 shares, against 5,073,730 on Tuesday. But there were fair gains in price for most of the list.
Poisonous fumes were emitted as a fire extinguisher was used on a small fire in a BMT car carrying 150 passengers yesterday. The passengers broke windows to get air and none was hurt.

Shipbuilding, ship repairing and allied industries have just completed their best year since 1954, it was reported yesterday. They might have reached a record production but for dificulties in obtaining steel.

THERE are men who walk every street, every avenue, every lane, court, square and alley in the city at least once every twelvemonth. They know New York better than any man in municipal service because they cover it all on foot, even to its back yards and its rooftops.

PACKING a suitcase is a little like making a souffle. Both require a certain skill, some precision and a sure knowledge of what goes in and when. A messy suitcase -- like a bad souffle -- simply means your methods aren't adequate.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 2 -Helicopters from the United States aircraft carrier Princeton dropped food and medicine today to marooned and starving flood victims. Relief operations were in full swing in all parts of Ceylon, ravaged last week by floods in which 225 were estimated to have been killed and perhaps 250,000 made homeless.

The Communist-dominated "Afro-Asian People's Solidarity Conference" organized by President Nasser has ended with actions and resolutions which scuttle Nasser's pretense of "positive neutrality" and open up new roads to Communist penetration.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway in a "flash" -- or advance -- annual report to holders of its 8,088,551 shares of common stock disclosed that 1957 was a record one both from the standpoint of gross revenues and net income.

The two children of the first marriage of Fulton Oursler, the author, are entitled to share equally in the $5,000,000 estate of their father with the two children of his second marriage, Supreme Court Justice Arthur Klein ruled yesterday.
Dallas, Tex., is planning to borrow $11,800,000 on serial bonds on Jan. 27. The obligations will finance public improvements and will come due from 1958 to 1978.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- The offer by the United States to furnish plans and fuel for atomic submarines to member nations of the North Atlantic alliance is being studied closely here, official sources said today.

M. Cohen of the Williams Real Estate Company, brokers, for the Tishman Realty Construction Company, builder and owner.

A Queens magistrate yesterday postponed a decision on whether to commit 16-year-old Warren Yeager to King's County Hospital for observation. He is charged with stabbing a doctor's receptionist to death on Dec. 23.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Governor Harriman announced a contest today to pick a new name for the Penn-Can Highway that would identify it with New York State rather than its terminal points.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Miss Frances Ann Iacoboni, 20 years old, of Leominster, became the first woman in the United States today to be sworn into the Army Reserve under a new program of obtaining Army medical specialists.

MIAMI, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Wheatley Stable's Bold Ruler, 1957 "horse of the year" and Calumet Farm's Bardstown drew top weight of 128 pounds today for the $100,000 added Widener Handicap at Hialeah Feb. 22.
TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today he would meet with Governor Harriman of New York next Friday to talk about New York's income tax on New Jersey residents.

OWEGO, N. Y., Jan. 2 -- Details were being worked out here today for "reconvening" the Nov. 14 Apalachin gang convention. The host this time will be the people of the State of New York.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 2 -- The reconstruction of the Cross County Parkway and the placing of a toll station on it in Mount Vernon became the first objectives of the new Westchester County Parkway Authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Navy is proposing that this nation's first nuclear-powered airplane be a seaplane.

Apparently there has been some break in the stalemate between Japan and the Republic of Korea. The Japanese Foreign Minister has announced an agreement on the release of nationals of each country who have been held in detention by the other. All the details have not been worked out but the process of movement is expected to start immediately.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Prof. Arthur Lehman Goodhart, American international law authority and master of University College, Oxford, said today that if Secretary of State Dulles would resign tomorrow "he would be making the greatest contribution to world peace that has ever been made by an American Secretary of State."
It Was Resolved -The tumult has died now, and the shouting. The whistles have stilled. The paper hats, which once perched so jauntily on the head, have been crumpled and discarded.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 2 -Communist China and India are building the first road suitable for automobiles to link the great wasteland of Tibet with India.
MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- The Soviet Government recalled Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky today from his command of the Transcaucasus Military District after he had served in that post for only ten weeks.
NEWARK, Jan. 2 -- The State Law Enforcement Council announced today that it would open public hearings Monday on New Jersey "aspects" of the gang meeting in Apalachin, N. Y.

Since 1953, S. N. Behrman has controlled the rights to Alva Johnston's popular book "The Legendary Mizners" in the hope of transferring the plot to the musical comedy stage. Yesterday it was learned that Mr. Behrman had extended the option through the end of this year.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 2 -- Integrated classroom sessions were resumed at Central High School today. Federalized National Guard troops continued to patrol the grounds.
BERLIN, Jan. 2 -- Soviet patrols appeared late today at Streets leading from Communist East Berlin into West Berlin.

VERY young women competed with established women of elegance in the annual list of the "World's Best Dressed Women." The 1957 list, announced today by the Couture Group of the New York Dress Institute, includes five women under 30 years of age, the Queen of England, two film stars and five titled women.
The D'Arcy Advertising Company, Inc., has been chosen to handle the Halo Shampoo account, with billings of more than $2,000,000 a year.

State Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter announced yesterday that he would deny any more requests for wiretapping orders by state and city law enforcement officers. He said the United States Supreme Court had held that the state law on such taps was a violation of Federal law.

The Middle East is not a safe or happy place today. Not safe for human beings, not safe for the spirit we associate with last week's and week's holidays. The news from Damascus has not been too good. Cairo has been witnessing a kind of vaudeville show that would be humorous if it were not so dangerous.

OSWEGO, N. Y., Jan. 2 -- Vincent A. Corsall, Mayor of Oswego, was dismissed today as a teacher at Oswego High School. A few hours later he escorted back to the school approximately thirty students who opposed his ouster.
A record for traffic deaths -160 -- was set in the nation's celebration of the new year.
TROY, N. Y., Jan. 2 (AP) -- The University of New Brunswick defeated Yale, 7 -- 3, tonight in the opening game of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's seventh annual round-robin hockey tournament.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Both First and Second Avenues, between the Midtown Tunnel and the Fifty-ninth Street bridge, literally crawl with cars, taxis, trucks and buses during business hours.
Roosevelt Raceway yesterday disclosed its plans for another big money season in 1958.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- J. C. Doyle, general sales and marketing manager of the Ford Motor Company's Edsel division, said today that the Edsel had started the new year with sales on the upswing.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 2 -- The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis today opened a two-day celebration of its twentieth anniversary by dedicating a polio Hall of Fame.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some ten or twelve years ago, when I last lived in New York, I gained a great deal of pleasure and knowledge from visiting the Museum of Science and Industry that was located in Radio City. Now that we are once more in the New York area, I planned to take my scientifically minded children to enjoy that same experience.

The United States will compete in the world bobsled championships at Garmisch-Partenkirschen, Germany, Jan. 25-26 and Feb. 1-2. A six-man team was named yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union from the leaders to the Lake Placid, N. Y., area.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 2 -- The Soviet Union's first earth satellite, launched into the ionosphere Oct. 4, may have made its return plunge today.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Powel Crosley Jr. indicated today he was "encouraged" by moves to keep his Redlegs in Cincinnati but he was closer "mentally" to moving than at any time in history.
MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- Acknowledgement that Alfred K. Stern, his wife the former Martha Dodd, and their son Robert were in the Soviet Union recently was published here today in the magazine Novoye Vremya.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Nineteen educators proposed today an immediate start on a threelevel program to raise the quality of the American educational system.

The continuing evidence of a business letdown seems to be giving dealers in Government securities warrant for raising their bids. That applies especially to the high-coupon, longterm issues brought out last summer and fall.
Futures prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. A post-holiday lull was evident in most markets. Trading was generally featureless.

ROME, Jan. 2 (AP) -- An American shipping pilot who worked for fifteen months on the Suez Canal said today that Egyptian police had forced him to leave his Ismailia home and had expelled him from the country without telling him why.
A revised Customs system of handling steamship baggage passed its first major test yesterday.
Charges published in the British press this week that the United States used unethical methods to sell warplanes to West Germany underscore one of the principal weaknesses of the Atlantic alliance.
Trans-Atlantic ship travel rose to its highest level in twentyseven years in 1957.
In a combined hold-up and burglary, two armed men took $10,190 at 107 Wilson Avenue, near Starr Street, Brooklyn, yesterday at 4:30 A. M.

"Ice Palace," Edna Ferber's first novel in five years, will be published March 27 by Doubleday. It is a story about modern Alaska and of the people who bridge the old Alaska and the new. While writing the story, Miss Ferber made four trips to Alaska, including one over the North Pole.

Any municipality harboring dreams of acquiring a major league franchise should concentrate its energies with just one objective in mind. It must equip itself with a modern stadium -- not one designed exclusively for baseball but one to serve as a year-round recreational arena that would reap revenue from many sources.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -The American Association of University Professors accused South Carolina's Governor today of having used state authority to interfere with a private Negro teachers college.
The Waltham Watch Company has completed a "multimillion-dollar royalty agreement" with Hallmark, Inc., under which the latter has been licensed to use the Waltham name for ten years.
BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Charles E. Wyzanski ruled today that Percival Goodman, a New York architect, was entitled to $24,568 for drawing plans for a synagogue in near-by Quincy.

A nonprofit group will open a $700,000 Institute for Special Education in Queens Jan. 27. The school's enrollment will be limited to 254 boys and girls, between the ages of 2 and 16, who, because of emotional, behavioral or mental difficulties, are ineligible for regular schooling.
No mouse in his right mind would normally think of showing up at a convention of cats, but that is what happened yesterday.
A 16-year-old boy was stopped by the police yesterday afternoon as he was about to dettonate a homemade pipe bomb on the rear fire escape of an upper East Side tenement.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Jan. 2 -Twelve Boy Scouts will hand Governor Harriman petitions tomorrow asking that an Ulster County landmark be preserved.
MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- Reversing a trend of recent years, the Soviet Government announced today an increase in the prices of some consumer goods.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 2 -- King Phumiphol Aduldet named Lieut. Gen. Thanom Kitkhachon Premier of Thailand last night. The new Government is heavily sprinkled with military officers and has a definite pro-West, anti-Communist leaning.

Garbed in glowing colors, as if they had stepped out of the illuminated pages of a medieval manuscript, members of the New York Pro Musica Antiqua enacted yesterday afternoon a twelfth-century musical drama, "The Play of Daniel," in The Cloisters of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

A stormy annual meeting of the New York Trust Company next Wednesday may have been averted when management agreed yesterday to "explore" merger feelers it said had come from several large New York banks.
The Swan-Finch Oil Corporation filed in Federal Court yesterday a voluntary petition for reorganization under the Bankruptcy Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -Representative Omar Burleson said today that the House Administration Committee soon would make public summaries of funds spent by touring Congressmen from United States-held foreign currencies in 1957.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -The United States has approved the Soviet Union's designation of Mikhail A. Menshikov, a top-ranking trade expert, as its new Ambassador to Washington.
HARTFORD, Jan. 2 -- Judge Boce Barlow was denied a salary of $7,500 a year today on a ruling by the Corporation Council that he was not a legal judge and could not be paid by the city.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am grateful to you for your thoughtful editorial of Dec. 27 concerning the dilemma which has enveloped the relationship between voluntary hospitals and Blue Cross.

Paul Keres of Russia, the leader in the international masters tournament at the Hastings chess congress, failed to finish his fourth-round game with Jonathan Penrose of England after a session lasting 41 moves, according to a report received last night through British news sources.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 2 -Officers of the Venezuelan Air Force and National Guard, many of whom were reported to have led yesterday's revolt, have been for some time among those in quiet opposition to the Government.
A sweeping reorganization of the Board of Standards and Appeals, provided for by the enactment of a new local law, was put into effect yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

The problem of what to do with radioactive waste may be solved by letting the deadly waste materials contain themselves. That, in effect, is the solution being studied by General Electric Company scientists at the Hanford Atomic Works near Richland, Wash.

BRISBANE, Australia, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Dick (Pancho) Gonzales, the pro tennis champion from Los Angeles, today defeated Australia's Lew Hoad in a thrilling five-set tennis contest that opened their 100-match series.
Opponents of the Lincoln Square redevelopment plan resumed their court battle against the $205,000,000 project yesterday.

CAIRO, Jan. 2 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt has in effect granted the Soviet bloc a base in Egypt from which Communists may direct and finance anti-Western movements and rebellions throughout Africa.

TRENTON, Jan. 2 -- State Senator James F. Murray Jr. contended today that Jersey City has legal jurisdiction over Ellis Island. He coupled this claim with another plea that the Federal Government not sell the island.

Directors of the Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company yesterday approved the sale of several of the company's subsidiaries known as the Hershey group of properties in Cuba to the Chiriqui Sugar Mills Corporation, Panama, for $24,500,000, consisting of cash and short term notes.
The strength of the Canadian dollar worked yesterday in favor of the Neediest.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -President Eisenhower returned today for a twenty-four-hour stay at the White House to complete work on his Budget and State of the Union Messages.
MARY CURTIS - VERNA, who has shown her versatility at the Metropolitan Opera this season by taking over leading roles on short notice, added another role to her Metropolitan repertory last night.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- Governor Harriman will ask the Legislature to approve a new $200,000,000 state housing bond issue. It would be subject to ratification by the voters at a referendum next fall.
The first Civil Service employe of New York City to be convicted of perjury for lying about Communist Party affiliations was sentenced yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions.

Samuel Reshevsky, leading in the United States championship tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy, was still undefeated in the tenth round at the Manhattan Chess Club last night. But after a five-hour session and forty moves had been recorded, his opponent, James T. Sherwin, was regarded as fairly certain to win upon the resumption of play.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- The management of the Mercantile National Bank of Chicago today filed suit in Circuit Court to prohibit an insurgent group led by James T. Igoe from voting at the annual meeting Jan. 21. Mr. Igoe has claimed control of more than 51 per cent of the 110,000 outstanding shares.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Jan. 2 -- The Rockland County grand jury will be asked next Monday to undertake a preliminary investigation of the tax confusion in the town of Clarkstown.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 2 -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru will begin tomorrow a series of meetings with political leaders from Asia, the West and Eastern Europe.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The Harriman Administration accused the Republican leadership in the Legislature today of practicing "tragically shortsighted economy" in cutting traffic safety appropriations from the Governor's budget.

Combined operating earnings of the First National City Bank of New York and its affiliate, the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, last year were $60,205,000, or $5.02 each on the 12,000,000 shares outstanding. When calculated on the same number of shares the comparable figures for 1956 were $51,962,000, or $4.33 a share.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Premier David Ben-Gurion has completed deliberations on the make-up of the Government. He is likely to present his proposed Cabinet to Parliament next week.
A nation-wide telephone strike appeared imminent as negotiators failed yesterday to reach agreement on a contract for long-lines workers of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 2 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that "the United Nations machinery" was available to governments if they wished to use it for disarmament negotiations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs predicted today that the nation's imports and exports would decline this year from their peak levels of 1957.
TRENTON, Jan. 2 -- Samue L. Bodine has offered to waiv his $10,000-a-year salary as Republican state chairman to hel his party wipe out its 195 campaign deficit of $157,000.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 2 -The total of refugees from the East registered in West Germany last year was 264,500, the Ministry for All-German Affairs announced. The average flow was 5,075 a week or 725 a day. Almost half, about 130,000, made their way to West Germany through West Berlin.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 2 (UP) -- President Iskander Mirza appealed to the United States today to bolster the Baghdad Pact by joining the alliance as a full member.
HAVANA, Friday, Jan. 3 -Gale force winds and a driving rain swept through Havana harbor last night ripping away a floating dock tied up to the Holland-America luxury liner, the Nieuw Amsterdam.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen's White House staff on disarmament has published 90,000 copies of a multicolored pamphlet telling the story of the Government's "dedicated crusade" to end the threat of nuclear war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--Perhaps it was the niggling character of Representative Celler's "counsel" Sunday, Dec. 29, to the President, to "resign temporarily," that evoked some clear signs of the instinctive reaction of the American people when they have had enough of partisanship and personal criticism.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 2 -- A spokesman for the Indonesian Army declined comment today as to whether or not this country had purchased military equipment from the Soviet Union. Reports to that effect were published here.
Howard G. (Jake) Cann, New York University's varsity basketball coach for the last thirty-five years and a distinguished "elder statesman" of the game, will retire at the close of the present season.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Frank Leahy, former Notre Dame football coach, was discharged from Passavant Hospital today following a check-up that prevented him from accepting a head coaching job at Texas A. and M.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 1 -- Mexico is taking a second look at a new-look Ambassador and apparently is satisfied with what she sees.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy will be a witness today before a legislative committee investigating the "bugging" by the Transit Authority of the Motormen's Benevolent Association.
PARIS, Jan. 2 -- A new British suggestion in the negotiations for a European free trade area is regarded as presaging concessions but as not going very far to define them.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 2 (AP) -The United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit, upheld today an injunction preventing a railroad union from taking action against a member who had quit the union because of a job change.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 2 (AP) -Russian cameras are superior to those used by Americans for auroral observations, a scientist said today.

The Soviet Union's earth satellites may have damaged American prestige, a Japanese professor said here yesterday, but the United States would damage itself even more by going through with a proposal to cut technical assistance personnel overseas.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Oklahoma State capitalized on the absence of Wilt Chamberlain tonight and spoiled Kansas' chances of a perfect basketball season, defeating the Jayhawks, 52 -- 50, in overtime.

Red Buttons will star as Hansel in the television production of "Hansel and Gretel." The fairy tale will be produced by Talent Associates, Ltd., and presented over the National Broadcasting Company network on April 27 from 6:30 to 7:30 P. M.
MEN who were not altogether happy with what Santa gave them this year carried back 3,000 flamboyant ties to five New York stores in the week following Christmas.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 2 -- The Bergen County Board of Freeholders today named Fred W. Meuter of Ridgefield as director for this year. He succeeds John K. Pollitt of Fair Lawn.

DON SUTHERIN kicked a 34-yard field goal in the final quarter and that was the margin by which Ohio State defeated Oregon in the Rose Bowl on New Year's Day. Since the bowl games represent the concluding phases of the previous season, there was something symbolic about the kick -- the return of the foot to football. It really came back this campaign.

TWO new species of game, one an exotic pheasant and one a hybrid fish, have been added to the growing list of sportsmen's quarries that various states hope will help to satisfy the insatiable demands of hunters and anglers.

Having weathered a holiday week that cost them millions because of the lack of snow, ski operators were stirring hopefully yesterday. Many of them still did not have much cover, but at least they had seen snow in recent days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Proposals for reorganization of the Defense Department to place a single commander at the head of the nation's armed forces gained strong bipartisan support today in Congress.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- A record of 184,000 cars, trucks and tractors were exported from the Ford Motor Company's plant at Dagenham, near London, in 1957, the company announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Two airlines -- Eastern and Northeast -- have protested a proposal of National Airlines to reduce night coach fares Jan. 13, but at the same time have filed fare reductions of their own.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Federal Power Commission was urged by its staff today to reject major engineering plans of the New York State Power Authority for the $600,000,000 Niagara hydroelectric power project.

EDDIE BROWN was a good boy, a middleweight who really had class and packed a punch. Doc Carroll, his manager, had brought him along carefully for nine years, teaching him all he knew. And nobody, nobody at all, knew as much about fighting as old Doc. He had never had a champion, but that wasn't his fault.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The Bristol Aeroplane Company and the Hawker-Siddeley group announced tonight the details of a joint company to be formed by them to produce a jet airliner for British European Airways.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The appointment of Dr. Finla G. Crawford as a member of the State Power Authority was reported today to have been approved in advance by the authority chairman, Robert Moses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Following is the text of a report issued today by the Educational Policies Commission, sponsored by the National Education Association and the American Association of School Administrators:

CAIRO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince and Premier, Prince Feisal, said today that efforts had been made by certain "American circles" to prevent conclusion of the recently signed Saudi-Japanese offshore oil agreement.

The Cherry-Burrell Corporation of Little Falls, N. Y., yesterday reported its net earnings for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 at $1,071,663, a gain of 4.8 per cent above the $1,036,892 earned in the preceding period.
DANVILLE, Ill., Jan. 2 (AP) -The Federal judge who had convicted the A. P. food chain of antitrust-law violations announced today his retirement from active service on the bench.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 2 -- The AB-PT Pictures Corporation plans to carry out its program of twelve features for the year by putting one a month before the cameras.

McCALL, Idaho, Jan. 2 (AP) -Leo Massa of Matawan, N. J., a member of the New York Finnish Ski Club, raced a ninemile cross-country course today in 1 hour 5 minutes 7 seconds and won the first elimination heat at the Federation Internationale de Ski tryouts.

"Wonderful Times" (1950), written and directed by Gunter Neumann, Fritz Aeckerle and Hans Vietzke, will be shown Sunday through Wednesday in the series, "Past and Present: A Selection of German Films, 1896-1957," at the Museum of Modern Art.
MADRID, Jan. 2 -- The Spanish fiesta, a symbol of millions in carefree, holiday-loving Spain, is in danger.
MONTREAL, Jan. 2 (UP) -Dickie Moore and Henri Richard, the National Hockey League's leading scorers, paced the Montreal Canadiens to a 5-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

The largest precision welding tool installation ever engineered in this country is fabricating parts for the Air Force's intercontinental ballistics missile Titan, the Air Reduction Company said yesterday.

The report of the Department of Health for 1957. serves to put into dramatic form some of the things that we may be likely to overlook unless they are called sharply to our attention. Death rate: 10.3 per thousand or just about what we have come to expect. Birth rate: still up, with the largest number of births since 1947. Also not unexpected.
John Wingate undertook to answer on his WABD-TV program "Night Beat" last night statements made by Michael T. Quill while being interviewed on the program on New Year's Eve.

Louis Talcott Stone, director of talent commitments for the Columbia Broadcasting System, was found dead yesterday in a room at the Roosevelt Hotel. He was 43 years old and lived at 44 West Seventy-seventh Street.

Business loans by the major New York City banks declined $95,000,000 in the last week of 1957, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a drop of $211,000,000 in loans for the comparable week a year earlier.

The Fountain House Foundation will benefit from a theatre party being arranged under the chairmanship of Mrs. H. Laurence Dowd and her aides, Mrs. Donald Flamm, Mrs. John C. Milne and Mrs. Philip S. Tashman. The event will take place at the Jan. 16 performance of "The Music Man," the musical by Meredith Willson at the Majestic Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Government today held the Crown Zellerbach Corporation in violation of the anti-merger law and ordered it to divest itself of the St. Helens Pulp and Paper Company, a major competitor it acquired in 1953.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- Piloted planes are here to stay for a while, an American airplane executive said here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A Wisconsin legislator asked the Federal District Court today to prevent the Agriculture Secretary from paying more than $3,000 to a farmer from the soil bank.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Jan. 2 -- A bluish-purple light that flitted along the north Jersey coast tonight was not a flying saucer or an invader from Mars. It was a United States plane that had a perfect right to be where it was.
It's not everybody who lives to be 85 years old, commutes for fifty-seven years, has a train named in his honor -- and can't get a seat on it.

RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 2 -- Two Americans absent without leave from Army units in Europe since last summer told their story at the United States naval base at Port-Lyautey today. They described enlistment in the French Foreign Legion and desertion to the "Algerian Liberation Army" in the hope of getting to the United States.

MERLE MILLER adapted his novel, "Reunion," for last night's drama on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2. On the printed page he had an opportunity to develop his characters, but on television he had to skeletonize his principals so sharply that he merely finished with a marathon of unconvincing emotionalism.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP) -Police Chief William Parker has settled out of court for $44,500 his $2,000,000 damage suit for remarks made on television by Mickey Cohen, former gambler.
A bill that would bring the Transit Authority's labor relations with employes under the law for the first time was made public yesterday.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 2 -- The rebellion against the Venezuelan Government that began yesterday ended at noon today with the surrender of rebel holdouts thirteen miles southwest of Caracas.

The first blow struck for Venezuelan freedom against the military dictatorship of General Perez Jimenez appears to have failed. Officers in the air force garrison at Maracay, fifty miles from Caracas, rebelled as the new year opened, but they did not have support from the army and navy. Thus they were doomed.
Maurice A. Bergman, Eastern studio representative for talent and literary properties of Universal Pictures Company, has resigned from the organization. effective today. He held the post since 1953.

THE new year brings with it litle prospect of saving money on the family food budget. Most commodities have risen in cost with the two most important, to the purse and the family cook, heading the top of the list. They are meat and vegetables.
The latest figures show that automobile production in this country in 1957 was the fourth highest on record. Last year's output was exceeded only in 1950, 1953 and 1955.

The city is seeking about $40,000,000 more in state aid to help balance its expense budget for the fiscal year starting July 1. That budget is expected to be substantially larger than the 1957-58 budget of $1,933,740,951.
Money eased in the week ended Wednesday as funds returned to member banks after the holidays, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Cecil Smith of San Antonio and Bob Skene of San Mateo, Calif., retained their ten-goal ratings in outdoor polo in the 1958 handicaps released yesterday by the United States Polo Association.
The Sunbeam Corporation yesterday lost a court fight here to maintain fixed retail prices on its small home appliances.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -Representative John E. Moss, chairman of the House Information Subcommittee, asked the Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, today for a "full explanation" of why science attaches had been withdrawn from United States embassies abroad.

MEMORIES of the past and thoughts of the future joined to cast a glow on last night's New York Philharmonic concert at Carnegie Hall. It was Leonard Bernstein's first appearance of the season, and his destiny as a conductor has been and will be bound up inextricably with this orchestra's.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP) -Norman Van Brocklin, quarterback for the Los Angeles Rams of the National Football League, tonight retired from professional football.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 2 -- The nation's newest superhighway -- the $464,000,000 Connecticut Turnpike -- was opened to traffic at 2:30 P. M. today. Cars, trucks and buses began using all but three miles of the 129-mile expressway after ribbon-cutting ceremonies here and at the toll road's northeastern terminus at Killingly, on the Rhode Island border.
The tenacity of the International Boxing Clb in trying to get two local boxers into the same ring apparently is about to pay off.
DETROIT, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Jimmy Skinner resigned today as coach of the Detroit Red Wings and was replaced by a former Red Wing center, Sid Abel.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Aneurin Bevan, the British Labor party's spokesman on foreign affairs, called today for a conference between the leaders of the Soviet Union and the heads of Government of the United States, Britain and France.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- New York's two Senators pledged today to fight in the approaching session for an overhauling of immigration laws.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 2 -The establishment of a combined engineering staff to design and build a thermonuclear fusion research device at Princeton University was announced today by the Allis-Chalmers Company and the Radio Corporation of America.

The Greater New York Association, which controls thoroughbred racing in New York State, yesterday made another move designed to halt the flow of the metropolitan betting public's dollars west (New Jersey) and south (Maryland).

GOLDSBORO, N. C., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Drueding Brothers of Philadelphia, said to be the world's largest manufacturer of chamois leather, announced today plans to transwer one-third of its plant operations here.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Grain futures started the new year mostly higher today, reflecting trade expectations of improved foreign demand in the immediate future.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -A Federal judge dismissed today a test case brought by two craft unions contesting National Labor Relations Board sanction of plant-wide rather than craft unions in the aluminum industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan 2 -- The memoirs of Harry S. Truman and a three-volume biography of Franklin D. Roosevelt headed a list of 200 books presented today to President Eisenhower for the White House library.
TOKYO, Jan. 2 -- Emperor Hirohito acknowledged the personal homage of thousands of his subjects at the Imperial Palace today in spite of occasional chilly rain.

DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 3 -- A taunting speech today by an Opposition member in Pakistan's National Assembly made it clear how tenuously the six-party Government coalition was holding on. It led to some embarrassing moments for Prime Minister Malik Firoz Khan Noon and gave him considerable cause for concern.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 -- An "economic merger" of the United States, the British Commonwealth and Western Europe, with this country as "senior partner," was proposed today.
The article of your distinguished correspondent M. S. Handler "Bonn Prosperity Stirs Uneasiness" in your issue of Dec. 29 discusses one of the most important problems of the new Germany.

The equipment manufacturing division of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., in East Paterson, N. J., has put in use a multiple-function automatic tester that makes possible thirty individual checks on wiring each minute.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 3 (AP) -- National Travelers Insurance Company and National Life Company, both with home offices in Des Moines, today announced their consolidation, effective as of Jan. 1.
HONG KONG, Jan. 3 -- Communist China claimed tonight the largest deposits of tungsten, tin and molybdenum of any country in the world and the third largest deposits of coal.

ROME, Jan. 3 -- Motorized policemen were called out today to quell demonstrations against Maria Callas, the prima donna who infuriated Rome's lovers of opera by walking out of the gala performance of Bellini's "Norma" last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The nation's atomic secrets were being taken out of Washington by the truckload today.
BALBOA, C. Z., Jan. 3 -- During the fiscal year of 1957, the Panama Canal collected about $3,000,000 in additional tolls as a result of the closing of the Suez Canal in October of 1956.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The six-man Civil Rights Commission was sworn in today and immediately got to work on its large and controversial assignment.
HONG KONG, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Communist China has rearrested Bishop Joseph Hu of Taichow and sentenced him and two priests to long prison terms, the Roman Catholic Sunday Examiner reported today.

DESPITE occasional evidence of his obvious powers as a flat designer, Leonid's new paintings of Far Eastern landscape, at Durlacher's, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, are a disappointment. His forte has always been the sophisticated stylization of a given scene so that it looks like itself as seen through art-nouveau spectacles, a style responsible for some effective canvases.
A child's anger should be respected, but not to the point of allowing him to smash vases and strike parents, a child psychologist warned recently.

ONE of the most quietly international if inconspicuous shops in New York is in the Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at Seventy-ninth Street, where you can buy jewelry, books, games, dolls, museum reproductions and objets d'art related to a diverse cross-section of countries and cultures.

Plans are nearing completion for the preview Tuesday of the fourth annual Winter Antiques Show. The benefit, sponsored by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Decorators, will benefit the East Side House Settlement.

City College's basketball team shattered Brooklyn College with a 10-point drive midway in the first half and went on to a 66-51 triumph before a capacity crowd of 1,200 at hte victors' Wingate Gymnasium last night.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Harriman was described by Republican legislative leaders today as inept, inefficient, vacillating, insincere, overly partisan and motivated by low-grade political expediency.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan urged last night that Congress adopt legislation to permit wiretapping by state law enforcement agencies.
HAVANA, Jan. 3 (UP) -- American tourists and Cubans shivered today in 55-degree temperatures in the wake of a twelve-hour storm that marooned guests in the newly opened Havana-Riviera Hotel.

LOGAN, Utah, Jan. 4 -- Executives of the nation's biggest aircraft manufacturers, shipyards, construction companies and even cereal makers are trekking thousands of miles to this tidy town of 15,000 in the lee of Utah's Wasatch Mountains.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 3 -- Sources close to Field Marshal Sarit Thanarat, Supreme Commander of Thailand's armed forces, said today he was planning to visit the United States as the guest of President Eisenhower as soon as health and politics permitted.

DETROIT, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today that this week's United States production would be 90,204 cars and trucks, compared with 92,290 units last week and 102,217 in the like week of last year.
ROME, Jan. 3 (UP) -- An opera official said today that Miss Callas' breakdown had been preceded by her celebrating New Year's Eve "without due precautions."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 3 Albert T. Scully and S. Turner Blanchard, candidates of the Taxpayers party seeking a recount in the Nov. 5 town election in Westport, today lost their suit in Superior Court.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 3 -- Eugene G. Blackford, chairman of the board of the Greenwich Publishing Company, today announced the sale of Greenwich Time to Gillespie Brothers, Inc., publishers of The Stamford Advocate.

When the New York Legislature convenes next week it should begin immediately a review of the Condon-Wadlin Law which, since 1947, has forbidden state and local employes of government to strike. The object of such a review should be to strengthen the law, make it more useful and effective, and prevent the official disregard for the law that has brought it into disrepute.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Top-seeded Bernard (Tut) Bartzen of Dallas had a close call and three seeded players were upset today in the Dixie tennis tournament.
BRISBANE, Australia, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Lew Hoad had his big game working to perfection tonight as he defeated Dick (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles in a hard-hitting four-set contest.
LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Workmen dug through centuries-old masonry today and uncovered the private riverside gateway used by the unpopular King Henry III to sneak into his Tower of London apartment.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 -- "Snob Hill," an original screen story by Ruth Brooks Flippen, has been acquired by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a starring property for Debbie Reynolds.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Ten bills affecting the powers and procedures of the state's public authorities were filed today for introduction in the 1958 Legislature.
The possibility of a grand jury investigation into the "bugging" by the Transit Authority of the headquarters and meeting places of the Motormen's Benevolent Association was indicated yesterday.
A mechanic who damaged two uranium slugs in a Long Island defense plant was placed on probation for eighteen months yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Three more Government statistical reports added details today to the picture of decline in the national economy.
TRENTON, Jan. 3 -- Unemployment in New Jersey is now greater than at any time since 1949 and the jobless figures of that year may soon be surpassed, a state official said today.

MADRID, Jan. 3 -- The visit here next week of Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, United States Army Chief of Staff, will coincide with a period of intense readjustment now being considered by Spanish military leaders.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Top-seeded Jean McCormick of Boston and the three other seeded competitors won second-round victories today at the opening of the women's New England squash racquets championship.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 3 -- A huge radio telescope that will follow the sun by day and catch signals from outer space by night will be built next June by night will be built, starting in June, for the University of Michigan.

Sitting can be as uncomfortable as standing, if there's enough of it, so the Hyster Company of Portland, Ore., wanted the best and the most comfortable seat design for its expanding line of lift trucks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Schick, Inc., of Lancaster, Pa., today filed with the Federal Trade Commission a general denial that its marketing of electric shavers was in any way illegal.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Britain's gold and dollar reserves recorded another substantial gain last month.

GEORGE COHEN is presenting his first exhibition in New York at the Charles Alan Gallery, 766 Madison Avenue. An instructor at Northwestern University, Cohen is also a versatile artist whose floating fancies are caught up in smile-provoking symbols, and whose originality shines through in the most unlikely places.

Paoli Rosi, lightweight boxer from Rieti, Italy, defeated Johnny Busso, East Side warrior, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The decision in favor of Rosi, who now lives in the Bronx, was by majority vote.

The Fulton Bag and Cotton Mills of Atlanta has sold two of its remaining three major plants to a new corporation owned by Charles Sammons, president of the Reserve Life Insurance Company of Dallas, it was learned yesterday.
Evidence has been found that modern electronic computers may be able to "learn" from experience and get things done without being told exactly how.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Department of the Interior estimated today that crude oil production in the United States this year would average 7,037,000 barrels a day, 1.8 per cent less than in 1957.
EVEN after he had shared with Tenzing Norkay the triumphant ascent of Mount Everest on May 29, 1953, Edmund Percival Hillary of Auckland, N. Z., gave his occupation as bee-keeper.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Grain futures ended sharply higher on the Board of Trade today.
Two Washington Heights apartment houses, where a retaining wall collapsed early Christmas morning, were completely evacuated yesterday by order of the Department of Buildings.

MOSCOW, Jan. 3 -- The first organized display of American goods in the Soviet Union next August presumably will be entirely private, organized by American business men with the cooperation of the Soviet Union and without the participation of the United States Government.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 3 -- A fifty-six-knot northwestern gale ripped Nassau today, smashing small sailing vessels, tearing up electrical installations, uprooting tall palm trees and disrupting traffic.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Hugh Bryson, a former maritime labor leader who was convicted of falsely swearing that he had no connection with the Communist party, lost an appeal for a reduction of his five-year sentence today.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad has created a new executive position, vice president for operations, and bestowed the office on Charles C. Shannon.

Fresh flowers, though they are the tonic of the winter season, have a great tendency to crumple under the steam of the radiator. Bouquets beginning to sag can get a refresher from the addition of any one of the assortment of artificial blooms now available.

Events today: Gounod's "Faust," Metropolitan Opera House, 2 o'clock; Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; Mozart's "Don Giovanni," Ansonia Opera Circle, Carnegie Hall, Chapter Room, 8:30; "The Play of Daniel," The Cloisters of the Metropolitan Museum of Art 2:30 and 4.
CINILLICOTHE, Mo., Jan. 3 (AP) -- There will be no new year -- no tomorrow -- for Belin Memorial University, whose founder once said he felt the Lord had called upon him to start it.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Harriman will make another attempt this year to get his Administration's labor program through a hostile Republican Legislature.
A fairly large number of old vessels appear to be headed for the scrap heap this year. And, indications are that they will bring a good price.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 3 -- New Delhi's annual political tourism season began today when a Soviet-built jet plane landed at Palam airport. The plane brought Viliam Siroky, Premier of Czechoslovakia, who will tour India for two weeks. Accompanying him were nine officials, including Vaclav David, Minister of Foreign Affairs.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- College baseball coaches, still irked over major league raiding of players, turned their attention today to semi-pro summer baseball for college athletes.
Negotiations for a new contract for 25,500 employes of the long lines division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company proved fruitless yesterday. But they will be resumed at 1 P. M. today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Senator James E. Murray, Democrat of Montana, today termed "grossly misleading" an Administration mineral production report that reported an increase in output last year.

If the city gives up its steam-producing plant for Bellevue hospital a proposed rate increase for about twenty other municipal buildings may not be necessary, according to Lewis E. Frank, assistant general manager of steam operations at the Consolidated Edison Company.

VIENNA, Jan. 3 (Reuters) -- The Government has started investigating charges of espionage, made by Vienna newspapers, against Jozsef Hamori, a member of the Hungarian Legation here, an Austrian Government spokesman said tonight.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 3 (Reuters) -- Thunderous applause and ten curtain calls tonight greeted the premiere of Francoise Sagan's new ballet, "Rendezvous Manque" (Broken Date).
COLUMBUS, Ga., Jan. 3 (UP) -- A policeman has been charged with murder in the death of a Negro minister who died from a beating received while in jail.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Senator Henry C. Dworshak, Republican of Idaho, called on the Administration today to demand that Great Britain use some of its "surplus" tax money this year "to pay its debt, rather than on a tax cut for British citizens."

One hundred thousand square feet in the Lincoln Circle Terminal in North Bergen, N. J., have been leased for twenty years by the Swift Line Transfer Company and the General Warehouse Company, affiliate concerns engaged in warehousing and distribution.

Adolescent day centers to provide the attention and guidance that some youngsters do not receive from their parents were proposed here yesterday by a Maryland psychiatrist.

MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (Canadian Press) -- The annual international joint sessions of representatives of the Great Lakes shipping industry are to be held Jan. 20 to 23 at the Seigniory Club, Montebello, Que.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Jan. 3 -- The Town Board of Clarkstown will meet here next week to decide what to do about its tax muddle. John W. Coyle, newly elected Supervisor, said the board probably would have to hire extra help.
IF there were any truth in the proposition that fishing is the contemplative sport it would be ice fishing that would attract the heavy thinkers.

Commissioner Ford C. Frick was believed yesterday to have gained another signal victory in his efforts to keep New York listed as "open territory" should the National League at any future time seek to establish another baseball club here.

The spiked-shoe set will be off and racing today in the first major meet of the 1958 indoor track and field campaign. It's the annual championship carnival of the Amateur Athletic Union's Metropolitan Association.

WARSAW, Jan. 3 -- Mao Tse-tung's projected visit to Poland is still only postponed from the official standpoint. But there are few if any expectations here that it will take place at all.

Y. A. Tittle, the San Francisco Forty-Niner quarterback who led six successful rallies in the final minutes of games in 1957, was named the National Football League player of the year yesterday in The United Press poll.

EPIPHANY, celebrated this Monday to commemorate the coming of the Magi, is no longer the occasion for the bountiful feasts of several generations ago. But the English custom of serving at that time Twelfth Cake, also called Twelfth Night, or Day, Cake, is too delightful to be forgotten.

The Rambler American, the shortest by thirty inches of any 1958 automobile manufactured in this country, will go on sale here this month. The manufacturer, the American Motors Corporation, said the auto would have the "lowest advertised delivered price of any United States-built car."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, asked the District Court at New York today to nullify an Interstate Commerce Commission decision in a cotton freight rate case.
Dick Clark may become the American Broadcasting Company's candidate to oppose the National Broadcasting Company's Perry Como starting next month.
Howard Rushmore shot and killed his estranged wife and then killed himself after an argument in a moving taxicab on Lexington Avenue at 102d Street last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A ruling was made formal today that special training and care for the mentally and physically handicapped were deductible as a medical expense on income tax returns.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Senate majority leader told a news conference today that the issues of national defense and foreign policy would have highest priorities after the second session of the Eighty-fifth Congress convened Tuesday.

Bobby Fischer, the 14-year-old national open champion, was back in first place last night in the United States title tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club after winning his adjourned tenth-round game from William Lombardy.
If Alexander H. Cohen follows through with his multiple theatrical plans scheduled for this year, he should be consistently busier than a mailman during Christmas time.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The stock market improved today under the lead of British Government securities. Trading volume and price movements remained small, however.

Roald Amundsen of Norway and Capt. Robert Falcon Scott of Britain led the only two previous expeditions to reach the South Pole by the overland route. They accomplished their journeys forty-six years ago.

John Winthrop, twelve times Governor of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, is the subject of a biographical study by Edmund S. Morgan entitled "The Puritan Dilemma." The author draws "some unusual conclusions" from his analysis of Winthrop, showing "the strength and weakness of Puritanism" as depicted by Winthrop's seeking to lead a godly life.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 3 -- Eighteen Venezuelan rebels who fled to Colombia yesterday were still in custody of the Colombian intelligence service today in the Caribbean port of Barranquilla, according to the national headquarters of the service.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- The French deficit in the European Payments Union in December was only $17,649,000 as compared with $30,000,000 in November and $39,000,000 in December, 1956. The union is the clearing house for debts on current account among seventeen European nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- A secret helicopter landing site has been established near Vice President Richard M. Nixon's home. It would evacuate him within minutes of notice of a surprise missile attack.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 3 -- The opening of the Connecticut Turnpike yesterday was followed today by some traffic woes here. During the afternoon rush hour a total of 1,656 cars used the Yankee Doodle Bridge at the turnpike, spanning the Norwalk River and linking the east and west sides of the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Claims that may total $5,000,000 piled up today against the proprietor of an army-navy store here. Albert Gershman, 33 years old, will face a hearing Monday on charges of swindling investors.

The Roman Catholic Missionary Society of St. Paul the Apostle, better known as the Paulist Fathers, will observe its centennial year throughout 1958.

Sales of the eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area for the last month of 1957 were 5 per cent higher on the average than those of December, 1956, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times. WELLINGTON, N. Z., Jan 3 (UP) -- The fact that Dr. Fuchs was over-all leader of the Commonwealth's two polar expeditions was emphasized today in a cable from New Zealand's Prime Minister, Walter Nash.

Market values of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose almost $2,600,000,000 yesterday as optimism swept almost every sector of the list.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The State Department told Indonesian officials today that the United States Government did not mean to imply in a recent press release that Indonesia's campaign against the Dutch was Communist-inspired.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 3 -- One family here thinks that the real spirit of Christmas lingered long past the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that the board end its investigation of possible dual control of Trans World Airlines and Northeast Airlines by Howard R. Hughes.

Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed mostly higher yesterday in generally quiet trading. Cocoa, zinc, copper, coffee, potatoes, and cottonseed oil rose; hides were mixed, and price movements for rubber, sugar and wool declined.
