CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Feature Double, scoring his first victory in four starts this winter, found the sloppy track to his liking as he took the seventh race today at Tropical Park.

Today's new film is "Trouble for Father," a Greek-made comedy with music, at the Cameo Theatre. Vasilis Logothepidis and Ylia Livycou head the cast of Peter S. Melleas' Olympus Production. A. Sakelarios directed the import, which has English titles and is being distributed by William Melleas-Greek Motion Pictures, Inc.

When Sir Edmund Percival Hillary, New Zealand bee-keeper, scaled the final heights of Mount Everest on May 29, 1953, he reached the top of the world -- the first man, along with his Sherpa guide, to do so. Yesterday, after crossing 1,200 miles of Antarctic snow and ice, he reached the bottom of the world -- the first man to do so by land in nearly a half century.
Our country owes an enormous debt to Frank C. Nash, who died Dec. 11 at the age of 47.
OSWEGO, N. Y., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Vincent A. Corsall, dismissed yesterday as a high school science teacher after he became Mayor of this city, charged tonight that politics had motivated the discharge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A Polish scientist, Dr. Jerzy Leon Nowinski, has asked for and received asylum in the United States, Attorney General William P. Rogers announced today. Dr. Nowinski, a specialist in thermoelasticity, is expected to assist the United States missile, program.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 3 -- Robert L. Bennett, medical director of the Warm Springs Foundation, demonstrated today the way in which intricate techniques worked out here in treatment and rehabilitation of poliomyelitis patients had been extended to twenty-five types of crippling diseases.

Opening of envelopes containing bills and reading the totals therein can he a grim business, and at least one suburban hardware store tries to make the arrivals of monthly bills colorful and stimulating affairs.
ANOTHER attack on the Federal chemical - spray program for insect control and its effect on wildlife has been broadcast, this time by the National Audubon Society.

Your "Slapstick in Cairo" editorial (Dec. 28) on the so-called Asian-African Peoples Solidarity Conference justifiably characterizes the Communist-dominated meeting as "ominous." But news dispatches which have treated this Soviet demonstration as a recent development are rather wide of the mark.
In a report made public by Mayor Wagner yesterday, the Juvenile Delinquency Evaluation Project renewed its recommendation against expansion of the city's system of "600" schools at this time.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -Congress returns next week to face six months of fateful effort.
In your issue of Dec. 22 Thomas G. Barnes implied that a student's education depends for its quality not primarily on time spent studying, but on the quality of the institution.

Margaret C. Shea, secretary of the New York City Commission for the Foster Care of Children, has been named director of the Bureau of Child Welfare by Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy. She succeeds James R. Dumpson, who was recently appointed first deputy commissioner of the Welfare Department.

A spectacular triple victory by New York University's Mike Herman, a feat previously unmatched in the half-century history of the meet, marked the indoor track and field championships of the Amateur Athletic Union's Metropolitan Association.

The last week of 1957 saw two significant developments in the field of atomic power, each marking an important step toward the goal of producing electricity from the atom at a cost competitive with power produced from conventional fuels.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 -California democrats hope to achieve next week-end some of the unity that the Republicans have been boasting about.

THIS week, appropriately at the outset of the New Year, Carl Sandburg celebrates his eightieth birthday. At 80, the poet walks with a bright step, talks with a crisp wisdom, sees with an innocent and unwavering eye. Each year, so it seems, America's great poet is reborn, the capacity of heart and vitality of mind unspent and even undiminished.

Higher prices for orange concentrate and fresh vegetables and fruits from Florida can be expected for some weeks to come. Prices for such products have risen chiefly as a result of the freeze in the Sunshine State on Dec. 11 and 12.
The weakness of petroleum-product prices has reached the stage where a general cut in crude oil prices seems likely.
The oldest canning company in the United States, the William Underwood Company of Watertown, Mass., yesterday elected its youngest president, George C. Seybolt, who is 43 years old.

Twenty-six newspaper circulation executives from nineteen states and Ontario, Canada, will discuss methods of increasing newspaper sales at a two-week seminar beginning tomorrow at the American Press Institute, Columbia University.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 4 -Because of the press of work in the new session of Congress, President Eisenhower is considering withdrawing from a scheduled part in Republican plans to open the 1958 political campaign.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Hoop Band, an 8-1 shot, outraced ten other thoroughbreds today in the $23,400 Robert E. Lee Handicap at Tropical Park. The winner ran the mile and a sixteenth in 1:42 1/5 over a fast track.

LAST week in television brought merciful relief from the excessive observance of Christmas, an impressive documentary on Marian Anderson's goodwill tour, several comprehensive news summaries, a superficial study of the film industry and a jazz show designed for squares.

Two Wall Street economists analyzed the current business recession yesterday at a luncheon forum in the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street. They agreed that the moderate contraction in business activity that set in last year would persist in the first six months of this year.
Plans to convert a Liberty type vessel to carry ore concentrates in slurry, or liquid form have been announced here by the Freeport Sulphur Company.

Federal employes generally are protected from summary dismissal by laws setting up procedures for hearings and appeals. In 1950 an act of Congress established exceptions by authorizing summary dismissal of employes in eleven "sensitive" agencies, such as the Defense and State Departments, and the President was empowered to apply the act to other agencies "in the best interests of national security."

Part of the fun of being a pleasure boat owner is having arguments. There is something about becoming a skipper that gives you a license to wrangle long and loud in the club grill or, if your voice is raucous enough, out in the storage yard where the half-gales of wind whistle by.
The feminine touch may be detected in the decor of the St. Regis barber shop, but since women are barred from its precincts, the designer never has seen the result of her handiwork.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, the Army's Chief of Research and Development, disclosed tonight that he had decided to retire from the Army.
Long service with the American Export Lines has ended for John Wright Sr., a vice president of the steamship company. Four other members of the line have also retired.

RECENTLY this department has discussed two significant trends in bridge: The rapid growth of tournament bridge, causing overwhelming attendance at the big tournaments; and the vast improvement in the techniques of bridge-by-television, which bids fair to make bridge a spectator sport for the first time in its long history.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 4 -- An agreement between the United States Internal Revenue Service and the Minnesota State Department of Taxation will increase state income tax revenues by $1,000,000 in the current biennium, it was predicted today.

Tickets are still available for the Jan. 20 benefit performance of "The Music Man." Mrs. Darwin R. James 3d and Mrs. Ralph Peters Jr. are chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the event, which will aid the Speedwell Society.

Close inspection of the cables, girders and general construction of the Brooklyn Bridge is not illegal. But it gives some persons the wrong idea, G. Van Der Sman, a Canadian civil engineer, found to his dismay yesterday.

A PHILADELPHIA Quaker, Catharine Morris Wright up in one of those vanishing communities that combined a high level of culture and literacy with the more common American virtues of probity, self-reliance and public spirit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The rising attitude in Congress for a single commander of the armed forces was decried today as a road to "national suicide" by the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Congressional year that opens Tuesday will put the severest strain yet on President Eisenhower's capacity for leadership. This is a compound of election year politics, of his own declining prestige, and of a sober conflict of viewpoint between the White House and the Democratically controlled Congress over how much urgency needs to be employed to recapture this nation's advantage in the world race for military and political pre-eminence.

IN 1754, shortly before the French and Indian War, six members of the James Johnson family of Township No. 4 (now Charlestown, N. H.) were carried away to Canada in an Indian raid. Mrs. Susanna Johnson, valiant wife and mother, kept a diary; it was published in 1807, and is the basis of this superior historical romance.

BONN, Jan. 4 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer celebrates his eighty-second birthday and ninth year of power tomorrow, encouraged on all sides to try for the biggest political prize -- a Western settlement with the Soviet Union.

The advent of the Soviet satellites would very well show the way to a much-needed reappraisal of the American system of education, according to the Educational Policies Commission. The commission issued last week a detailed study intended to reassure the nation that its educational system has all the necessary basic elements.

THE new session of the New York State Legislature, which will start Wednesday noon, is scheduled to receive a proposal to make a living museum and tourist attraction out of a mile or two of the old Erie Canal.

WHEN Edward Weston, generally acknowledged as America's greatest photographer, died at his home in Carmel, Calif., last week, photography lost its best representative among the arts, for Weston was esteemed by artists in other fields as a kindred spirit.
An hour-to-hour peace persisted yesterday on the long-distance lines of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

WHAT is entertainment on the stage?, a reader inquires of this department. After seeing "West Side Story" and listening repeatedly to the recording. he is satisfied that it "possesses the universality of true art." Everything about it -- theme, music, choreography -- seems to him extraordinarily eloquent.

BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, Jan. 4 -- Venezuelan prisons were filled this week-end with military officers and others suspected of having been "enemies of peace" in the brief insurrection that was crushed two days ago.
Tomorrow one of the biggest single retailing events of 1958 will begin in New York City.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Army announced today the award of $51,800,000 in contracts to the Chrysler Corporation to speed production of ballistic missiles.

TWO huge and appropriately festive sets of jazz recordings, rich and varied as holiday fruit cakes, have just been added to the already staggering quantity of jazz disks. One is the twelve-disk series culled from the reminiscences-with-illustrations set down by the late Jelly Roll Morton for the Library of Congress and now reissued by Riverside.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 -- Federal officials asserted today that 700 and possibly as many as 900 persons of Chinese ancestry had been proved to be in this country illegally.

FROM Rosita's cascaron shower at the carnival in Peru to Kwan Ling's Chinese fireworks on the Moon's Birthday, children make merry in Alma Reck's festive little collection of ten holidays. In Rome, Beppo and Maria compete in the Piazza with shouts, whistles and trumpets to see who can make the most noise at the Fair of Befana on January 5, the Eve of Epiphany.
THE issue over whether a flight engineer in a jet plane should or should not be a qualified pilot in addition to his other qualifications threatens to make trouble for this country's airlines.

ALTHOUGH it may be said in all fairness that the New York Film Critics are a group of sixteen rather stubborn individuals, it is notable that it didn't take them long to agree that the best motion picture of 1957 was "The Bridge on the River Kwai."

AS the authors of "How to Have a Show" point out, there are few better methods of raising money or of providing fun and entertainment than putting on an amateur show. With a fine appreciation of the pleasures and problems involved, Jeanne Bendick and Barbara Berk have outlined how to present all types of productions, from charades to circuses, white elephant sales to puppetry.

The year 1957 was a busy one for the New York office of the Securities and Exchange Commission. In fact, Paul Windels Jr., the regional administrator, said last week: "Statistically 1957 was our busiest year in the courts."

One of the most efficient push-button railroads in the world is now on exhibit at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia, grinding and snaking its way around 1,000 feet of miniature track. Put into operation a short while ago, the system is called the "Penn-reading" in honor of the two full-sized railroads, the Pennsylvania and the Reading, that sponsored its construction.

ON Dec. 4, 1955, David Sarnoff made a television appearance to announce all the brave plans for the new opera company that had been formed by the Radio Corporation of America and the National Broadcasting Company.

NINETY minutes of carefully planned children's programs are basic each Monday through Saturday on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's national television network. Sunday there is one hour of such programing.

STUART, Fla. -- The dedication last week of the new causeway and bridges spanning the St. Lucie and Indian Rivers from the Stuart area to Hutchinson Island opened up a sparsely inhabited fifteen-mile-long strip as a resort area.

THE first major novelty of the New Year will be the American debut of Inbal, Dance Theatre of Israel, tomorrow at 8 at the Martin Beck Theatre. It will play there for three weeks and then set out on tour, under the management of S. Hurok and the sponsorship of the America-Israel Cultural Foundation.

A VETERAN observer in the Groves of Academe, Stringfellow Barr has bitter and hilarious things to say about American college education. They make this sadistically satirical novel both funny and appalling.

THE revision in the method of clearing passengers' baggage at the New York docks announced by Collector of Customs Robert W. Dill has two main purposes: to bring order into the inspection of baggage and to avoid any possibility of favoritism by customs agents on behalf of any arriving passenger.
IN the usual welter of Christmas productions, an enormously successful and quite undistinguished theatrical year has come to an end.
The St. John's University basketball team was still unbeaten and considered still untested at the end of the basketball program at Madison Square Garden last night.

WELL, they're over now. both the holidays and that old year. The books that nestled beneath the Christmas tree have been put into the cases, their donors have been thanked. Also, all of the books of 1957 have been put away.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 -- San Francisco's labor leaders pledged a fight last night against Senator William F. Knwoland's candidacy for Governor of California and his espousal of "right-to-work" legis-legislation.

In his article "How the Analyst Stands the Pace" (Nov. 24), Morton M. Hunt brackets the psychiatric technique developed by the late Dr. Wilhelm Reich together with such "dubious" practices as "dianetics auditing, love-making and the like."
HONG KONG, Jan. 4 -- The Chinese Communist regime has adopted to a limited extent the Yugoslav practice of enabling workers to participate in the management of enterprises.

WHEN Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney organized a party at the old Whitney Studio Club more than fifty years ago, or when she staged an impromptu exhibition, it was usually with the intention of finding a discreet means of helping to sustain the living American artist.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- Observers here believe that efforts to establish closer ties between Iran and the Soviet Union have resulted in more cordial relations than at any time in the last few decades.
" THE amateurs have always crowded the highways to everywhere." says narrator Frank Hughes. "so it's never been easy for the pros to get through."

The theatre benefit commit-I tee for Cancer Care of the National Cancer Foundation, which is arranging for the Thursday performance of "The Music Man," has reported an excellent response. A few tickets remain. They may be obtained at Cancer Care, 37 East Sixty-eighth Street.
TROUBLE, trouble, nothing but toil and trouble. That seems to be the fix in which Joseph Papp repeatedly finds himself with his free New York Shakespeare Festival, now in the Heckscher Theatre.

CAIRO, Jan. 3 -- Professional Kremlin-inspired peace front organizers made important contacts in Cairo this week with scores of prospective converts and supporters from the deserts, mountains and jungles of Africa and the seething Middle East.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Soviet bloc's economic offensive in under-developed areas is being carefully planned and skillfully executed.
SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 30 -- El Salvador appears to be giving increasing consideration to the idea of seeking markets for coffee -- it's the nation's chief product -- behind the Iron Curtain.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- The development of political issues for next fall's state campaign appeared to be the main concern of both Republicans and Democrats today as they prepared for the legislative session that opens next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -A predominantly Protestant organization called today on potential Roman Catholic candidates for President or Vice President to take a definite stand for or against what it said were the following:

IF the reluctant reception accorded Governor Harriman's traffic-safety program by his newly appointed Citizens Council is any criterion, traffic reforms in this state will encounter some rough going when they come before the Legislature, which opens its sessions this week.
ROME, Sunday, Jan. 5 -- Maria Callas has offered to sing this week in the opera house where she walked out on the opening night performance last Thursday. She was turned down.
The Dominican Republic has opened a major shipyard in the Caribbean, commodious enough to accommodate most of the world's modern dry cargo vessels.

Contracts with salary figures totaling close to $500,000 have just been dropped into the mails by the Yankees. The last batch, according to Lee MacPhail, the Bombers' assistant general manager, went yesterday and the complete sum could well be a record.

U. N. Secretary General Hammarskjold. speaking at a press conference last Thursday, hit on a good phrase when he was asked whether any meetings on disarmament would be held "under the aegis of the United Nations." He said, "It is natural that there is a stage of groping in diplomatic operations of this type."
LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- High-altitude winds reaching 200 miles an hour roared eastward over the Atlantic today, pushing European-bound airliners to a batch of new records.
AS if young parents learning the ways of their first baby didn't always have tough days now and then, once in a while a statistic pops up to make life seem even more complicated. Item:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 -Princeton defeated the University of Pennsylvania, 80 -- 68, in the opening Ivy League basketball game for both teams before 3,776 fans in the first game of a Palestra double-header tonight.

NEWARK, Jan. 4 -- The 58-year-old secretary-treasurer of the Suburban Police Bowling League was free in $500 bail today to await a hearing Monday in Magistrates Court on a charge of stealing from the mails.

The moonwatchers kept a death vigil on Sputnik I last week. Soviet Premier Bulganin said to reporters on Friday, "For all I know it may have burned out already." In three months the first earth satellite had circled the globe more than 1,300 times and traveled some 35,000,000 miles.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Contractors building the United States part of the St. Lawrence Seaway are disputing subsoil specifications prepared by Army engineers.

THE 5 per cent increase in rail passenger fares granted to eleven Eastern railroads by the Interstate Commerce Commission went into effect last week. The roads are Central of New Jersey; Chicago South Shore, and South Bend; Lehigh Valley; Monon: New Jersey and New York; New York Central; Pennsylvania; Pittsburgh and Lake Erie; Pennsylvania-Reading-Seashore; the Reading; and the Wabash.

FC. SCHANG'S answer to to Ross Parmenter should not stand unchallenged. Too much is at stake for too many people and too little has been said publicly on the subject of the organized audience business. Mr. Schang and his colleagues of Community and Civic concerts cannot be allowed to pretend their "wonderful scheme," as Mr. Schang puts it, is the "one big ray of light" for the young soloists of these United States.

STORRS, Conn., Jan. 4 -- Manhattan basketball team broke into an early lead and held it throughout to defeat Connecticut, 62 -- 57, before a sellout crowd of 4,500 fans tonight. The victory was the sixth in nine starts for Manhattan.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Britain's cotton textile industry is worried. This is nothing new, for the position of the industry has been deteriorating steadily. But several new factors have deepened the apprehension.

Public investment funds managed by the State of New Jersey held $720,069,924 of securities in twenty-seven accounts as of the end of the fiscal year ended June 30, according to a report by the State Investment Council.

THE National Seed Storage -- a specialized building where seed stocks will be preserved for future use -- is now under construction on the campus of Colorado State University at Fort Collins, Colo. The structural framework should be completed by July 1.

OCALA, Fla. -- At one time this north central Florida city had little to offer tourists except Silver Springs, six miles to the east, and Rainbow Springs, twenty-four miles to the west. Today it has become one of the busiest tourist spots in the state with many added attractions, not the least of which are the horse breeding farms in this (Marion) county.

In her interesting article on the new office buildings going up in Manhattan Ada Louise Huxtable, in "Park Avenue School of Architecture" (Dec. 15). refers briefly to the single most serious obstacle to good architecture in New York: that obstacle is the antiquated zoning resolution with its complicated setback provisions which force almost every tall New York building into the shape of a deformed ziggurat.

THE fate-line in the palm of Van Wyck Brooks has been read more publicly than that of any other living American critic. In his youth, the period of "America's Coming-of-Age," he was plainly destined to be a literary radical. Later, in the period of "The Flowering of New England," he veered toward something else.

THE success of "Sunrise Semester," an educational program offering lectures on great literature, has prompted WCBS-TV to attempt a commercial book program titled "Have You Read?" The proposed half-hour program would be conducted by Dr. Floyd Zulli Jr., who also does "Sunrise Semester," and be presented on Sunday afternoons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- A Federal judge issued a temporary restraining order today that had the effect of holding up the Government's efforts to have the United Electrical Workers Union declared Communist-infiltrated.

Ticker tape kept Walter L. Morgan busy last fall.

In his recent letter Mr. Schang referred to the "crying need for more and better concert opportunities for the soloist." He went on to show what Community Concerts does to fill part of this need by providing nearly 5,000 annual concert opportunities.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 3 -- A total of 8,986 ships arrived at Hampton Roads ports during 1957, establishing a record in port activity. The volume was spurred by a record of 60,674,170 tons of coal exported during the year.

The American merchant marine faces several threats to its prosperity in 1958, in the opinion of Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute. There is a delicate balance between advance and decline, he added last week.

MENLO PARK, Calif., Jan. 4 -- The Stanford Research Institute has analyzed the performance of the Soviet Union in speeding scientific and technological development and is proposing a means of matching it.

Fordham's basketball team snapped a three-game losing string last night by routing Columbia, 103 -- 79, at the Fordham gymnasium. A crowd of 2,000 saw the thirty-third meeting between the intra - city rivals.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 4 -Dartmouth started its Ivy League basketball season by trouncing Yale, last year's champion, 82 -- 70, tonight in Alumni Gymnasium. Rudy LaRusso, a 6-foot 6-inch junior forward from Brooklyn, was the Indians' mainstay, pumping in 22 points and hauling down twenty-one rebounds.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Republican legislative leaders called on Governor Harriman today to cooperate with them in the new legisative session to solve critical problems facing the state. The Legislature opens on Wednesday.
COURSES in landscape painting and flower and vegetable gardening will begin this week at the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park. Advance registration is necessary.
A thirty-ton trailer-truck, its driver dead, crashed into a dry-cleaning shop on First Avenue yesterday. Four persons were injured.
Frank Lane, dynamic general manager of the Cleveland Indians, conferred with Lee MacPhail, assistant general manager of the Yankees, yesterday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 4 -- The Soviet Army and Navy were told today to remember Stalin's morale-building pronouncements in World War II because they had not lost their importance.
Out of town buyers have been converging on New York for the year's biggest season, the spring apparel lines opening this week.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- Joe Santore, 10 years old, and his fellow members of Class 5-D at the Daniel Webster School here have reecived official acknowledgment of their gift of $2.01 to the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- After opening up a comfortable first-half lead, Colgate had to stave off a spirited bid in the closing minutes before defeating the Army quintet, 79 to 77, in the field house today. Connecting with 40 per cent of their shots in the first half, the Red Raiders raced to an 47-31 margin at the intermission.
John Joseph Toohy is the ideal occupant of the job he holds, general manager of the E. R. Squibb Sons division of the $600,000,000 Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The perennial foes in the atomic energy field -- the Atomic Energy Commission and the Democrats on the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy -- are starting off their battle this year on an unusual note of harmony.

ABURLY, quarrelsome, blue-eyed South African, Roy Campbell made large claims for himself as a man of action: big-game hunter, shark-fisher, bull-fighter, horseman, sailor, soldier, and circus-performer. He wrote that he counted on his life, which had been bang-full of physical kicks and shocks, ending with a bang, not with a whimper.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 4 -- A motorist can save himself only fifteen minutes by using the new Connecticut Turnpike for the trip between the New York State line here and Providence -- or so a trial round trip

THE second guess is infallible. It's the first guess that gets guys into trouble. So here are some first guesses as to what will happen in sports for the coming year. Then this Fearless Forecaster will hop into his trusty, ol' space ship and go racing around the world like sputnik or John Foster Dulles.

This past week the nation's leaders in the fight against poliomyelitis met at the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation to commemorate the twentieth anniversary of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis by dedicating a polio Hall of Fame honoring seventeen men and women who had played leading roles in the fight against polio.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 4 -- Indonesia accused the Netherlands today of seeking to apply both military pressure and economic sanctions against her in reprisal for the anti-Dutch drive here.

Physicists of the United States Army Signal Engineering Laboratories at Fort Monmouth, N. J., have explored the weather to an altitude of sixty miles, the Department of the Army announced last week. The readings were made in a series of five summer rocket firings in connection with the International Geophysical Year.

THE question of who holds the shadow and who holds the substance of power in the entourage of a President is as old as the Presidency itself. But for all its reoccurrence, there are significant differences in accent when the question is asked.

Since World War II the United States has made foreign aid. both economic and military, a major instrument of its foreign policy. As the State Department report on Soviet foreign aid last week shows vividly, however, the United States is now facing vigorous competition from a major Soviet program in this field, one being conducted with considerable subtlety and effectiveness.

After a brief holiday lull the art season resumes its activities with a flood of new exhibitions this week. Artists of Europe, Asia and America are represented in the many group and one-man shows, with the names of many well-known contemporaries appearing among the exhibitors.
Some economists believe that an increase in homebuilding in 1958 could be the determining factor in bringing the United States out of the business recession into which it has begun to turn.

WASHINGTON (Science Service) -- The need for large doses of pain-killing narcotics for badly burned patients has been eliminated by the use of electrically charged ions, according to Dr. Theodore A. David, Northeastern Hospital, Philadelphia, Pa.

SHREWD shoppers of the New York trading area know R. H. Macy Co. as a glittering bazaar filled with desirable merchandise. Readers of the metropolitan gazettes know Macy's as a sprightly user of white space, happily jousting with its neighbor, Gimbels.

Although Paul Keres, a Soviet grand master, adjourned his fifth-round game with Dr. S. Fazekas, England, at the annual chess congress in Hastings, England, he retained first place with a score of 3 1/2 -- 1/2, according to a report from London yesterday.

The first session of the Eighty-fifth Congress came to an end eighteen weeks ago. Its preoccupations had been budget-cutting and stamping "Made on Capitol Hill" on the relatively few of President Eisenhower's proposals it approved.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The overriding fact in Washington today is that President Eisenhower and his Administration must govern the country for over three more years.
SOUTH POLE, Jan. 4 -- "I came to the pole." Sir Edmund Hillary said today, "because I wanted to come to the pole. Some people have to have a scientific reason. Not me."

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 30 -- Fifty Korean traders are making a renewed effort to collect from the United States Government monies they lost on dollar purchases when the hwan was revalued from 180 to $1 up to 500 to $1 on Aug. 15, 1955.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 4 -President Eisenhower's home town is trying to keep its place in history, but is not sure whether to look forward or backward.

Twilight Concerts presented a program of chamber music at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon, a highlight of which was the first New York performance of Paul Hindemith's 1949 Sonata for Contrabass and Piano.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -The German Embassy said today that five United States educators and five music critics were scheduled to leave Jan. 12 for a visit to Germany as guests of the German Government.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- On several fronts now the Soviet Union is maneuvering for a new relationship with the United States.
Makers of giant computers have become part-time school teachers.
The Internal Revenue Service here announced yesterday that telephone aid to taxpayers would again be stressed during this income tax season.

FOR spraying paint, shellac or varnish over toys, models or other small objects, an ordinary insecticide spray gun will often do the trick. Use the type which has a pumping action that maintains a steady pressure inside the tank or cup.

I HAVE perhaps an odd complaint. I think the critics are too kind. At least in certain cases. They can pan a play, but they always say they are sorry for Shirley Booth or Ethel Merman or Beatrice Lillie if they do not have a role worthy of their talents.

Construction of a new Iranian Embassy in Washington, D. C., is expected to begin late this summer. The one-and-a-half story brick and stone structure will be erected on property adjacent to the present embassy at 3005 Massachusetts Avenue, N. W.

WITHIN the last year at least three historical novels made capital out of the fact that more women were executed for witchcraft in the century of the philosopher - mathematician Sir Isaac Newton (1642-1727) than at any other time in history. This novel of seventeenth- century England has its hackneyed black witch.

The police closed their investigation yesterday of the deaths of Howard Rushmore and his wife, Frances. Mr. Rushmore shot and killed his wife in a taxicab at Lexington Avenue and 102d Street at 7:05 P. M. Friday. Then he turned the revolver to his head and killed himself.
PEIPING, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- In at least two stores on Peiping's main shopping thorough-fare there are hats for sale that cost the equivalent of about $300 -- and these are hats for men.
MONTREAL, Dec. 31 -- Concern for the traffic volume in 1958 was voiced today in a year-end message by Gordon R. McGregor, president of Trans-Canada Air Lines.

WITH "The Brothers Karamazov" only recently behind him, Richard Brooks has taken on another typical writing-directing assignment for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. This is the Tennessee Williams play, "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof." George Cukor had studied its movie prospects at the invitation of Lawrence Weingarten, producer, and decided that it wasn't his dish.
MONTREAL, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Bert Olmstead scored a goal in the final minute tonight to give the Montreal Canadians a 2-1 victory over Detroit as Sid Abel made his coaching debut with the Red Wings.
LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Manchester Guardian commented today that "compulsory medical examinations clearly would not help" prevent sick political leaders from damaging their countries' interests.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Jan. 4 -- Two Dutch experts in land reclamation suggested today the erection of dikes along part of the Hackensack River to convert a large section of the Jersey Meadows to productive use.

" FOR the artist all roads once led to Rome; yesterday to Paris. Today, for the artist in the theatre, whether actor, director, or designer, the road leads to Moscow and the theatres of the U. S. S. R.," wrote Lee Simonson in 1935, and his observation was completely warranted.

ONLY in the past year or so have Americans begun to learn some of the details of a prodigious undertaking in America's system of defense. This is the DEW Line -- Distant Early Warning -- northernmost of three "radar fences," which span the continent between the industrial and governmental centers of the United States and the North Pole (or rather the Soviet territories beyond the Pole).

HONG KONG, Jan. 4 -- A Peiping radio broadcast heard here tonight announced the dismissal of five leading officials in Hunan, Mao Tse-tung's native province in south-central China. The announcement followed the report of a similar discharge of top officials in Chekiang Province on the East China coast.

Y., Jan. 4 -- Charles Tremblay, a member of the Brattleboro Outing Club, turned in a sparkling second flight today to clinch honors in the annual Swedish Ski Club jumping tournament. Competing in temperatures that hovered about 10 above zero, the victor soared 158 feet in his second try to take the top award with ease.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 4 -- Three persons were killed early today in the most serious of a long series of political bombings here. Until now the explosions had been arranged with evident care to avoid loss of life.

The American merchant marine in 1957 demonstrated its ability to respond quickly to national needs in an emergency, The Government has reported. Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of Germany, celebrates his eighty-second birthday today. AFTER a temporary "thaw," Peiping and Moscow are once more using their technique of "persuasion" to squeeze intellectuals back into a rigid Marxist-Leninist mold and make the artists among them produce great works by strict Communist party formula.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 4 -- Changes scheduled for Monday in Suffolk County's administration include the election of a new chairman of the Board of Supervisors and the appointment of a County Coordinator.
A leading New York rabbi declared yesterday that the East and the West "will live together or they are doomed to die together."

BAYONNE, N. J., Jan. 4 -- The City Commission has adopted a resolution calling for a conference with the board of directors of the Esso Standard Oil Company on the lay-off of 800 workers at its refinery here.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 4 (UP) -- An Atlas, biggest of this country's missile weapons, was test-fired on the ground tonight in preparation for launching.

A program in business administration, designed for women but taught in the most part by men, is being conducted at Radcliffe College. The faculty is supplied by the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, just across Massachusetts Avenue in Cambridge.
ROME, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Pope Pius XII said in a speech made public today that the "hatred" with which "enemies of the Church" attacked parochial schools was a sign of the schools' importance.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Singapore's Chief Minister, Lim Yew Hock, appealed today for Western economic aid for Singapore and other parts of Southeast Asia. He warned that such aid was the only hope of saving this strategic area from communism.
SEATTLE -- The Pacific Northwest in 1957 felt the impact of a depressed lumber market.
With a record 1957 behind it, the life insurance industry expects the new year to be marked by competition -- a slowly growing trend in the last two years.

STANDING before a lectern, Archibald MacLeish read a condensation of his new verse drama, "J. B.," for almost two. hours last night in the Kaufmann Concert Hall of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue at Ninety-second Street.

Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York hailed the Christian church yesterday as an "everlasting tradition." He spoke at a special service observing the 125th anniversary of the Church of the Epiphany, York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street.

As railroad equipment builders have increasingly diversified their activities since World War II it has become increasingly popular to assure investors and analysts that the companies can get along well without building freight cars.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 5 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Soviet Ambassador Andrei A. Smirnov conferred today at the Federal Chancellery when the diplomatic corps called to congratulate Dr. Adenauer on his eighty-second birthday.

Concern over proposals to tax advertising has subsided in Norfolk, Va., and St. Louis. However, the court battle over Baltimore's new taxes likely holds the key to whether such ordinances will crop up elsewhere.
The Federal Reserve Banks, largest handlers of checks in the nation, are looking forward to the day when most checks are listed, sorted and proved by automatic electronic equipment.

Atomic power? Definitely. But at a high cost.
Manufacturers of printing presses for newspapers did well last year and expect 1958 to be as good and perhaps better. The chief reason cited for the rosy outlook was the advance in the use of color.
The paint industry expects sales this year to equal if not better the record $1,600,000,000 volume of 1957.
The United States capital investment boom topped out in 1957 -- and recession spread through the land.
Lumbermen had a word for their industry's performance last year: "Tough."
NEW ORLEANS -- Chemical and petroleum products plants accounted for more than half of Lousiana's $239,259,513 in new industry in 1957, the State Department of Commerce and Industry has just reported.

The flat glass industry, which has been hard hit by foreign imports, is slowly improving.

Thailand's new Premier, General Thanom, has given out his first statement on foreign policy since he formed his Government. If any reassurance were needed by the friends of Thailand, this would certainly supply it.
The aluminum industry enters the new year with a surplus of metal, more capacity than it needs to fill the present demand -- and a hefty 38 per cent expansion program well under way.

Quantity production of an electron microscope that magnifies specimens 200,000 times will begin this year at the Radio Corporation of America.

Prime Minister Macmillan's address to the British people on Saturday night was in part an effort to mollify voters attracted by the Labor party's campaign for a "high level" international conference and for the immediate and unconditional suspension of hydrogen bomb tests.
MACY'S is a century old this year, but she doesn't look a day over 16.

" THE MARRIAGE OF FIGARO" was staged at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday evening. Roberta Peters as Susanna, Rosalind Elias as Cherubino and Martial Singher as the Count made first appearances of the season in their roles.
United States Attorney Paul W. Williams agreed yesterday that the United States Supreme Court had held that state laws permitting wiretapping violated Federal law.

The electric industry's seventy-fifth year was a specially busy one.

Employment was hitting new peaks and, as late as March 1, about 500 concerns had committed themselves to spend upward of $1,400,000,000 on new capital improvements by 1961.

The market for automobile liability insurance in the New York metropolitan area is tight and getting tighter, underwriters acknowledged yesterday.

The pharmaceutical industry had the highest sales, earnings and dividends in its history last year. An increase of 5 to 10 per cent in business in 1958 is forecast by the head of one of the nation's leading pharmaceutical and chemical manufacturing concerns.

New stocks become active trading favorites on the New York Stock Exchange every year, but over a long period of years only a few issues have been able to maintain their position by being included in the list of twenty most active stocks traded each year.

A decade of unbroken sales volume records continued last year in the toy industry. Retail volume climbed to $1,500,000,000 last year, a new high, according to Robert W. Muessel, president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Before a record crowd of 27,500, Peder Pytte, a recent Denver University graduate, captured Class A honors in the Norway Ski Club's annual jumping tournament today.

Samuel Reshevsky's white king was still in the center of the board, on its original square, when early yesterday morning George Kramer resigned to him their postponed eleventh-round game in the United States championship for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club.

The major portion of the rear main-floor lobby area at 100 Church Street has been leased by the Statistical Tabulating Corporation for the lew York offices and eastern 'division iheadquarters of its punchedcard talulattng service.
Expansion of banking and other private financial activities has continued to parallel the rapid growth of the Puerto Rican economy.

There was no discernible trend to commodity volume on the New York exchanges last year. Most items registered a slight decline. The over-all volume of trading was off, but there were a few notable exceptions.

The outset of each new year brings its own special set of questions, and there can be little doubt as to what question in particular was uppermost in men's minds with the arrival of January, 1957. Could we, it was being widely asked, contain the increasing momentum of confidence that had carried the economy in the previous two and a half years to all-time highs of production, investment and employment?
The nation's airlines flew higher than ever in 1957.
The New York City Mission Society's DeWitt Church was dedicated yesterday at 280 Rivington Street. It is in the Baruch housing project on the Lower East Side.
A readjustment of oil operations last year reflected the fluctuating demand caused largely by the Suez crisis.

The first of a new series of reports, published in the news columns today, offers another good example of the healthy self-examination to which the United States has been forced by Soviet technical and political successes. This report on the military aspects of United States security represents the collective judgment of a distinguished panel of private citizens. It is a good example of public-spirited service.

THE strongest man in baseball undoubtedly is Ted Kluszewski, a monument of muscle. He used to scare pitchers merely by striding to the plate with sleeves cut so close to the shoulders that every rippling sinew in his oak-hewed arms sent waves of terror all the way to the mound.
Last week was a woeful one for some of the top-ranking college basketball squads in the nation.
A completely automatic parking garage that will accommodate 276 cars will be opened in the summer of 1959 west of Eighth Avenue between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in 1957 continued its high volume of loans to nations throughout the world. The prospect is for this to continue.

CLEVELAND -- Auto dealers in the Cleveland area have been encountering increasing "psychological resistance to sales," but express confidence that prospective buyers will take their hands out of their pockets in 1958.

ALTHOUGH the mezzo-soprano Betty-Allen is known to local concertgoers through numerous appearances in oratorio, opera and concert, her performance at Town Hall last night was her solo recital debut, and a large audience was on hand for the occasion.
Americans continued to eat high last year, spending a record $75,000,000,000 for food.

SPARTANBURG, S. C., Jan. 5 (UP) -- Donald S. Russell, who resigned recently as president of the University of South Carolina, tonight became the first announced candidate for Governor in the June 10 Democratic primary.
WASHINGTON -World politics and world economics provide a turbulent setting for the 1958 battle over United States tariff law.

What is perhaps the most important work dealing with the problem of Government economic controls to make its appearance in recent years is also probably the shortest. It runs to but eighty-eight pages.

Tight money left its mark on bond refunding in 1957. The total of bonds called for redemption before maturity fell to $221,347,000 from $668,070,000 in 1956. It was the lowest yearly total since this compilation of bond retirements was started in 1927 by The New York Times.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Jan. 1 -- During summer the South Pole plateau receives more energy from the sun than any other place on earth.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 5 -- President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain have been in touch since they met in Paris last month during the sessions of the North Atlantic Council.

The Commerce and Industry Insurance Company has been organized as a new wholly owned subsidiary of Associated Reciprocal Exchanges, Schuyler Merritt 2d, president and chief executive officer of both companies, announced over the week-end.
The year just past was the second disappointing one in a row for the nation's copper and brass mills. The year ahead holds some promise of improvement -- but some disturbing problems, too.
Following is the text of the summary of a report on "International Security -- The Military Aspect" made by the Special Studies Project of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, Inc:

ROME, Jan. 5 -- In the wake of the "scandal at the opera" the United States and Italy came close to a diplomatic incident today. The central figure was Elsa Maxwell, professional party-giver and American newspaper columnist.
WASHINGTON -- For Bob Yarbrough, 29, of Atlanta, Ga., 1957 was a good year.
The United States market for foreign bonds payable in United States dollars is expected to widen further after a period of substantial enlargement in the year now past.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The first of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund reported released today, is a reminder of a significant fact, namely, that much of the best thinking in the world today on foreign policy problems is being done by private citizens and institutions in the United States.

LONG applause and cheers were the reward of Philippe Entremont, 23-year-old French pianist, for his performance of Prokofieff's Third Concerto with the New York Philharmonic Saturday night in Carnegie Hall.
Satellites, rockets and missiles are the main dish these days of D. S. Kennedy. Co.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The new session of Congress will begin with intensive scrutiny of the decision of Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin to retire from the Army.
MINNEAPOLIS -- A moderate decline in economic activity in the first half of 1958, with a subsequent recovery in the latter half of the year is foreseen for the Ninth Federal Reserve District.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- While oil experts here would not comment for the record on Signor Mattei's remarks, their attitude left no doubt that the president of the Italian oil agency was a thorn in the side of American oil interests.
The cotton surplus problem, a source of concern for years, seems on the way out, particularly with respect to the better grades.

In your issue of Dec. 22 you published a letter from Prof. Pieter Geyl, who expressed his disagreement with your correspondent in attributing the term "nationalism" to the Dutch attitude as regards their dispute with Indonesia. In this matter I can agree with the professor, since Indonesian and Dutch nationalism are not in any sense identical.

The New York Knickerbockers could not have performed in a more desultory fashion as they dropped a 101-to-100 decision to the Cincinnati Royals in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
Business ran up against a paradox last year: Sales went up; profits came down.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Grain futures rose last week for the first time since early December.

The Soviet satellites were compared yesterday with the Star of Bethlehem that guided the Magi to the Christ Child. The Rev. Oscar V. Lynch drew the parallel in a sermon at the 10 A. M. solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Your editorial of Dec. 27 about Blue Cross was a justifiable criticism of the present administration of a valuable organization. In less than twenty-five years Blue Cross plans have enabled two-thirds of the people in the New York metropolitan area and fifty million in the United States to insure themselves against most of their hospitalization expenses. It would be a misfortune for us all if such an agency should decline because of unwise management.
Most manufacturers of housewares, spurred by fierce competition in 1957, managed to hold the price line despite increased costs.

ATLANTA -- Employment in the South's textile mills, principal segment of the region's economy, reflects in labor index statistics a fairly accurate account of the rise and fall of the South's work force.

The International Monetary Fund had a year of record activity in 1957. The fund will probably not provide as much new credit in 1958, but new advances are likely to continue to exceed repayments by borrowers.

You reported recently that an important disagreement has arisen in our Government concerning the reply to be given to the Soviet Union with respect to her recent disarmament proposals. This disagreement raises a basic issue about our willingness to negotiate in good faith with Russia.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Tennessee laws requiring segregated public transportation are being challenged here tomorrow in United States District Court.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 5 -- The Netherlands starts the new year under the influence of general cuts in spending, which are having an increasing psychological effect, a continued scarcity of capital, uncertainty about world trade and events in Indonesia.
Lower prices on the two leading stock exchanges here in 1957 were reflected in the cost of memberships.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The stock markets began the New Year last week as they ended the old -- on a quiet note.

As the big man walked through the noonday crowd on Lexington Avenue the other day, many people stared hard as if they remembered him. Many of them did. Gene Tunney, the former heavyweight champion, is not an easy person to forget, even though he is now a business executive of 60 and has not had a fight in thirty years.
WASHINGTON -- Farmers wrote a most significant story for American agriculture in 1957. It was one of migration and change portending further massive changes in American farms and farmers.
ATLANTA -- The Southern states in 1957 set a record for acquisition of new manufacturing plants, the Southern Association of Science and Industry reports.
Competition in the supermarket field is increasing, according to Curt Kornblau, research director of the Super Market Institute.

The life of a double agent is the subject of "The Cat With Two Faces," by Gordon Young, which Coward-McCann will publish Feb. 6. The "Cat" of the title was Mathilde Carre, "a tiny Frenchwoman of striking appearance." She was for some time an important figure in the French Resistance Movement and the mistress of one of its leaders.

DETROIT, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Gordie Howe scored his twentieth goal of the season tonight and assisted on another as the Detroit Red Wings gained a 3-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game.
The armed forces must be prepared to develop a device to stop or destroy a hostile satellite, Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, retiring Army chief of research and development, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, said today that the farm cost-price squeeze was a "major problem" in 1957 and showed few signs of improvement this year.
Like hurricane hunters, the nation's money managers often, must begin interpreting the next storm before the last has fully subsided.

The soft coal industry's recovery program suffered a slight setback last year Although a further upsurge had been expected, the decline in general industrial activity resulted in a reduction of 15,000,000 tons in demand below the 500,000,000 in 1956.
The "Adma Enterprise," the first underwater drilling barge of its type in the Middle East, has arrived at Das Island in the Persian Gulf after a 6,800-mile tow by tugs from Germany.

ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Six skiers from the United States turned in poor performances today in an international slalom event, which served as a tune-up for the world championships in Austria next month.
RIVERHEAD, L. I. -- Marked changes were recorded in the economy picture of Nassau and Suffolk Counties during 1957.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- A new state-financed dormitory for 200 men students will be opened tomorrow at the State University's Agricultural and Technical Institute at Alfred. It cost $868,760.

HONG KONG, Monday, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The mothers of three American prisoners held by Red China on spy charges crossed the border at Lowu today and entered the Communist mainland, en route to prison reunions with their sons.

Ed Sullivan, who seems undecided whether his rating destiny lies with eggheads or rock 'n' rollers, negotiated a formidable coup on Channel 2 last night in presenting an extended excerpt from Eugene O'Neill's "Long Day's Journey Into Night."

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell urged his congregation yesterday to "put the past with all its blunders and mistakes into the hands of God and leave it there and close the gate behind it." The subject of his sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, was "Breaking the Shackles of the Past."

Governor Harriman received an ultimatum yesterday to set in motion a special fight on organized crime or the Republican-controlled Legislature would act without him. Two choices were offered to him: to agree to a special prosecutor or to create a new state commission.

The year just ended saw steady progress in the employment of the physically handicapped. Despite a reduction in the latter part of 1957 in general employment, it appears probable that the number of job placements of physically handicapped persons by public employment services surpassed the 300,000 made in 1956.

PUERTO RICO'S personality has many facets. Many an American tourist thinks of it as a lush sunny island for vacationing. Business men regard it as a tax-free haven. Now the American fashion world may have another concept because Puerto Rico is setting out to prove that besides being a first-class textile-apparel-manufacturing center it deserves some recognition as an island rich in designers.

One of America's staples, the nickel candy bar, faces a rough time this year. Higher prices for cocoa beans, the raw material for chocolate, may force manufacturers to raise prices, reduce the size of the bars or to turn to synthetic flavoring.

Though spending for general business expansion will probably be less this year than it was in 1957, the nation's chain stores are optimistically planning to spend 12 per cent more than they did last year for new or improved facilities.
The seesaw battle for first place in size among New York City's banks and second place nationally has turned again in favor of the Chase Manhattan Bank, the bank's year-end statement indicates.
The car and truck renting and leasing industry did business estimated at $460,000,000 last year, an increase of 20 per cent over its $384,000,000 volume in 1956.
A mild winter and Nov. 21 disturbed what would otherwise have been another record year for the natural gas industry.

Perhaps because of waning interest in Canadian oils and mines, turnover of stocks on the American Stock Exchange slipped last year below the 228,000,000-share figures for both 1955 and 1956. The aggregate was 214,011,566, still better than in any save those two years since 1932.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah -- The work force reduction in copper mining and the steel industry, with no rise in employment predicted before spring, gives the Utah business pictures a statistically bleak aspect at the start of the new year. Aside from the specific weak spots in nonferrous metal mining and steel the economic outlook seems fairly bright.

A new plan to reorganize the state's court system was made public yesterday. The plan is the work of the Temporary Commission on the Courts, an official state body, of which Harrison Tweed is chairman.

Airframe manufactures started 1957 with every right to think themselves immune to the ups and downs of the business cycle. Ever since 1953 they had been flying high without a single setback as defense and commercial commitments mounted from year to year.
Bishop Frederick Buckley Newell of the New York Area of the Methodist Church said yesterday that the United States was afflicted with a new "creeping isolationism."
Almost $2,000,000,000 worth of all kinds of home furnishings were sold through interior decorators last year.

ATLANTA -- The regional field office of the United States Department of Commerce reports that 35.1 per cent of the female population of 14 years of age and older in the sixteen Southern and border states was in the region's labor force.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska -- Alaska's business leaders face 1958 with restrained optimism.
The management side in waterfront labor negotiations will have a new look when the existing longshore contract comes up for renewal.
New York retains its supremacy as the nation's top port in value of foreign tonage handled. But -- surprise -- it only ranks third in total foreign trade tonnage.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Gay Brewer Jr., a 25-year-old golf professional from Cincinnati, thrilled thousands of spectators late today when he sank a 15-foot putt on the eighteenth green. This put him in the lead at the end of the third round of the hotly contested $35,000 Los Angeles Open.
The Police Department announced yesterday that 1,848 crimes were committed in the city's public schools during school hours in the first eleven months of last year.
CHICAGO -- Highly diversified Chicago takes comfort and pride in the built-in stability that variety provides in periods of adjustment.
Production of fir plywood rose again last year, a new high, but lagging demand and weak prices continued to plague producers.
About 83.8 per cent of the nation's population now live in areas where liquor is sold legally, according to the Distilled Spirits Institute of Washington.
Several aspects of store selling hours became quite controversial toward the end of 1957. They will probably be even more hotly argued this year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 5 -- Jean Kerr's rollicking account of family life in an old house in Larchmont, "Please Don't Eat the Daisies," has been bought for filming by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The picture is slated to be made in the summer with Joseph Pasternak as the producer.
Joseph G. Moriarty will be installed as commodore of the Rudder Club Wednesday at the organization's monthly dinner-meeting. The affair will be held in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

Textile mill production in 1957 was marked by a downturn that toward the year's end resulted in a firmer price picture. Earlier, declining consumption had brought about an overabundance of goods, and prices of cotton fabrics, for instance, dropped to an eight-year low.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Some of the nation's largest missiles appeared today to be set for firing this week.
PHILADELPHIA -- Historically, 1957 was a "good" but not a "boom" year in the Greater Philadelphia metropolitan area.
A Cavalcade of Great American Films will be presented at the Brussels Worlds' Fair this year, it was announced yesterday by Howard S. Cullman United States Commissioner General for the Fair.

LOS ANGELES -- Los Angeles County, the nation's most populous, with 5,560,000 inhabitants, continued in 1957 to grow at a rate of 600 persons a day. About one-third of this is a natural population increase, the rest migration.

Approximately 2,117,151 cases of Maine sardines were packed last year, according to the State Department of Agriculture. This total was about 5 per cent below the 2,221,000 cases produced by the industry in 1956 and well below the 1950-56 average annual output of 2,485,000 cases.

The dividend pie shared by stockholders in 1957 was the juiciest ever. While figures for the full twelve months have not yet been compiled, the total through November came to a record of $9,364,000,000 compared with $9,039,000,000 for the like 1956 period, a 3.6 per cent increase.

The telephone and telegraph industries were relatively pleased with 1957. Their growth continued, though at a somewhat slower pace than in recent years, and they seemed generally successful in their never-ending pursuit for higher rates.

This country has 765 young Hungarian refugee students with collegiate scholarships valued at $1,500,000, the Institute of International Education and the World University Service reported yesterday. They said the refugees had scholarships in 290 colleges and universities in forty-six states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 5 (UP) -- Rutgers University disclosed today it had granted a ninety-nine-year lease on a ten and one-half acre site to the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame for the first unit of a projected shrine.

ROME, Jan. 5 -- ENRICO MATTEI, the ambitious, hard-driving and moody ruler of Italy's Government-owned oil and energy empire, known as E. N. I., is considered one of the most powerful men in the country.

The skies are less hazy over Pittsburgh, Chicago, Youngstown and other steel centers these days. Furnaces that account for 40 per cent of the nation's steel production are cool and smokeless -- made idle by the diminished demand.
BOSTON, Jan. 5 -- The Rev. Dr. Albert Buckner Coe, president of the Massachusetts Congregational Christian Conference, will retire April 16, when he reaches his seventieth birthday.
The familiar vending machine has become big business, and, with hot food and drink among its wares, is adding fresh volume.
Three new films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
Business showed two faces to lenders last year.
Traffic over the nation's inland waterways last year reached a peak for the twelfth consecutive year since the industry was revitalized after World War II.
The Jewish People's Philharmonic Chorus presented its annual midseason and Schaefer concert at Town Hall Saturday night, with Eugene Malek conducting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Government announced plans today to borrow another $180,000,000 of new cash outside the debt limit.
Following a ten-year record of 215,000,00 gallons in 1956, apparent liquor consumption leveled off at about 210,000,000 to 212,000,000 gallons last year.

Investment yields on new offerings of railroad equipment trust certificates climbed last year to the highest levels since the early Nineteen Thirties as a result of the progressively tight money market that prevailed over most of 1957.
WASHINGTON -- The precept of a balanced budget, keystone of the Eisenhower Administration's fiscal policy, collided with requirements of the space age as 1958 began.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Sarah Lawrence College reported today it would increase its facilities 40 per cent to meet the rising demand for higher education. The college has 400 students and by next year is to have 550.
THE science prophet Hugo Gernsback is neither meek nor modest like most of the prophets of Scripture. His recorded tearing of the veil of tomorrow stands up astonishingly. He sees no point in denial.
The remarkable economic growth of Puerto Rico continued last year and will undoubtedly gain again in 1958.
MALVERNE, L. I., Jan. 5 -- A 17-year-old boy was killed by a Long Island Railroad train here today when he fell backward after jumping off the tracks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Gloom has begun to gather among the top leadership of the Republican party in Illinois over a White House announcement that President Eisenhower may not attend its fund-raising dinner here Jan. 20.

All the scoring in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night was confined to the first period. And all the scoring was done by the Canadiens of Montreal as they sent the New York Rangers to a 4-to-0 defeat.
Following a ten-year record of 215,000,00 gallons in 1956, apparent liquor consumption leveled off at about 210,000,000 to 212,000,000 gallons last year.

Investment yields on new offerings of railroad equipment trust certificates climbed last year to the highest levels since the early Nineteen Thirties as a result of the progressively tight money market that prevailed over most of 1957.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Perhaps the most disturbing development in British politics has been the injection of a virulent strain of anti-Americanism into the debate over foreign policy.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 5 -- Argentine financial and political leaders said today that they were bewildered by the nation's recently released budget for the 1957-58 fiscal year.

The distaff side of the family can take much of the credit for the fact that 172,000,000 Americans last year spent more than $18,500,000,000 on wearing apparel in 1957, about $750,000,000 more than in 1956.
MALVERNE, L. I., Jan. 5 -- A 17-year-old boy was killed by a Long Island Railroad train here today when he fell backward after jumping off the tracks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Gloom has begun to gather among the top leadership of the Republican party in Illinois over a White House announcement that President Eisenhower may not attend its fund-raising dinner here Jan. 20.

All the scoring in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night was confined to the first period. And all the scoring was done by the Canadiens of Montreal as they sent the New York Rangers to a 4-to-0 defeat.

In his letter "Israel's Boundarieso published Dec. 31 Fayez Sayegh argues, first, that the Israeli Government and the United Nations Security Council recognize differences between various parts of Israel's territory and, second, that Israel's frontiers are only provisional, so that they are not fitting objects of international guarantees.
THE phone rang and the operator said that California was calling, just a minute please.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -Measured by official statistics, 1957 was a year of solid achievement for the Yugoslav economy.

PERTH, Australia, Jan. 6 (UP) -- Barry MacKay, America's new Davis Cup player from Dayton, Ohio, gained the quarterfinals at the West Australian tennis championship today by defeating John Blacklock of Australia, 6 -- 4, 5 -- 7, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2.

MELBOURNE, Australia -Australia's economic prospects for 1958 are reasonably good, but bankers and economists agree that the effects of drought in some states in 1957 will create special problems that have not arisen in recent flush production years.
The Police Department reported yesterday that 613 men, women and children were killed on the city's streets and highways last year.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 5 -- The reins of Westchester's $44,000,000-a-year county government were placed in the hands of a merchant and a plumber today.
LONDON -- The recovery of the British automobile industry from the slump it suffered in 1956 is regarded here as the most encouraging industrial trend in Britain in the last year.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden -- Economic conditions here in 1957 were moderately favorable. The general dip in industrial production throughout the Western world has begun to show up in Sweden.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 (UP) -- The United States Navy's two top submarine commanders denied today that the Navy had turned down two years ago a proposal to build missile-carrying atomic submarines.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- A modest rise in volume and the continued recovery on Wall Street had a beneficial effect on stock market prices here today. Gains, however, were generally very small among the principal industrial sections.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -Chuckling and applauding, President Eisenhower got a New Year's greeting today in song from a group of Atlanta, Ga., schoolboys.
Friday's total of blood obtained by the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program was 450 pints.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- A United Nations mission reported today that there was deep concern in Italian Somaliland over the probable economic plight of the territory after it becomes independent in 1960.
WESTFIELD, Mass., Jan. 6 -- Nothing much can be done about a man like Ray Balch, a deer hunter of this town, but there is always a compulsion to try. Balch makes it impossible not to try.
WARSAW, Jan. 6 -- A new style for Soviet diplomats in Communist Poland is being fashioned by Piotr A. Abrasimov, who took over as the Kremlin's Ambassador here three months ago.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 -- A trial of the Colorado River lawsuit between Arizona and California was resumed in a Federal courtroom today after a recess of almost five months.

LONDON -- Despite increasing foreign competition and the depressed state of the shipping market, the British shipbuilding industry came through 1957 healthy and prosperous. The only diminution of optimism in the industry concerned its longterm prospects vis-a-vis its biggest competitor, Japan, which can offer quicker delivery dates.
The Salvation Army opened its annual appeal yesterday with 2,000 volunteers already enlisted.

PARIS -- The new year begins with renewed efforts to avert a worsening of the crisis plaguing France's internal and external finances. This crisis started in the spring of 1957 and led on Aug. 10 to a devaluation of the franc. It is not certain that this step went quite far enough.

The news from the nation's lamp makers that two of every three Americans live and work under poor lighting conditions is another example of man's refusal to turn back to the past and of his insistence to look ever forward.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission was told today that delay in the granting of a final license to construct a $600,000,000 Niagara Falls power project had caused "inestimable harm."
The recent announcement by several eminent scientists that ability to control the weather may be necessary to America's survival as first-class power should not, I believe, pass without comment.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Republican legislative leaders voiced hope today that temporary cuts in the personal income tax could be continued for another year. The reductions amount to a maximum of $35 for each taxpayer. They represent an aggregate saving of $40,000,000 a year for all taxpayers.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 6 (Reuters) -- Dr. Vivian Fuchs, British Antarctic explorer, refused to call it quits today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -From telephones to bean soup, the Capitol is ready for Congress to come back.
BONN, Germany -- Lufthansa, West Germany's commercial airline, which was revived in 1955, reported further progress in its build-up last year.
ALGIERS, Algeria -- Perhaps the most striking economic developments last year in Algeria were the inflationary trend and the big increase in the commercial trade deficit.
An "Old New York" theme, faithful even to the detail of barber-shop harmony, ran through ceremonies yesterday beginning Macy's centennial celebration.

TOKYO -- Japan's total fish haul for 1957 showed a very favorable figure. The Agriculture and Forestry Ministry estimated that 50,028,000 tons of fish valued at about $555,000,000 were caught last year. The catch was an increase of 14 per cent over 1956.
An anonymous gift of $100 arrived for the Neediest yesterday from Madison, N. J., with this explanation:

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Conover, who live here at 1251 Flagler Drive, sailed their new yawl Revonoc, a name that is Conover spelled backward, to Miami in October, then flew north.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Secretary of State can constitutionally deny a passport to a citizen on the basis of confidential information.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The recent subway strike in New York City emphasizes the need for revising the Condon-Wadlin Act, in Governor Harriman's view. This law deals with strikes by public employes.
Supreme Court Justice Samuel Coleman has dismissed a suit brought by Meyer Levin against Cheryl Crawford, producer, in connection with the play, "The Diary of Anne Frank," it was learned yesterday.

The traveler by sea going around the western bulge of Africa past the island of Fernando Po and into the Bight of Biafra will find himself opposite the Cameroons, a former German colony now divided into two U. N. trusteeships, one British, one French.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland -- Iceland's foreign commerce in 1957 was characterized by the steady increase in trade with Eastern Europe, primarily with the Soviet Union, and the rapid decline in trade with the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -Rear Admiral Hyman George Rickover has been driven to greatness and controversy by a consuming personal philosophy that "the more you sweat in peace the less you bleed in war."

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The EastWest nonaggression pact proposed by Britain is intended primarily to assist the negotiation of agreements between the Soviet Union and the Western powers, Foreign Office officials said today.

The Soviet declaration yesterday that a reduction of 300,000 men in its armed forces is to take place has more propaganda and political than military importance. As with earlier similar Soviet claims, there is no way of checking whether such a reduction actually will take place.
PRAGUE -- The Czechoslovak economy continued to make cautious progress in 1957 despite shortcomings in various branches of production.
PARIS -- France completed one five-year atomic program and started another in 1957.

HONG KONG -- The economy of Communist China continued to expand during 1957. The rate of growth, however, diminished compared with previous years, and serious difficulties developed in the sphere of food and raw materials production.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 6 -- The Federal Government was warned today to keep "hands off" higher education.
Mild - mannered Howard (Jake) Cann, whose long reign as basketball coach at New York University is soon to end, yesterday made his strongest -as well as loudest and longest -- assertion in years.
The Transit Authority hopes to squeeze out 2,000 jobs in the next two years as part of its economy program to ward off a higher subway and bus fare in 1959.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 6 -West Germany's first attempts to equip its armed forces with European-made munitions have achieved little so far but headaches and disappointments. appointments.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- Fifty employes of Warner Brothers have been dismissed in a new economy move that has affected practically all departments of the studio, including the company's police force.

ANKARA, Turkey -- Aided financially and technically by her Western allies, particularly the United States, Turkey is making the long uphill pull toward economic independence, a goal that is still far off.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of Naval Operations, predicted today the Navy could develop and place in operation a nuclear-powered seaplane in two years. However, he did not disclose whether the Navy has been given authority to proceed.
NEW DELHI, India -- For India 1957 should have been a year of celebration. It turned out to be a year of desperation.
Philip Barry Jr., son of the late playwright, will produce "Darling Buds of Spring" as his first movie under a contract signed last November with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
Motorola, Inc., will market the first truly portable television set about two years from now.

Polo angels, unlike their Broadway counterparts, are fast disappearing from the face of the earth. The wealthy sportsmen trying to sustain interest in polo by providing horses for young riders are not meeting with much success.
WARSAW -- Polish agricultural production rose by 4 per cent last year, the result of a new policy encouraging private enterprise among the peasants.
