Preliminary design figures for one of the world's largest pieces of precision machinery -- a steerable 600 - foot - wide aluminum dish to catch faint radio signals from outer space -- were made public here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Retail workers began a limited strike today against stores of Montgomery Ward Co. in fifty-three cities.

The State Motor Vehicle Bureau suspended yesterday the driver's license of Deputy Police Commissioner Robert J. Mangum. The action was for failure to report the automobile accident in which Mr. Mangum and his wife were injured on Oct. 12.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The country's chief naval officer spoke out sharply today against the growing number of proposals to reorganize the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Most of these proposals, including the one contained in the recommendations of a Rockefeller Brothers Fund report, would increase the role and authorityof the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs.

Events today: Aaron Rosand, violinist, Carnegie Hall; Lyric Wind Ensemble, Carnegie Recital Hall, and Concert of Contemporary Chamber Music, B. de Rothschild Foundation, 316 East Sixty-third Street, all at 8:30 P. M.
Notre Dame officials were elated but not surprised yesterday that the Fighting Irish football team was voted as making the No. 1 comeback of 1957.

OSLO, Norway -- This nation's economy managed to emerge unscathed from the general international business-setback in 1957. Evidence: the gross national product increased by 3.5 per cent, about the same as in the last five years.

Mayor Wagner' lent his support yesterday to the opening of the annual drive for funds for a medical center near Haifa, Israel, that will bear his name. He spoke at a luncheon meeting at the Plaza Hotel where the Civil Service Employes Committee for Histradrut launched its 1958 drive among city employes.
BONN, Germany -- West German industrial power consolidated its position in 1957 as the backbone of the West European economic structure.
ROME -- The sector of the Italian economy that advanced most rapidly in 1957 was foreign trade, export and imports having reached new heights.
HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 6 (AP) -The president of the National Council of Farmer Cooperatives said agriculture wanted to join and share in the high rate of prosperity in the United States.

Louis J. Lefkowitz, the State Attorney General, reported yesterday that more than 1,000 complaints of frauds against the buying public had been made to his office since he established a consumer protection division ten weeks ago.

LONDON -- For most of 1957 the picture of Britain's foreign trade was not an encouraging one for a nation that lives -or dies -- on its ability to export. The position began to improve late in the year and the experts at the Board of Trade are confident that it will continue to do so this year.
Shipyard workers at the Todd Corporation Brooklyn plant did a double-take recently when the tanker Mississippi was hauled into drydock.

A Polish housewife watching a demonstration of easily prepared United States foods as if it were a magician's performance. Yugoslavs solemnly fascinated at the chromium musicalclock workings of an American supermarket.

PARIS -- French industrial production continued in 1957 its annual increase of 10 per cent. This was one of the most favorable factors in an otherwise worrisome economic and financial situation. Based on 1952 as 100, the official production index reached 145 in January, 148 in February, 146 in March, 156 in May, 154 in June, 140 in July, 99 in August, 149 in September and 152 in October.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- Harry Ackerman, independent television-film producer and former network executive, will become head of production at Screen Gems, the Columbia Pictures TV-film subsidiary, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Following are excerpts from the speech by Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of Naval Operations, at the National Press Club today:
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands -- American industry, Dutch money and Surinam (Dutch Guiana) resources are being combined to exploit rich new reserves of bauxite, the raw material of aluminum.

BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, Jan. 6 -- United States friendliness for the Venezuelan dictatorship bewilders the young Venezuelan fliers who obtained refuge here after their unsuccessful New Year's Day revolt.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland -- The high hopes of further expanding Northern Ireland industry this year rest on a big stepping-up of United States private investment, which is already about u14,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of class I rail carriers for last November at $46,000,000, off 33 1/3 per cent from the $69,000,000 earned in the same month in 1956.
BONN, Germany -- For the fifth consecutive year West German built a half million housing units in 1957. As usual, it led the world in housing construction on a per capita basis.

Induction services for Justice Birdie Amsterdam, the first woman elected to the Supreme Court in New York State, were held yesterday in a flowered-bedecked court room in the County Court House in Foley Square.
If more persons showed as much interest in potential young tennis players as Murray Eisenstadt, the Davis Cup might be here instead of in Australia.
DAMASCUS, Syria -- The outstanding economic development in this part of the Middle East has been the rapidly increasing role of the Communist countries of Eastern Europe in foreign trade.
Moves to establish free trade in Western Europe will present a disturbing as well as significant problem for the United States this year.
PARIS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- French trading with the dollar zone and Western Europe was out of the red for the first time in month during December, the Finance Ministry reported today.

ZURICH, Switzerland -- As foreign trade figures show, prosperity in Switzerland reached new peaks in 1957. United States business profited from it abundantly. Measured by value, imports from the United States increased by more than 29 per cent, doubling trade surplus in favor of the United States.
Stock prices swept upward for thirty minutes yesterday, then trickled down the rest of the day. They ended with a moderate loss.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -President Eisenhower has decided on a qualified rejection of the Soviet proposals for an East-West heads-of-government meeting and for an East-West nonaggression pact.

Network rivalry seemingly will undergo a one-hour truce on Feb. 1. From 9 to 10 o'clock that evening Dean Martin's television show on the National Broadcasting Company chain will present guest stars from the other two networks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a Virginia libel judgment against a newspaper for having published a story based on official court records.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Don C. Collins, president of the American National Cattlemen's Association, told some 2,000 delegates to its national convention today that their "investment in integrity has paid off."
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Following is a digest of the Republican program for the new legislative session as announced today by the Republican legislative leaders:

Mickey Crawford, a middle-weight from Saginaw, Mich., defeated Chico Vejar of Stamford, Conn., in the star bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The decision was unanimous and was well received by the crowd of 1,203.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 6 -Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain has aroused interest and some qualified hopes in the Middle East with his proposal for an East-West non-aggression pact.
TRENTON, Jan. 6 -- The State Supreme Court today upheld the right of Bergen County to widen Forest Avenue from State Route 4 in Paramus north to Westwood.
WARSAW -- Poland headed into 1958 with a grim warning from her leaders that little or no economic betterment could be expected in the coming twelve months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Treasury bill rate rose somewhat this week but remained well below the Federal Reserve discount rate, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average rate on $1,700,000,000 of the 91-day discount bills was 2.858 per cent, compared with the 15-month low of 2.752 per cent set last week.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- France will take no position on British proposals for a nonaggression pact with the Soviet Union pending a review of the matter within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, a spokesman said today.
United Nations action to find the Batista Government in Cuba in violation of the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights was urged here last night by Dr. Carl Manuel Urrutia Lleo.
BEIRUT, Lebanon -- The oil pipeline has become as much a part of the Arab world today as the donkey or the camel and figured far more prominently in last year's developments.
BERLIN -- Communist East Germany, which has its capital in East Berlin, reports economic gains in 1957.
A New York Times correspondent in Moscow said last night by telephone that a rumor was circulating in the Soviet capital that a Russian rocket had been launched with a man aboard.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Grain futures retreated in moderately active dealings on the Board of Trade today.
MOSCOW -- The Soviet Union and its leaders were justifiably proud of their feat in successfully launching two earth satellites during 1957.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark -About the best that can be said for the economy of this country is that it continued to stagnate throughout 1957. There was no marked deterioration and no notable improvement.
LONDON -- The fight to keep the pound sterling strong and to defeat inflation was the chief economic theme in Britain last year.

A junior theatre benefit committee under the co-chairmanship of Mrs. Hugh Cullman and Mrs. Truman M. Talley is aiding in plans for a theatre party for the benefit of the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

WHEN Chi Pai-Shih died last September, he had lived ninety-five years by Chinese count but had died at the age of 97. This was because in 1937 the master Chinese contemporary painter was told by a fortune-teller that his seventy-fifth and seventysixth years would bring misfortune.

TAIPEI, Taiwan -- In spite of increased productivity in recent years, the economy of Taiwan is still largely dependent on United States aid. The annual trade deficit has averaged between $80,000,000 and $100,000,000 for five years, and it has been American economic aid that has bridged this gap.
THOSE who like boiled beef are usually articulate on its merits. But nowhere has the slow-simmered meat come in for as much discussion as it did in Vienna in the days before World War II.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -Brown coal, for generations relegated to the role of an economic orphan in comparison with hard coal, has emerged in recent years as a Cinderella among fuel in southeastern and Eastern Europe.
New York University's Institute of Fine Arts has acquired a spacious new home, the James B. Duke mansion at 1 East Seventy-eighth Street, at Fifth Avenue.
ROME -- Industry showed an extremely strong upward trend throughout 1957. Despite fears and rumors of impending depression, Italian manufacturing was in high gear as the year drew to its close.
ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Roger Staub of Switzerland won the giant slalom race in the international ski tournament today as American contestants made a poor showing.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP) -The American Football Coaches Association reported today sixteen football players died last year of injuries directly attributable to the gridiron. Thirteen of them were high school boys.
IF ELOISE is contemplating a fresh spring wardrobe, she has only to knock at Room 1236 of (where else but), the Plaza Hotel.
BONN, Germany -- West Germany's rebuilt and modernized productive machine again spewed forth record qua quantities of manufactured goods in 1957.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin testified today that he was retiring from the Army because he was "no longer being considered for promotion and assignment to a more responsible position."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Chairman Johnson of the Senate Preparedness subcommittee may be able to induce his bipartisan group to make a report on the condition of the military defense of the United States that will be unanimous; and also be nonpartisan by reason of neither stating nor implying a conclusion whether the current Administration or the preceding.

APPREHENSIONS over the fate of "Studio One" were fully justified last night. The pioneer dramatic program offered its first presentation from Hollywood, and the show was pretentious mediocrity (Channel 2).
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Following are major issues facing the second session of the Eighty-fifth Congress, which convenes tomorrow:
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -World industrial production reached record proportions in 1957. However, there were clear indications that the boom was beginning to abate.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 4 -- An agreement among Latin-American coffee-producing countries to withhold supplies will place a severe strain on the economy of the smaller nations. Guatemala, for example, relies on coffee exports for 75 to 80 per cent of her earnings abroad.

When Max Miller was a young man in 1932 he wrote "I Cover the Waterfront" and had a best seller to his credit. Since then, he has written twenty-four other books. His newest, "Shinny Of Your Own Side," will be issued Feb. 6 by Doubleday.

To the blind, the process of separating the yolk of an egg from the white is likely to be a major problem. But, by cupping the hand and breaking an egg into it, it's a simple process to allow the egg white to slip between the fingers into a bowl.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.2 per cent in the week ended Tuesday, Dec. 24. The index was unchanged in the week ended Tuesday, Dec. 31, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The indexes for Dec. 31 and Dec. 24 were 118.4 (1947-49 equals 100), compared with 118.2 for Dec. 17.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- Republican leaders began a campaign today to blame the Democratic Administration of former President Truman for this country's lag behind the Soviet Union in the race for missile supremacy.

Oil companies, particularly the big international ones, are planning high capital expenditures for 1958. They do not believe, as the Gulf Oil Corporation put it, that "the exile of one Russian dog into outer space is the beginning of the world's end."

AUCKLAND, N. Z. -- The New Zealand economy in 1957 was predominantly healthy. The deliberate deflation of the credit squeeze helped to maintain reasonably stable prices and incomes. The pressures of overemployment fell away a shade.

LONDON -- Atomic energy and its by-products are the basis of Britain's fastest-growing major industry. The British count heavily on nuclear fuel as a source of industrial power for their long-term economic survival.
SWIFTON, Ark., Jan. 6 (AP) -George Kell, infielder of the Baltimore Orioles, said today he was retiring from baseball as an active player.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -The Treasury failed today to produce its regular daily statement of the Government's financial position for only the third time in the eighty-one years that the statements have been published.
WARSAW -- The average wage of Polish industrial workers increased by 17 per cent last year. But even the Government recognized that this still left wages at an extremely low level.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Willie Mays today signed a 1958 contract with the San Francisco Giants at an estimated 65,000. This makes him the highest salaried player in the baseball club's history.
CAIRO -- Egypt has weathered more or less successfully a year of economic turmoil. In a more highly developed country it might have brought about chaos and bankruptcy.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) -- For Israel 1957 was another year of increase, both in economic growth and the problems that go with it.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6 -- While stepping up the drive to portray itself as a peace-loving nation, the Soviet Union continued tonight to depict the United States as a hysterical country determined to maintain the armaments race.

THE Dance Theatre of Israel, which calls itself Inbal, or "the tongue of a bell," made its first American appearance last night at the Martin Beck Theatre, and a rich and rare treat it proved to be. Nothing remotely like it has been seen in these parts before.
ATHENS -- There is among Greeks a growing feeling that they themselves can do something to remove the curse of poverty from their beautiful, rocky, infertile country.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 6 -- Venezuela began the first week after the short-lived rebellion calmly.
The NATO conference has come and gone. Three hundred billion dollars has been spent during the past ten years and still no peace is in sight.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development borrowed $150,000,000 in the United States market yesterday on 4 1/4 per cent bonds of limited callability and due Jan. 15, 1979.
Having relished doing Jean Anouilh's "Waltz of the Toreadors,'' Robert Whitehead is willing to go ahead with another comedy by the prolific French dramatist.

The Trans-Lux Distributing Corporation has acquired United States rights to the FrenchSpanish coproduction, "The Lovemaker." The import, described as the "tragi-comic story of the ruin of a proud and lonely girl in a small town," was filmed in Spain, with Betsy Blair as star. Juan Bardem directed the French-dialogue film.

Jose Quintero, director of the two current Eugene O'Neill productions, "Long Day's Journey into Night" and "The Iceman Cometh," will make his debut in opera next season at the Metropolitan Opera House. He will direct a new production of the twin bill, Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" and Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci."

TOKYO -- Japanese shipyards expect to launch 182 ships of 2,024,000 gross tons in the 195758 fiscal year ending March 31. That is 84,053 more tons -- as much more as one super tanker -- than was sent down the ways in the 1956-57 fiscal year and it undoubtedly retained for this country leadership among the world's shipbuilders in calendar 1957.
The Presbyterian Labor Temple will vacate its premises at 242 East Fourteenth Street within the next five months and turn over the building and its facilities to the New York City Mission Society.
Apparently some of the predictions heard on Seventh Avenue recently that department store buyers were spending their budgets with special care this year are true.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 6 (AP) -A Navy Mercator plane carrying twelve men crashed near here today, demolishing three small houses and damaging three others. The plane and the house it struck last burned. Four of the airmen were unaccounted for.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- Supreme Court Justice Robert Doscher requested the Rockland County grand jury today to investigate the tax and assessment confusion in the town of Clarkstown.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 6 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion has re-established the five-party coalition that governed Israel before he resigned Dec. 31.

From nail polish to shoe polish. That's the latest diversification of Revlon, Inc. which yesterday announced the acquisition of the Knomark Manufacturing Company, Inc., Brooklyn manufacturer of shoe polishes and related consumer products.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -Continuing its crackdown on violators of its rules covering financial aid to athletes, the National Collegiate Athletic Association today placed two member colleges on probation.

MELBOURNE, Australia -The Commonwealth Department of Trade survey of manufacturing activity in Australia says that while it was remarkably stable in the first nine months of 1957, there is some anxiety over the future.

ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- Columbia initiated its 1958 Ivy League season with a 60-56 upset victory over the Cornell five tonight before 2,600 persons. Stan Needleman, a sophomore, directed the Lion offensive against an all-court press which the Big Red employed for the last thirteen and a half minutes.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., which includes Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus in its retail chain, showed increased sales and earnings in the thirteen, thirty-nine and fifty-three weeks ended Nov. 2 over those of the similar periods a year earlier.
DALLAS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The sun popped from behind dark clouds today and warmed a vast area of West Texas in which snow yesterday trapped more than 500 travelers.
Heavily increased readership from color ads in newspapers as opposed to conventional black-and-white was reported yesterday at the convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 -- The Soviet Government announced tonight that it would reduce the size of its armed forces this year by 300,000 men.

Plans are being drawn for the construction of a new edifice for St. Mary's Catholic Church of the Byzantine Rite following an assemblage of land that was completed last week. The final parcel, known as 244 East Fifteenth Street, was acquired from the Harbru Realty Corporation through S. Edwin Kazdin Co., broker.
BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Behind a fog of crises, intrigues and tensions, the Middle East has completed a year marked by recovery and development.

The Cuban revolutionary movement was struck by the equivalent of an atomic bomb when a long, impassioned letter from Fidel Castro reached Miami. Fidel, as everyone calls him, was writing from his embattled quarters in the Sierra Maestra at the eastern end of the island.

The volume of state and municipal long-term financing increased 27 per cent in 1957 to $6,924,534,448, according to The Daily Bond Buyer of New York. This is about $44,000,000 below the record $6,968,641,896 established in 1954.
LISBON, Portugal -- This peaceful agricultural country of southwest Europe is being gently bumped by the impact of the new industrial age.
The Soviet Union's economic war against the West reached a new high in the closing days of 1957 after having gained major successes earlier in the year.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 6 -The economic potential of Long Island cannot be realized without a solution of the area's critical transportation problems, according to an industrial survey issued today.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The nation's auto industry sharply curtailed operations last week. Shortened by the New Year holiday and inventory-balancing shutdowns, the auto makers made only 78,377 cars, compared with 79,945 in the preceding week and 91,098 units in the like 1956 week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers, said today the Federal Government had in its hands the means to halt the economic downturn.
A crime was committed in the "bugging" of the Motormen's Benevolent Association by the Transit Authority, according to Assemblyman Anthony P. Savarese Jr.

After projecting a second half rise in retail sales mainly on an increase in consumer spending, Prof. Malcolm P. McNair, of Harvard University, said last night that a greatly increased defense budget "between $50,000,000,000 and $60,000,000,000 would be appropriate and economically feasible."
British studies looking toward a supersonic airliner are not promising in the view of a man who could cast an influential vote on such a project.
VIENNA -- Austria concluded her second full year of independence in better economic condition than almost any European country except. West Germany.
ROME -- Crops were poor, but booming industry made 1957 another good year for the Italian economy.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 -An aircraft company executive was ordained a priest of the Episcopal Church today in a service at St. Paul's Cathedral.

It is indicative of the world's longing for peace that Prime Minister Macmillan's suggestion of a nonaggression pact between East and West has aroused wide attention as offering one possible approach to an end of the cold war and the threat of atomic annihilation.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Walter O'Malley took another step today toward getting the famed Pasadena Rose Bowl as a home for his siteless Dodgers in 1958 and 1959.
HONG KONG, Jan. 6 -- A Peiping broadcast received here tonight reported that industry in Communist China was now pre-eminent in the national economy.

The session of Congress that opens in Washington today may be one of the most important in modern American history. It may well determine whether or not we Americans, through our elected representatives, have the imagination, the resilience and the will -- as we surely have the strength -- to pull ourselves together for the long haul.

YOU might take "First Love and Other Sorrows,"* by Harold Brodkey, as a collection of sketches for a novel that was never published. One of the stories appeared in Mademoiselle. The others were published in The New Yorker. When you read them in sequence you see they trace, with skill and subtlety, a familiar American road toward maturity.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- Hope for the future and concern for the present marked 1957 economic trends in Africa south of the Sahara.
The Grand Union Company, which operates an Eastern chain of 381 food stores, set records in sales and earnings for the nine months ended Nov. 30.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

RABAT, Morocco -- What was once French North Africa -- and now comprises the independent states of Morocco and Tunisia, with rebellion-torn Algeria between them -- moved painfully last year toward a sort of economic symbiosis with France.
The Chesapeake Ohio Railway has a new vice president. He is Owen Clarke, who resigned last month as chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Peter Thorneycroft resigned tonight as Chancellor of the Exchequer in a bitter split with the Government over economic policy.

NEWARK, Jan. 6 -- Two New York State troopers today linked a police official of West New York, N. J., with an attempted bribe to keep an underworld figure from going to prison on motor vehicle violations.

HAVANA, Jan. 6 -- The Cuban Government charged today that Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, former President of Cuba; Fidel Castro, rebel leader, and the outlawed Communist party had joined forces in the attempts to overthrow President Batista.
The Italian Line declined yesterday to negotiate a contract with its office workers here until their union local was certified by the National Labor Relations Board.
BOWLING GREEN, Ky., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Warren Circuit Court dismissed today treason and conspiracy indictments against three Confederate generals, one a former Vice President of the United States.
The Bendix Aviation Corporation achieved record sales and earnings in its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, Malcolm P. Ferguson, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement.
The New York Board of Rabbis presented a citation yesterday to Mayor Wagner for his support of the New York City Chaplaincy program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A 4-4 division in the Supreme Court today prevented resolution of the question whether a person acquitted by a Federal jury may thereafter be tried for the same crime in a state court.
PARIS -- Mounting foreign trade deficits wiped out France's hard currency reserves during 1957.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The suggestion by Sir David Eccles, President of the Board of Trade, for a kind of "economic merger" of the United States and the nations of the British Commonwealth and Western Europe, is in line with the British Government's policy of encouraging the economic integration of the West.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Ann Whitman, President Eisenhower's personal secretary, was stopped for speeding today as she tried to catch up with the Presidential motorcade motoring here from Gettysburg, Pa.

Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, said yesterday that he still believed that the Polo Grounds and its parking lot would make a good site for privately financed apartment construction. Mr. Moses said, however, that the city was not negotiating with the owners of the baseball park.
The city meant business when it recently announced a "get-tough" policy toward the 1958-1959 departmental budgets, Budget Director Abraham D. Beame indicated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilizaion today rejected claims of wool textile producers that imports of woolen fabrics should be curbed as a "threat to national security."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -The Supreme Court reversed today the first conviction of an alien for failing to deport himself under a proviso of the 1950 Internal Security Act.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- After five hours of animated discussion today, the foreign ministers of six nations were far apart on the choice of a site for the administration of the European Economic and Atomic Energy Communities.

Without prior warning to the public and without explanation Governor Harriman has politely dumped John E. Burton from membership on the State Power Authority. Mr. Burton had served with distinction for eight years, during which the difficult problems of power development on the St. Lawrence and the preliminaries at Niagara Falls were dealt with.

HELSINKI, Finland -- This shapes up as a difficult year for Finland. The country has gone through a financial crisis -- and it is still not over its troubles. Some important steps, however, have been taken to ease the situation. Chief of these was devaluation.
Several thousand out-of-town retailers converged yesterday on the Statler Hotel for the forty-seventh annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

If any further evidence is needed that New York State's traffic safety program is wholly inadequate to meet the crisis on our highways it can be found, unhappily, in the catastrophic New Year's Day record of twenty-two dead in road mishaps -- the highest of any state in the country.

Tallulah Bankhead as Catherine the Great, Gwen Verdon as Nell Gwynn and Ricardo Montalban as the King of Siam will be among those featured in a midnight pageant entitled "Imperial Favorites," to be presented at t he Imperial Ball on Friday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The men who design America's furniture have come down out of the clouds of high style to produce practical designs keyed to today's living, judging from a survey of the wholesale furnishings markets, which opened last week in Grand Rapids and today in Chicago.
The Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission is proposing that the Long Island, New York Central and New Haven Railroads be tied into a subsidized tri-state commuter network.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 6 -- The Indonesian Army warned today that "strong measures" would be taken against any plotters conspiring to overthrow the Government during President Sukarno's "rest cure" abroad.
Multi - million - dollar, longrange research into the hazards of pesticides was urged here yesterday by the Conservation Foundation and the New York Zoological Society.
The stock companies selling automobile liability insurance in New York State said yesterday they had a record underwriting loss of more than $24,000,000 for 1956.
PARIS -- Oil production in the French Sahara is expected to total 14,000,000 tons a year starting in 1960, according to official sources.

LICIA ALBANESE sang the part of Mimi in Puccini's "La Boheme" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time this season. Two of her colleagues, Giulio Gari as Rodolfo and Nicola Moscona as Colline, also were new to their roles this season.

SEOUL, Korea -- South Korea achieved the most notable economic gains in 1957 since the creation of the republic in 1948, despite the continuing problem of maintaining the world's fourth largest army while rebuilding a war-shattered economy.
Samuel Reshevsky, international grandmaster, suffered his first defeat in the United States chess championship at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.
BONN, Germany -- The slowdown in world trade had its effect in 1957 on the great port cities where West Germany's shipping and shipbuilding industries are situated.
The three Southern members of the new Civil Rights Commission were urged yesterday not to use their position "to delay action, gloss over conditions and ignore known evils."

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands -- Call it adjustment, leveling-off, the end of the boom: whatever its name, the Netherlands and Belgium began to feel it in 1957. And the outlook this year is for more of the same, even with remedies planned or underway.

PARIS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Communistfomented terrorism in the Cameroons has been sharply reduced since two companies of French troops were sent in three weeks ago, an Overseas Territories Ministry official said today.
A 40-year-old deaf mute who also is blind has made good in his job as an assembler of electrical parts in a Brooklyn factory.
ZURICH, Switzerland -- Except for one small loan of 5,000,000 francs (4.37 francs=$1) to an Austrian mortgage bank last March, no foreign loans were floated in Switzerland in 1957.
BOMBAY, Jan. 6 -- Thousands of demonstrators rioted in Madras against Prime Minster Jawaharlal Nehru today. In clashes with the police twentyfive persons were injured and twenty-six arrested.

The Metropolitan Container Corporation has signed a lease for 14,000 square feet on the ground floor and in the basement of the Purepac Building, at 503 East Seventy-second Street. The transaction was negotiated by Edward Sayle, broker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -Judge John Sirica refused in United States District Court today to grant a temporary restraining order against the transfer of assets of the Washington local of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union.
HONG KONG, Jan. 6 -- Chinese Communist officials lost no time in criticizing United States policy when they ushered five Americans into their country from Hong Kong today.

George Hopkins, a lawyer here since 1912, left bonds valued at $300,000 to a former client, Miss Eleanora R. Sears, a Boston sportswoman. His will was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan took command in the first two holes of the final round today and went on to capture the $35,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state personal property tax may constitutionally be levied on imported iron ore stored for use at a steel mill.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -On his flight to Teheran for the "Big Three" conference of 1943, President Franklin D. Roosevelt peered down expectantly for his first sight of the famed cedars of Lebanon, and other forests mentioned in medieval history.

Net operating earnings of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York last year were $31,298,278, or $5.21 a share, compared with $28,234,067, or $4.70 a share the year before, based on the number of shares now outstanding.
The United States Coast Guard will offer public instruction courses to neophyte boat owners in New York and New Jersey beginning next month through its auxiliary units.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 -- Three new floors for research laboratories will replace one of four amphitheatres in a remodeling program under way at the Harvard Medical School. The $2,500,000 project is due for completion a year hence.
TRENTON, Jan. 6 -- New Jersey Democrats will reduce the number of Assembly employes from 119 to fifty when they take control of that house next week for the first time in twenty years.

TOKYO -- Japan's business boom, the greatest in her history, is slowing down because of the doubtful outlook for foreign exchange resources, which are the lifeblood of the economy. Six months ago the Government itself put the brakes on burgeoning business expansion by tightening credit. This action was motivated by an increasing drain on foreign exchange, without which the Japanese cannot import raw materials necessary to support industrial growth.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The defense debate got louder here today, and in some ways funnier.

SALLY VICTOR is a softy. There isn't a stiff hat anywhere in her new collection for spring. It highlights gaily printed silks and cottons, waferthin felts and straws, all tucked and pleated like material. Her favorite shapes are the cloche, turban and roller-brimmed breton, all gently molded.

J. H. Whitney Co. has announced the admission of four general partners. They are Charles E. Brown, Howard D. Brundage, John P. Horgan Jr. and Fred M. van Eck. The company is a private investment firm with interests in the oil, gas, radio, television, electronics, frozen food, power tool, shipping and chemical fields.
Prices of cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 22 points off to 6 points up yesterday, with the near months weak.

ROME -- Last year was the second poor year in succession for Italian agriculture. The gross product of agriculture, forestry and fishing, which are lumped together in Italian statistics, was equal in 1957 to what it was in 1956. And 1956 was 2.6 per cent below 1955.

BONN, Germany -- West Germany's economic expansion was braked last year by an ever-tightening labor market. A worsening shortage of workers is expected to be the chief limiting factor on further expansion.
BERLIN -- In defiance of Communist threats, West Berlin continues to invest steadily in making itself a bright little island of free enterprise deep inside the gray stretch of East Germany.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Congress is reassembling tomorrow in a mood resembling the past and almost forgotten urgencies of wartime.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. announced today that he would try to put an anti-segregation amendment on President Eisenhower's proposed billion-dollar school aid program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Representative John B. Bennett, Republican of Michigan, said today he would introduce bill when Congress reconvenes designed to reduce sharply copper imports.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -President Eisenhower's budget will estimate a deficit for the current fiscal year, now halfway complete.

DUBLIN -- For the first time since 1946 the Republic of Ireland, which comprises twentysix of the thirty-two counties, had in 1957 a small surplus on its balance of trade instead of a deficit. Government measures taken over the last two years to curb imports and expand exports have reduced an adverse trade balance of u60,500,000 by more than u25,000,000 (u1 equals $2.78 1/8 ).

HONG KONG -- The countries of Southeast Asia, with the exception of Indonesia, had a relatively good economic year in 1957. Production and foreign trade were, in general, maintained at good levels and budgetary positions kept in manageable terms.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The International Printing Pressmen's and Assistants' Union and the American Newspaper Publishers Association signed today a five-year renewal of their arbitration agreement.

The rehabilitation programs of the Volunteer Service Photographers will be aided as a result of a theatre party on Jan. 23. "Two for the Seesaw," starring Henry Fonda, has been selected for the event. The play is scheduled to open at the Booth Theatre Jan. 16.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -President Eisenhower's budget will estimate a deficit for the current fiscal year, now halfway complete.
The Board of Education is carrying its recruitment campaign for new teachers directly to the parents of city pupils.

SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 6 -The scheduled biennial meeting of the five Central American republics' foreign ministers has been postponed for the third time, pending national elections in Guatemala and Costa Rica.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 6 (UP) -Harvey Conover, of Mamaroneck, N. Y., sportsman-publisher, and four other persons were missing in wind-lashed seas off the southern coast of Florida today in a forty-five-foot racing yawl.

MANILA -- The Philippine economy is admittedly sick. Competent analysts think it is overstimulated by foreign aid and encouragement and undernourished in the elements that could be provided by united purpose and national application to hard work.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands -- One of the first tangible results of the European Economic Community (Euromarket) will be seen in this great port.

DUBLIN -- For the first time since 1946 the Republic of Ireland, which comprises twentysix of the thirty-two counties, had in 1957 a small surplus on its balance of trade instead of a deficit. Government measures taken over the last two years to curb imports and expand exports have reduced an adverse trade balance of u60,500,000 by more than u25,000,000 (u1 equals $2.78 1/8 ).

HONG KONG -- The countries of Southeast Asia, with the exception of Indonesia, had a relatively good economic year in 1957. Production and foreign trade were, in general, maintained at good levels and budgetary positions kept in manageable terms.

MANILA -- The Philippine economy is admittedly sick. Competent analysts think it is overstimulated by foreign aid and encouragement and undernourished in the elements that could be provided by united purpose and national application to hard work.
New York parking meter receipts will set a new record at more than $7,000,000 in 1958, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley predicted yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 7 -- The two new economic communities that are to unite six European nations began to take official shape today but failed to acquire a capital.

TRENTON, Jan. 7 -- An authority on Soviet affairs declared today that the United States could achieve lasting world peace if it could keep pace with Russian arms development and avoid war for ten or fifteen years.
The flow of United States goods and private investment to Latin America rose on a record flood tide in 1957.

The financially stricken New York Shakespeare Festival, the fate of which hinges on whether it is allocated life-giving funds today from the Board of Estimate, received a helping hand late yesterday from Actors Equity Association.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Fred Hooper's Olymar, a highly regarded 3-year-old colt, made a successful winter debut in the Sun City Purse today at Tropical Park.
MONTREAL -- President Eisenhower's illness late in November and continued Soviet intransigence contributed heavily to the downward trend in prices on Montreal stock markets last year.
MOSCOW, Jan. 7 -- What sputniks and tractors don't accomplish for Soviet prestige at the Brussels World's Fair this summer, Moscow will try to gain with song and dance.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 7--Mayor Jacques Chevallier of Algiers has become optimistic about an early solution of Algeria's civil war.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 7 -- Education will be a potent influence in shaping Germany's future because of the lessons of the past, Dr. James B. Conant asserted tonight.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 7 -- President Sukarno of Indonesia said upon his arrival by plane today that his country's present policy was "a positive contribution toward peace and stability in Southeast Asia." The Indonesian leader is here

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Following is the text of a statement by Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Senate majority leader and chairman of the Preparedness subcommittee, to a meeting of Democratic Senators today:
LONDON, Jan. 7 (Reuters)--Malcolm Muggeridge, controversial writer, tonight made another provocative suggestion--the abolition of Queen Elizabeth's New Year's Honors List.

Gian-Carlo Menotti announced yesterday that, having succeeded in raising $136,000, he would present a three-week festival in Italy next summer. One of its chief aims will be to demonstrate to Europeans the skills and talents of young Americans in opera, ballet, theatre and painting.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -An assessment of Latin America's reaction to the European common market is in prospect for mid-March, as the climax of meetings to be held in the first quarter of 1958 in Santiago, Chile.
POMONA, Calif., Jan. 7 (AP) -- The racing empire of the late Louis B. Mayer was dispersed today following the sale of fifty-nine horses last night for a total of $821,000.
Consolidated net operating earnings of the Marine Midland Corporation and its constituent banks and affiliates climbed to a record of $14,663,655 last year.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The newest trend in furniture design is permanent, built-in, rather than furniture, a group of designers agreed at a meeting in the American furniture mart here this morning.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- In spite of "some temporary problems," leaders of the business community in this West Coast province say they see no cause for alarm in the long view. However, they seem to have some misgivings about the immediate future.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Representatives of Britain's major symphony orchestras have appealed to the Arts Council for 90,000 ($252,000) in additional financial aid.

REGINA, Sask. -- Hopes have been voiced that the multi-milliondollar hydroelectric and irrigation project will be started this year on the South Saskatchewan River, about ninety miles south of Sasketoon.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 7 (AP) -A national fund for research to catch up with the many new ways of stimulating race horses to run faster was announced today.

WOLFVILLE, N. S., Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Kings South Progressive Conservatives Association has asked the Canadian Government to allow United States airlines to operate between Nova Scotia and the United States because Trans-Canada Air Lines "does not provide a
The Public Housing Administration plans to offer $67,135,000 of new housing bonds on Feb. 5.
A heavy blanket of snow fell on metropolitan New York yesterday in 1958's first storm. The Weather Bureau said five inches of snow had fallen at the Battery.

The Lower East Side committee of the Visiting. Nurse Service of New York will sponsor its eleventh annual tea dance in the Crystal Ballroom of the Park Lane on Jan. 23. Articles donated by guests at the dance will be sold at the Bargain Box, 1579 Third Avenue, providing additional funds for the nursing service.
BUENOS AIRES -- Argentina's foreign trade deficit continued to grow last year and all signs were that it would be even greater this year. The chief deficit was in trade with the United States.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The Legislature reassembles here tomorrow for a state election-year session in which shrinking revenues are expected to brake new spending programs.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Brazil exported greater quantities of iron and manganese ore in 1957 than ever before. The prospects are for continued gains as demand and operations increase.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 7 -Recommendations for solving Long Island's transportation problems were studied today by county officials and business and industry leaders.

The Emil Mogul Company, Inc., has elected Alfred Paul Berger a vice president. Mr. Berger was with the agency when it began in 1940 with four employes and billings of $200,000. (It now employs 136, and billings exceed $10,000,000.)

MEXICO CITY -- When President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines took office five years ago he ended a six-year spending spree that had done much to prime Mexico's economic pumps but that had left its Treasury reeling.

Since Gladstone, the office of Chancellor of the Exchequer has been second only to the Prime Minister's in importance and authority in the British Cabinet. For a Chancellor to resign on a matter of principle, as Peter Thorneycroft did on Monday, is an extraordinary event and one that is bound to have some repercussions.

In recent emphasis on safe driving and highway expansion needs, the Government of British Columbia cited figures that also serve as an index of the province's economic growth. The number of motor vehicles equipped with British Columbian license plates in 1935 amounted to only 96,867 and ten years later was still only 132,282.
James R. Dyer has been nominated for his third successive one-year term as chairman of the American Stock Exchange. The election will be held on Feb. 10.

The American Hardware Corporation yesterday assumed control of the Savage Arms Corporation management with the election of six directors to the eleven-man Savage board. The six, all officials of American Hardware or sympathetic to the company, were named at a special meeting of the Savage board here.

Formation of a membership corporation of seven commercial banks in New York State was disclosed yesterday. It was described as an association for exchange of information and experience in all phases of banking.
HAVANA -- The construction of a shipyard in Cuba and the building of twenty-five cargo vessels is the latest project on the Cuban Government's industrialization's program.

Last-minute pressure proved too much for the New York Knickerbockers as they dropped a 114-to-112 decision to the St. Louis Hawks in the feature of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 7 -The greater New York area is the least Protestant of this country's twenty major metropolitan centers, it was disclosed here today.
EDMONTON, Alberta -- The oil industry in Alberta felt the pinch of reduced export marketings in the second half of 1957.

AT least Lew Fonseca has stopped using the same, tired plot for each of the world series movies he annually produces, directs and narrates. No longer does he have the Yankees winning the dang thing like the gun-shootin' hero of a Western horse opera. He varied the denouement of his most recent cinema offering by having the Milwaukee Braves ride triumphantly over the horizon just like the Indians who caught up with Custer.
Nelson A. Rockefeller said yesterday that "there is no need to be frightened" by the report of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund on the nation's military posture.
The Board of Higher Education took the first step yesterday to establish a two-year community college in Queens.

Recently the Export-Import Bank of Washington, overseas lending arm of the United States Treasury, lent $550 to a company in Georgia to permit the export of a disk harrow to a buyer in Brazil. It was the smallest loan in the bank's twentythree-year history.

The New York Rangers, who will be without the services of Dean Prentice for quite some time, have made changes in a couple of their lines in an attempt to get out of their slump at the expense of the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 7 -- A proposal that the state insure mortgage loans made to community development groups for factory construction by private investors was made by Gov. Dennis J. Roberts today in his annual message to the Legislature.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 7 (AP) -- The efforts of Walter O'Malley's homeless Dodgers to get the Pasadena Rose Bowl as a temporary haven ran into a new legal snarl today.

Expanded operations have been scheduled this year for Panama's free trade zone at Colon. The zone, now in its tenth year, offers a strategic base for further processing and re-export distribution of goods for Latin American markets.

Plans are being completed for the Jan. 16 benefit performance of "Look Homeward, Angel" at the Barrymore Theatre. The event, sponsored by the New York Wellesley Club, will aid the college's faculty-salary fund.
A little-known tree -- the caranday palm -- is one of Paraguay's most important natural resources. The potential may go far to aid an under-developed country.

Presidents of 109 companies, mostly large ones, have taken a long look into the future for Dun Bradstreet, Inc. On the average, they predicted that their profits would rise 57.8 per cent by 1962, sales would rise 34 per cent, invested capital 27 per cent and number of employes 15 per cent.

THE highly seasoned tomato sauce of Naples and Sicily, redolent with garlic and basil, is just one of the proper dressings for spaghetti, macaroni, polenta (much like our corn meal) and for the other starchy staples of Italy.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Negotiations for the return of Mickey Rooney to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in his once familiar role of Andy Hardy have been completed.
