TORONTO -- Deepening of the rock-bottom Welland Canal -one of the world's busiest waterways -- is being carried out quickly, efficiently and safely by a new, air-cushioned blasting technique.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Fifty to 100 of the state's 1,000 migrant labor camps have unsatisfactory health conditions, a state investigation showed today.
The city asked the Appellate Division yesterday to permit no delay in the transfer of property for the $205,000,000 Lincoln Square redevelopment.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- A sudden rise of grain shipments through British Columbia ports has been one of the encouraging factors on the West Coast in 1957. More prairie wheat has moved through elevators here than through eastern Canadian shipping points.

Four major finance companies yesterday announced across-the-board cuts of 1/8 per centage point in commercial paper rates effective today. The rate is the interest which these companies pay on their short-term obligations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, Army Chief of Research and Development, will join Maj. Gen. Bernard A. Schriever, Air Force missile expert, and Rear Admiral John E. Clark, of the Navy's missile division, in an appearance on the Jan. 19 "Wide Wide World" program, "Missile Men," according to an announcement by the National Broadcasting Company.

Stockholders of Canadian companies received a record $722,959,865 in dividend payments in 1957, or 8 per cent above the previous peak of $668,680,599 in 1956. Last year was the fourth consecutive year for record dividends, according to J. R. Timmins Co., Toronto, brokerage firm that keeps a running count of dividends.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Following is the text of the White House announcement on President Eisenhower's request to Congress for more money for the Department of Defense for the current fiscal year:

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras -The first sample of Honduran newsprint paper was recently delivered to the Honduran National Economic Council, an initial step in the creation of a $50,000,000 pulp and paper industry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A former Justice Department official who has been a vigorous critic of court procedures became today the chief administrative officer of the Federal judiciary system.

The Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Inc., had record earnings in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, Norman Tishman, president, said in the annual report issued yesterday. It was the second consecutive record for profits.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -Senator Warren G. Magnuson said today that Secretary of State Dulles' resignation "would be the best thing that could happen for the free world psychologically."

WHEN Mister Bones was a 5-year-old in 1878 on his father's farm in Carbondale in the Kansas coal measure country, he walked behind the ox-drawn plow. The plow turned up fossilized sea shells by the hundred. The boy filled a farm shed with them.

The New York Legislature convenes today in its 181st annual session with plenty of work to do and, we regret to expect, plenty of politics to play. We hope Governor Harriman and the Republican legislative leaders won't forget which comes first in importance to the welfare of the state.

The Diocesan iIissionars-and hurch Extension Society of le Protestant Episcopal Church New York has purchased the acant blockfront on tile west de of Castle Hill Avenue beveen Lafayette and Yirgil venue in the Bronx.
Patrons and patronesses have been announced for the Viennese Opera Ball, which will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Jan. 17.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan flew off to India today convinced that he had settled the "little local difficulties" in his Government. But politicians saw a major crisis in the offing for his Conservative party.

Owners of property where a collapsed retaining wall forced the evacuation of sixty-four Washington Heights families must replace it with a safe wall, Commissioner of Buildings Bernard J. Gillroy said yesterday.
Many good seats are still available for the two theatre parties that will aid the work of the Vocational Advisory Service.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 7 -- Spokesmen for Catholic and Protestant colleges adopted a joint policy today for church-related institutions of higher education.
Sugar-exporting countries of Latin America have just completed the most profitable year since 1951, when the Korean conflict sent prices soaring.

Air freight in 1957 continued the rapid development it had known since the early post-war years. The airline industry estimated the average gain in freight business last year among the country's scheduled ones at 20 per cent in more than in 1956.

The chief source of tin in America is at the roof of the world -- the "altiplano" of Bolivia. This is a highland plateau more than 12,000 feet above sea level, surrounded by the snowcapped ranges of the Andes.
Trinidad's economy appears to be more secure now than it has been in a number of years, if 1957 was any indication.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The Marquess of Salisbury, who resigned from the Government last March in a disagreement over policy on Cyprus, warned today against any move by Britain that would affront Turkey.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 7 -- Premier David BenGurion was officially returned to office tonight as Israel's Government crisis ended.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Governor Harriman was reported today to favor a program of compulsory hospitalization for narcotic addicts.

Preparations for this year's enlarged national sports car rally program are in full swing. The first big event will be the Florida Triangle Rally during the week-end preceding the annual Grand Prix of Endurance (twelve-hour race), which will be held at Sebing March 22.

With one subway strike over and the threat of another ended, and most of us back underground, it's time to review some of the things learned during the recent unpleasantness, when many of the trains actually had stopped running.
QUEBEC -- The Province of Quebec, per capita the world's largest producer of hydroelectric power, plans to increase its generating capacity by 36 per cent within the next three years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -Senator Lyndon B. Johnson called today for a national policy dedicated to winning control of outer space.
WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Messenger Stake, the richest event in harness racing with an estimated value of $125,000, will be held July 4, Roosevelt Raceway disclosed today.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- The Peace River area of north-eastern British Columbia will be served by a new link to the rest of the province when the Pacific Great Eastern Railway reaches Dawson Creek and Fort St. John in mid-1958.
TORONTO -- The biggest expansion in the history of the pipe-making industry in Ontario took place in 1957 with the opening of three new mills representing a total investment of $37,000,000.
AT this late date it is no longer necessary to observe that Tennessee Williams is a writer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for an additional $1,370,000,000 to speed missile development and expand air defenses. Of this amount, $1,260,000,000 would be in new funds.

NEW YORK CITY's army of working women now numbers 1,073,911. Of these, 375,745 are involved in some kind of secretarial or clerical work earning weekly salaries ranging from $60 to $120 and up. Their numbers are steadily increasing with each year and one of these new additions is the young woman shown in the photographs at the right.

NEWARK, Jan. 7 -- The disappearance of the Director of Public Safety of West New York from his usual precincts became less of a mystery here today as a surprise witness testified before the State Law Enforcement Council.

The Canadian interest structure is easing and with the exchange premium on the Canadian dollar is tending to diminish. Therefore the dependency of Canada on the United States capital market is likely to be less acute this year than in 1957, according to the investment banking house of Wood, Gundy Co.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Administration has decided to trim its budget request for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare nearly $300,000,000 below the amount it asked last year.
Canadian investment companies look for the economy to resume its growth in 1958, with total output continuing at a high level.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- A rift of several years standing within the Republican leadership of the Legislature was patched up today.
TORONTO -- Natural gas first came to this second largest Canadian city (pop. 1,400,000) early in 1955. Its rapid acceptance by both home owners and industry since then has been remarkable.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- In a statement released at the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention today, Vic Obeck, the director of athletics at New York University, emphasized that Howard Cann had not been "fired" but would retire, at his own request, at the end of this season.
MELBOURNE, Jan. 7 -- Federal Trade Department officials at Canberra believe that despite severed diplomatic and trade relations, the Soviet Union may be buying Australian wool through Polish bidders.

A biography of Calouste Gulbenkian (1869-1955), one of "the richest, most mysterious men the world has ever known," will be published Feb. 6 by Rinehart. Entitled "Mr. Five Per Cent," it is the work of Ralph Hewins.

Negotiations to bring commuters on New Jersey railroads into Manhattan by the way of the Hudson and Manhattan tubes were disclosed yesterday. The negotiations were projected as a basis for developing an alalternative to the proposed New York-New Jersey transit loop.

Joseph S. Robinson has been elected chairman of the board of the American Ice Company. He fills the vacancy created by the death of Charles S. Small. Mr. Robinson is the largest individual stockholder in American Ice.
ROME, Jan. 7 -- The Rome Opera rejected today Maria Callas' offer to sing without fee in scheduled performances tomorrow and Saturday.

WINNIPEG, Man. -- One of the world's oldest and richest trading companies was founded on a fashion in hats. The Hudson's Bay Company, now closing its books on its 289th year of business, sold most of its first furs to hat makers.

PERTH, Australia, Jan. 7 (UP) -- Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, and Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn, America's entries in the West Australian tennis championships, easily gained the men's doubles semi-finals today.

GUATEMALA -- This country's Five-Year Plan for public works, initiated in 1954 by the late President Carlos Castillo Armas, has been financed with liberal United States aid, the Guatemalan Government's own resources and loans.

An aging eleven-story building on the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street soon will be stripped to its steel skeleton and rebuilt as a nineteen-story office structure sheathed in aluminum and glass.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 7 (Reuters) -- Gales and blizzards swept northern Europe today and took the lives of at least nine men whose ship foundered and sunk off the Dutch coast.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Milwaukee County Board of Supervisors today approved the County Stadium baseball rental contract proposed by its park and recreation committee and sent it to the Milwaukee Braves for approval or rejection.
A recorded address by Lester B. Pearson of Canada will be broadcast by radio Saturday evening at the same time that the winner of the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize will be interviewed live on television.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that its use of "bugging" equipment in future subway strike situations was highly unlikely.

WINNIPEG, Man. -- The sharp crack of sledges driving spikes echoed across the Precambrian shield on a sunny afternoon late in October and marked the completion of one phase of the $175,000,000 International Nickel Company development 400 miles north of here.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Jan. 7 -- White-rabbit hunters of this region are suffering as only white - rabbit hunters without snow can suffer. Their passionate bellows can be heard clearly above the petulant whining of the skiers.

The San Francisco Forty- Niners yesterday placed four men on The Associated Press National Football League All- Star team. The world champion Detroit Lions, the Green Bay Packers and Baltimore Colts had three representatives each.

CALGARY, Alberta--As 1957 ended Alberta was starting on its third battle over the export of natural gas. The possibility existed that a royal commission might defer a policy settlement for a long time.

HALIFAX, N. S. -- Shippers and producers in Canada's Martime Provinces received a little bonanza during 1957. Last July the Federal Government finally agreed to a cut in rail freight rates to points out of the provinces to other parts of Canada.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- The new superintendent of the Westfield State Farm here, a prison and reformatory for women, intends to add more femininity to the 590 inmates and morale-building facilities to the 260-acre reservation.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 7 -Two large motels, one at Ardsley and the other at Albany, have been battling in State Supreme Court here for the exclusive right to the name Thruway Motel. In a 3,000-word decision today, Justice Samuel W. Eager ruled that neither had the exclusive right to the name.

Pete Rademacher, whose only claim to professional boxing fame is his knockout by Floyd Patterson, the world heavy-weight champion, will join five other former leading amateur boxers on a European tour to entertain American service men.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association today left the door open for Army, Navy and the Air Force Academy to continue sending athletes to preparatory schools to facilitate their admission to the academies.
HONG KONG, Jan. 7 -- Shanghai has mapped drastic plans to hold down its burgeoning population. The program is part of a new campaign in China to check the drift to urban centers.
The art of conversation is not dead. It never will be for those who wear hats by William J. As usual, this boy from Boston is full of beans.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- The principal producer of bananas in Costa Rica is the United Fruit Company of Boston, and Costa Rica in turn is the largest banana-growing country in the company's far-flung "empire."
MANY women deserve medals for good housekeeping, but Natalie Donohue is the first actually to receive one.
TORONTO -- Trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange zigzagged through the troubled last half of 1957. However, toward the end of the year the market rallied quickly after every setback.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Bill Quillian of Seattle let the way into the third round of the Florida West Coast tennis tournament with a 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1 victory over Jim Vuille of St. Petersburg today.

Hofman Laboratories, Inc., manufacturer of iron and steel forgings, leased the former plant of the Eagle Tool Mcchine Company at 5 Evans Terminal Road, Hillside, N. J. The plant is a one-story structure containing 21,000 square feet.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 7 (UP) -- The authoritative business publication Review of the River Plate today estimated that Argentine Government expenses for the 1957-58 fiscal year were $1,468,000,000, or $282,472,000 above the officially announced figure.
The new chairman of the American Committee of the International Press Institute is Paul Block Jr. of The Toledo Blade. James Kerney Jr. of The Trenton Times will be honorary chairman.

TORONTO -- Canadians use more tobacco per capita than any other country in the world and more than 99 per cent of it is grown in sandy soil in Quebec and Ontario. Until the Nineteen Thirties that land had been written off as useless for agriculture.

PANAMA -- The economy of the Republic of Panama made solid long-term gain last year in fisheries, agriculture and the circulation of increased payroll monies earned by its residents employed in the Canal Zone, which had an exceptionally heavy year.
ELIZABETH ARDEN thinks pink. The rosiest and most romantic resort fashions in town are now assembled in her Fifth Avenue salon ready to pop into the suitcases of south-bound travelers.

The First Boston Corporation and Kidder, Peabody Co. jointly head an underwriting group offering today $50,000,000 of Commercial Credit Company 4 1/8 per cent 20-year notes at 99 to yield 4.2 per cent.

FIVE contemporary chamber works, all of them relatively brief, were introduced last night at a concert presented by the B. de Rothschild Foundation for the Arts and Sciences at 316 East Sixty-third Street.
A recent sale of roadbuilding machinery to Venezuela, the construction of a cement plant in Mexico and the shipment of textile equipment to Greece might seem unrelated events.
QUEBEC -- The mineral industry of Quebec, second in importance only to pulp and paper, had a year of mixed blessings.

With $2.4 million supplied by Congress, the Department of Agriculture has already started on its program to spread across millions of acres of Southern farmland a lethal poison known as dieldrin, more toxic than DDT, and to do it at the rate of two pounds per acre.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The United States and France reached almost full agreement today on replies to recent Soviet proposals for new efforts to ease East-West tensions.
The Mangel Stores Corporation received a certificate of merit last night from Mayor Wagner for helping to "keep New York City a great place in which to do business."
A 3-month-old girl died in a Brooklyn tenement fire yesterday morning because her 9year-old brother had tried to be helpful.

Jamaica, probably the most gorgeous chunk of bauxite in the world, has issued an economic report indicating the one-time isle of planters and pirates is becoming a sturdy little mining and industrial country with a tourist-tempting calypso beat.
As 1957 drew to a close your newspaper gave deserved emphasis through editorials and news columns to the serious problems of American farmers and farm workers.
REGINA, Sask. -- The economy of this province remained surprisingly buoyant in 1957 despite the drop in cash farm receipts. Tax revenues actually ran higher than in the preceding year.
SAN SALVADOR -- Though some plans for public works will be abandoned because of reduced Government revenues, El Salvador will complete all those that have been started.
SANTIAGO, Chile -- A sharp drop in copper prices seriously affected Chile's economy last year.
MOUNT-KISCO, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- A plan to change the names of twenty-seven streets here on Feb. 1 turned out to be more of a headache today than anyone had anticipated.

EDMONTON, Alberta -- All signs indicate the chemical industry will become an industrial giant in Alberta. In the new year, more millions will be spent as various projects are developed to take advantage of the huge reserves of natural gas and oil.

" A Farewell To Arms," David O. Selznick's adaptation of the Ernest Hemingway novel, with Rock Hudson, Jennifer Jones and Vittorio De Sica, has been scheduled to open on Friday, Jan. 24, at the Roxy Theatre.

YELLOWKNIFE, N. W. T. -Three routes have been suggested for a railway to the mineral-rich Great Slave Lake region of the Northwest Territories, particularly to Pine Point on the south shore of the lake.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- The last full year of Jose Figueres' Government has seen a slowing of the economic pace, notably in the public works program. It was attributed to over-optimistic financial planning and to the previous year's strikes, floods, blowdowns and crop blights.

New Yorkers donated 349 pints of blood to the Red Cross Monday. Employes of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, stock brokers, at 70 Pine Street, gave 141 pints toward this total. Members of the Knights of Pythias at Congregation Derech Emonch, 199 Beach Sixty-seventh Street, Arverne, Queens, gave 123 pints.

EMME'S spring hat collection by Adolfo skyrockets to new heights. The tall turbans steal the show, though the collection includes pretty feminine cloches, bretons, deep-brimmed slouches and wide-brimmed portrait hats, all enhanced with ribbons, bows or flowers.

APEACEABLE abstract domain is Felix Ruvolo's in his latest paintings at the Poindexter Gallery, 21 West Fifty-sixth Street. Ruvolo, who used to organize his paintings in rhythmic but closely defined sequences of form and color, has relaxed greatly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -United States exports, not including military aid, held virtually steady in November at the October level, the Bureau of the Census estimated today. The November estimate was $1,602,000,000, compared with $1,599,000,000 in October.

Bobby Fischer, the 14-year-old Brooklyn schoolboy who is the national open titleholder, last night became the United States champion by finishing first in the tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Western replies to recent Soviet peace appeals will be delayed at least ten days or two weeks.

BERLIN, Jan. 7 (UP) -- The United States, Britain and France charged in a protest note today that the Soviet Union had violated Big Four agreements in transferring control of travel visas to East Germany.

If Senator Thurmond likes to think of himself as a responsible interpreter and defender of our Constitution, how can he possibly assert that states' rights are being trod upon when civil liberties are upheld?
Columbia University announced yesterday a $200 increase in tuition for the academic year beginning next September. Tuition will rise from $30 to $37 a credit point.
MONTREAL -- Although the St. Lawrence Seaway is not scheduled to be formally opened by Queen Elizabeth until early in 1959, the economic impact is already being felt throughout this entire area.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- More than 100 bills were introduced in the House of Representatives today as the second session of the Eighty-fifth Congress got under way.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -President Eisenhower's farm received soil-bank payments of $2,009.60 for not growing corn and wheat in the last two years.
TORONTO -- Several Canadian subsidiaries of parent companies in the United States are replacing executives from the United States with young Canadians.

OTTAWA -- Exploration for oil overshadowed all other mineral activities in Canada's Yukon and Northwest Territories last year. All signs point to the probability that the search for oil will again dominate the picture in 1958. Immense areas of northern bush country are under survey by such large oil companies as Shell, Mobil Oil of Canada and British-American Oil, which last year spent more than $3,000,000 in exploratory work.
Latin-American coffee-producing countries have just finished a trying year. Prices declined gradually most of 1957. Coupled with lower prices was a reduction in exports.

HARTFORD, Jan. 7 -- John Lodge, Ambassador to Spain, addressed a Republican luncheon group today without giving indication that he would be a candidate for the party's nomination for Governor this year.
MOSCOW, Jan. 7 -- Pravda called on Communists today to pursue vigorously the proclaimed goal of a united front with non-Communists.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz declared again yesterday that he would conduct "one massed drive against organized mobster operations" in the state if Governor Harriman directed him to do so. However, he complained that the Governor had refused so far to issue such a directive.
TRENTON, Jan. 7 -- The five-year-old New Jersey Law Enforcement Council, long a controversial agency, will be disbanded next Tuesday.
MIAMI, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Hope that a New York publisher's missing boat had been located was dashed today.

EDMONTON, Alberta -- A three-man commission appointed by the Alberta Government is grappling with the problems of northern development. Its report, to be submitted, to the next regular session opening about Feb. 13, is expected to have a major bearing on industrial expansion plans.

Deputy Police Commissioner Robert J. Mangum will appear at Police Headquarters Friday afternoon to resume his explanation of why he countermanded a friend's arrest last Sept. 25, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy moved today to squelch a brewing interservice fight over whether the Air Force or Navy should develop the first nuclear-powered plane.
THE Lyric Wind Ensemble, a quintet, gave a concert last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. The assisting artist was Leonid Hambro, piano soloist in Mozart's E flat Quintet for Piano and Winds, K. 452.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 7 (Reuters) -- Sweden was prepared to modify her traditional neutrality and intervene militarily in occupied Norway at the end of April, 1945, according to a statement published by the Swedish Foreign Ministry here today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 7 -- At least five Roman Catholic priests have been arrested here since the New Year's revolt against the Government. There were indications that the Church might soon adopt a strong attitude against the regime.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- A vital question at this moment to coffee-priducing countries is whether the recent emergency measures to stabilize world coffee prices by a "withholding" agreement between the coffee republics will work in practice.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 7--One of Dr. Konrad Adenauer's trusted lieutenants who can be relied on to do the right thing at the right time is Prof. Walter Hallstein, a soft-spoken bachelor who is Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.
AARON ROSAND, Indiana-born violinist who played his first local recital in two years at Carnegie Hall last night, reaffirmed the favorable impression he made at earlier appearances here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The foreign travels of Congressional committee members cost $291,248.02 in foreign currencies alone during the last fiscal year. This total, reported to Congress today, does not include the American dollar expenditures made from appropriations to the committees the travelers represented.

WINNIPEG, Man. -- One of Canada's oldest and largest grain and investment concerns, James Richardson Sons, Ltd., celebrated a century in business in September with a unique trans-Canada birthday party.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Three Israelis were sentenced to life imprisonment today for the assassination of Dr. Israel Kastner, who had been found guilty of preparing the way for a mass murder of Hungarian Jews by Nazi police during World War II.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Grain futures, with the exception of corn, closed higher on the Board of Trade here today.
The last thirty minutes of trading in yesterday's stock market brought a sharp lift to prices.
HAVANA -- The United States Technical Assistance Program is proving to be an important factor in the economic development of Cuba.

TOKYO, Jan. 7 -- The Japanese Cabinet agreed in principle today to extend $15,000,000 in long-term, low-interest loans to the countries of Southeast Asia. Details will be worked out by the bureau chiefs of the economic ministries concerned.
HAVANA -- Cuba, after a highly prosperous year, entered 1958 with excellent prospects marred only by the possibility of continued political violence.
CARACAS, Venezuela -Venezuela's prosperity continued in 1957.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -President Eisenhower expects a "material pick-up" in the economy after the middle of the year, it was disclosed today.

UNLESS my count is mistaken, Van Wyck Brooks' new book, "From a Writer's Notebook,"* is his twentyfifth. Like most of its twenty-four predecessors this newest work by the most eminent living American literary critic is written with smooth skill and is obviously the product of an interesting and a first-rate mind.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The officers at key points in the Senate and House of Representatives have not changed from the line-up that took hold as the Eighty-fifth Congress convened last Jan. 3. They are as follows:

A woman who pleaded guilty last October to stealing $244,000 from her employer received a suspended sentence yesterday in General Sessions Court. She is Miss Frances Ranne, 39 years old, of 2275 Barker Avenue, the Bronx.

SPARTA, Ga., Jan. 7 (UP) -Marvin E. Moate, Speaker of the Georgia House of Representatives, proposed today that the state re-enact the poll tax as a means of cutting down "as much as 75 per cent of the Negro voters."
HALIFAX, N. S. -- Nova Scotia's apple growers, who love their traditional market in Britain through World War II, and happy these days.
BOGOTA, Colombia -- Colombia spent a difficult year in 1957 trying to clean up the economic chaos left by Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, the ousted dictator.

The chief spokesman for 25,500 unionized long-distance telephone workers warned yesterday that a strike was "imminent." However, the union head gave assurance that no walkout would come until after union and company representatives met again this morning.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- Louis Armand, the Frenchman named today to direct the European Atomic Energy Community, is described by an associate as "one of those rare technicians with a farranging imagination and the ability to express his imaginings in facts."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Congress met today and declared its readiness to join the Eisenhower Administration in a concerted effort to strengthen the nation's security.
Bronx County Judge Samuel J. Joseph yesterday criticized reformers of juvenile delinquents and, in particular, the staff of a Police Athletic League unit.

It seems to me that the average high school student generally admires the athlete, rather than the scholar, in school. In fact, the bright student frequently refrains from overly spectacular achievement as a result of this backward attitude, with a consequent waste of intellectual ability.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Administration is considering the possibility of lowering interest rates on loans to underdeveloped countries.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- Efforts to make cacao a second national export crop, and thus to some extent relieve economic stability from its virtual dependence on coffee, went ahead last year under the twin stimuli of increased production and unexpectedly better world prices.
There will be a new kind of waterfront strike in the Port of New York this morning.
LA PAZ, Bolivia -- Bolivia hopes that 1958 will see change for the better in her economy.

It is well to be reminded at least once a year that not Europe or Africa or Asia but Latin America and Canada are the most important places in the world for the trade and security of the United States. Popular interest is a capricious phenomenon, and one of its dictates is that there should be little attention paid to our hemispheric neighbors.

HAVANA -- The search for petroleum in Cuba, which brought a rush of wildcat oil operators to the scene and created a near boom in 1954 and 1955, has settled down to scientific exploration and test drilling.
Robert Moses, chairman of the State Power Authority, rejected yesterday a group of proposals from the Interior Department for operation of the Niagara power project.
The City Stores Company, which operates sixty-one department and specialty stores in fifteen states, elected Max Robb president yesterday.

A sampling of 500 "competent inventors" showed yesterday that one-third had defense ideas they had not submitted to the Government. Their reason for not doing so was "an unfavorable picture of both the reception and rewards."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The intercontinental ballistic missile program is still handicapped by inadequate funds and no decision has yet been made in the Pentagon to expedite the offagain-on-again nuclear aircraft project.

The advent of atomic-powered icebreakers, new type icebreaking cargo ships, designs for portable nuclear power units and new means of polar transport has enforced a reappraisal of Antarctica's potential. Presumably the continent that caps the bottom of the world has mineral resources comparable to those of other large land masses -- it is almost as large as Europe and the United States combined.

A family saved $15 for the Neediest by going without meat for a week. A letter from "the E. family" yesterday said its five members sent the amount in memory of Thomas F. Cahill, who died in November.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Official figures showed today that the national stockpile of critical materials was more than 91 per cent full. The goal is a stockpile that will provide for a three-year supply.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 7 -- A grenade exploded here tonight near a trolley-car stop outside a neighborhood movie theatre. Thirteen persons were injured.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua -- For the second consecutive year, this country had an adverse balance of trade. This was not indicated by figures for the first nine months that showed imports amounting to $60,816,092, against exports of $61,595,534.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- The sharp drop on world markets of the prices of most of the commodities that are Latin America's lifeblood seriously affected last year the region's capacity to import as well as to go on at desired speed with basic economic development.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas sounded the keynote for the new session of Congress today, and it wasn't the Senate Democratic leader's portentous statement on missiles that did it, either.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay -Little Uruguay entered 1958 facing big problems.
The emergence of Sears, Roebuck Co., as an advertiser in national magazines was detailed yesterday at a meeting of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Statler Hotel.
The North American newsprint picture changed sharply last year. After a long period in which demand outstripped productive capacity, supplies finally caught up to, and then passed demand.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -Pennsylvania and Navy jointly announced today that they would continue their football series at Franklin Field through 1960.

The Hospital for Special Surgery at 535 East Seventieth Street, said to be the first orthopedic hospital in the United States, will receive the proceeds of the performance on March 27 of "The Entertainer." The play is scheduled to open at the Belasco Theatre Feb. 12.

MEXICO CITY -- The insurance business in Mexico has been expanding at the rate of 20 per cent a year for a decade, according to a study just released by the National Bank of Foreign Commerce. Thus it is the fastest growing business in the country. In 1910 only one insurance company operated in Mexico. Today there are more than forty companies in the capital, and several score smaller, regional organizations in the interior.
BUENOS AIRES -- Argentina faces continued economic hardships in this critical election year.
MANANTIALES, Tierra del Fuego -- The oil industry has made the "Land of Fire" live up to its name again.
The Port of New Orleans last year achieved the best foreign trade performance in its history.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras -A "realistic" economic program now being discussed by Honduran economic planners and political leaders ties the future development of this country to United States assistance.
VANCOUVER, B. C. -- The arrival of British Columbia and Alberta natural gas was probably the most important single industrial event for this province in 1957.
WELLINGTON, N. Z., Jan. 7 (Reuters) -- Dr. Fuchs and his team advanced another thirty-one miles toward the Pole today.
Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges.
MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 7 -Albanian military planes have forced down a United States Air Force jet, the Tirana radio said today.
Two 19-year-old Civil Air Patrol cadets back from McMurdo Sound in the Antarctic, have arrived in New York for a tour of the city.

Four college students were held yesterday in $10,000 bail each on grand larceny charges. They are accused of having stolen an unspecified number of books and phonograph records from public libraries in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -House Speaker Sam Rayburn predicted today consideration of an Alaskan statehood bill at this session of Congress.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Jan. 7 -- Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah, the tall Kashmiri Moslem who was one of India's great leaders until he was arrested four and a half years ago, will leave his mountainside prison soon, probably in a matter of days.

After a brief period during President Eisenhower's first term when it seemed that international tensions were being somewhat relaxed, we are again plunging headlong back into the awful abyss of the cold war -- or worse.

The pre-election hue and cry of the proponents and opponents of a constitutional convention has died down since the adverse decision to the holding of a convention rendered by the votes on last Election Day. The problem of how best to amend or revise the State Constitution remains.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -President Eisenhower will make a political speech at a Republican dinner in Chicago Jan. 20, as originally scheduled.

HALIFAX, N. S. -- Nova Scotia, like its sister Maritime Provinces on Canada's east coast, is still not sharing fully in the nation's expanding economy. Far removed from the markets in Central Canada and beset by high freight rates to get its products there, Nova Scotia's industrial development has been meager when measured against that of other provinces.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Important long-range achievements were recorded by Brazil last year in her uphill struggle for economic development, but the 1957 ledger was closed with melancholy features.

SAN SALVADOR -- El Salvador enters the New Year with the realization that, as President Jose Maria Lemus has put it, her "years of the seven fat cows" have ended. But with an international agreement in operation to support coffee prices, and with a sound currency and growing industries, this tiny, densely settled Central-American republic faces 1958 with cautious optimism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -An official of the CurtissWright Corporation testified today that integrated use of its tools and those owned by the Air Force had saved the Government "millions of dollars" in the manufacture of airplane engines.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas made his long-expected move today into the center of the political arena.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 7 -- Communist China has offered a $20,000,000 loan to Indonesia on a long-term basis for industrial purposes.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 7 (UP) -- A blonde, who handles herself perfectly in the clinches, is winning a unanimous decision today over all those boxing skeptics who feel a woman's place is in the home and not in the prize ring.
GUATEMALA -- Political instability and the deteriorated coffee situation are casting long shadows on the Guatemalan economy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Senate Rackets Committee is about to start its second year in business, with political dissension threatening its effectiveness.

George Killion, president of American President Lines, Ltd., has received the sixth annual award of the New York Foreign Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association. The award was made in recognition of Mr. Killion's "many important con

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 7 (Reuters) -- Israel was reported tonight to have told Western Ambassadors the work of a special United Nations mission here would be jeopardized if the Security Council debated a Jordanian complaint against Israel concerning the demilitarized zone at Mount Scopus.

MONTREAL -- A little island in the St. Lawrence River long the retreat of nuns of the Congregation of Notre Dame has been sold to private interests, incorporated into a suburb of the City of Montreal, and is about to become a residential community linked to the mainland by a bridge.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation announced today it would develop a major part of its studio property in West Los Angeles into a "master planned city" to accommodate a resident working population of 37,000.
More than $2 billion worth of Government purchasing has been earmarked for small business, Wendell B. Barnes, Administrator of the Small Business Administration, said last night.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras -The international monetary reserves of Honduras have declined for the third straight year, but prospects for reversing this trend are improving.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Yesterday's resignation of Peter Thorneycroft as Chancellor of the Exchequer led to widespread initial marking down of prices on the stock market today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Soviet Army newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda singled out the Transcaucacus command today in asserting that political indoctrination had been inadequate in the military forces.
OTTAWA -- Canada, after a good year in 1957, entered 1958 hoping for continued prosperity at present levels. However, she did not expect the sensational spurts of the last few years to be repeated.
LONDON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- Dr. Willem Drees, Premier of the Netherlands, said today that Indonesia had destroyed all chances for a compromise solution of the controversy over Netherlands New Guinea.
Pan American World Airways will offer economy service on more than half of its trans-Atlantic flights in the summer.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The Conference of Antivivisection Societies protested to the Soviet Embassy today that there was nothing that could be learned from dogs sent into space that could not be learned better from instruments.
Ecuador's economic health was demonstrated in 1957 by a $5,000,000 foreign trade surplus, long-term fiscal policies and the removal of almost all trade restrictions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower and other Government officials prayed for enduring world peace at a special church service today marking the reconvening of Congress.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The State Banking Department has recommended an increase in the amount of capital required to start a bank or open an office of a foreign bank in New York.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Sir Edmund Hillary, leader of the New Zealand party in the British Commonwealth's Trans-Antarctic Expedition, has been asked to "report at once" on his plans to aid his leader, Dr. Vivian Fuchs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -The Secretary of the Army today offered Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin certain promotion to four-star general and a choice of two major Army assignments if he would withdraw his announced plan to retire at the end of March.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- A House Armed Services subcommittee called today for suspension of the forced separation of veteran officers who are only a few years short of earning retirement benefits.

Clem McCarthy, 75-year-old sports announcer, appeared in State Supreme Court in a wheelchair yesterday to testify in his $250,000 damage suit against Edward J. C. Owen, advertising executive. The case is being heard by Supreme Court Justice Henry Epstein and a jury.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Dr. James R. Killian Jr., scientific adviser to President Eisenhower, said tonight that the United States was still technologically superior to the Soviet Union. But he said it must accelerate its efforts to maintain this supremacy.

WHILE the furniture buyers of the country milled around Chicago's Merchandise Mart this week, Bloomingdale's staff here in New York put the finishing touches on its annual mid-winter room settings. The store is leading off with the first showing here of the much-touted Shaker-inspired group designed by MacDougall Stewart for the Drexel Furniture Company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- State Department sources suggested today that the rumors of a manned Soviet missile flight might have been prompted by a fictitious broadcast Sunday on Moscow radio.

LIMA, Peru -- Though exports and imports have continued at record figures and employment and construction are at a high level, there is concern in both Government and private business circles as to what the future may hold. This is induced chiefly by the uncertainty in the United States and some European countries.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -For every dollar lent by the United States Export-Import Bank to Chile's thriving steel plant at Huachipato, the company has spent $2 for supplies and services in the United States.
THE annual month-long water-color exhibition at the New York City Center Gallery includes seventy-five examples in a range from illustrative realism to complete non-objective.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -This week's offering of $750,000,000 in Federal National Mortgage Association notes will bear an interest rate of 3 5/8 per cent, the Treasury announced today. The notes will be dated Jan. 20 and will mature Aug. 23, 1960.
The Yale School of Drama is to represent the United States in August at the International Festival of University Theatres at the Brussels World's Fair.

"The Court of Last Resort" will be terminated April 4. The film series about crime detection, which made its debut last fall, is televised on Fridays from 8 to 8:30 P. M. by the National Broadcasting Company.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The stock market was more buoyant today and most sections erased nearly all of Tuesday's losses.
Personnel of Fort Monmouth, N. J., will give blood to the Red Cross today.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 8 -- Residents of the Shorehaven community on the waterfront here are objecting to plans by the Norwalk Jewish Center to establish a recreational facility in the neighborhood.
Importance of continuing research in the textile industry was stressed last night at a meeting of the American Association of Textile Technology, Inc., at the Vanderbilt Hotel.
HONG KONG, Jan. 8 -- Hundreds of thousands of Chinese Communist officials are beginning a tough new life down on the farm this winter.
Thoroughbred racing in New York State experienced a big year in 1957, with patrons wagering $416,941,870, according to the annual report of the State Racing Commission released yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (Reuters) -York City, a struggling Third Division English League team, today scored a stunning 3-0 upset over Birmingham City of the First Division in a thirdround Football Association Cup game.

FATHERS-TO-BE today may spurn the traditionally smoke-filled hospital waiting room. Some prefer, instead, to be at their wife's side during her labor, and occasionally even venture into the delivery room to offer comfort and assurance during the birth.
TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 8 -- The Toronto Stock Exchange tonight announced measures designed to end a recent spate of unethical practices.
SEATTLE, Jan. 8 -- Music lovers of Seattle today welcomed the news that Milton Katims is staying as conductor of the Seattle Symphony.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 8 -- Navy's basketball team held Gettysburg to four field goals in the first half in posting a 63-45 victory over the Bullets today.
CORNING, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- More than 100 antique humpen -- German drinking vessels, some of which hold as much as three quarts -- have been received as a gift by the Corning Museum of Glass here.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Republican leaders of the Legislature have concluded that their party's chances of recapturing the State Administration this year would be improved by a spring primary and an early nominating convention.
The nation's railroads, particularly the big Eastern systems that are suffering crippling passenger service losses, are on record that 1958 will be a mighty rough year for profits.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, called today for high-priority action to reorganize the United States military set-up.

Objectors to the Lincoln Square redevelopment disputed in court yesterday the city's contention that only Fordham University could be injured if Fordham were ruled ineligible to participate after the city had taken title to the area.

In an exhibition of fabrics both old and reproduced that opened yesterday at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 57 East Fifty-seventh Street, the personalities of Madame de Pompadour and Madame du Barry live again.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Jan. 8 -- If you want to find out why a promising welterweight boxer such as Gale Kerwin is going up in proficiency and coming down in weight, the best place to get the answer is in a department store on Rockaway Avenue in this South Shore community.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -President Eisenhower will deliver to Congress tomorrow a 5,500-word State of the Union message that his press secretary calls "different from anything we've ever given."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Senate rackets committee announced today two new series of public hearings.

Plans to expand the Bronx Zoo and the Aquarium at Coney Island were disclosed last night at the sixty-second annual meeting of the New York Zoological Society. Dr. Fairfield Osborn, president of the society, said that $660,000 would be spent to modernize the zoo.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Committee for a National Trade Policy objected today to a provision of the Administration's proposals to extend the Reciprocal Trade Law for five years.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 8 -A seven-year community campaign to establish a state-operated technical institute in the heart of the Fairfield County industrial area is about to show results.

TRENTON, Jan. 8 -- An investigation of possible links between the underworld and North New Jersey officials, dropped yesterday by the State Law Enforcement Council, will be continued by a local grand jury.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -Secretary of State Dulles told a Congressional committee today that a meeting of the heads of government of the United States and the Soviet Union at this time would be futile.

"The Lost One" (1951), directed by and featuring Peter Lorre, will be shown today through Saturday in the series "Past and Present: a Selection of German Films, 1896-1957," at the Museum of Modern Art. Screenings take place in the museum auditorium daily at 3 and 5:30 P. M.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 8 (UP) -Eddie Arcaro suffered sprained ligaments in his left knee today when he was thrown by a 2-year-old maiden filly at Santa Anita race track. Doctors said he probably would be sidelined for ten days.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Governor Harriman promised today a crackdown on two methods that unscrupulous businessmen use to fleece unwary buyers -- phony bargains and "bait" advertising.
City and state officials are investigating a complaint that a critically ill woman was the victim of mistreatment and bungling at Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn last week.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 8 -- West Germany has paid out $1,500,000,000 to Jews and other victims of Nazi persecution under a twelve-year restitution program launched five years ago.

A dispatch from Moscow to this newspaper indicates that the Soviet Union plans to use this year's world's fair in Brussels as a vehicle to prove that it excels the United States in virtually every phase of human activity, from the technical and scientific to the artistic.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- The Soviet Union's most famous composer, Dmitri Shostakovich, joined today the chorus of officials who are trying to drown out jazz and sentimental pop tunes that continue to appeal to segments of Soviet youth.
Increased powers for the City Council were urged yesterday by Council President Abe Stark.
There is something wrong with the picture of a three-star General and the Secretary of the Army publicly discussing the terms on which the General would, or would not, receive his fourth star.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- A pledge of Parliamentary support by the three Ministers who had resigned steadied the position of the Conservative Government today.
A former United States Navy officer has been arrested in Cuba, his brother said here yesterday in making known appeals on his behalf to the State Department and United States Embassy in Havana.

Johnny Dio was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions Court to serve fifteen to thirty years in prison for labor extortion and conspiracy. Before he was sentenced by Judge John A. Mullen he was lectured by both the judge and an assistant to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The purchase of an additional twenty-two acres of land in Chavez Ravine, the chosen site for the Los Angeles Dodgers' ballpark, today was delayed until after the June 3 referendum vote.
In a 2-to-1 decision the United States Court of Appeals granted bail to Frank Costello yesterday pending the appeal of a ruling denying the gambler a new trial on income tax evasion charges.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 8 -- Shai K. Ophir, Israeli pantomimist, will play the title role Feb. 2 in "Rumpelstiltskin," the second of the "Shirley Temple's Storybook" fairy tales to be produced by Henry Jaffe Productions.
The country's biggest retail trade organization went on record yesterday as favoring Sunday closings for all but a few kinds of stores.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -A former official of the Eisenhower Administration called today for a substantial reduction in income and corporation taxes to restore business confidence and halt what he termed a drift "into socialism."
ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Following are the major recommendations in Governor Harriman's annual message to the Legislature today:

Your editorial of Dec. 30 "Moscow's Glass House" suggests that if the Russians are sincerely anti-imperialistic they should give up their own lands "from the Urals to the Pacific." "Have the Russians any more right in Siberia," your writer asks, "than Englishmen have in Kenya or Indians in South Africa?"

When the Queen of New Zealand (better known to us as Queen Elizabeth II of England) was in Auckland on a trip at the end of 1953 she referred to the Commonwealth as "an equal partnership of nations." Such being the case, it was logical that a British Prime Minister in office should for the first time go out to visit the Commonwealth nations in Asia and the antipodes.

HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 8 (AP) -- A 16-year-old white boy was stabbed critically today in a fight with Negro passengers on a city bus. The incident occurred after he had ordered a Negro girl to move from the seat next to him, the police said.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 8 -- The $18,000,000 Gregory Gardens housing project, already approved by Federal agencies, is now the subject of a local dispute on arrangements to finance the low-rent development.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Governor Harriman told the Legislature today that within two years New York State would be the country's principal producer of Christmas trees.

Governor Harriman's fourth annual message, prefacing a state election year in which he will stand for a second term, is self-confident but moderate in tone, almost devoid of new excursion in policy, and cautious of greater spending because of the state's "increasingly stringent financial situation."
BERLIN, Jan. 8 -- The Communist regime indicated today that the East Germans' austere standard of living would be improved only if citizens worked harder.

THE world of food has not ignored the fact that we live in an age of space and speed. The General Foods Corporation made it known this week that its product called Minute Rice no longer requires the thirteen minutes' preparation that it used to. The revised version, available in grocery stores in a new carton, can be fully cooked in exactly five minutes from package to plate.

Lenox, Inc., big manufacturer of fine china, is entering the plastic dinnerware field through the purchase of the Branchell Company, at a price exceeding $2,000,000. Based on a combined sales volume of some $14,000,000 a year, Lenox will rank as the nation's leader in the dinnerware field.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the holiday shortened week ended Tuesday, Dec. 31:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Gen. Thomas D. White told investigating Senators today that the Administration had trimmed a new Air Force request for money to speed development of ballistic missiles.
District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Kings County defended last night the use of legal wiretapping by prosecutors in crime investigations.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 (UP) -Governor Harriman today sent to the Senate for confirmation the nomniations of John A. Davis of New York and Mary Louise Nice of Tonawanda to the State Commission Against Discrimination.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- The Harriman Administration entrusted nineteen of its program proposals today to the Republican-controlled Legislature.
Maracay, Venezuela, where the abortive revolt against Dictator Marcos Perez Jimenez commenced the other day, is a garrison town in tropical lowlands west of the capital, Caracas.

AT a time when the Impressionists were intent on banishing black from their palette, Odilon Redon possessed black ever more tenderly, pulling out his haunted visions from the depths of a spellbinding darkness that only Rembrandt and Goya had known before him.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- Fanya (Dora) Kaplan, who as a young Social Revolutionary forty years ago shot and seriously wounded Lenin, was reported tonight to have died last month in a Moscow prison. She was thought to have been about 70 years old.
VARIETY is the spice of Irene's spring and summer hats, designed by Bob Green. No woman will have a problem picking out one that will please her husband, for every hat is completely feminine.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- Army's hockey team was toppled from the ranks of the unbeaten today, but the cadets' basketball and swimming squads fared better.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The Defense Department reported today that its world-wide property holdings were valued at $146,000,000,000 last June 30. It said the total included everything from typewriters to aircraft carriers.
OTTAWA, Jan. 8 -- Further action to dispose of some of Canada's huge stores of unsold wheat to relieve hunger in Southeast Asia was announced in the House of Commons today.
Stanley M. Isaacs, 75-year-old Republican minority of one in the newly installed City Council, was elected the Council's Minority Leader for the third time yesterday.
MIAMI, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A vast sea and air search for the missing yacht Revonoc continued in the Atlantic Ocean today without any encouraging reports from the Coast Guard.

After five years of labor, and some grievous setbacks, a pre-federal European union having as its ultimate goal a United States of Europe has at last started on its way. This union takes the form of a European Economic Community and a European Atomic Energy Community comprising six West European nations with a combined total of 175,000,000 people.

Having personally inspected the newly opened "Paddle Your Own Canoe" in London, Michael Myerberg is on the verge of signing contracts for the purchase of the comedy. Max Regnier wrote the play, based on a scenario by Andre Gillois.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Grain futures prices, caught between a lag in export business and continued prospects for a big 1958 winter wheat yield, finished mostly lower on the Board of Trade today.

The sixteenth annual Carey Thomas Award for creative book publishing has been given to Frederick A. Praeger for publishing "The New Class: An Analysis of the Communist System," by Milovan Djilas. The award, established by the R. R. Bowker Company, bears the names of Isaiah Thomas of Worcester, "father of the American book trade," and Mathew Carey, noted Philadelphia publisher of a century and a half ago.
PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Renewed Communist overtures for unity of action with Western Socialist movements were ignored by leaders of the Socialist International, who met here today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Sugar Hart lashed away at Larry Baker to gain a unanimous decision in a ten-round welterweight bout tonight at the Chicago Stadium.
VIEWERS who consider themselves smarter than the average television quiz show contestant should enjoy the new Channel 2 program called "Dotto."

William Michelman, who had contracted to buy the four-story building at 449 West Fifty-sixth Street, has resold his contract to an investing client of Irving Bira, broker in the deal. The property is 50 by 100 feet and contains thirty-one apartments. It was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $114,400.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- The Republican leadership in the Senate moved today to speed the legislative session before it was an hour old.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.

PERTH, Australia, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Another exciting match loomed today between Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, and Australia's Mal Anderson after they advanced to the semifinals of the West Australia tennis championships. Anderson defeated the Ohioan in a five-set Davis Cup match at Melbourne last month.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 8 -- Martine Carol, French actress, will star with Jeff Chandler and Jack Palance in "The Extra Edge."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Defense Department will propose in next year's military budget a one-third increase in funds for research and development of new weapons.

A sharp pain darted through me as I read the advertisement in The Times announcing that the General Services Administration "is now authorized to offer one of the most famous landmarks in the world, Ellis Island, for commercial use." A phase of the American dream is going down the drain of materialism.

It took a hat trick by Camille Henry last night to snap the New York Rangers' losing streak. The three-goal output by the Broadway Blues' sniper did not bring victory, but it enabled the Rangers to earn a 5-to-5 deadlock with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden.
William Talbert, Davis Cup team captain, and Donald Budge, former world champion, are members of a committee named to make new monthly awards for outstanding service or achievement in lawn tennis.
Brooklyn College, one of the four municipal institutions of higher learning in New York City, yesterday disclosed its intention of returning to intercollegiate football.
James H. Van Alen and Alastair B. Martin, both of New York, gained a second-round victory in the pro-amateur doubles handicap court tennis tournament yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -Twenty-three former Hollywood actors, writers and stagehands told the Supreme Court today that they had been unconstitutionally blacklisted from the movie industry.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- A member of the National Coal Board declared today that Britain's new industrial machinery was not increasing production as rapidly as that in the United States was being stepped up.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 8 -- Venezuela's dictatorial regime veered today toward the path of conciliation in an effort to repair the serious political damage inflicted by the revolt a week ago.
The three ore carriers of the Ford Motor Company's Great Lakes fleet transported their second highest tonnage volume during the 1957 season.
Dade County, Fla., sold $14,500,000 of jail and courthouse bonds to an investment group headed jointly by Halsey, Stuart Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co.
The "Park Avenue" beetle -- so called because it thrives on the luxury of wall-to-wall carpeting -- has become the city's No. 1 residential destructive pest.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -Witnesses for commercial airlines told Congress today that more Federal aid would be needed to adapt the nation's airports for commercial jet planes.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 8 -- The Association of American Colleges split today on the issue of Federal aid to higher education.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Governor Harriman proposed today the creation of a three-member state crime commission for a centralized attack on crime and racketeering.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -Outlays for new construction last year totaled $47,300,000,000, or 3 per cent more than the record spending of 1956, the Commerce and Labor Departments reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -Representative Victor L. Anfuso, Democrat of Brooklyn, introduced today a bill to eliminate the acreage reserve section of the Administration's soil bank program after 1958.

IN a recent review of Raymond Aron's "The Opium of the Intellectuals," I had a sentence noting that since M. Aron's book had first appeared in France some three years ago, it offered American readers the disadvantages of dated topical allusions. Thanks to the vagaries of my writing with a quill pen, or something, the word topical appeared as tropical in the printed version.
The Hilton Hotels International disclosed yesterday that its executives had been questioned by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan in his investigation of the Albert Anastasia murder.

Cocoa futures rallied late in the day on the New York Cocoa Exchange, raising all positions except the near-by January the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit. The late strength reflected buying in anticipation of higher grinding reports expected late yesterday.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 8 -- Gov. Thomas B. Stanley urged Virginia's Legislature today to hold firm to his program that so far has kept the state's public schools segregated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Government estimated today that the 41,000-mile interstate highway construction program would cost $37,622,000,000. This is $10,000,000,000 more than was contemplated when Congress approved the program.
The Daily Worker will cease publication after next Monday, according to an announcement in today's issue of the Communist party organ.
The debt securities of two utilities and two railroads amounting to more than $78,000,000 are being offered publicly to investors today. The offerings are:
VALLETTA, Malta, Jan. 8 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Dom Mintoff said today there now was no need for Malta to sever her colonial ties with Britain as he had threatened last week.

SEVERAL new rifles are now on the market to confuse the competition among gunmakers in the production of new calibers, new designs and new gimmicks. Most of these are 22-calibers and, in view of the constant flow of new models, it would be nice to know how many people in this country are target plinkers.

The metropolitan area sanded, salted, plowed and shoveled its way out yesterday after a snow-fall that reached five inches in the city and more than a foot in some suburbs. Vehicular traffic was slowed, but no major tie-ups were reported.
The outlook for a peaceful settlement of a wage dispute involving 25,500 long-distance telephone workers brightened again yesterday. On Tuesday a union spokesman said a strike appeared "imminent."

Brantwood Camp in Peterborough, N. H., where city boys are sent for two-week summer vacations, will gain as a result of the Feb. 6 performance of "Two for the Seesaw." The new play, which co-stars Henry Fonda and Anne Bancroft, is scheduled to open next Thursday at the Booth Theatre.

IF one characteristic of antiques stands out above another it is infinite variety. But when antiques are in the quality class, as they are at the Winter Antiques Show, which opened yesterday, some customers may wryly propose cost as a runner-up in distinguishing traits.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Federal Housing Administration took two steps today to stimulate the current revival in home building.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- France passed on to her Minister in Albania today a request for "information" on a United States jet trainer and its pilot forced down by Albanian fighters. This action was taken prior to receipt of a request by Washington for French intervention to obtain the release of the plane and pilot.

AMONG the specialist enterprises that help to give New York a musical life in depth the Bach Aria Group is one of the most valuable. There is nothing high-pressure about it. The area it has chosen for its own, the cantatas and arias and other rarely heard works of Bach, does not encourage a flamboyant posture, but it is immensely rewarding when cultivated with sincerity and taste.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- When the President tomorrow completes his State of the Union message to Congress, assembled in joint session, the first firm outlines of the answer to a momentous question of this age will be apparent. The question is: Can and will he fully and firmly lead the United States, and hence the free world?
HONOLULU, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Admiral Maurice Curts, deputy commander of the Pacific Fleet, has reversed the convictions of four Marine brig guards accused of brutality, the Navy announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -Representative Charles R. Brownson, Republican of Indiana, has the solution for interservice rivalry in the Pentagon -- make 'em all full generals.

WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 8 -- Dogs that follow their young masters to school have been giving school officials here a difficult time. Dog Warden John Turnbull said he had received many complaints in the last two weeks.

Cincinnati, one of the nation's strongest collegiate basketball teams, will meet Seton Hall in the second game of tonight's double-header at Madison Square Garden. Another good team, Xavier of Ohio, is pitted against Iona in the opener at 7:15.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -An airlines spokesman today recommended that military transport flights be reduced and that more military business be given to commercial airlines.

New York's first no contract, no work strike by steamship office workers will shift from the waterfront to State Supreme Court this morning. The strike began Tuesday when contract negotiations bogged down.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Jan. 8 -- Sheikh Abdullah, one of the most important political prisoners in Asia, became a free man -- and a power in his native Kashmir -- at 5 P. M. today.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (AP) -Mrs. Valerie Nelson today divorced Donald M. Nelson, industrialist, World War II War Production Board chief. Mr. Nelson agreed to pay her $1,000 a month alimony and to turn over between $350,000 and $400,000 in assets.
More than a quarter of a century of labor peace was ended last night when millinery workers called a nation-wide strike to enforce wage demands.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, "reluctantly" approved today Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin's request for retirement. Mr. Brucker made a last effort to persuade the Army research chief to change his mind, even after General Gavin had told the Senate Preparedness subcommittee that his decision to quit March 31 was "final."
A Supreme Court jury early this morning awarded Meyer Levin, author-playwright, $50,000 in damages in his suit over the play "The Diary of Anne Frank."
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 8 -- A pall that could not be attributed entirely to the winter weather hung over this city today. Brussels has not been chosen -- so far, at least -- the "capital of Europe."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -Government losses in carrying out farm price support programs are running about 18 per cent less than a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Commerce Department announced today it had eliminated private industry executives from the top job in all twenty-four of its industry divisions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission painted a glowing picture today of progress in atomic power development.
The moon may be a dead sphere now, but it could become a very lively place if Mayor Wagner and the Attorney General have their way.
TRENTON, Jan. 8 -- New Jersey was urged today to adopt a statute resigned to prevent involvement by legislators and other state officials in conflicts of interest.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Lloyd Sharrar's field goal with two seconds to play marked a sensational rally by unbeaten West Virginia as the nation's No. 1 basketball team scored a 76 -- 75 victory over Villanova tonight in the first game of a double-header at the Palestra.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 8 (Reuters) -- Sir Edmund Hillary said today he would help Dr. Vivian Fuchs and his team "beat the weather" by dropping emergency fuel supplies and by leading him on the last leg of his trans-Antarctic trek.
Employes of the Roxy Theatre have selected the Neediest as beneficiary of their 1957 Christmas charity fund. Their contribution of $218.75 was the largest gift received yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 8 -- Estimates of military power in Germany indicated today that the balance would shift temporarily in favor of the United States if the Soviet command withdrew 41,000 men from East Germany, as has been announced.

TRENTON, Jan. 8 -- The State Department of Conservation and Economic Development today asked the Federal Government to underwrite two-thirds of the cost of a $210,000 study of slum clearance operations in metropolitan North Jersey.
Cotton futures moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) up to 13 points (65 cents a bale) off on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- The Soviet Government reasserted today its "historical" rights to regard Peter the Great Bay off Vladivostok as its private property and warned the Japanese to keep out.
Lower earnings for the first fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31 were estimated here yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders of Mergenthaler Lino-type Company.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., plans to spend this year a record $200,000,000 for expansion of its utilitynetwork, Charles E. Eble, president, told yesterday's luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

Traders marked time yesterday for the President's State of the Union message and stocks hardly moved. The average eased a bit. Volume stayed about the same, 2,230,000 shares, against 2,220,000 on Tuesday.
CHICAGO, Jan. a (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ALBANY, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Bills that would increase the State Police force from 1,200 to 1,700 men and speed pay rises in the lower ranks were introduced today by two Syracuse Republicans.

ALFONSO MONTECINO started a four - concert series last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association that will encompass the forty-eight preludes and fugues of Bach's "Well Tempered Clavier."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 8 -- The Indonesian Army stressed today that "military exercises" scheduled for Jakarta tomorrow should not be interpreted as anything more than that.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- The Legislature got Governor Harriman's message in a new, streamlined form today.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Jan. 8 -- Bob Bornholdt's field goal with forty seconds of the five-minute overtime period remaining gave the United States Merchant Marine Academy basketball team a 58-to-57 victory over Queens College tonight. Bornholdt also sent the game into overtime when he scored just before the regular playing time ended to knot the count at 51-all.
The General Dynamics Corporation, whose stock was the second most active on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, has been the subject of new merger rumors for weeks.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 8 -- Evidence of public discontent, restlessness and a desire for governmental changes has been growing here in recent months.
