LIMA, Peru, Jan. 8 -- The resignation of Juan Pardo Heeren as Minister of Finance and Commerce was announced to the Government last night.
The possible abolition of the City Council or a change in the election of its members was suggested last night by Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -A House investigating subcommittee announced today that it had won the right to subpoena the files of Government regulatory agencies.
DETROIT, Jan. 8 -- Lay-offs totaling nearly 10,000 workers were disclosed today in the auto industry and at an associated company.

Having clinched first prize in the semi-final round, Paul Keres of Russia lost for the first time in yesterday's ninth and final round of the international chess masters tournament in Hastings, England, bowing to Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia, according to a report received through British news sources.
NEWARK, Jan. 8 -- Mayor Wagner said today that New York was opposed to the $500,000,000 New York-New Jersey transit loop proposed this week by the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission.

Ski Sketch: Harry W. Voege sat in the offices of his big housewares firm on the northeast corner of Manhattan's Murray and West Streets yesterday. Through his street-level windows, he watched Sanitation Department workers dump fresh powder snow into manholes.

From his double vantage point as chairman of the Senate Preparedness subcommittee and majority leader, Senator Lyndon Johnson issued a timely call at the opening of Congress for Americans to wake up to "the peril of the hour." We hope and expect that the President will strike a similar note of urgency today.

NEWARK, Jan. 8 -- The development of the Jersey Meadows for marine recreation was pinpointed as the Metropolitan Regional Conference voted today to cooperate in a $60,000 three-state survey of space available for parks.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- The Soviet Union has launched a new system of decentralized guidance of agricultural production.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- A former member of a Teamsters Union local in Jersey City testified today that local leaders rigged a 1956 election.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Gov. George M. Leader of Pennsylvania urged Congress today to approve a $5,000,000,000 ten-year program to eliminate the "national disgrace" of slums. He said every American was entitled to a decent home.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, a leader in last year's civil rights fight in the Senate, announced today that he would soon present a new civil rights bill "with bipartisan sponsorship."
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- C. Douglas Dillon warned tonight that the Soviet economic challenge was too "serious and menacing" to be brushed aside.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Representative James P. Fulton, Republican of Pennsylvania, told Secretary of State John Foster Dulles today that he should order Harold Stassen to choose between his job as disarmament adviser to the President and running for Governor of Pennsylvania.

Mayor Wagner took his campaign for economy in expense budget estimates directly to the Municipal Building yesterday. He told about three dozen commissioners and agency representatives to be conservative in their 1958-59 figuring.

UNQUALIFIED opposition to an American citizen doing espionage work for the Communists was about the only point clearly registered last night by "The Velvet Trap," David Davidson's play on the "Kraft Television Theatre" over Channel 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -Lieut. Gen. James Maurice (Slim Jim) Gavin was born in Brooklyn. And at the Pentagon today some were calling him the Leo Durocher of the Army -- brilliant in his field and outspoken.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon was the principal speaker today at a luncheon meeting of the American Football Coaches Association.
Last night's opera at the Metropolitan was "La Forza del Destino," and Carlo Bergonzi, making his first appearance with the company as Don Alvaro, took the evening's top honors.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 8 -- West Germany's military contribution to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is of "prime importance" to freedom in Europe, Dr. James B. Conant said tonight at Harvard University.

The advertising account of Alitalia, the Italian airline, has been awarded to Dowd, Redfield Johnstone, Inc. This ended a two-month search by the company. Fourteen agencies had solicited the business.
PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Britain won support from the North Atlantic Council today on her claims for continued payments by West Germany to offset the cost of maintaining British forces on the Continent.
DETROIT Jan. 8 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers broke a four-game winning streak of the Cincinnati Royals tonight with a 123-105 National Basketball Association victory at the Detroit Olympia.

PEIPING, Jan. 8 (Reuters) -The mothers of two United States civilians jailed by the Chinese Communists since the Korean War arrived here tonight. They still were uncertain when they would be allowed to visit their sons or whether the jailed men even knew they were here.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- Angry citizens tonight demanded that the Board of Education here make plans immediately to build two new high schools.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 8 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain talked today with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru on the chances of easing East-West tensions.
Bernard F. Gimbel, chairman of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., received the Tobe Award last night as Retailer of the Year at a dinner in the St. Regis Hotel.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Special exemptions for foreign corporations from Securities and Exchange Commission rules were attacked today as favoritism by an S. E. C. commissioner.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The price of milk -- low to the dairyman and high to the housewife -- is a major concern of Governor Harriman in his annual message to the Legislature.
Admiral Arthur W. Radford said yesterday he was confident the United States was ahead of the Soviet Union in over-all military strength and in the race for technological superiority.
A 6-foot-3, husky Southerner will speak for many of the nation's big stores this year.

Domestic production of crude oil and condensate in the week ended last Friday dropped 76,300 barrels to 6,863,460 a day, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This compared with 7,416,815 barrels a day a year ago.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -Opposition to the idea of giving the service academies a blanket waiver from a proposed amendment barring pre-admission financial aid to athletes was evidenced today.

The five-story apartment house at 270 East 161st Street, southeast corner of Morris Avenue, the Bronx, has been resold by Bernard Siegel. The building contains apartments for fourteen families and a store. It was acquired by a syndicate of investors represented by Samuel A. Chodrow.

The city Administration and the Board of Education were urged yesterday by teachers' representatives to take measures to end the teacher shortage here. A recent board report showed that more than 5,000 teaching vacancies existed in the public school system.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The American Council on Education asked Congress today to approve an "across-the-board" college scholarship program that would not be limited to the science field.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- This suburban city today began studying a formula for school integration recommended by a team of New York college professors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Lewis L. Strauss indicated today that the Atomic Energy Commission had no plans to reopen the security case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, physicist.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 8 -- Protestant churches were called upon here today to "reorient" their approach or admit defeat in the battle for the soul of urban America.

GEORGE BALANCHINE is a most surprising man. His "Gounod Symphony," which had its premiere last night at the City Center by the New York City Ballet, gave every indication in advance of being just another of his resourceful manipulations of the classic idiom on the basis of a musical composition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Sir Harold Caccia, British Ambassador to the United States, warned today that the Chinese Communist-Soviet economic offensive now under way posed a fresh challenge to the economic assets of both Britain and the United States.

DUCK hunters of this region, who have been crooning out of tune all season because of good (and therefor bad) weather, might listen to the joyous caroling from farther South. Or maybe it wouldn't be a good idea, at that.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told the New York Young Republican Club yesterday that the United States must try to meet the needs of the people in the Middle East if it is to win friends there.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Aides of James R. Hoffa announced today that 100 officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters already had pledged contributions of $1,040 each to a fund designed to succor unionists in trouble with the law.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- The rapid growth of this Rockland County seat has created a serious bottleneck in the local post office.

THE Merchandise Mart, the gigantic wholesale furniture showcase in Chicago, will open its doors to the public for the first time next Friday. As soon as furniture buyers -- some 30,000 of them are estimated to attend this semi-annual market -- clear out of the building, everyone will be allowed in for a ten-day look.

OTTAWA, Jan. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker indicated today that the Canadian Government was not planning an early decision on whether to allow the export of natural gas by Trans-Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd.
PEIPING, Jan. 9 (Reuters) -- Three American mothers met their imprisoned sons today for the first time since the Korean war or before and found them well.

Rights to James Leo Herlihy's novelette, "A Summer for the Dead," have been acquired by Walter Starcke. The author will be responsible for the adaptation, too. Published in The Paris Review, the story develops in a Pasadena, Calif., boarding house.
Strauss "Der Rosenkavalier" ran its glittering course at the Metropolitan Opera last night for the third time under the leadership of Karl Boehm.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- Dr. Yussuf Haikal, Jordanian representative at the United Nations, challenged Mrs. Golda Meir, Foreign Minister of Israel, today over the strategic Mount Scopus area near Jerusalem.
HAVANA, Jan. 9 -- Nine persons have been killed and two wounded in mysterious shootings in Oriente Province in the last week, according to the Urgency Court of Santiago.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 9 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, speaking at a dinner in honor of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain, said tonight that Mr. Macmillan's recent suggestion for a nonaggression pact between East and West had been warmly welcomed in India.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- The state's first prosecution of a corporation for exposing employes to excessive radiation ended today when a suspended sentence was imposed here by Police Justice John F. Reed Jr.

MR. JOHN has thought of a million ways to brim a hat. This is his key silhouette. A close second is the high crowned shape. Flower concoctions round out his hat tributes to beautiful women, for Mr. John believes that all women -- so long as they are in fashion -- are beautiful.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- The General Assembly's Committee on South-West Africa decided today to defer action while a three-nation "good offices" body attempts to gain an agreement on the territory's status.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Some of the Naga tribesmen fighting for independence from India were reported today to have asked for temporary asylum in Burma.
Fluoridation of the city's drinking water to cut tooth decay was approved yesterday by the policy-making council of the state medical society.

LUEBECK, Germany, Jan. 9 (Reuters) -- The owners of the ill-fated sailing ship Pamir branded today as forged a message in a bottle, found washed up on an English beach, that blamed the captain for the disaster that took eighty lives.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 9 -- (AP) -- Thirteen-year-old Ilse Konrads, the newest of Australia's swimming prodigies, tonight shattered the world free-style records for 880 yards and 800 meters in winning the New South Wales championship.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 9. (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers closed with a rush tonight and defeated the Boston Celtics, 136 -- 123, in a National Basketball Association game. The Celtics played without Bill Russell for the first time since he joined the club thirteen months ago.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 507 persons who had passed the written examination for the bar. The examination, on Nov. 7-8, was taken by 1,026 applicants.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Some potentially explosive emotional and political issues are being balanced against the cold realities of costs and military security in the island of Trinidad.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 9 -- A leading New York church executive declared here today that Protestantism had failed to penetrate the culture of modern cities.
BERLIN, Jan. 9 -- The, East German Volkskammer (Parliament) approved today an economic plan calling for a 25 per cent increase in industrial production in the next three years.
ROME, Jan. 9 -- Communist-dominated labor unions ceased to control a majority of Italian workers in 1957. Deputy Giulio Pastore, head of a group of free labor unions, said at a news conference today.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions, a group of forty unions with a total of about 3,000,000 members, announced today that it planned to seek an increase in trade between Britain and the Communist countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Labor leaders have quietly but firmly told Senate racket investigators they are going a bit far afield. The unionists said that there was a limit to the cooperation that respectable labor could give to the Senate committee.

Four new nominees for membership on the board of Loew's, Inc., were named yesterday by Joseph R. Vogel, president of the big motion-picture producer, following a meeting of the directorate at the headquarters here.

The proposed $12,500,000 Park Row redevelopment project was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The cooperative slum clearance enterprise for 400 middle-income families will rise in lower Manhattan near City Hall.
The Transport Workers Union yesterday approved a contract worked out on New Year's Eve at City Hall. The vote was 8,128 to 2,310 for acceptance.
An old custom of group giving to the Neediest is being kept up by former students at a New York preparatory school.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 9 -- City Commissioner James F. Murray Jr. urged the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad today to produce early estimates on the cost of a connection here with the Jersey Central Railroad.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's State of the Union Message to Congress yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
WALLINGFORD, Conn., Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that it would fly four high school boys to a testing center at Chincoteague, Va., to fire a homemade rocket.
SEATTLE, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Dave Beck Jr. lost his bid today for a new trial on his grand larceny conviction. The judge said he would be inclined also to deny a retrial for Dave Beck Sr.
A leading Chinese surgeon sat in a midtown hotel yesterday and recalled the fates that had made him an Oriental-style Horatio Alger.
The report of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and its consolidated subsidiaries for the quarter ended Nov. 30 disclosed yesterday a net income of $7,443,989 after taxes and other charges.
A record budget of $249,102,600 was adopted yesterday by the Port of New York Authority. It represents an increase of 11 per cent over 1957.
NO man ever set down his political credo more simply than did Irving McNeil Ives in once observing that he sought "to improve the world -- not reform it."
PARIS, Jan. 9 -- The French will present a plan of their own for a European free trade area. It will be set against the British proposals in the negotiations by seventeen European nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- In a four-hour session with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today, Secretary of State Dulles put great stress on the need to meet the threat posed by the Soviet economic offensive in under-developed areas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- A finding of the Subversive Activities Control Board that the Communist party must register as a subversive organization was reversed by the United States Court of Appeals here today in a decision breaking new legal ground.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Democratic National Chairman, Paul M. Butler, assailed the message. In a statement he said "the delays, lags and failures to which Mr. Eisenhower entered an indirect plea of guilty in his talk today did not occur overnight. They occurred over the last five years."

Pictures of birds on the wing, in water, on trees and in the field have been spread on the walls of the American Museum of Natural History in an extraordinary collection of field sketches by the late Louis Agassiz Fuertes.
NAHA, Okinawa, Jan. 9 -- The Soviet Union's lead over the United States in missile science was aired thoroughly at an election rally on this semitropical island last night.

Yogi Berra, for many years now the Yankees' top-ranking catcher, was in an agreeable mood yesterday. He agreed he had not had a very good season in 1957. And, in becoming the first Bomber to sign his 1958 contract, he agreed to take a cut in salary, the first he has been asked to accept since becoming a Yankee regular in 1947.

An undergraduate committee composed of her classmates at Sweet Briar College has been formed by Miss Marylee Matthews to aid the alumnae of New York in arranging their annual scholarship fund benefit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Over Government objections, Federal Judge Charles F. McLaughlin today ordered a trial involving meat packers shifted to Chicago.

Jewel's Reward, the Maine Chance Farm colt that set a 2-year-old earning record in 1957, was assigned the top weight of 126 pounds yesterday for the Experimental Free Handicap. The $25,000 added mile-and-a-sixteenth race will be held in April during the early days of the Jamaica meeting.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- British Government loan issues again scored rises in more active trading today. Price changes among industrial shares were mostly small with falls predominating in many leading groups.

New Yorkers learned something new about boating yesterday from Gloucester, Mass., the saltiest seaport in the country. Gloucester is quaint and does things quaintly, to wit: It has twice elected a woman for Mayor.

Operators of ski areas in six Eastern states were busy dusting off their welcome mats yesterday for the biggest invasion of the season. Uniformly good snow-running conditions was the magnet expected to attract famished skiing enthusiasts.

A performance by the Mettropolitan Opera of Offenbach's operetta. "La Perichole" will be televised on Sunday, Jan. 26, from 4 to 5:30 P. M. It will be featured on the "Omnibus" program over the National Broadcasting Company network.

MONTREAL, Jan. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Restraint in making demands must become the responsibility not only of labor and business, but of the electorate and government as well, James Muir, chairman and president of the Royal Bank of Canada, said today at the bank's annual meeting.

Brown Shoe Company's business in the first two months of its fiscal year was "fairly good and ahead of last year," H. B. Hall, treasurer, told the annual meeting yesterday. He added, however, that incoming orders for Brown's wholesale division were behind last year's pace indicating that some merchants had not bought yet for the Easter season.

The Merritt-Chapman and Scott Corporation was the apparent low bidder yesterday for construction of the Lewiston power plant of the State Power Authority's Niagara project. It submitted a bid of $98,288,498.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 9 -- The Indonesian Foreign Ministry expressed opposition today to a Dutch suggestion that the United Nations Commission for Indonesia "act" in the dispute over Netherlands New Guinea.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 8 points off to 6 points higher than on Wednesday. (One point equals one-hundredth of a cent a pound.)
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Export business in wheat and corn and processor buying of soybeans gave nearly all the grain deliveries a moderate lift on the Board of Trade today.

It is too soon to tell just what effect the release of Sheikh Abdullah from his four and a half years' detention will have on the vexed question of the disposition of Kashmir. He was admittedly a political power of great consequence. Whether he can resume that power is not yet known.

Harold Callender's dispatch from Paris dated Jan. 6 indicates that the foreign ministers have been unable to agree upon the choice of a site for the administration of the European Economic and Atomic Energy Communities. In this impasse I suggest that they consider Vienna.
Dierks Forests, Inc., 75-year-old Southern pine lumber products concern, has entered the pulp and paper field with the start of operations at a new $12,000,000 integrated mill in Pine Bluff, Ark.
DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 9 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff has rejected a protest of Darien home owners against the projected widening of Route 136.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 9 -- Five Roman Catholic priests remained in the custody of the secret police here this afternoon as relations between the Church and Venezuela's dictatorial regime deteriorated.
Frank Lloyd Wright told a group of business leaders here yesterday what he thought was amiss with the city's buildings, the country's automobiles and the world's politics.
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 10 -- President Eisenhower's State of the Union Message evoked questions rather than confidence in Britain this morning.

Marcel Paille will be "on probation" in the New York Rangers' next two National Hockey League games. Coach Phil Watson yesterday said at the New York Hockey Writers luncheon that his goalie had missed too many easy stops in recent contests.
A judge who said that he preferred friendly settlements to judicial rulings brought an end yesterday to New York's first strike by ship line white collar workers.

JAMES JONES' second novel, "Some Came Running," is published today. It is 1,266 closely printed pages and approximately 650,000 words long. That is more than seven times longer than most novels. After devoting the greater part of three days to reading "Some Came Running" I still have not been able to read it all. But I have done my best.
Representative Charles O. Porter, Democrat of Oregon, renewed yesterday his attack on Morris L. Ernst, New York lawyer retained by the Dominican Republic in the Galindez case.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Jan. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Wheat exports of 27,900,000 bushels in November were the largest for the month since 1952 and the best for any month since June, 1956.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP)--A lawyer for the teamsters union accused the Senate select committee on improper activities in the Labor or Management Field today of pumping evidence into the rank-and-file court fight against the election of Hoffa as a teamster president.
New York City's sixty-four different types of lamp posts, most of which are antiquated, are to be replaced eventually by a new kind of all-purpose street lighting standard.

An indication of how the international oil companies fared last year is provided by the Gulf Oil Corporation. William L. Naylor, senior vice president of Gulf, told the Financial Analysts of Philadelphia yesterday that the company showed gains in nearly every phase of operations in 1957.

Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, the domestic sugar contract, copper, tin, hides, rubber and coffee declined; the world sugar positions, cottonseed oil and burlap rose, and price movements for potatoes and wool were mixed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May) announced today a half-point reduction in the purchase and marketing fees that it charges lenders from whom it buys mortgages. The move is designed to stimulate housing activity.

The Polymer Chemicals division of W. R. Grace Co. yesterday dedicated its new Baton Rouge, La., high density polyethylene plant. The facility, representing an investment of more than $20,000,000, has a production capacity of 25,000 tons a year of the plastic -- also known as linear or low-pressure polyethylene -- which the company will offer under the trade name of Grex.

DR. OTTO KLITGORD is known mostly for the push he has given technical education. He is president of the New York City Community College of Applied Arts and Sciences in Brooklyn. His degrees string out longer than a dinosaur's tail.

It's too bad that those little pamphlets issued seasonally by the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc. (Pershing Square, 90 East Forty-second Street), don't get into the hands of more New Yorkers than they do.
MAYBE it's too silly to mention. But suppose you judge that for yourself. Or possibly it would require the services of a dream interpreter to read significance into it.
ARE the two Ionesco plays, put on at the Phoenix last evening, interesting pieces of theatre? In this department's opinion, the answer is "yes."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Eisenhower said today "there are solid grounds for confidence that economic growth will be resumed without an extended interruption."

Mrs. Henry Steeger was elected president of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service yesterday. She succeeds Mrs. Eric H. Haight. The organization held its annual meeting at the New York School of Social Work, 2 East Ninety-first Street.

Normally, we of the newspaper world grieve when we hear that a newspaper has died. A voice has been stilled in the market place of opinion and fellow craftsmen have lost their jobs. But in the case of The Daily Worker, we suspect, there will be few if any tears shed in the newspaper world of this country.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 9 (Reuters) -- King Norodom Suramarit dissolved Cambodia's National Assembly yesterday because of its "encroachment on the Government's powers," it was authoritatively learned here today.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Putting with precision that brought six birdies and an eagle, Bob Rosburg today captured the first-round lead in the $50,000 Bing Crosby golf tournament with a seven-under-par 65.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- An international "science for peace" program to attain "a good life for all" was suggested today by President Eisenhower.

RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 9 -Spanish-Moroccan negotiations on the withdrawal of the peseta and on monetary unification of the northern and southern zones of Morocco have reached what appears to be an impasse, the Moroccan radio reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- There was an unvoiced question on the lips of many as President Eisenhower came down the aisle in the House chamber today.

Loans to business at the larger New York banks declined $249,000,000 in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $142,000,000 in the like week a year ago.

"He's merely wonderful." That's how one college coach described Oscar Robertson, Cincinnati University's 19-year-old sophomore, who last night staged the greatest one-man show in Madison Square Garden basketball history.

THE urgency of world affairs is having repercussions in television, both in the attitudes of the networks toward their responsibilities in the field of news and related documentaries and in response from viewers.
The city's expense budget for the fiscal year starting July 1 apparently will have to be at least $75,000,000 higher than the current budget of $1,933,470,951.
The Feb. 4 performance of "Two for the Seesaw" will benefit the Harvard Law School Association of New York City. Funds realized will go to the Harvard Law School Fund.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MOSCOW, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Russia will take part in the Wimbledon lawn tennis championships for the first time this year, it was disclosed today.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 9 -- The week-old Connecticut Turnpike already has given substantial traffic relief to the Fairfield County communities along its path.
Last Tuesday afternoon, while Charles (Tombstone) Smith was sparring in a Los Angeles gymnasium, he got a phone call offering him his first bout in New York.

Negotiations between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and a union of long - distance telephone workers continued yesterday, with no significant progress toward a settlement of contract terms.

CHATEAUROUX, France, Jan. 9 (UP) -- United States Air Force officials announced tonight that Communist Albania had agreed to release Maj. Howard J. Curran, who was forced down on Albanian soil in his jet fighter plane Dec. 23.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Eisenhower presented to Congress today an eight-point program to deal with atomic missile war, economic "cold war," and the brush-fire war in the Pentagon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- A House subcommittee planning to investigate Federal regulatory agencies is seriously split over its general counsel.
BLONDES can cause a lot of trouble. But often it's not as much anguish as they went through to get to be blondes in the first place.
MIAMI, Jan. 9 (UP) -- The second cold wave of the season locked Florida in a deep freeze today.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- The recent underworld convention in rural Apalachin, N. Y., was in reality a session of the Mafia grand council, the legislative watchdog committee was told today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Walter Byers, the executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said today that it had given informal approval to a summer baseball program and referred it to the N. C. A. A. council for implementation.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 9 -- A shipyard worker in an iron hat pinch-hit for Mrs. Richard M. Nixon at a launching today.
QAZIGUND, Kashmir, Jan. 9 -- The Lion of Kashmir gave his friends, enemies and his own family proof today that four and a half years of imprisonment had not dulled his talent for political drama.

ROME, Jan. 9 -- The aristocracy can still exercise leadership if its representatives will become examples of Christian virtues Pius XII told 600 members of Rome's "black" noble and patrician families today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The timing of Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin's latest notes today seemed intended to trump President Eisenhower's call for United States military strength with a call for peace between East and West.
The first national strike in any part of the needle trades industry yesterday virtually cut off all the country's production of women's hats.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, said today that he was studying legislative ways of moving the capital from Washington to a "more protected" area of the country.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (AP) -County Supervisor Kenneth Hahn said today the Los Angeles Dodgers would not play this season in Pasadena's Rose Bowl.

The struggle in the Mediterranean during the Napoleonic Wars is analyzed in "The War in the Mediterranean, 1803-1810," by Piers Mackesy. The author examines the strategy and actions by which England kept control of the Mediterranean and access to the shores of Southern Europe, the Near East and North Africa during Napoleon's years of great power on the continent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 471,749 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
MIAMI BEACH. Jan. 9 -- A greater cultural exchange program between the United States and the Soviet Union was urged here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Administration sources said tonight that President Eisenhower had decided to assume personal command of the defense situation. This disclosure came after the President had told Congress in his State of the Union Message that he intended to recommend a reorganization of the Defense Department.

Arbitration proceedings are pending between Alfred Bester and David Merrick. The cause of the dispute is "Destry Rides Again," a prospective entry under Mr. Merrick's banner. Mr. Bester had been chosen to furnish the plot for the musical, which is to have songs by Harold J. Rome.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Representative Graham A. Barden, Democrat of North Carolina, who is chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, warnd both parties today against injecting politics into efforts to improve scientific education.

I am pleased to note that John Diebold read my letter which you published in The New York Times of Dec. 20 relative to the use of electronic computing machines by the City of New York. Unfortunately, I do not think Mr. Diebold read this missive very carefully, since if he had there would have been little need for his reply published on Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -Representative Emanuel Celler said today that the House Judiciary Committee would offer a proposal for temporary succession by the Vice President if a President becomes incapacitated.

Canadians fear that the United States is taking too large a role in making economic decisions affecting the Dominion, Sydney E. Smith, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, said last night.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- According to diplomats in Europe, the Soviet Union's latest letters to the Western powers, offering to discuss substantive issues of maximum importance, have given it a strong diplomatic position.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- An examiner of the Federal Maritime Board recommended today that Matson Orient Line,

LONDON, Jan. 9 (Reuters) -Following is an unofficial translation of a summary broadcast tonight by the Moscow radio's German service of Premier Nikalai A. Bulganin's letters to nineteen Western Governments:

Ten years ago, on Jan. 13, 1948, Solomon Mikhoels, director of the Moscow Jewish State Theatre and chairman of the Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee, died in an accident under mystifying circumstances. The Kremlin ordered an imposing funeral and then denounced him post-hurnously in 1953 as a "Jewish bourgeois-nationalist conspirator."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9 -- Dr. James B. Conant took issue tonight with proposals to neutralize, Germany as the price for her unification.

Harvard, which carried off last year's title without losing a game, again has been tabbed as the team to beat in the Ivy Hockey League. That five-team circuit's twenty-fifth campaign will get under way tomorrow night, with Harvard playing at Princeton and Yale at Dartmouth.

GASTON BERTRAND, a Belgian artist whose earlier work fell squarely in the geometric nonobjective tradition, has recently reconsidered his stance, judging from the exhibtion at the Stable Gallery, 924 Seventh Avenue.
An IRT express train stalled in the East River tunnel yesterday morning during the rush hour, delaying several thousand Manhattan-bound passengers up to forty-five minutes.
OSSINING, N. Y., Jan. 9 -Elmer Francis (Trigger) Burke died in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison tonight for the murder of a longshoreman.
The $500,000 advertising account of Woolite, Inc., has been awarded to Fletcher D. Richards, Inc.

An independent film production company has been formed by Harold Robbins Gene Milford and Raymond Scott. Under the title of Miro Productions, Inc., the organization situated at 22 West Fifty-seventh Street, will engage in production primarily in New York.

Two Nobel Peace Prize winners, Lester B. Pearson of Canada and Lord John Boyd Orr of Great Britain will speak here tomorrow night at the fourteenth annual dinner and forum of the American Nobel Anniversary Committee.
Soft pink lighting and red and pink roses interspersed with huge pink cabbage roses decorated the grand ballroom of the Plaza last night for the fifth annual Ball of Roses.

Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida realty operator and builder, has purchased the shopping center at Newbridge Road and Bellmore Avenue in North Bellmore, L. I. The Nassau County store property contains two acres of land. It was sold by Bernard Associates.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson called today for a speed-up beyond present Administration plans in the production of ballistic missiles.

i A floor in the office building rising at 200 East Forty-second Street has been leased by Jseph Durst, builder and owner, to the Wheeler King Agency of the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company. Joseph F. Bernstein of the realty brokerage company bearing his name was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- President Eisenhower confessed to Congress today -- or so it appeared from his carefully chosen words -- that his Administration had failed to foresee the advantages to be won by launching the first man-made earth satellite.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9 -- Carl Krueger, independent producer, filed today in Los Angeles Superior Court a $4,000,000 damage suit against Linda Cristal, actress, and Universal-International Pictures.
Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division, First Department, announced yesterday the appointment of James McGurrin to the lifetime post of New York County Clerk.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Governor Harriman may send his budget recommendations to the Legislature earlier than usual this year, it was reported today.

The Consolidated Foods Corporation, Chicago, canner, processor and distributor of foods, reported yesterday that it had attained record sales of $163,490,322 in the twenty-four weeks ended on Dec. 14. This was 5 per cent more than the $155,312,501 volume for the 1956 period.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan 9 -Ben Gazzara has been signed by "Playhouse 90" to star in "The Violent Heart," an adaptation of the Daphne du Maurier drama, "The Little Photographer.''
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 9 -- In an editorial titled "Mr. Dulles Should Go" The Kansas City Star viewed the decision of the Secretary of State to remain on the job "with the deepest regret."

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Frank Ivy, 41-year-old coach of the Edmonton Eskimos in the Canadian Professional Football League, tonight signed a contract as head coach of the Chicago Cardinals. He replaced Ray Richards, who resigned Saturday.

SEBRING, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Marge Burns of Greensboro, N. C., won the third annual seventy-two-hole women's golf tournament at the Harder Hall course today after finishing in the runner-up spot for the past two years.

Legislative leaders in Albany are holding in readiness a plan to redivide the state into two banking districts, one comprising New York City, Long Island, Westchester and Rockland Counties, the other the remainder of up-state New York.
DALLAS, Jan. 9 (AP) -- George Schepps, a former owner of the Dallas club, got an option to buy the Texas League franchise tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Following are excerpts from today's court of Appeals opinion extending the Jencks case ruling some administrative proceedings:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -The Reynolds Metals Company, one of the major aluminum producers, today was charged by the Federal Trade Commission with illegally acquiring one of its customers, Arrow Brands, Inc., of Long Beach, Calif.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- A proposal to maintain the present racial balance in high school classes gained the tentative approval today of City Councilmen.

DAVID DIAMOND'S Fourth is a remarkably good symphony, but you would not know it from the indifference which has been its fate. In New York it was played once a years ago by the Juilliard orchestra, while works much less professional and much less musical have had their song with the New York Philharmonic in this interval.

BRIDES-TO-BE in 1958 will find a red carpet rolled out for them on the third floor of Arnold Constable. At a showing yesterday of bridal and attendants' gowns, it was obvious the store will cater to every girl's concept of how she should look going down the aisle.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -France is seeking $600,000,000 to $700,000,000 in credits to see her through 1958, diplomatic authorities said today.
The New Year's uprising in Venezuela remains the most dramatic and important event in Latin-American affairs since the overthrow of the Rojas Pinilla dictatorship in neighboring Colombia last May.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)--Senator James O. Eastland said today that the Soviet "kidnapping" of German economic scientists after World War II might pose a greater threat than the abduction of German space scientists.

An appropriation of $4,500,000 to help improve the construction of school and college buildings was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation. The fund will be used to establish and support an independent, nonprofit organization called the Educational Facilities Laboratories.

South Carolina has set Jan. 28 for the sale of $8,000,000 in school building bonds at public bidding. The issue will mature from 1959 to 1974. The state's last sale of school bonds was a $10,000,000 offering last March.
BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- A proposal by community sportsmen to install a rifle range in the new 3,600,000 Fox Lane High School has provoked mild controversy in this area.

THE combination of the continued spiraling cost of meat plus a second freeze in Florida, whence come most of our vegetables and fruits during the winter months, has brought a rising tide of higher prices to strain the week-end shopper's budget.

HAVANA, Jan. 9 (UP) -- The New York gambler Joseph (Joe Rivers) Silesi said today that District Attorney Frank S. Hogan could "drop dead" before he got any "voluntary" cooperation in the Albert Anastasia murder investigation.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 9 -- Rebel saboteurs blew up today the railroad line over which the first oil from the Sahara was scheduled to pass north to a Mediterranean port, bound for France.

The opportunity for the American shipping industry to take over the annual transportation of 600,000 servicemen and their dependents to bases throughout the world was offered last night by the commander of the Military Sea Transportation Service.
The stock market tipped down in the final thirty minutes yesterday and closed with a moderate loss. Volume was 2,180,000 shares, compared with 2,230,000 on Wednesday.

MONTREAL, Jan. 9 (UP) -The Montreal Canadiens, playing without three of their stars, rolled up their highest score in more than two seasons tonight, routing the last-place Chicago Black Hawks, 11 -- 3.
MOSCOW, Jan. 9 -- The Soviet Union has called for a broad top-level conference of the heads of government of East and West to meet in two or three months to discuss outstanding issues.

Four youths who checked out only the best books from Brooklyn public libraries over the last three years could wind up having another thrown at them by a judge. He threw a couple of titles yesterday -- petit larceny and grand larceny.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Congress responded to President Eisenhower's message today with unusual human warmth and formal approval but a good deal of private reserve and concern.
Howard Dietz, vice president in charge of advertising publicity and exploitation of Loew's, Inc., has relinquished the post to become a consultant to the company. No successor has been named.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 9 -- A Nationalist Government crisis has followed the impeachment proceedings started against Premier O. K. Yui. Two crucial meetings were held today to deal with the matter.
PERTH, Australia, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Barry MacKay and Ron Holmberg and the Australian duo of Neale Fraser and Mal Anderson today gained the doubles final of the West Australia tennis championships.
GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Europeans dominated the twentieth Grindelwald ski races for women today, but Americans finished well in the giant slalom.
Personnel of the United States Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn will give blood to the Red Cross today. Blood will also be collected at the W. L. Maxson Corporation, 460 West Thirty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -While the Bulganin notes were being translated in world capitals, the Moscow radio broadcast an 1,100-word summary of the lengthy letter to President Eisenhower in a program for United States listeners.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Alexander P. de Seversky, a pioneer aircraft designer and supporter of air power, advocated today a single Air Force command with subordinate bureaus for the Navy and Army.

Point 8 of the President's message was a declaration of this country's renewed determination to wage total peace. In the interest of such a peace the President called upon the peoples of the Soviet empire to join us and all other peace-loving nations in works of peace: to stop the armament race, to reduce international tensions and to use science not for the destruction but for the betterment of mankind.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- When the President today finished reading to Congress his message on the State of the Union a heavy burden of proof rested on those who have called into question his will to lead the country, and his possession of the physical and mental vigor required.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9 -- George Sidney, president of the Screen Directors Guild, proposed today that the motion-picture industry stage its own Sunday night "super-variety" kind of television show.
WELLINGTON, N. Z., Jan. 9 (Reuters) -- Dr. Vivian Fuchs and his British expedition advanced today to within 230 miles of the South Pole.
A woodcock with considerable pride turned up yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Straus at 44 East Seventy-third Street.
Europe's new "Common Market" promises to exert increasingly strong influence on both United States export trade and tariff policies, a trade group was told yesterday.

United States Attorney Paul W. Williams said yesterday that four men who were believed to have attended the meeting at Apalachin, N. Y., on Nov. 14 but whose names were never listed by the police had been subpoenaed by the Federal rackets grand jury.

The forty-seventh annual convention of the National Retail Merchants Association -- from 1911 until Tuesday afternoon known as the National Retail Dry Goods Association -- ended last night with a dinner in the grand ballroom of the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Senator Edward J. Thye, Republican of Minnesota, introduced today the first Senate bill of the new session. His measure would block a move by Ezra T. Benson, Agriculture Secretary, to cut dairy price supports April 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation of Shreveport, La., won tentative permission today to convert a part of its "Little Inch" pipeline from natural gas service to transportation of petroleum products.

In recent letters to The Times, Pearl Max of the New York City Board of Higher Education and Catherine Kadragic have called for a nationwide registry for college teachers. I would like to point out that an apparatus for nationwide recruitment of teachers -- a Professional Placement Network -- had recently been set up and is already being used by some secondary schools, colleges and teachers.

The best thing about President Eisenhower's State of the Union message yesterday was his program for "imperative" action, and his emphasis on the weapons of peace -- notably economic aid -- as equal to the weapons of war in their importance to the defense of the United States and the free world.
The chairman of the Transit Authority accused politicians yesterday of acting like politicians.
TRENTON, Jan. 9 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared today that a quick solution to the North Jersey rapid transit situation was vitally needed.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- The Court of Appeals upheld unanimously today a town ordinance requiring motorists to deposit in a meter the required, coin "immediately" upon entering a parking space.

Bulganin of the Soviet Union to support the peace proposals made yesterday by Moscow to the Western powers. Barbed-wire and farm fence coated with aluminum is approaching the commercial stage after extensive field testing, it was reported by Van H. Leichliter, president of the American Steel and Wire Division of the United States Steel Corporation.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The nation's economy will be moving upward in March, Dr. Gordon W. McKinley, director of economic and investment research for the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said today.

DETROIT, Jan. 10 (AP) -Passenger car production in American factories this week should total 121,292 units, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. This compares with 76,653 last week and 147,129 in the like 1957 week.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 10 -- Hollywood studio workers brought home the bacon from television this week. While only eleven theatrical motion pictures were before the cameras in local studios, some sixtyseven movies, mostly of the half-hour variety, were being made for TV exhibition.

SOUTH POLE, Jan. 5 -- Living at the South Pole station is an adventure that takes stamina, good humor and adaptability.
City College of New York and Springfield (Mass.) College were named yesterday the outstanding college soccer teams in the country for the 1957 season.
The Nestle-LeMur Company, maker of cosmetics and toilet goods, is expanding its operations into the proprietary drug field through the acquisition of the Carroll Dunham Smith Pharmacal Company.
John Gates, for ten years editor of The Daily Worker, announced yesterday his resignation from the Communist party. At the same time he quit his editorship.

Fred H. Hill, realty operator, has contracted to buy 251 East Sixty-first Street from Samoroff Building, Inc. The property is 19.6 by 100 feet and contains a private dwelling in the front of the plot and a studio building in the rear.

Summer hotel and roominghouse owners in Seaside and Hammels, on the Rockaway Peninsula, are in a quandary.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- The Government announced new measures tonight to halt inflation and declared its general freeze on prices would continue.
PERTH, Australia, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Two young members of the U. S. Davis Cup team, Barry MacKay and Ron Holmberg, were eliminated today in the semi-finals of the West Australian tennis championships.

KUD, Kashmir, Jan. 10 -There is a special kind of sadness to the story of Sheikh Abdullah: "My poor boy," a lady in the shawls called him during the years she sat home and waited and wept. "Lion of Kashmir," little bands of men and children shouted in the streets when they heard he had been released Wednesday, "Comrade," Jawaharlal Nehru once called him.

Michael (Mickey) Bowers, former longshore boss on West Side piers, moved yesterday in Federal Court for a new trial. He is now serving five years for income tax evasion. He charged that his rights were violated because a juror had read a Government -printed handbook for jurors before the trial.
Representative Kenneth B. Keating's show will begin in New York tomorrow on WOR-TV.

The American people always have depended upon the printed word to defend liberty and human rights. Forces of truth and liberty, over the years, have been aided by New York City as the world's center of printing, publishing and advertising.

"Countdown for Tomorrow," a new book by Martin Caidin, is planned for March 1 publication by Dutton. Mr. Caidin, whose previous books include a history of the United States Air Force, attempts to answer such questions as how the Soviet earth satellites and other similar devices work and why the United States has lagged in developments in the missile field.
Edmund Leahy, described to the State Crime Commission in 1953 as the main loan shark on the West Side waterfront area, was sentenced yesterday to a year in prison for lending money without a license.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 10 -The Government spokesman said today the latest communications from Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier, to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer contained military threats against West Germany.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Air Force's chief missile officer sharply opposes a major defense reorganization plan that President Eisenhower supports.
A plea to save "lone wolf researchers" from the threat of extinction was sounded here last night.

LONDON. ENGLAND'S Shakespeare Memorial Theatre at Stratford-on-Avon begins its ninety-ninth season on April 8 with "Romeo and Juliet.'' Richard Johnson will appear as Romeo and Dorothy Tutin as Juliet.
SHIRLEY TEMPLE will make her debut tonight as a television personality with a few of the disadvantages usually associated with the entrance into the medium of the one-time, big-name movie star.

A story appeared on the front page of The New York Times of Dec. 29 reporting the United States' plans to reduce the number of technicians working in under-developed lands on the basis of recommendations made by Vice President Nixon. This is evidence of an unfortunate practice which appears more and more frequently.

" THE ICEMAN COMETH," Eugene O'Neill's towering drama that, as a tenant at the Circle in the Square Theatre for more than two years is among the leading long-run hits off Broadway, now is definitely headed toward the screen.

MIAMI -- "Just follow the crowd," was Henry M. Flagler's retort to a rival promoter's taunt of "Where is Miami?" and the great railroad builder and pioneer developer of the east coast of Florida, was right.
" What's Ahead for Higher Education?" will be the theme of the tenth annual Barnard Forum on Saturday, Feb. 8, in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Dartmouth's basketball team defeated Columbia, 82 -- 60, last night at the Columbia University Hall gymnasium. In the process the Green scored the most field goals, thirty-seven, ever made against the Lions in their basketball history.

In 1949, when President Eisenhower first bought acreage near Gettysburg, it was a run-down 189-acre dairy and poultry farm. Today, expanded to 479 acres and considerably renovated, the farm is devoted primarily to cattle-raising. But about 123 acres are normally given over to wheat and corn.

A QUESTION arose a few days ago: Who is buying all the 22-caliber rifles that rifle-makers pour onto the market in new shapes every year? And the answer came back like a jai-alai ball from the wall: High school students.

A MAJOR Swedish writer, and one of the most eloquent defenders of humane Western values, Par Lagerkvist received the Nobel Prize in 1951. In the same year his novel "Barabbas" was published in the United States with a foreword by Andre Gide.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers were held to a 1-1 tie by Luton Town today but retained their 6-point lead in the English Soccer League's first division.

An experimental program in science to encourage "creative thinking and research-mindedness" among top secondary school students will be conducted this summer by the Horace Mann School in Riverdale, the Bronx.

About 40,000 United States school children have sailed the seven seas in the last four years without leaving their classrooms. They have liked nautical life so much that they are asking for more armchair sailing than can be provided for them now.

A 20-PFENNIG red-brown stamp has been issued by West Germany in honor of the renowned scholar, the Rev. Dr. Leo Baeck, formerly a prominent rabbi in Berlin. Dr. Baeck was well known in this country because for a number of years he was Alumni Effoymson Visiting Professor at Hebrew Union College -- Jewish Institute of Religion in Cincinnati, and frequently lectured under the seminary's auspices at its college in New York.

This book is important not only as an extraordinary first novel of a gifted new author, but as an articulate literary voice of the Polish peasant in America. Here is an interweaving of three generations: the old Pole married to the soil of his native land, the uprooted immigrant transplanted in American industry, and the first generation of Poles born in America.
Two decisions in the State Supreme Court have held that the city wrongly dismissed two employes it had called "security risks" when it failed to show that they were in sensitive positions.

IT may sound like a winter daydream, but there is an apartment on Manhattan's fashionable East Side where 250 narcissus have started to bloom. In addition, camellias, azaleas and flowering clerodendron vines provide a colorful contrast to the city skyline.
CAIRO, Jan. 10 -- Egypt's avowed "positive neutrality" was sidetracked once again today in favor of the Soviet Union and against the United States.

IF a concerted, reasoned effort were to be made to give the lyric theatre a secure place across America, what would be the best way to start? Should the priority go to the building of theatres, the encouragement of composers and librettists or the proper training of performers?
Plans have been anounced for a theatre party on April 24 for the benefit of the work of the Children's Aid Society.

ON THE authority of Borys Conrad, the writer's son, Lewis Nichols in "In and Out of Books" claims that Joseph Conrad was born on Dec. 6, 1857. The actual date is Dec. 3. The French original of the biography by G. Jean-Aubry published here under the most inappropriate title, "The Sea Dreamer," i. e., "Vie de Conrad" lists the date correctly "21 november/3 decembre 1857."
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Steve Stenson of New York won the 220-yard dash and placed second in the mile today to take the lead in the Eastern States outdoor speed-skating championship.
The children's recreational program at Kings County Hospital will benefit from the annual ball of the Junior League of Brooklyn.

The dollar volume of all building permits issued in Cuyahoga County last year declined 11 per cent below the 1956 level to a three-year low of $310,000,000. Non-residential building dropped 17 per cent. Combined data for one and two-family houses showed a 15 per cent decrease in dollar volume and a 23 per cent slump in the actual number of permits.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -Two Soviet artists -- Emil Gilels, pianist, and Leonid Kogan, violinist -- will perform with the Philadelphia Orchestra at the 101st anniversary program of the Academy of Music on Jan. 25.

I STARTED my new play "Winkelberg" three years ago, and rewrote it a half-dozen times. Of the original script (which I thought rather excellent) hardly a third remains. I mention this because I have never before (alone) written anything for the theatre that haunted me, and kept me reworking it.

MIAMI -- In a region which specializes in hectic and frequently exhausting diversion, night and day, Fairchild Tropical Garden offers an oasis of peace and quiet beauty, a kind of manmade Garden of Eden, within ten miles of the heart of downtown Miami.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Eisenhower moved today to arouse public support for those Congressional stepchildren -- foreign aid and trade.

MONTPELIER, Vt. -- With ski developments being increased and expanded throughout the northern reaches of the United States, Vermont remains in the forefront in the matter of progress. Although some of the nation's more famous ski areas are within its borders, the Green Mountain State continues to look ahead.

REPORTS of real estate deals involving film studio properties cropped up again last week after the disclosure by Twentieth Century-Fox that 176 acres of its 284-acre studio site were to be transformed into a multi-million-dollar apartment house and office building center.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11 -- Princeton withstood Yale's second-half rally to gain its second Ivy League basketball victory, 79 -- 77, in the Payne Whitney gym tonight.

NUERNBERG, Germany, Jan. 11 (UP) -- A United States Army soldier, with his eyes on a world record, switched to left-handed bowling today after straining his right wrist while only halfway to his 500-game goal.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 11 -- Yesterday's successful flight of the Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile was jeopardized by the loss within the intricate and inaccessible machinery of the rocket of a metal pin two and a half inches long.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 11 -- Two major issues emerged here this week as the Association of American Colleges ended a series of deliberations on higher education. The first concerned educational financial support. The second, and from the long-range point of view the more important, centered around the curriculum which colleges should stress in a sputnik-dominated age.
About 360 women attended the First World Congress of Widows and Widowers held in Enschede, Holland. (Only twenty widowers showed up.)

Prof. Paul B. Sears, noted Yale University botanist, warned in his presidential address before the American Association for the Advancement of Science that "our future security may depend less upon priority in exploring outer space than upon our wisdom in managing the space in which we live."

THIS well-written, skillfully woven account by Constantine FitzGibbon of the ordeal of London during the blitz is essentially the story of ordinary men and women, and how they lived, worked and fought during the long days and nights when their city was in the very front-line of the war.
Outstanding art attractions this week include the Whitney Museum's exhibition "Nature in Abstraction," made up of selected work by contemporary American painters and sculptors.

YOU recently published a letter from Jose Lopez-Rey in which he stated that "Andre Malraux is the only well-known living Goya scholar or critic who still believes that the socalled 'self-portrait' at the museum of Vienna which you (The New York Times) reproduced, is a work by the master rather than a banal pastiche."

TO judge by dispatches from New York Times correspondents, the Communist bailiffs are again tightening the discipline of writers in Russia. Their opposite numbers are performing the same duties in Czechoslovakia and Hungary.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 11 -- Bill Casper gained a tie for the lead at 206 with Bob Rosburg in the third round of the $50,000 Bing Crosby golf tournament today.
President Eisenhower put his foreign economic program in dramatic perspective last week as essential for countering Russia's "total cold war."
Former President Harry S. Truman criticized President Eisenhower yesterday as having failed to coordinate the armed services and end bitter inter-service wrangling.

ARNOLD SHAW, who apparently is not one of those negative, irresponsible novelists, ends his review of "The Jazz Makers," edited by Nat Shapiro and Nat Hentoff, with a plea for moral uplift. Let jazz criticism, he says, sponsor what "John Lewis, Dave Brubeck and others are consciously seeking to develop among jazzmen -- a new sense of personal responsibility.''
A nation-wide millinery strike appeared yesterday to be on the verge of settlement.

Sir David Eccles, President of the Board of Trade in Prime Minister Macmillan's Cabinet, urges Americans to lower their tariffs and also to help get English recognized as the world language as two steps toward a broad merger of Western nations.

BEFORE the premiere of his "Persephone" at the Paris Opera in 1934, Stravinsky published a manifesto. It is a striking document, not only for what it clarifies in "Persephone" but for what it foreshadows in Stravinsky's latest works, the ballet "Agon," and his choral homage to Venice, "Canticum Sacrum."

EDWIN MUIR in his review of "First Poems" by Minou Drouet, failed to make any mention of the most conclusive validation of Minou's authorship: France's Society of Authors, Composers, and Music Publishers, investigating Minou's authorship, subjected her to a rather exhaustive examination after which it issued a public statement that she had proved to the Society's satisfaction that she truly was the author of the poems credited to her.

The Soviet demand for another conference at Geneva of the heads of government is obviously unacceptable to the United States and to most members of the North Atlantic Alliance. Even if they were ready to negotiate on disarmament and everything else, the Soviet proposal for balanced participation -- half Western countries, half Communists or neutralists -- would rule out such a meeting.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Jan. 12 -- The Soviet Union would like to see established in Europe a zone free of atomic weapons extending from the Arctic Circle to the Mediterranean Sea.

BILOXI, Miss., Jan. 11 -- Harold B. Minor, former Ambassador to Lebanon, asserted tonight that re-establishment of an American position of leadership in the Middle East hinged on "realistic" assessment of the Arab-Israeli dispute.
FRESNO, Calif., Jan. 11 -- A cheering, whistling convention of California Democrats endorsed Representative Clair Engle late today as its 1958 Senatorial candidate.

EVEN to serious readers the name of Jowett is apt to recall only this celebrated jingle written during the height of his fame at Balliol College, Oxford. It is now sixty years since, in 1897, Lewis Campbell and Evelyn Abbott published their biography and no work of weight on Jowett has appeared since.
MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- Soviet Communists surveyed their international movement today and did not find things going altogether to their liking.

DETROIT, Jan. 11 -- Top leaders of the United Automobile Workers are preparing to announce on Monday collective bargaining proposals that are expected to surprise the auto industry and perhaps the country.

ON Dec. 22, the first page of this harassed section bore a review of a book called "Soviet Education for Science and Technology." In the middle of it was an illustration -- a collective farm girl standing before a blackboard containing mathematical formulae.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Joseph S. (Joey) Fay, paroled Newark labor extortionist, has been summoned to testify in the Senate investigation of his old union, the International Union of Operating Engineers.

The future economy of the free world is closely tied to the vast oil resources that lie beneath desert sands from Iran to Morocco. In recent years the struggle for access to that oil has spread, with new nations trying to get concessions in areas long held largely by a few Western powers.

Hurok, and observed through an interpreter, confining himself to Russian, that:

A CAMP follower, so the dictionary tells us, is "one, not a soldier, who hangs on to an army." The camp followers of Ugo Pirro's brief and bloody story are certainly not soldiers. They are girls, fifteen of them, mostly from respectable Greek families, whom the narrator, as a lieutenant in the Italian Army of Occupation, was ordered to escort from Athens to Italian Army brothels during the last war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The North Atlantic powers will tell the Soviet Union next week that a top-level conference should be held only after preliminary diplomatic discussions have demonstrated a prospect of some agreement.
As a veteran high school teacher, I resent deeply Hans Rosenhaupt's statement about us in his letter "Hope for Seniors" (Dec. 29).
One man was electrocuted and another was rescued in accidents yesterday on the BMT Brighton Beach subway line in Brooklyn.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9 -- Japanese capitalists appear to have struck a snag in their efforts to break into Middle Eastern oil production.

VIENNA, Jan. 11 -- The sentencing in Budapest this week of Cardinal Mindszenty's secretary and sixteen other priests and students accused of offenses against the Hungarian regime drew the Western World's attention once more to that tragic country.
The port's ship cleaners, painters and general maintenance men have reached a new working agreement.
MONTREAL -- The winter-sports areas of the Laurentians have, in recent years, spread out beyond the traditional resort of the cold-weather tourist.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -Abba Eban, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, said tonight that Israel would not permit regional and world tensions to "paralyze her into inertia."

HERE are some tender and witty pieces, most of them in the form of autobiographical narrative -- and, where they are not, seem still to be within the framework of personal history. In its fourth semi-annual study of the capital market, R. W. Pressprich Co., investment bankers, estimates that the demand for new investment funds in the first half of this year will be $15,700,000,000. The supply of individual savings in the form of insurance company, savings bank and pension fund money is placed at $14,100,000,000.

Ted Williams, renowned slugger of the Boston Red Sox, and Larry Goetz, retired National League umpire, have been chosen for top honors by the New York Chapter, Baseball Writers Association of America, when the scribes hold their thirty-fifth annual dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on the night of Jan. 26.
Lee Oma, former boxer, was released in $500 bail yesterday on a charge of procuring. Two women to whom Oma allegedly directed plainclothes men were held on charges of prostitution.
EACH new session is a testing ground for the institutions of Congress, but recent events have indicated plainly that in 1958 the House of Representatives faces its biggest challenge.

THIS is the beginning of the year for everyone else, a time for book-balancing, soul-searching and economic self-analysis, but for the travel and resort folk it is already the middle of the winter season. This chronological aberration is a bit of good fortune for the travel industry because, while its season anticipates the calendar, its booms and its recessions lag a few months behind the indices for the rest of the nation's economy.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Health Insurance Plans announced today that it would renew its fight to close gaps in health insurance coverage.

WARSAW, Jan. 11 -- Richard H. S. Crossman said here today that United States military bases would be retained in Britain under a Socialist Government. Mr. Crossman is a member of the British Parliament and of the Labor party's National Executive.
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- The voters of the Thirtyseventh Congressional District will go to the polls Tuesday to choose a successor to Representative W. Sterling Cole of Bath.

CORTLAND, N. Y. -- Reflecting confidence in New York State's current ski boom, operators of snow areas in the Empire State are making impressive plans for the future. A case in point is the activity of a group of Cortland business men who have just opened Greek Peak, a new ski center for which $150,000 was supplied by local investors.

PERTH, Australia, Jan. 11 (AP) -- A sailboat excursion delayed the men's doubles final in the West Australian tennis championships for nearly two hours today, after which the Aussie stars, Mal Anderson and Neale Fraser, defeated Barry MacKay and Ron Holmberg of the United States.

President Eisenhower, in his State of the Union message, alluded to negotiating with the Soviet Union, and Secretary of State Dulles dealt with the subject in a press conference. Here are excerpts from the two men's remarks.

The Navajo Indians ran their business affairs last year as efficiently as many giant corporations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Workers in increasing numbers are being laid off their jobs across the nation, a survey by the Associated Press of key production areas has shown.

LONDON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Soviet scientists said today that they had cracked one of the major barriers to space travel by man with proof that "no harm" would come to living creatures from the mysterious condition of weightlessness in space.

HALF the fun of collecting house plants is finding the right containers for them. There are so many decorative ways to "slipcover" the old clay flower pots that not even the shelf of flowerless foliage plants need look undistinguished.

YOU might suppose that a two-character play like "Two for the Seesaw" would be a lark to do compared to the usual play with many roles. You would be quite wrong, according to the five persons involved in this drama of a marriage on the rocks, which opens Thursday at the Booth.

THE Harvard way of life survives in a world of committee men, group thinkers and the kind of person who is described as the "organization man," the hero of so many modern institutions. TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 31 -- Iran's first department store has created enthusiasm verging on riot. Crowds fighting to get into the four-story shop on opening day two weeks ago were checked by the police. Policemen still man all doors to prevent overcrowding.
OTTAWA, Jan. 11 -- Canadian irritation over United States trade policies has sharpened to the point that there is growing pressure on the Government to introduce retaliatory measures.

NAHA, Okinawa, Jan. 11 -- The United States' twelve-year rule of Okinawa goes on trial tomorrow before a jury of nearly 100,000 eligible voters in the election of a new Mayor of Naha, the island's capital.

ALLOW me to express disappointment in Bruce Catton's review of J. F. C. Fuller's "Grant and Lee." Of the three books reviewed together, on the subject of the Civil War, the most original and penetrating is Fuller's book.
The total world supply of wool available for purchase during the 1957-58 season has been estimated at 2,925,000,000 pounds clean, according to the Wool Bureau.

LOS ANGELES -- Among the nation's least-known insular possessions of especial tourist interest is the chain of eight eminences called the Channel Islands, twenty to sixty miles offshore, extending for 150 miles along the southern California coast.

DAVOS, Switzerland -- Although Davos is one of the most famous ski resorts in Europe, the latest fad in skiing here is not to ski at all. During the past two seasons hotel keepers have noted a growing crowd of vacationists who came for the social life and who, throughout their stay, never once stooped to strap on a pair of the lacquered boards.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -The Philadelphia Eagles discharged their head coach, Hugh Devore, today and Hampton Pool of the Toronto Argonauts appeared the No. 1 choice to become the fifth coach of the National Football League club since 1950.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 11 -- Robert (Bobo) Sheehan, Middlebury College's varsity ski coach, turned in the fastest time in the downhill-race today as the two-day men's Eastern senior Alpine championships got under way at Big Bromley.

The Communist party of the United States gave signs of nearing the end of the road last week with the announcement that The Daily Worker will be discontinued after tomorrow and the resignation of Daily Worker Editor John Gates from the party.
An appeal to the soviet Union to grant its three million jews "spiritual and cultural freedom" was made last night by Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 11 -- This town's largest property owner has renewed his campaign against four-acre zoning here.

CARNIVAL in the Caribbean, this year arriving in February, is the grand climax of the year. The entire island population goes on colorful binge, basically the one pagan-Christian outburst from Trinidad to Yucatan, but gathering from place to place in color, rhythm, and festive detail.

With the publication of "Vanity Fair" in 1846-48. Thackeray securely established his eminence as the only serious contender to the supremacy of Dickens. The preceding thirtyfive years had been a period of impecunious struggle.

LITTLETON, N. H. -- This colorful Granite Mountain village, situated a few miles to the west of the towering Mount Washington, highest peak in the East (6,288 feet), is the ski capital of the East. Housed in this pretty New England community are the offices of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association, from which much propaganda of interest to skiers emanates and where policies concerning the Eastern competitive program are formulated.

GREENPORT, L. I., Jan. 11 -- The 110-foot fishing craft Hiwal, disabled and at the mercy of high winds and heavy seas, was taken in tow by a Coast Guard cutter early today, forty miles southeast of Montauk Point, L. I. The cutter had raced 150 miles last night to assist. Both put in here at 5:30 P. M.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 11 -- A committee to try to stamp out false and misleading automobile advertising was named today by the National Automobile Dealers Association.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 -- First steps were taken this week to submit an open-shop proposal to California voters as an initiative measure on next November's election ballot. It would prohibit making union membership a requirement for employment job.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 11 -- Five years more will be needed to complete the redevelopment program that Norwalk undertook after the disastrous flood of October, 1955.

MADRID, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Unconfirmed reports from Rio de Oro said that Spanish forces began operations at dawn today to wipe out Moroccan raiders in that West African colony.

Roscoe C. Wright, a literary letter carrier whose knowledge of poetry won him $16,000 on a television show two years ago, now earns his living in the world of books. He operates an elevator in the Queens Borough Public Library.

MONTREAL, Jan. 11 -The Montreal Canadiens trampled the New York Rangers, 9 -- 3, tonight for their eighth straight victory and stretched their National Hockey League lead to nineteen points. A crowd of 14,117 saw the Canadiens triumph in the Forum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A flood of Soviet "peace" propaganda is swirling around the Western statesmen lately united in the Paris NATO "summit" conference. And it would be idle to pretend that they do not find it disconcerting.
LONDON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Dr. Vivian Fuchs, leader of the British Antarctic Expedition, has moved thirty miles closer to the South Pole, the expedition's London Headquarters was told tonight.

COLLECTING species of a single genus of plants is one of the most intriguing phases of gardening. My first venture in collecting species of dicentra began when a friend brought me a clump of native plumy bleeding heart (Dicentra eximia) from the West Virginia mountains. Road-making machinery was turning these plants from their rocky beds.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 11 -- The United States jet pilot, who made an emergency landing in Communist Albania, Dec. 23, arrived here today. But his T-33 plane, which burst a tire on landing, remained in Albanian custody.

HONG KONG, Jan 11 -- A steady increase in trade and economic interdependence between Communist China and the Soviet Union is forecast in a New Year review of Chinese-Russian trade. The review was published in the authoritative Peiping daily Ta Kung Pao, which specializes in economic matters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The right of Americans to travel abroad -- a subject much disputed in the courts over the last decade but never finally settled -- will be considered by the Supreme Court before the end of its present term this June.

EIGHT Dye Transfer prints from 8x10-inch Kodachromes photographed in 1947 by Edward Weston, the noted American photographer, who died two weeks ago at his home in Carmel, Calif., are on display through Sunday in the Kodak Information Center and Exhibit in Grand Central Terminal.
