IN the Toynbeean panorama of history, civilizations live or die according to their response to challenge. Under this rule our Western civilization will likewise live or die according to its response to the gravest challenge it has ever faced -- the challenge of Communist totalitarianism.

Because of the ring. a hastily organized expedition arrives from America led by Dr. Carrol, a half-mad scholar bent on proving from Essenic relics that Christ was a myth.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 11 -- French Government authorities in Algeria charged Tunisia with "a new act of cobelligerence" in the Algerian nationalist rebellion after a frontier incident this morning.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Swedish Government asked Parliament today to approve a record budget of the equivalent of nearly three billion dollars. At least 16 per cent of it was earmarked for defense.
PARIS, Jan. 11 -- French negotiators flew toward Washington tonight a seek loans of almost $400,000,000 to keep France's economy going and permit her to participate in the European common market.

SARASOTA, Fla. -- This resort area has long prided itself on the cultural advantages it offers to visitors and residents alike. MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 11 -- The Soviet Union and Rumania have made a serious bid to become Uruguay's suppliers of refined petroleum products.

ORLANDO, Fla. -- Judging by the number of inquiries being received in Florida by the Development Commission at Tallahassee and the state's Skin Divers Association at Orlando, many winter vacationists want to spend at least part of their trip under water.

This country got rid of a record volume of surplus farm products in the fifteen months ended Sept. 30 last. The net reduction in such stocks carried them down from $8.3 billion on June 30, 1956, to $6.9 billion on Sept. 30, 1957, a net decline of $1.4 billion.
PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 11 -- Harvard's hockey team defeated Princeton tonight at Baker Ring in its Ivy League opener, 7 -- 2, Terry O'Malley, a substitute scored three Crimson goals.

French and German modern paintings, together with drawings, prints and pre-Columbian and modern sculptures, will be auctioned Wednesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

Cotton has just closed its best year in the free world outside the United States. Production, consumption and the international movement were all at record levels.

DOWN here on the west-most shores of the Pacific Ocean an American director is recreating in his own fictional way an historical event that occurred just about a century ago. The imaginative director is John Huston, and he is here to make "The Barbarian," with John Wayne as Townsend Harris, the first American Ambassador to the forbidden empire.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 11 -- A large quantity of side arms presumably stolen from the Mexican Army has been traced to Guatemala, a reliable source revealed today. He said the weapons were in the hands of supporters of Col. Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, who was ousted as President three and a half years ago.
A New York Air National Guard fighter pilot parachuted to safety yesterday from a damaged F-94B jet over Rockaway Beach. The plane crashed in the ocean southwest of Fort Tilden.

Cindy Lowe, 11-year-old tomboy, and her friends, fat Emmet, the baker's son, and Hank MacBride, find and explore a concealed passage in the Lowes' house.

THE show season for camellias is now under way in the South. Fanciers might like to note some of the major displays on their calendars.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- Conventions and skiing are the lodestones which draw most visitors to Colorado these days, but a new breed of tourist is showing himself all over the state in modest volume.

The four and a half million dollar contribution that the Ford Foundation is making to the improvement of school and college construction and plant promises results out of all proportion to the size of the grant -- which, of course, is the ideal for all foundation giving.

MIAMI BEACH -- The majority of the thousands of vacationists due to arrive here for the peak weeks of the winter season will stay at modified American plan hotels. In most northern resorts, such news would be regarded as of little consequence, but for Miami Beach it marks an important development in its economy and guest-look since the beginning of the post-war building boom, ten years ago.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 11 -Mayor Thomas D'Alesandro of Baltimore has agreed to quit the race for Governor of Maryland to run for United States Senator.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- The newest and one of the most elaborate theaters in the United States, the Royal Poinciana Playhouse, will open here on the shore of Lake Worth on Feb. 3, while in West Palm Beach, the Palm Beach Musicarnival will start a twelve-week season of tent shows on Jan. 24.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 1 -- This hustling port city begins the new year with one resolution written larger than all others: find the money for a harbor extension program that will make Rotterdam the undisputed shipping gateway to Western Europe.

The 1957 pattern of the steamship charter market has continued into this year. Last week the market slipped again, with coal and grain cargo rates off slightly.

For the first time in the 160-year history of the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 West Seventy-third Street, a woman preached at the regular morning service yesterday. She is Mrs. Pat Nicholson, who conducted he service in the absence of her husband, the Rev. George Nicholson, minister of the church.

When the Board of Estimate listened for thirteen hours last March to thirty-four speakers supporting fluoridation of New York City's water supply and fifty-four against it one bewildered board member asked: "Whose opinions are we going to accept?"

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 12 -- Yul Brynner has added another picture to his busy schedule. He has agreed to star in the Jerry Wald-Twentieth Century Fox production of William Faulkner's novel, "The Sound and the Fury."

Various members of the New York Knickerbockers, including and especially Coach Vince Boryla, took turns in "getting hot" yesterday at Madison Square Garden, where the Knicks lost in overtime, 115 -- 110, to the Philadelphia Warriors.

IN the catalogue of cold weather vegetables, "T" most assuredly stands for turnips. And turnips -- in comparison with the garden produce of spring -have frequently been relegated to the role of rations for the poor and untutored.

Early next month two Quakers plan to cast off in their thirty-foot ketch Golden Rule and sail from San Pedro, Calif., to the central Pacific to dramatize protests against nuclear test. The Atomic Energy Commission has scheduled a series of tests at Eniwetok Atoll in April.

FEDERAL LENDING AND LOAN INSURANCE. By R. J. Saulnier, Harold G. Halcrow and Neil H. Jacoby, 566 pp. Princeton University Press, Princeton. $12. Between 1917 and 1953 the United States Government made loans or guaranteed loans within its economy to a cumulative total of $138.7 billion, using more than sixty agencies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- British and French officials here declined today to comment on President Eisenhower's appeal to the Soviet Union to join the United States in renouncing the use of the veto power "to prevent the Security Council from proposing methods for the pacific settlement of disputes."

The Jan. 29 evening performance of "Look Homeward Angel" at the Barrymore Theatre will benefit the Neighborhood Children's Center. Benefit proceeds will help the center at 1833 Lexington Avenue to carry on its nursery-school and after-school program for youngsters.

SUNNYVALE, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Dr. H. Guyford Stever of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has been named to head a new special committee on space technology by the Government's research roganization for studying flight problems.

Lehman Brothers, investment bankers, will have twenty general partners in the firm, the largest number in its history, with the admission of four new general partners. They are subject to the approval of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange.
PEIPING, Jan. 12 -- China's economic difficulties and last year's ripples of political unrest have failed to weaken the control that the Communist Government maintains over 650,000,000 people.
MIAMI, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Walter Hansgen of Westfield, N. J., won the ninety-mile Orange Bowl sports car race today when the auto driven by the favored Carroll Sherby was forced out after fifty miles.

The directors of the American ORT Federation (Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training) voted yesterday to expand the overseas program. It will include vocational training for 30,000 persons in Israel, Poland, North Africa and other areas.
Indoor ground-breaking ceremonies were held yesterday in Queens for a new three-story Cerebral Palsy Center at 164th Street and Goethals Avenue, Jamaica.
THE Concert Society of New York presented its fourth concert of the season late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. The program was played by the Albeneri Trio.
The committee has been announced for the dinner dance to be given by the Women's Auxiliary Board of the Lenox Hill Hospital on Feb. 6 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
BEERSHEBA, Israel, Jan 6 -- Israel's campaign to populate and utilize the Negev gained new monentum during 1957.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 12 (AP) -One St. Louis radio station is in revolt against rock 'n' roll music.

Plans have been filed for a five-story building containing classrooms and a library on the campus of Barnard College. The building will be on the east side of Claremont Avenue and north of West ll6th Street. It will cost $1,500,000.
Sixty-eight members of the Metropolitan Opera Company have signed an open letter to President Eisenhower asking for an enlargement of United States participation in the Brussels World's Fair of 1958.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The National Science Foundation invited universities and colleges today to send in proposals for special courses for high school science and mathematics teachers during the 1958-59 academic year.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Eddie Erdelatz, Navy's head coach, said today he would fly to Texas tomorrow to talk with officials about the head football coaching job at Texas A. M.
ROME, Jan. 12 -- Soviet offers of unspecified concessions to Italy in exchange for turning the country into a zone free of nuclear weapons received an immediate negative reply today.
McHENRY BOATWRIGHT, baritone, interpreted a varied program with skill in his Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Jan. 8 -Education officials irately denied today that California high school boys were studying cooking when they should be studying science.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 12 -- The Baghdad Pact meeting in Ankara this month is being presented by responsible sources as a crucial test of the whole United States position in the Middle East.
James Reston's piece on the Rockefeller report in The Times for Jan. 6 cited with commendation the projects on foreign policy analysis now under way at a number of universities.

Terry Sawchuk gave an excellent exhibition of the fine art of goal - tending at Madison Square Garden last night. The Detroit Red Wings' net guardian was riddled by the New York Rangers through the entire game, but he played his position splendidly as his mates registered a 3-to-2 triumph over the local outfit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A Congressional watchdog committee reported today that the big preparedness job "still lies ahead." It warned that "means must be found to provide solutions of major unsolved problems without delay."
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 12 -Automobile manufacturers were criticized today for the sale of new cars to New York State at $400 below dealer's cost.

In his letter published Jan. 3 headlined "Blue Cross Practices" Charles E. Gregory overlooks an important point. His suggested exemption similar to that of other insurances will not work, but every doctor will agree that a large percentage of his patients, although covered by Blue Cross, do not belong in an overcrowded hospital.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 12 (UP) -- Israel rejected a Communist Hungarian protest that accused the Israeli legation officials in Budapest of having engaged in "illegal" activities, it was disclosed last night.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 12 -- College football rulemakers adopted a revolutionary change in the game's scoring system and relaxed substitution barriers another notch today. Both changes take effect immediately.

The role of a minister should be more that of a "student" and less that of an "errand boy and an administrator," the Rev. Dr. Ralph Curry Walker said yesterday. He preached at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street.

THE magic of fairyland came hauntingly alive last night in a superb production of "Beauty and the Beast" over Channel 4. It was the first presentation of the new "Shirley Temple's Storybook" hour and a more auspicious premiere could hardly be asked.

FRESNO, Calif., Jan. 12 -- California Democrats accused Senator William F. Knowland today of seeking the Governorship on a "clean unionism" program "dishonestly conceived for selfish political motives."
The Central Trades and Labor Council in this city has quietly expelled 125,000 local members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
The premiere of the motion picture "The Quiet American" on Feb. 5 at the Victoria Theatre will be a benefit for the International Rescue Committee.

Aldo (Buff) Donelli, Columbia's head football coach, said last night that he was "against" the conversion rule passed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday. Donelli, the first of the Ivy League coaches to comment on the change, said, "Ultimately it must take the kicking out of football altogether."

The hopes for peace in this world lie largely in the United Nations. Until there is a certainty of peace -- thus far distressingly uncertain -- accompanied by a drastic disarmament, there can be no world-wide spiritual or physical well-being. The present distrust among the great powers with their arms race to nowhere stirs a whirlpool of fear down which much of the world's wealth is being inexorably sucked
Cotton futures prices closed irregular last week on the New York Cotton Exchange.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 12 -- Richard Witkin, aviation editor of The New York Times, received tonight the Strebig-Dobben Memorial Award, presented annually by Trans World Airlines to the writer "who has contributed most to public understanding of commercial aviation."
Prince Souvanna Phouma, Premier of the Indochinese Kingdom of Laos, arrived in New York yesterday with professions of abiding friendship for the West.

EARLSVILLE, Ill., "just a wide stretch in the road west of Chicago," had a high school enrollment of fifteen boys when Herbert Orrin Crisler was a student there. All except two of them played football.

Two new works were conducted by Leonard Bernstein at the Saturday evening concert of the New York Philharmonic. There were really three new works on the program, for David Diamond's Fourth Symphony had been introduced by the Philharmonic only last Thursday.
The Communist Daily Worker suspended publication with today's issue, but its front page carried two banner headlines: "We'll Be Back! Fighting for Peace, Democracy and Socialism."
SAN MARINO, Jan. 12 (UP) -- The ousted San Marino Reds are seeking the help of Italy's big Communist party to regain control of this tiny republic, the new anti-Communist Government said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Israel Bond Organization voted here today to raise $75,000,000 by the sale of Israel bonds this year to provide Israel "with the economic armor to assure her stability, security and development."
New commitments assumed by the Ford Foundation in 1957 for the furtherance of its educational and philanthropic aims totaled more than $83,000,000.

"Bitter Lemons," a new book by Lawrence Durrell, is planned for March publication by Dutton. It is an "impressionistic" study of the moods and atmospheres of Cyprus during the troubled years 1953-56. The author, an Englishman, went to the island a year before the political situation about union with Greece erupted.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The shock of Peter Thorneycroft's surprising resignation as Chancellor of the Exchequer seemed to be wearing off in financial circles at the end of last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- In answer to the British who have been worried that their island might evaporate if one of the Air Force's bombers should crash while carrying an atomic bomb, this Government has reported that a plane carrying a nuclear weapon has actually crashed in this country.
SCOTT BASE, Antarctica, Jan. 12 -- On Oct. 14 our tractor train of one Weasel and three farm tractors set off from Scott Base across the Ross Ice Shelf.
NAHA, Okinawa, Monday, Jan. 13 -- The voters on this strategic Umted States air base island had today apparently selected a bitterly anti-American Mayor for Naha, their capital city.

There used to be a popular song titled "It's So Nice to Have a Man Around the House." According to a feature article that appeared the other day on the page given over to news of special interest to women, a New Jersey inventor named Win Johns spends a good deal of his waking hours meeting problems stemming from the vagaries of home ownership.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- President Eisenhower's message to Moscow replying to a letter from Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin, was greeted unenthusiastically in editorial comment in early editions of tomorrow's London newspapers.

VIENNA, Jan. 12 -- A recrudescence of "bourgeois nationalism" in Slovakia is worrying the Czechoslovak Communist party, according to the Bratislava radio. It might become even more worrisome if a proposal to withdraw Soviet troops from Czechoslovakia should be seriously considered at the proposed high-level conference on easing East-West tension.

The New York Shakespeare Festival Company, which has been hailed by drama critics as an impressive cultural achievement, will have to abandon its free theatre project on Jan. 25 because of depleted funds.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Councils to ready the faithful of both political parties for the 1958 election campaigns will begin here this week and continue through the end of the month.
The possibility of controlling the fusion reaction by magnetic confinement of super-heated heavy hydrogen was suggested near the end of World War II by scientists at Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- A Westchester Committee for the Advancement of Science and Mathematics was established today. Sixty persons, including teachers and researchers representing universities, colleges, secondary and elementary schools, foundations and industries, met to plan assistance to talented students and toadults with special interest in the subjects.

TEN years ago the historian Allan Nevins of Columbia University saw a stumbling block ahead for historians of generations yet to be. Before the twentieth century men had relied chiefly on letters to keep them in touch with associates in their calling, or in government.

The Regional Plan Association has come to the conclusion, after looking over the trend of home construction in the New York region for the first half of 1957, that New York City, in terms of population and housing, might appropriately be compared with the Red Queen in Alice in Wonderland, who ran as hard as she could to stay in the same place.
ONLY in its closing minutes did last night's "Dinah Shore Chevy Show" on Channel 4 fulfill some of the promise that had been offered by the names in its cast.

Cabell, Medinger, Forsyth Decker, a law firm now at 522 Fifth Avenue, has leased offices in the Seagram Building at 375 Park Avenue, at Fifty-second Street. The lease is for fifteen years and was negotiated by Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agents for the building.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- An American physician is reported to be facing a jail term in East Berlin on a charge of illegal trade in East German photographic equipment. He was identified today in Neues Deutschland, an East Berlin newspaper, as Dr. Walter Steinberg.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Negotiations between the Los Angeles Dodgers and Pasadena officials for use of the Rose Bowl for the Dodgers' 1958 and 1959 home baseball games entered the final phase today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Grain futures prices sagged all along the line last week under a variety of influences and finished well below the closing prices a week earlier.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Arnold Uhrlass of Yonkers flashed in first in the three-mile and 880-yard races today to win the senior men's title of the Eastern States outdoor speed skating champions.

A two-level building is planned for occupancy by International Business Machines at the northeast corner of the Grand Concourse and East 150th Street in the Bronx. Work has been started on the foundations of a structure from plans by Herbert H. and Clarence Lilien, architects.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 12 -Underworld information obtained after a gangland convention was halted last November by the state police at Apalachin, N. Y., led today to a raid here on a floating dice game.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 12 -- Malcolm Roberts, Lone Star Boat Club, defeated Jack Harang of the home club, 15 -- 14, 11 -- 15, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 14, in the singles final of the twenty-sixth annual Luckenbach Memorial squash racquets tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.
Inge Borkh, soprano, will make her Metropolitan Opera debut in the title role of Strauss' "Salome" on Friday evening, Jan. 24, as a feature of the thirteenth week of opera at the Metropolitan.

Britain's holdings of gold and dollar reserve showed another substantial gain last month, increasing by $88 million to a year-end figure of $2,273 million. This represents a rise of $140 million from the final figure for 1956. Even more striking, however, is the fact that it represents a recovery of $423 million from the 1957 low point of $1,850 million, touched in the month of September.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Ross Tarlton and his Hamilton, Ont., Thistles repeated as Douglas Medal champions as the twenty-second annual invitation bonspiel ended at the St. Andrews Golf Club curling rink today.
WARSAW, Jan. 12 -- The Government today crushed the hopes of thousands of Poles to travel in the West.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Administration is approaching some Democratic Congressmen with offers to keep their Republican campaign opponents from attacking them if the Democrats support the foreign aid and trade programs.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Last week's snowfall and the current run of frigid weather have turned this year-round play area into a winter sports mecca. This weekend the area had one of its largest crowds in recent years.

In a statement made to the press early last week Senator William F. Knowland of California, minority leader of the Senate, retailed the views of the President on the business outlook. The President, he told newsmen, expects "a material pick-up" in the economy after the middle of the new year, and feels that "1958, as a whole, will be better than 1957."
Four students on The New York Times Youth Forum concluded in general yesterday that there was plenty of good leadership available if the world would only make use of it.

Sidney Kingsley said yesterday that he may produce his play "Detective Story" for the Columbia Broadcasting System television network during the 1958-59 season. It would be done as a special ninety-minute show.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Bill Casper captured the $50,000 Bing Crosby golf tournament today as he fired a 1-under-par 71 for a 72-hole total of 277.
The leader of the national millinery strike predicted last night that all the union's 22,000 striking members would be back on the job tomorrow morning.
Religious fervor was tested yesterday afternoon in icy waters by two Greek youths who dived into the Hudson River to recover a cross.

Marriage was described yesterday as not only a sacrament and a vocation but also a means of attaining a closer union with God. The Rev. Raymond T. Powers made the observation in a sermon at the 10 A. M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Hollywood movie-makers are about to latch on to the latest in psychological camera trickery -- subliminal projection. The technique for communicating hidden information to an audience is to be tried out, apparently for the first time, in a feature-length motion picture.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just returned to my home from the hospital where I have been bedded for the past three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Drastic reductions in domestic programs, many of them in the fields of health, education and welfare, were proposed by President Eisenhower today to offset increased military spending.

A syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. is offering for public subscription today $5, 000,000 of new 4.8 per cent preferred stock of the Iowa Power and Light Company. The offering consists of 50,000 shares of $100 par value stock at $100 a share.
OWEGO, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- A rural grand jury in the old courthouse here will hear its first witness tomorrow in the Apalachin gang inquiry.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 12 -- Latin America's outstanding example of the welfare state is in serious economic trouble. In time, those economic difficulties may lead to serious political ones.
Commodity futures prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull and featureless.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A woman's death beneath the wheels of a train led indirectly today to the collision of two other trains, killing a flagman and injuring some fifty passengers.

What's wrong with our defense organization and the steps needed to strengthen it are the subject of a study by two career Army officers and a political scientist. Entitled "Forging a New Sword," the book is written by Col. Robert R. Kintner in association with Col. Joseph I. Coffey and Raymond J. Albright, all of whom have had working experience at the Pentagon.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 13 -- A retired Army lieutenant colonel tried a daring robbery of the Bing Crosby golf tournament receipts early today but was disarmed after a hand-to-hand battle with a deputy sheriff.
The Government lost a round yesterday in its fight to block the merger of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.

The City Health Department is considering adopting regulations that for the first time would require the registration of X-ray machines used by physicians and dentists and the regular inspection of such equipment.

A broad - shouldered, 205-pound Catholic priest is getting a sizeable workout this week as he prepares for the ninth annual Cardinal Hayes High School Games that will be held Saturday in the 102d Engineers Armory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The St. Lawrence Seaway is expected to take in $1,500,000 in tolls in its first two and one-half months of operation, President Eisenhower said today in his budget message.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -The Budget Bureau will soon receive a bill for approximately $82,000 from Raymond Blattenberger, the Public Printer. The Public Printer runs the Government Printing Office, which has just turned out 5,000 copies of a 1,024-page volume of fig ures under the title "The Budget of the United States Government for the Fiscal Year ending June 30, 1959.
The importance of environmental factors in mental retardation was stressed yesterday in a three-year survey of research in the field.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Federal Judge Richmond B. Keech today threw out of court a suit by Corliss Lamont contesting refusal of the State Department to consider a passport application from him.

TUNISIA, Jan. 13 -- The Tunisian Government denied today a French charge that an Algerian nationalist guerrilla force took five French soldiers into Tunisia Saturday as prisoners after an engagement on the Algerian side of the frontier.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 13 -- John Hulsen, Republican leader of Huntington Town, was charged today with extorting $23,000 from sand and gravel operators in the township.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Jan. 9 -- The Navy is not talking, but the survey for an ice-free airfield at near-by Marble Point appears to be shaping up favorably.
Disabled persons -- especially those who are doing what they can to earn a living in spite of their misfortune -- are suffering from added handicaps because of the Federal tax law.
Substantially larger sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the Continental Motors Corporation and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, 1957.

Thousands of buyers and manufacturers' representatives flocked to the Statler Hotel here yesterday for the opening session of the thirty-first annual convention of the National Wholesale Dry Goods Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The growing defense reliance on push-button weapons was illustrated in dollars and cents in the President's budget message today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- The Defense Department opened a campaign tonight to prevent the public from building up any great expectation that the next Vanguard rocket test would place an earth satellite in orbit.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Governor Harriman told his Cabinet this afternoon that his new budget would recommend $67,000,000 more for state assistance to local governments than the present budget.
Louis M. Simon will relinquish his post as director of the American Theatre Wing's Professional Training Center on Jan. 24.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 13 -- Methods of excluding nonresidents from more of Westchester County's overburdened parks, beaches and pools near the Bronx were discussed today by the Board of Supervisors.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today Texas may impose its liquor stamp tax on rum bought in Mexico by a North Carolina resident for personal use in his home state.
A proposal to permit taxpayers to subtract any increase in state and local school taxes from their Federal income tax bills was advocated here yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As an average American I fully realize the grave situation facing our country, and though of very modest means, I am ready, as no doubt many millions of Americans are, to make the sacrifices our Government will deem necessary in order to effectively meet and resolve the present crisis.

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- President Eisenhower's response to the Soviet peace offensive, as seen from Paris, has both helped to even the propaganda score and increased the likelihood of some form of East-West negotiations.
The nation's two largest copper producers cut the price of refined copper 2 cents a pound yesterday, to 25 cents.

Events today: Bizet's "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P. M.; Julian Olevsky, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Lya de Barberiis, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Rossini's "Barber of Seville, Operas-in-Brief, Town Hall, 5:30.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 13 -- The political victory won yesterday by Willy Brandt, Governing Mayor of West Berlin, is appraised here as a gain for the "reform" faction of the Social Democratic party. Herr Brandt wrested the chairmanship of the Berlin branch of the party from Franz Neumann, who had held the office for twelve years.
SHIVER our timbers. Popeye -- and all his crew -- have climbed aboard S. S. Abraham Straus.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The 1960 Olympic winter games got a mention in President Eisenhower's Budget Message today. He asked Congress to provide $4,000,000 so that the Federal Government could help California stage the games in Squaw Valley.

The second session of the Eighty-fifth Congress opened a week ago, and in that time has received two major pronouncements from the President. While more messages will be coming from Mr. Eisenhower detailing his legislative proposals for the year, Congress already has a fairly good idea of what will be expected of it before it adjourns in time for the 1958 election campaign.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Congress received President Eisenhower's Budget Message today with the speed-up reading usually given the annual money document.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The watchdog committee questioned three Assemblymen, today on their roles in interceding for a racketeer in a 1956 speeding case.

DETROIT, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Carl Stellato, president of the United Auto Workers Ford Local 600, said today he was "deeply disappointed" with Walter P. Reuther's decision to drop demands for a shorter work week in favor of a share of the auto industry's profits.

The Canadian Pacific liner Empress of England arrived yesterday from Liverpool by way of Canada for her first visit to New York. The 25,000-ton ship was welcomed by police helicopters and city fireboats as she sailed up the Upper Bay at 8 A. M.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The Legislature observed tonight the centennial year of one of its most distinguished former members, Theodore Roosevelt.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 13 -- Stevan Dedijer, Princeton-educated Yugoslav scientist, has been refused a passport to resume his interrupted studies in nuclear physics at a Swedish university.
The battle to unseat John J. O'Rourke as president of the Teemsters Joint Council here will be joined tonight when nominations are made for next month's election of officers.

Voters in one Queens state Senate District and two Bronx Assembly Districts will go to the polls today in special elections to fill vacancies in three seats in the Legislature formerly held by Democrats.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- Revised and expanded indexes of world industrial production from 1948 through the first half of 1957 appear in the Monthly Bulletin of Statistics of the United Nations, published today.

THE chemise may have a great future at Chanel in Paris but, as far as American channels are concerned it looks like a flop. Television, a medium that has considerable fashion influence, has to date rejected the sack dress.

The New York City Housing Authority is planning to receive bids on Jan. 21 on $32,358,000 of short-term notes for the financing of three state-subsidized low-rent projects -- Bushwick Houses, in Brooklyn; Manhattanville Houses, Manhattan; and Castle Hill Houses, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Eisenhower's budget for the coming fiscal year predicts, depends on and may contribute to quick recovery from the current business recession.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 13 (Reuters) -- Stefan Sebesta was dismissed today from his post as Deputy Premier of the Slovak regional government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A subpoena was issued today calling upon an American living in the Dominican Republic to testify before a grand jury investigating the disappearance of Jesus Maria de Galindez and Gerald L. Murphy.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 13 -- A $220,000 Federal grant to Northwestern University for research on highway accidents was announced here today.

One passage in President Eisenhower's letter to Premier Bulganin brings back echoes of the famous conferences at which the mutually suspicious victors in the second World War hammered the United Nations Charter into shape: Dumbarton Oaks in 1944; Yalta in early 1945; San Francisco in the hopeful spring of 1945.
A Markets Department bidding procedure for a five-year lease of city-owned cold storage facilities was assailed yesterday as "morally indefensible and legally improper."

Pietro Cimara suffered a stroke last night while conducting at the Metropolitan Opera House. He toppled from the podium and his place was taken instantly by a young violinist in the orchestra who kept the performance going without interruption.

Crumpled sheets of ice flowed seaward in the Hudson River yesterday as warming skies and an outgoing tide broke up a one-inch crust formed in the night. It had gathered along the shores above the George Washington Bridge.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to help keep afloat a ship construction program that floundered badly during the last session.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -Following is the text of President Eisenhower's Budget Message, presented to Congress today:

A white rooster named Petushok helped to usher in the Russian New Year last night at the ninth annual Bal Blanc at the Ambassador. Petushok is expected to bring good luck to the hundreds who stroked him during the festivities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Business demands for Federal tax reform and rate cuts mounted today as Congress received from President Eisenhower a record peacetime spending budget.

The football teams under the jurisdiction of the Public Schools Athletic League and the Catholic High Schools Football League are the only ones in the metropolitan area likely to adopt the new conversion rule enacted by the football rules committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Senate rackets investigating committee voted today to ask the Senate for $500,000 and another year in which to do its job. The proposed budget is the same as this year's.

Financial problems are bothering Carmen Capalbo and Stanley Chase, producers with headquarters at the Bijou. Because they lack funds to pay the rent, the intimate house, which was leased by them through next October, has reverted to the City Investing Company.

TAKEN as sheer sound, the bass-baritone of Donald Gramm in his second Town Hall recital last night was an attractively resonant, straightforward, manly voice. It was something of a surprise to discover toward the end of the recital that he could color it, too.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Most sections of the stock market were dull today. At the outset British Government securities continued their advance but by the close they had eased.

Asian influenza delayed a gift to the Neediest from the Youth Rehabilitation Center of Italy, Inc. A check for $50 arrived yesterday after several officers of the New York organization had recovered from the disease and were able to make the donation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Supreme Court struck a blow today for the embattled commuter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -Contrary to general expectations President Eisenhower's budget today contained two recommendations for tax changes, besides the previously known proposal for extending present levels of corporation and excise taxes.

ALTHOUGH the dramatic series called "Kitty Foyle" made its debut yesterday on Channel 4, the actress who will play the title role will not be seen for the first five weeks. This may be one of the nicest things that ever happened to her.
OTTAWA, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Cmdr. Thomas J. Keane of Forest Halls, Queens, has been appointed executive commissioner for relationships in the Boy Scouts International Bureau.

The Protestant CoUncil of the City of New York voiced vigorous opposition yesterday to the Condon-Wadlin anti-strike law. It called on the 1958 session of the Legislature to repeal or modify it and to "make this a matter for early consideration."

President Eisenhower's reply to Premier Bulganin's message holds the door open to another East-West summit meeting, on two conditions. One precludes a bilateral Soviet-American deal to be imposed on other nations and specifies that, "as appropriate," other nations must participate in discussions affecting their interests.

Roswell Magill, chairman of Tax Foundation, Inc., and former under secretary of the Treasury, said yesterday that President Eisenhower's budget might force Congress to "choose between an increase in the mountainous national debt and an increase in record-breaking taxes."
The Grand Union Company plans to expand offerings of non-food products, Lansing P. Shield, president, said yesterday at a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

The open-air pushcart market, a picturesque feature of New York City life since 1880, may soon pass into the limbo of things remembered. Markets Commissioner Anthony Masciarelli said yesterday he planned to recommend to Mayor Wagner next month that the curbside pushcart markets be ended as too great an economic drain on the city.
BOSTON, Jan. 13 -- The three railroads serving Boston were notified by the State Public Utilities today to take "immediate steps" to clear station platforms of snow.
A new opera fantasy by Deems Taylor, "The Dragon," based on the play of the same name by Lady Gregory, will be produced by the New York University Opera Workshop on Feb. 6, 7, and 8.
Union and shipping officials indicated yesterday that they soon would sign an "incomplete" contract rather than continue longer without one.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today upheld the convictions of three persons charged with evading Federal income taxes on large sums made in the World War II black market in sugar.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- State Department officials said today that the next move toward an East-West heads-of-government conference was up to the Soviet Union.
Printing Week, to continue through Saturday, was observed at City Hall yesterday.
Cotton futures declined yesterday in quiet trading. Final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange showed losses of 5 to 19 points (25 to 95 cents a bale).
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 13 -- This city is considering joining the ranks of Fairfield County communities that charge non-residents for use of their public beaches.
President Justice Harry P. Eppig of the Municipal Court declared yesterday that his court could make no further reductions in its budget request for the fiscal year 1958-59.
In sluggish trading, stocks dipped briefly yesterday and then made a slow recovery to end the day with a small gain.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Supreme Court unanimously reversed today a Post Office ban on the mailing of nudist magazines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Subliminal Projection Company brought its "secret sell" to Washington today and openly tried to persuade Government leaders that the new form of advertising is not really a bugaboo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The constitutionality of a Congressional statute adopting past and future state criminal laws by reference to cover army camps and other federal enclaves was upheld today by the Supreme Court.

THIS record-fish business might as well be stopped right now, for the protection of property rights in the International Game Fish Association and other enterprises that certify records. Joe Brooks has set out to get all the records and is well on his way.
HONG KONG, Jan. 13 -- Pacts signed by Communist China and Yemen in Peiping yesterday open the way for Chinese participation in the economic and cultural affairs of the Yemenite Kingdom.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 13 -- The Soviet Union has turned down with thanks the proposal of an Indian elder statesman that Moscow take advantage of the moral privilege of being the first to renounce unconditionally the use of nuclear weapons.
DETROIT, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Strikes and worker lay-offs have slowed auto production at several plants.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- Indonesia today denied accusations by the Netherlands that she had illegally seized Dutch enterprises and mistreated Dutch citizens.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Eisenhower sent Congress his fifth and largest budget today. It calls for record peacetime spending.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 13 -- There's good news tonight for those who wear shirts.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 13 (UP) -- The game warden who accused Gov. A. B. (Happy) Chandler and two others of breaking hunting laws got his job back today.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Jan. 13 (UP) -- Navy's Eddie Erdelatz came to Texas A. and M. today to talk about a coaching vacancy, but did little to clear up the confusion that has enveloped the Aggie picture almost since the day Paul Bryant left for Alabama.
CHARLESTON, S. C., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Herbert Hoover said today "the frontiers of science and better understanding of human welfare are steadily opening."
The Superior Oil Company of California plans to resume the payment of dividends this year, H. B. Keck, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting in Los Angeles yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, heard himself eulogized today as an ideal United States Senator.

Larry MacPhail, the volatile former president of the Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Yankees, predicted last night that "the Dodgers will never play at the Los Angeles Coliseum, the Rose Bowl or in Chavez Ravine."
How accurate are the key economic barometers? That's a pretty question.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Pacific Coast League today voted in three new clubs -- Spokane, Salt Lake City and Phoenix, Ariz.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- More than 9,000 scientists from forty-three countries joined today in urging immediate action to stop tests of nuclear bombs by international agreement.

B. Brewster Jennings, chairman and chief executive officer of the Socony Mobil Oil Company, has announced that he will retire on Feb. 1. Albert L. Nickerson, president since July, 1955, will succeed Mr. Jennings as chief executive officer while retaining the presidency.

OTTAWA, Jan. 13 -- The Canadian Government has initiated a study of the United States social security system with the possibility in mind of applying it to Canada, Prime Minister John Diefenbaker told the House of Commons today.
DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- The United Auto Workers made public today a two-level collective bargaining program for 1958 calling for an unusual profit-sharing plan in addition to higher wages.

Officials in professional football were united yesterday in regarding the new conversion rule adopted by the rules committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association as none of their business. Nor did any predict that the professional organization, the National Football League, would follow suit.

HOT breads for breakfast, always received with enthusiasm, are particularly welcome on a cold winter morning. The two recipes suggested here combine a baking powder batter with fruit; in one it is canned apple slices; in the other, cooked, pitted prunes.
New York University and the Atomic Energy Commission are joining forces to further their research and teaching programs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's budget message to Congress today was viewed as still another bearish influence on the Board of Trade and grain futures prices sagged again, some fairly sharply.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A former president of a Teamsters Union local at Bakersfield, Calif., testified today that he had signed credentials for delegates to the teamsters conference but had not read what he had signed.

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- The organization for European Economic Cooperation warned today that the successful surmounting of the oil supply problem during the Suez crisis a year ago should not lull Europe into a sense of false security.
MIAMI, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Denver, seeded No. 3, and Dave Harum of Coral Gables, No. 4, today reached the second round of the Coral Cables-University of Miami Tennis Tournament.
TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner will deliver his fourth annual message tomorrow before a joint session of the 1958 Legislature.
Personnel of the New York Stock Exchange and of member firms will give blood today at Federal Memorial Hall, Wall and Nassau Streets, on the second day of a three-day donation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, advocated today a cautious approach to any reorganization of the Defense Department.
Dr. Anthony M. Palermo, a physician for the New York Giants baseball team, was convicted yesterday of evading $30,619 in income taxes.
Two committees of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York yesterday recommended legal restrictions on wiretapping and electronic eavesdropping by law officers.

The dress rehearsal for the world premiere of "Vanessa," with music by Samuel Barber and libretto by Gian-Carlo Menotti, was held at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. The performance, scheduled for tomorrow night, will be the first world premiere presented by Rudolf Bing as manager of the Metropolitan.

Washington, Jan. 13 -- The question of whether Soviet cartoonists can attend the May convention of the American Association of Editorial Cartoonists was settled today when the State Department agreed to the proposed visit. The convention is to be in Indianapolis.

The General Sessions courtroom of Judge Irwin D. Davidson was so crowded yesterday that court personnel had to crane their necks to see the defendants.
Thousands of commuters had a bad time of it yesterday morning as a result of railroad mishaps at widely spaced points in the city area.
Notre Dame scored the upset of the year for 1957 when it broke Oklahoma's record string of football victories at forty-seven in a 7-0 game on Nov. 16.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Congress responded with skepticism today to President Eisenhower's forecast of a balanced budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared today that the need for United states foreign aid was particularly acute in view of the Soviet Union's program of economic aid to some countries.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One of the greatest deterrents to a massive Federal program in aid of higher education is the fear that the Government cannot afford it. Happily this fear is unjustified. In fact, it is demonstrable that such a program would insure the Government eventually a very handsome annual profit on a strict accounting basis.

A record play-off pool of $75,000, representing an increase of 50 per cent over last year, was disclosed yesterday by the National Basketball Association, together with plans for the 1958 post-season play-offs.

Travel writers must subject themselves to peril in trifling or tremendous quantities for our vicarious adventure. SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 13 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin submitted to the Legislature today a budget for $262,381,228 for the next fiscal year. A rise of ten points in three months is not bad, by market speculation yardsticks, This winter, however, the ten-point rises seem to be more common to bonds than to stocks. Yesterday the long-term Treasury bonds spurted again, the new 4s and 3 7/8s to new highs.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 13 -- A task force of twenty-five Atlantic Fleet warships left here today to begin an extensive ten-day exercise. It will emphasize offensive air strikes against East Coast targets, anti-submarine warfare and air defense techniques.

NAHA, Okinawa, Jan. 13 -- United States military authorities were galled today by the realization that a political reform they had instituted contributed decisively to the election of one of the bitterest foes of the United States in Okinawa.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 13 -- The Government told Parliament today that the Netherlands had agreed "in principle" to the establishment of missile bases on her territory "if necessary."

West Virginia strengthened its grip at the top of the United Press major college basketball ratings yesterday, but all except two of the other teams in the first ten shifted places in the wake of several upsets.
