WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -Silos in Afghanistan, oil-drilling rigs in India, bridges in Egypt, a tire factory in Indonesia -- these are some of the projects being built with loans and technicians supplied by the Soviet bloc.
THE Japanese Home fashions Show opens tomorrow at the Japan Trade Center, 393 Fifth Avenue, to continue through Jan. 31.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The leader of the influential French employers' organization called today for a vigorous and sustained reform of France's finances if the nation was to hold its own in the new European economic community.

ARTHUR ELIAS, whose recent paintings are on view at the Peridot Gallery, 820 Madison Avenue, confines his compositions to the interior of his studio. His favorite props are the broad table pitched up slightly to meet the needs of his compositions; the various pots and bottles the artist likes to have about him, and occasional plants or dried stalks of corn.
James Rossetti, former president of the Greater New York Cartmen's Association, may get back the business license he lost as a result of the.Senate rackets investigation.

A Texas investor has purchased the property at 747-57 Second Avenue and 239-45 East Fortieth Street, the northwest corner, from Seventh Estate, Inc., Maurice Epstein, president. No immediate plans for using the property were announced by the buyer, who recently bought the southwest corner of Second Avenue and Fortieth Street.
A Polish theoretical physicist who obtained political asylum in the United States was reunited here yesterday with his wife and daughter.
Talk is cheap, thee old saying goes. But, as fas as Budget Director Abraham D. Beame is concerned, the adage does not apply to the city's 116 agencies.
The city's hope of taking possession of the site for the proposed $205,000,000 Lincoln Square redevelopment by Jan. 31 -- the announced target date -- disappeared yesterday.
Seven one-hour television symposiums on national affairs will be presented as successor to the Columbia Broadcasting System's "The Seven Lively Arts," starting next month.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Jan. 14 (UP) -- Navy's head football coach, Eddie Erdelatz, today said he wanted no part of the Texas A. and M. set-up because it "scared" him. And his feelings got him into a heated verbal exchange with Aggie officials before he left town.

An exhibition of forty-three masterpieces, paintings and sculpture from the collection of the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, will open with two previews Tuesday at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Those concerned with the quality of public education in a state which must provide more than its share of the kind of leadership required for our times commend you for your excellent editorial of Jan. 8.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 14 -Archbishop Makarios has applied to the Turkish Consul General in Athens for a visa to visit Turkey, Turkish officials said today.

WILLIAM HUMPHREY'S first novel, 'Home From the Hill," is still another exploration of passionate emotion and tragic violence in the small-town South. But instead of writing baroque allegory about decadence under the magnolias, Mr. Humphrey has written a dramatic narrative about entirely believable people.

A new tool expected to reduce costs and expedite production of a wide range of reinforced plastic items such as boats, truck bodies and swimming pools was announced yesterday by the Rand Development Corporation of Cleveland.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 14 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to have offered to help Indonesia in the shipping crisis stemming from her anti-Dutch campaign.

A rank-and-file movement to oust James G. Cross as international president of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union has been started in a key New York local. The union was expelled recently from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations for corrupt practices.
HAVANA, Jan. 14 -- Rebel columns struck boldly into the plains around the big sugar port of Manzanillo in southeastern Cuba today.
A State Labor Relations Board trial examiner yesterday recommended the dismissal of charges of unfair labor practices brought against the Stork Club by striking waiters and kitchen employes.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 14 -- One of the Nation's leading business figures bit the hand that was feeding him today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The New York State Banking Department has filed a brief with the Federal Reserve Board, underscoring its feeling that supervision of bank holding companies is a matter for state authority.

Section 755, New York City Administrative Code, states that "within four hours after snow has ceased to fall" sidewalks must be cleared of snow and ice. If this law were better observed and enforced the problem of slush, covered by Sanitary Code Section 53, would be eliminated automatically.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Dag Hammarskjold will take up the deadlock over disarmament negotiations during his visit to London this week.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- The revised proposals for court reform by the Tweed Commission are running into trouble in the Legislature.
West Virginia, unbeaten in twelve games, continued to set a torrid pace in the Associated Press' weekly college basketball poll yesterday.

SEVERAL of the fresh vegetables that usually are economical choices here at this season suddenly cost as much as luxurious imported endive and hearts of palm. Put the blame on the recent freezes in Florida. As a result of crop damage, that state has not been able to supply us with the usual quantities of vegetables like peas, green beans, limas, beets and cucumbers.
OWEGO, N. Y., Jan. 14 -Lawyers for delegates to the Apalachin underworld convention have decided upon a "double jeopardy" plea as their clients' excuse for refusing an expected offer of immunity.
Dr. Manuel Urrutia, Cuban Opposition leader, charged yesterday that President Batista had encouraged gambling and contraband in narcotics as "one way of corrupting the people."
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Dr. Geoffrey F. Fisher, the Archbishop of Canterbury, condemned artificial insemination by donors today as "an offense against the social and legal implications of marriage."
BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Tommy Tibbs of Boston outboxed Willie Pep tonight and gained a split decision in a ten-round contest. Tibbs weighed 131 pounds. Pep 129 3/4.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Race relations have worsened in the South in the last year, the Tuskegee Institute says, and realistic action is imperative "if serious difficulties are to be avoided in the near future."
PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The French Cabinet risked its life today soon after the National Assembly had begun its first session of 1958.
LONDON, Jan. 14 (AP) --South Africa's Willie Toweel, the British Empire lightweight champion, outpointed Cuba's Orlando Zulueta tonight in a ten-round bout. Each boxer weighed 135 pounds.
A syndicate of investors headed by Edward L. Lane has taken title to the two five-story buildings at 115-17 East Fifty-seventh Street from Henry Goelet, realty investor and builder.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Seven members of the House of Commons said in a report published today that racial partnership in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland was not yet a reality to nonwhites there.
Six of the oustanding sports car competition figures of 1957 received plaques from The New York Times yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Madison Avenue Sports Car Driving and Chowder Society.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -Organized labor's prescription of wage increases as the key to curing the current recession won the backing today of the Conference on Economic Progress.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- France said today that Soviet peace proposals ignored the political problems -- notably German unification -- that are responsible for the "unhealthy situation" that has persisted for ten years.
ALTHOUGH the chief character is called "Winkelberg" in Ben Hecht's drama, which opened at the Renata last evening, he represents Maxwell Bodenheim, the Village poet, murdered there in 1954.
The demand for luxury apartments on a tenant-ownership basis has induced a builder to switch from a rental to a cooperative operation in the building he is erecting at 30 East Sixty-second Street.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 14 -Edsel, the disappointment of the 1958 car-model year, will lose its identity as a separate division of the Ford Motor Company.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa. Jan. 14 -- Methodists have spent more than $100,000,000 annually since 1954 in constructing and improving church buildings in this country, a church board was told today. There are more than 9,000,000 members of the Methodist church in the United States.

William Shakespeare has some disillusioning things to say about politicians, even statesmen, and doubtless these days Joseph Papp, one of this city's most successful producers of Shakespeare, unhappily concurs. So might New York, since Mr. Papp is the producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, whose free performances in city parks last summer and whose "King Richard III" last summer were so excellent.
The program fund of the Junior Council of the Museum of Modern Art will benefit from a preview showing of the Bareiss Collection on April 22.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Governor Harriman was accused today of attempting to spread panic over the national economy for partisan political purposes.

A sharp rebuff to the latest Soviet efforts to ally Communists and Socialists abroad in new "popular fronts" has been administered by the leaders of the Socialist-International. Meeting in Paris, these leaders representing the principal Socialist parties of Europe, reaffirmed their "unanimous will" to support the defense of the free world against both Communist aggression and infiltration.

The management of the Grace National Bank said yesterday that the use of general credit controls by the Federal Reserve System had been ineffective in halting rising prices and that some "new techniques" for controlling prices should be devised.

"Bonjour Tristesse," Otto Preminger's film version of the Francoise Sagan novel, starring Deborah Kerr, David Niven and Jean Seberg, arrives today at the Capitol. The romantic drama, filmed in France in wide screen and color, is being presented by Columbia Pictures.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -Senate investigators were urged today to remove legal handicaps that are "endangering" the entire railroad industry and threatening to plunge the "seven big passenger-carrying lines in the East into bankruptcy."

"The Entertainer," starring Sir Laurence Olivier, is going into the Royale. Feb. 12 is the opening date for the John Osborne drama, staged by Tony Richardson. An engagement spanning eight weeks has been announced for the London hit.
The Stoneybrook races at Southern Pines, N. C., On Saturday, March 22, will open the 1958 spring hunt schedule, the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association disclosed yesterday.

THE audience for "Matinee Theatre" on Channel 4 yesterday was probably larger and more attentive than ever. For this daily drama program was presenting Sarah Churchill in a live version of "The Makropoulous Secret."

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 14 -Al Wilkinson, a third-string defenseman, scored the deciding goal as Princeton tripped American International College, 4 -- 3, tonight in Baker Rink. Wilkinson's long shot from the blue line capped a second-period rally in which the Tigers overcame a 3-1 deficit.

FOR the second time this season Madison Square Garden was transformed last night into an ice cavern of dazzling colors featuring spectacular pageants, beauteous ballerinas on skates, costumes of opulent design and enough comic antics for both the young and old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -President Eisenhower told Republican Congressional leaders today that world-wide press and public reactions to his latest message to Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin had been very favorable.

A leading spokesman for New York State savings banks voiced optimism yesterday that savings banks, savings and loan associations and commercial banks in the state would agree soon on a common program for revising the State Banking Law.

Walter Hagen, a slim, serious, boyish-looking man of 37, told yesterday of the eight minutes he spent Monday night on the podium at the Metropolitan Opera House. He has been playing in the second violin section of the orchestra since 1946 and has always had dreams of being a conductor.

JUIAN OLEVSKY, young American violinist, who made his debut here in 1949, gave his fifth New York recital last night at Carnegie Hall. He presented a fine, meaty program and he played it like the first-rate artist he has become.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -President Eisenhower ordered immediate development today of a second airport for the national capital area.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The Legislature got a four-hour lecture today. The subject: What's wrong with the Legislature.
Officials of New York City, Boston and New Britain, Conn., are backing Federal legislation to extend the benefits of tax-exempt investment income to shareholders of investment companies.

If anyone wishes to help increase understanding between the people of the United States and those of other countries he is invited to obtain a name of someone overseas from Letters Abroad, so that he may exchange ideas by mail. Hundreds of young men and women -- including those from many new nations -have asked for American pen friends.

The newest of new looks in the automobile industry this year has been supplied by Walter P. Reuther. None of the handsome 1958 models produced by the Big Three auto makers compares in originality with the collective bargaining program put forward by the president of the United Automobile Workers.

NEWARK, Jan. 14 -- Municipal departments and agencies here finished last year with $1,575,781 unspent from their 1957 appropriations, it was reported today by John T. Mahoney, city budget officer. The money will be transferred to the city's current funds.
Weather records of the United States outpost at the South Pole indicate that the British tractors seeking to cross Antartica will encounter severe conditions within a few weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The International Cotton Advisory Commitee said today there was much interest in world markets in what this country might do to prevent possible shortages of some grades of cotton.
NEWARK, Jan. 14 -- A former Mayor of Newark and the Mayor of Elizabeth testified today that flight operations at Newark Airport were disturbing the daily routine of residents.

Maurice A. Bergman, who has held a variety of executive positions in the motion-picture industry over the last three decades, has been named to the newly created position of director of public affairs for the Motion Picture Association of America.

TRUMBULL, Conn., Jan. 14 -Edward De Courcy, chairman of the Connecticut Council on Freedom of Information, said today that his organization would investigate the exclusion of the public and press from a portion of the Representative Town Meeting here last night.
Certification of the Steamship Office Workers Union as official bargaining agent for Italia Line clerical employes here was virtually assured yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The Dow Chemical Company, in its report for the six months ended Nov. 30, disclosed yesterday that sales and earnings topped the totals of a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The merged labor movement has abolished nearly a hundred organizers' jobs informed sources reported today.

The National Malleable and Steel Castings Company, Cleveland, will expand into the nonferrous field through the acquisition of the Grand Rapids Plating Company and its subsidiary, Grand Rapids Die Casting Company.
Wind and rain pounded the city yesterday, clearing most streets of snow and taking a toll in ripped umbrellas.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP) -- The rapid march of seeded talent in the Coral Gables-University of Miami tennis tournament continued today in the second round of competition but upsets were numerous among unseeded foreign players.

An electronic typing calculator that can be easily operated by the average typist has been developed by International Business Machines Corporation. Priced at $5,600, the device was unveiled yesterday at a press conference here. Deliveries will begin in the second quarter.

At the second day of the National Wholesale Dry Goods Association's convention and merchandise show yesterday at the Statler Hotel it was apparent that though attendance records might be broken, sales records probably would not be.

Penn-Texas Corporation has sold another subsidiary, Tex-Penn Oil and Gas Corporation. This was disclosed in a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The sales price was $1,440,000 and the buyer was the Judarth Corporation of New York.
The Lever Brothers Company showed here yesterday pink and white striped toothpaste, called Stripe.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- The Government newspaper Izvestia reported today that President Eisenhower's budget message weighed four pounds but could be summed up in two words: "war budget."
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The British Government appeared today to be assuming a more flexible attitude toward Communist proposals for the creation of a zone in Central Europe free of nuclear weapons.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:
MADISON AVENUE, known as "Ulcer Alley" among ad men, now harbors the most relaxed executive in all New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Following is the text of a resume prepared by the United States Government on the status of Soviet bloc aid in eleven countries from 1955 through 1957:

Fire in a New Haven Railroad engine and a power failure in a ferry terminal stranded more than 70,000 commuters and other travelers during the rush hour last night. No trains ran into or out of Grand Central Terminal from 4:26 to 5:25 o'clock, and schedules did not return to normal until 9:30.

The famous librettist, Sir William Gilbert, is the subject of a new biography by Hesketh Pearson, which Harper will publish Feb. 5. "Gilbert: His Life and Strife" is based on all the private letters of Sir William. It covers the entire career of the man who with Sir Arthur Sullivan "raised light opera to an art."

MR. FREDERICS is fickle. He believes in many spring hat silhouettes. He hails the chemise as the perfect background dress for all his hat shapes. Rollers, cloches, turbans and high-crowned shapes, flowered and plain, intrigue him.

WARSAW, Jan. 14 -- The Roman Catholic Church has regained a measure of control over charity in Poland for the first time since Charitas, its own charity organization, was taken out of Church hands in 1949.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Peter Thorneycroft, who resigned last week as Chancellor of the Ex-chequer in a dispute over economic policy, disclaimed tonight any intention of leading a revolt in the Conservative party.
COLUMBUS, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The first Soviet satellite split into eight fragments before falling earlier this month, Ohio State University scientists said today.

TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- More than 3,000 Democrats from all parts of New Jersey converged on the State House today to watch their party take control of the State Assembly for the first time in twenty years.
The State of New York borrowed $37,500,000 in the public market yesterday to finance construction of mental health institutions.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 14 -- Superior Court Judge J. Wallace Leyden ruled today that a permit to alter a private residence in Saddle River for school purposes had been issued illegally. He also held that the revocation of the permit under an amended zoning code was a valid exercise of police power by the borough.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Eisenhower followed up his Budget Message to Congress with a request today for $518,000,000 in pay increases for the armed forces. Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, pointed out in a letter to Sam Rayburn, Speaker of the House, that "in time of peace, patriotism alone is not a sufficient motivation for a career in the armed forces."

SAN FRANCISO, Jan. 14 -Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, said here today that this country's prospective military stalemate with the Soviet Union would put an increased burden on education in nonmilitary fields.

Futures prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, the domestic sugar contract, potatoes, cottonseed oil, copper, wool and hides rose; coffee, world sugar positions, rubber and lead declined, and price movements or zinc were mixed.

A man who said his brother had been killed by a fall or suicide jump from their hotel bedroom was arrested here last night and charged with murder. The dead man, it was learned, was not related to the man who identified him. The police charged that the victim had been pushed from the window for the purpose of collecting $6,912 insurance.
The city's budget practices were called "penny wise and pound foolish" yesterday by Irving Ben Cooper, Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions.
A member of Mayor Wagner's special baseball committee said yesterday, "There is still a possibility" of getting a National League club for New York City in 1958.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Britain challenged United States supremacy in long-range jet, airliners today with the largest single order ever placed for a British civil plane.

The vital relationship of the mutual security program to the military, political and economic strength of the United States and to the peace of the world is clearly pointed up in the President's budget message. Congress, please take note.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Jan. 14 -- R. S. Garfield Todd, Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia, announced a new cabinet today to replace the one that resigned Saturday.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 14 (UP) -President Warren Giles of the National League today denied a charge by Larry MacPhail that ball parks were "obsolete" and cited examples of where large sums of money had been expended for their improvement throughout the league.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The legislative watchdog committee chairman defended today the actions of three Assemblymen whose names have figured in the investigation of the Apalachin convention of hoodlums.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas called on the Administration today to invite all members of the United Nations to join this country in a drive to conquer outer space and to preserve it for peaceful uses.

The endowment fund of the Casa Italiana of Columbia University will gain as a result of a special private preview Monday evening of an exhibition of post-war paintings by forty-four Italian artists. The exhibition will be continued from Tuesday through Feb. 8 at the Casa at Amsterdam Avenue and 117th Street.
PATUXENT RIVER, Md., Jan. 14 (UP) -- A Navy SuperConstellation plane crashed today at Patuxent River Naval Air Station, killing all nine men aboard.
TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called today for a 1-cent increase in the state's tax on gasoline to finance further expansion of New Jersey's highway system.
TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- Following are excerpts from the text of Gov. Robert B. Meyner's annual address today to a joint session of the 182d New Jersey Legislature:

We are engaged at the moment in a heightened discussion of elements of strength and weakness in our defense structure. This should not be restricted to debates on domestic organization and procedure, or disputes over how much money should be spent for what. Our defense is not domestic, but worldwide.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -- Two Qantas Empire Airways Super Constellation airliners left Essendon airport here today, one flying east and the other west to launch a new round-the-world service. The two are to meet in London, 12,500 miles away, on Thursday.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, Jan. 14 -- A major political crisis seemed at hand in this usually somnolent British colony today as a general strike paralyzed the island.

They have been back at school for some days now, even though it does not seem so. The house appears to vibrate still. It is as though the walls had become so saturated with noise that the echoes will not die.

TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- Lawrence A. Whipple was named today by Attorney General Grover C. Richman Jr. as acting prosecutor of Hudson County and a deputy attorney general. Mr. Whipple long has been a close associate of John V. Kenny, former Mayor of Jersey City.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Soybean futures prices were the star performers on the Board of Trade today following a report that the Government's estimate of surplus stocks of beans from the 1957-58 crop was far too high.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- The Ministry of Defense confirmed tonight that Col. Gen. Alexei S. Zheltov had been dismissed as chief of the Main Political Administration of the armed forces.
The State Judicial Conference has endorsed the new Tweed plan to reorganize the state court system.

Julien J. Soubiran of Darien, Conn., last night was re-elected to his third term as president of the New York Athletic Club by a unanimous vote. Joseph J. Lordi and Alfred Foster, both of New York, were re-elected vice president and secretary, respectively, at the eighty-ninth annual meeting held in the gymnasium of the city clubhouse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -Television advertisers who now sponsor film shows may initiate a trend back to live programs next fall if producers of filmed shows do not provide greater flexibility in their contracts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Government is starting a program to keep scientists abreast of Soviet research.

An American was named yesterday by the Music Critics Circle of New York as the composer of the best new orchestral work performed in this city during 1957. He is Leo Smit, 36-year-old composer-pianist. The work that won him the award was his Symphony No. 1, introduced here by the Boston Symphony on Feb. 6.
W. C. Hale Jr. has been elected president of South Chester Tube Company, Chester, Pa. He was also elected chairman of the board of the company's subsidiary, Dodge Steel Company, Tacony, Philadelphia.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 14 -- The Air Force Missile Test Center at Cape Canaveral launched a Bomarc this morning and a Redstone tonight.
DETROIT, Jan. 14 -- Walter P. Reuther accused Harlow H. Curtice today of "mental and moral gymnastics" in opposing profit sharing for workers and consumers while approving such a plan for executives.

Velisa Mugosa, Yugoslav runner, took an official bow at the Metropolitan Track Writers luncheon yesterday at Leone's. With an interpreter to assist in relaying his answers, Mugosa felt that he would be a success as a competitor in this country.

THE theatre programs handed to patrons of the opera and of some thirty Broadway playhouses every day are a city institution. For almost seventy-five years they have been distributed free, the publisher taking his profit from advertising. In Europe the theatre patron must buy his program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -Judge Alexander Holtzoff ruled in Federal District Court here today that the armed forces had the right to court-martial their civilian employes serving overseas.

There are few polls of recent years in Latin America that have aroused as much anxiety around the hemisphere as the Presidential elections which are to take place on Sunday in Guatemala. There are reasons to worry.

General hospitals in New York are too hasty in sending some patients to municipal psychiatric services, Hospital Commissioner Morris A. Jacobs said yesterday. He was referring to those who became "a little difficult to manage."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Air Force hopes to launch a military reconnaissance satellite with a recoverable capsule by the spring of 1959.

GAUHATI, India, Jan. 14 -- Four thousand visitors of a special sort, sixty-four elephants and a few tons of bamboo turned a dusty stretch of barren ground in northeast India today into the political capital of the country.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The free world has lost the initiative in its propaganda contest with the Soviet bloc. Recently we have gone from defeat to defeat. It is not merely a question of winning the allegiance, or at least the tolerance, of uncommitted peoples.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Dr. George A. Whipple, a Nobel laureate, expressed surprise today that his name had been attached to a petition urging an internationl ban on tests of nuclear weapons.

THE Whitney Museum will open to the public today a highly controversial exhibition entitled "Nature in Abstraction." Prepared by John I. H. Baur, curator, the display brings together fortyeight paintings and ten pieces of sculpture by fifty-eight artists.

A building syndicate organized by George W. Warnecke Co. has assembled a site at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street for improvement with a nineteen-story and penthouse apartment building.
Hearings will begin early next month for employes who took part in the subway strike of Dec. 9-16, the Transit Authority said yesterday.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A Syrian Army spokesman reported today a gun battle between Turks and Syrians, a sixty - minute exchange on Syria's northeast corner.

A STRANGE and rather fascinating program of piano music was selected by Lya de Barberiis for her Town Hall debut last night. Apart from Brahms' "Variations and Fugue on a Theme by Handel" there was virtually nothing that is standard concert fare these days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -President Eisenhower told Congress today that the United Nations' record clearly demonstrated that its processes were capable of relaxing tensions and resolving disputes if nations are willing to respect the opinions of mankind."

City Title Insurance Company's operations have expanded sharply, reflecting "a recent increase in real estate activity as a result of an easing in mortgage borrowing conditions," Saul Fromkes, president, informed stockholders of this at yesterday's annual meeting.
WHEN an adolescent begins to defy parental authority and becomes highly critical of adults in general, he is actually beginning to define his own personality.

ROME, Jan. 14 (UP) -- Pope Pius XII told theology students today that the basic philosophy of St. Thomas Aquinas, thirteenth century theologian, remained valid despite the progress of worldly science.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -The Treasury asked Congress today for a $5,000,000,000 temporary increase in the national debt ceiling, to last until June 30, 1959. The ceiling is now $275,000,000,000.

A LITTLE more than two decades ago the Works Projects Administration moved its New York headquarters from downtown Manhattan to Eighth Avenue and Sixtyfirst Street. The move, logistically, involved tons of records, office equipment and the like. In charge of the project was Army Capt. Arthur Gilbert Trudeau, assigned as an assistant administrator in the W. P. A. Of his work then one of his bosses said yesterday:

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 14 -- A Chinese Communist officer who defected to the Chinese Nationalists last month said today that the Nationalist island's close tie with the United States was a deterrent to any Communist plans for invading Taiwan.

VIENNA, Jan. 14 -- The International Atomic Energy Agency, which was established to promote the peaceful use of fissionable products, also will ultimately extend its scope to cover the still more promising field of atomic fusion.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 14 -- Stockholders of the First National Bank and Trust Company of New Canaan today approved a merger plan with the Fairfield County Trust Company. The vote was 26,654 to 1,042 shares in favor of the merger.

RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 14 -- Morocco has dodged a Soviet diplomatic drive for recognition. In a note delivered to the Soviet Embassy in Paris and made public here tonight, Morocco affirmed her position as a "link" between the two world blocs.
The Maritime Association of the Port of New York will file a protest with the Interstate Commerce Commission against a railroad proposal to increase freight rates and charges for other services.
Howard C. Sheperd, chairman of the First National City Bank of New York, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that he saw no immediate reason rates to cut the bank's lending rates.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 14 -- Student demonstrations against the regime erupted in Caracas again today. They lacked the character of a generalized movement, however.

The four-story apartment building at 1571 Forty-second Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by S. Axelrod. The building con- tains forty-four apartments and six stores and occupies a plot 120 by 100 feet. The buyer, an investing client of Korsch Sternklar, paid cash over mort- gages of $150,000.
American Airlines, Inc., showed a sharp drop in its net income last year despite record evenues, passengers carried and freight ton-miles.

McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Jan. 15 (UP) -- A Navy bacteriologist announced today that he had discovered living bacteria between 800 and 3,000 years old ninety-five feet beneath the ice at the South Pole.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Armour Co. today reported net income in the fiscal year ended Nov. 2 of $3,370,270. This was equal to 72 cents a common share.

THE profit that teenagers derive from after-school jobs and summer employment is much more than pecuniary, according to Eli Cohen, newly appointed executive secretary of the National Child Labor Committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -The Navy ordered to Washington today two ship-design specialists to help speed its Polaris missile and atomic submarine project.
David Sarnoff, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, was elected last night chairman of the board of trustees of the American Heritage Foundation.
SCOTT BASE, Antarctica, Jan. 15 -- Dr. Vivian Fuchs and his British trans-Arctic party were reported today to be about 105 miles from the South Pole.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 5 -- Indonesia's request for arms and political support from Yugoslavia will be underscored by the arrival here Friday of President Sukarno.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 15 (AP) -Twenty-two or more persons were killed and several score were injured today by an earthquake that rocked the city of Arequipa, high in the Andes, for ninety seconds. Situated 7,800 feet above sea level, Arequipa has a population of 132,000.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 15 -- Guerrilla activities in eastern Algeria have increased during the last ten days and indicate that the rebels may be starting their long-threatened winter offensive.

GAUHATI, India, Jan. 15 -India's political leaders took a look at the problems of the world today and then turned back for a look at the things that interest their constituents a great deal more -- the problems at home.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference:

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Governor Harriman, in a special message to the Legislature, reported today that he would include in his budget this year a total of $530,000 for various aspects of the state-wide "year of history" observance in 1959.
DUBLIN, Jan. 15 -- The second floor of a hotel in Ennis, the county town of Clare, collapsed during an auction today and eight persons lost their lives. Twenty-five others were injured.

The New Haven Railroad yesterday gave its riders an apology and explanation for Tuesday's tie-up and expressed the hope that it would not happen again. One of its new $280,000 electric-Diesel engines caught fire in the Park Avenue Tunnel and disrupted New Haven and New York Central traffic for hours.

Stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company approved at a special meeting yesterday the largest private financing in corporate history. Of the 53, 413,161 votes cast, 99.24 per cent approved the issuance of $718,313,000 of convertible debentures. There were 64,648,178 shares eligible to vote and approval of 43,098,786 shares was required.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
Short-term money rates continued to work their way downward yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was told today that railroads serving the Port of New York were losing $30,000,000 annually on export-import traffic under present rates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Jan. 8:
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Governor Harriman rejected tonight the idea that increases in state aid for education might result in the allocation of less local funds for schools.
TOKYO, Jan. 15 -- Japan may be forced to compromise and join a Western company in drilling for oil in the Persian Gulf.

THINGS having changed a little since the fifteenth century, Walter Sorell has brought an old morality play up to date. He calls his version "Everyman Today," and it was played yesterday afternoon in the James Memorial Chapel, Claremont Avenue at 121st Street.
Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin called yesterday for the creation of an airborne "shock force" of about eight pentomic divisions to cope with the danger of limited aggression.
The two major segments of the American shipping industry offered cautiously worded but differing views yesterday of President Eisenhower's statement on maritime affairs in Monday's budget message.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The gulf between the railroads of the populous East and their more fortunate brethren of the agricultural South and the West opened wide at a Senate hearing today.

WHEN Paul Pilgrim administered the considerable sports program at the New York Athletic Club, few were even aware of his existence. He functioned without ostentation, because he was modest almost to the point of shyness. He shunned both spotlight and acclaim in life and it almost seemed that fate ordained that his death also should be virtually unnoticed. That's the way Paul would have preferred it.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- Army's highly-regarded hockey team continued its march toward another successful season by defeating Holy Cross, 9 to 1, at Smith Rink today.

Directors of the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., yesterday cut the extra quarterly dividend in half, after having paid 50 cents extra each quarter for almost three years. During the same period, the company paid a regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share, in addition to the extra.

One of the nation's leading authorities on mass transportation said yesterday that expenditures during the next twenty years to meet metropolitan transportation needs would be exceeded only by the cost of national defense.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- A special committee recommended today that a list of witnesses who had testified anonymously regarding Soviet repression of the 1956 revolt in Hungary should now be burned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- In a moment of rare drama at the Supreme Court today, the Government confessed that the Army had no legal right to give men less than honorable discharges as security risks on the basis of activities before induction.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- The creation of a state counterpart of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to wage war on organized crime was suggested today by the chairman of the legislative watchdog committee.
COMPOSER Samuel Barber likes to tell the story of the Chinese corporal who wrote to him after his Second Symphony, commissioned by and dedicated to the Army Air Forces, had its premiere in 1944.

AFTER eleven long years the Metropolitan Opera, America's principal lyric theatre, has produced a new American opera again. As if this were not enough to make a citizen giddy with pride, the new work, "Vanessa," which had its premiere last night, turns out to be the best American opera ever presented at the stately theatre on Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street.
LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Britain today qualified a third team for the World Soccer Cup matches in Sweden next June and took a big step toward putting a fourth in the sixteennation finals.
ATHENS, Jan. 15 -- Turkey has rejected a request by Archbishop Makarios of Cyprus that he be permitted to visit that country.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 15 -- Indonesia plans to earmark special funds to finance a program in "cooperation" with the Soviet Union in the atomic field, it was reported here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Following are the highlights of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

A syndicate of investors has purchased the store building at the southwest corner of Boston Post Road and Purdy Avenue, Rye, N. Y. The building occupies a plot 325 by 208 feet. It was sold by David S. Meister, New York realty investor and builder, who erected it last year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The House of Representatives unanimously approved today an emergency military construction program that includes a newly developed ballistic-missile warning system.
Canadian Breweries, Ltd., yesterday reported record sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1957.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 15 (UP) -- The national security (secret) police fired into an anti-Government demonstration today, wounding two teen-age boys.

Frederick Brisson is planning a Broadway musical production of "The Loving Couple," the best-selling novel written by Patrick Dennis under the pseudonym of Virginia Rowans. It is earmarked for presentation during the 1958-59 season.
Stocks made moderate gains in relatively light trading yesterday, influenced by inflationary inferences the market drew from the President's press conference.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 15 -- Provisional President Guillermo Flores Avendano warned today that the Government would not tolerate post-election demonstrations or concentrations of out-of-city visitors.

SCOTT BASE, Antarctica, Jan., 13 -- We arrived on the Polar plateau on Oct. 31, having covered a total distance of 390 miles. But because of our westerly trend, we were still only ten miles nearer to the Pole than Scott Base.
The 1958 spring apartment house canvass for funds by United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, Inc., is scheduled for March 18, with a goal of $260,000.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- A conference between Governor Harriman and leaders of the Republican majorities in the Legislature produced today the possibility of compromises on several major issues.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A salary rise of 7 1/2 per cent for 1,500,000 Government workers was approved unanimously today by the Senate Committee on Post Office and Civil Service.

Jack Smith will succeed Art Baker as master of ceremonies on "You Asked for It" effective Jan. 26. On that date the American Broadcasting Company television program will move to the new time of 9:30 to 10 on Sunday evenings, immediately after the new Sid Caesar show.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Federal Reserve Board reduced margin requirements for stock transactions from 70 to 50 per cent today. The change means that a buyer now must put up only 50 per cent of the price of the stock, instead of the former 70 per cent.
A Swedish engineer has warned scientists to consider carefully the possibility that disastrous tides might he created on earth by the explosion of a hydrogen bomb on the moon.
RUTHERFORD, N. J., Jan. 15 -- Sir Leslie Munro, President of the United Nations General Assembly, said today that the Assembly was the only place in which to solve the problems of the space age.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -President Eisenhower was both optimistic and fatalistic about his health today.

WHEN a symphonic concert is deeply thrilling it is one of the most thrilling experiences possible in human life. The concert Pierre Monteux led with the Boston Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall was of that order.

DENVER, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The United States Communist party helped to formulate policies of the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers during the Nineteen Forties, a former Communist testified yesterday.
WASHINGTON, JAN. 15 (UP) -- The naval ordinance laboratory announced today it had developed a "fantastic" electronic device that should speed development of better anti-aircraft missiles.
Michael J. Quill came up yesterday with his own formula for luring "millions" of riders into the subways and preserving the 15-cent fare.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -President Eisenhower disclaimed today any intention of imposing his reorganization plans on the military establishment.
Vice Admiral John H. Sides asserted yesterday that the nation's development of longrange missiles was "progressing very well."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Eisenhower's Gettysburg farms received $1,120 in Federal conservation payments last year under a program his Administration had sought to abolish.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Ambassador Norman Robertson of Canada, delivered a formal note of protest today against a new United States restriction on oil imports.
Long Island Rail Road commuters may soon be confronted with another fare increase, it was indicated yesterday.
The implications of many recent reports in the press appear to be misleading and to need clarification.

Although a certain time has passed, memory continues to look back upon last Christmas morning. As usual, many things were scattered with thoughtful carelessness beneath the tree. First was a sled. It is true no one of the household really is of an age requiring a sled -- still, the thought is part of the Christmas picture, and so there was a sled.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 15 -- The Foreign Ministry instructed Costa Rica's United Nations delegation today to invite representatives of Canada, Uruguay, Switzerland, the United States, Chile and Belgium to observe the elections here Feb. 2.
NEWARK, Jan. 15 -- Bernard M. Shanley, President Eisenhower's former appointments secretary, became a "full-time" Republican candidate today for United States Senator from New Jersey.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 15 -State highway officials met with Mayor Irving C. Freese today in an effort to end congestion caused on two of the city's main arteries by the opening of the Connecticut Turnpike.
The City Planning Commission established Thirtieth Street yesterday as the official route of the proposed $88,000,000 MidManhattan Crosstown Expressway.

The endorsement of the Tweed commission proposals by the State Judicial Conference has given thoroughgoing court reform welcome, and much needed, impetus. The make-up of the conference and the thoroughness of its study of the commission's plan lend special force to its support.

For the last four months Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays have meant conservative tie, tweed jacket, organic chemistry and Shakespearean English to Gerald Medoff. Tuesdays and Thursdays have meant a worn railroad cap, scuffed-up shoes, and l00-pound sacks of flour.

The nation's major chain and mail order companies wound up 1957 with sales 5.1 per cent higher than in 1956, according to a survey completed yesterday by Teh New York Times. The rise from 1955 to 1956 was 8.6 per cent.

THE days have arrived when there are more spirals in the price of food than are found in Medusa's headdress. Consequently, one of the questions most frequently directed to this department is whether there is more nutritional value in the expensive cuts of beef than there is in cheaper ones.
MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- In a cautious but cool tone, the Soviet Union offered tonight its first comment on President Eisenhower's reply to Moscow's request for another East-West meeting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The recent statement by Lewis L. Strauss that the Government has no plans to review the adverse security finding against Dr. J. Robert Oppenseimer was echoed today by President Eisenhower.
FOR the last week Manhattan's decorating and architectural circles have been busy feting a home wrecker from Italy named Gio Ponti.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 15 -- The Protestant unity movement has made greater strides in India than in any other nation, it was reported here today.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Premier O. K. Yui replied today to charges of dereliction of duty that brought about his impeachment by the Control Yuan, Nationalist China's top watchdog body.
The New York State Legislature is once again in session.
Patrons for the forty-eighth annual BlUe Ridge Ball hve been announced. The event will take place at the St. Regis P. oof on Jan. 31.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Coliseum Commission late today again postponed action on the Los Angeles Dodgers after Walter O'Malley, president of the baseball club, had offered a flat sum of $200,000 a year to play in the big stadium.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -Dave Beck has pledged the Teamsters Union to cooperate with other unions despite its expulsion from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Cincinnatians seemed reasonably assured tonight that their Redlegs of the National League would continue to play baseball here for the next five years.
The Meiklejohn twins are almost even again today.
FOR one short superb scene, "Code of the Corner" achieved the feeling of real theatre on Channel 4's "Kraft Television Theatre" last night.

An injured baby boy wrapped in a wet and muddy blanket was found abandoned yesterday morning in the dark vestibule of a Greenwich Village apartment house at 146 West Eleventh Street. His left arm was broken and his face was cut and swollen.

THERE is scant likelihood that we shall establish beachheads on another planet in time to find there a dependable home for the Dodgers. If the planet is already inhabited, of course, the explosive question of colonialism is bound to stir new uproars, perhaps breed fresh varieties of war, in interstellar space.

The National Basketball Association president, Maurice Podoloff, yesterday denied the request of the New York Knickerbockers' coach, Vince Boryla, for a public hearing on Boryla's run-in with a referee, Lou Eisenstein, last Sunday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.
Bob Satterfield, a heavyweight, and Chuck Spieser, a light heavyweight, retired from boxing yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -The Post Office Department, having failed to make any headway with dogs, decided today to turn on their owners.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 15 -- The automobile industry was told today that the public was not too pleased with some features of new cars or some of the methods used to sell them.

President Perez Jimenez of Venezuela still clings precariously to his dictatorial position. To give him credit, he has shown resourcefulness, courage and brains in staying on the summit of power. However, he has had to pay a price for this victory which undoubtedly leaves him weaker than before.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, Jan. 15 -- All major resort hotels of this British colony closed their doors today as a general strike continued. There was no prospect of an early settlement.

The State of Missouri raised $55,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance the construction of state buildings. The money was obtained from the sale of bonds maturing serially from 1959 to 1979.

New Yorkers were told yesterday that the day would come when they would cease being the top dogs of the metropolitan area. Dennis O'Harrow of Chicago, executive director of the American Society of Planning Officials, said that "as powerful and dominant as New York is now, by 1978 the city and its five boroughs will be moving into a subordinate position in the great New York metropolitan area."

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Two experienced legislators proposed today that newly elected lawmakers undergo an orientation course in state government before being asked to vote on a multimillion dollar budget.

A state committee recommended yesterday another one-year extension of the state's seven-year-old Security Risk Law. It said administrative interpretations had already restricted the law's scope to only "sensitive positions," as the group recommended a year ago.
A leading exponent of "wholesale" banking predicted yesterday that his position would be justified soon.
The Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company, maker of bowling, school and gymnasium equipment, has moved to acquire MacGregor Sports Products, Inc., producer of athletic and sporting goods.
A Ruby anniversary dinner dance, marking the fortieth birthday of the Maternity Center Association, took place last evening in the Plaza in a setting of ruby and pink.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, got a resounding vote of confidence today from President Eisenhower.
UTICA, N. Y., Jan. 15 (AP) -- The State Health Commissioner said today that New York State's tuberculosis hospitals were more than one-third empty.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Bill Quillian, a Seattle tennis player now stationed at Fort Rucker, Ala., swept into the round of sixteen today in the Coral Gables-University of Miami tennis tournament in straight love sets.
The Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation announced yesterday its entry into the plastics field through the acquisition of the Plastray Corporation. The price was not disclosed.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 -- The Massachusetts Hospital Association recommended to member hospitals today that they discontinue charging patients an initial fee of $15. The step was taken in an effort to resolve an issue raised by Francis X. Lang, State Commissioner of Administration and Finance, over the propriety of the charge made when admitting patients.

The European response to the latest Soviet proposals is every bit as firm as President Eisenhower's response, and in some respects even firmer. This is evident in France's reply to the Bulganin notes. It is evident in Chancellor Adenauer's broadcast, foreshadowing the German reply.
John T. Potter said yesterday that he had requested forty manufacturers of electronic computers to halt the alleged infringement of a patent held by him.

Formation of a jointly owned company to develop and produce boron compounds for rocket and missile propulsion fuels was announced yesterday by the Aerojet-General Corporation and the Stauffer Chemical Company, New York.

A floor in the tower of the office building being erected by Joseph Durst at 200 East Fortysecond Street has been leased by F. C. Huyck Sons, manufacturers of textile products and precision instruments. James P. Cookson, of Collins, Tuttle Co., negotiated the lease.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines forecast today that market demand for domestic crude oil in February would be 7,230,000 barrels a day. This compares with demand of 7,075,000 barrels a day forecast for January.
Even more important than its substantive contents are the implications for American foreign policy contained in Prime Minister Macmillan's proposal for a pact with the Soviets.
Interests affiliated with the Bankers Securities Corporation have acquired a large interest in United Stores Corporation from Rober W. Babson and his affiliated companies and clients.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Spokesmen for baseball's minor leagues took their case against major league television to the Justice Department today, but got no promise of Government help.
MADRID, Jan. 15 -- Spain announced today that a major attack by the so-called Saharan Army of Liberation in northwestern Africa had been repulsed after fierce fighting all day Monday.
Lorne (Gump) Worsley, the seasoned goalie who had been sent to the minors earlier this season, was recalled by the New York Rangers yesterday to replace Marcel Paille.
Fidel Castro has disclaimed any aspiration to the Presidency of Cuba either in a replacement of the present regime by a provisional government or in the next elected administration.

An editor of a Spanish-language newspaper here said last night that Morris Ernst had told him he had proof that Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo had not been responsible for the disappearance of Dr. Jesus de Galindez.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- It was more than eight years ago, at St. Louis before the American Bar Association, that President Dwight D. Eisenhower of Columbia University expounded a political philosophy which President Eisenhower of the United States told his news conference today "I have lived by" ever since, "still believe in * * * and try to practice * * *."
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- A new technical assistance plan for Africa south of the Sahara has been agreed upon by eight nations with major interests in the area.
A familiar figure will be missing at the Board of Education today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- A seven-member hearing panel of the Civic Aeronautics Board opened an inquiry today on the flight of a Pan American Airways Clipper that was lost in the Pacific on Nov. 8.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A variety of influences carried nearly all grain futures prices higher on the Board of Trade today.
THERE are 402 items in this year's Audubon Annual at the National Academy, Fifth Avenue at Eighty-ninth Street, and among them more fresh and accomplished works than ever before.

In 1935, when Wolfgang Leonhard was 13 years old, he was taken to the Soviet Union by his mother, a German Communist who vanished in the purge of 1936. Leonhard was reared as a "child of the state" in a Soviet children's home and deeply indoctrinated with Communist ideology.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 15 -- A new United Service Organization's center to serve the 15,000 service men on Long Island is being completed as a cooperative venture.
HOUSTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The chairman of the board of directors of Texas A. M. college today dissolved the board's athletic subcommittee.
PARIS, Jan. 15 -- The British proposal for agricultural goods contains these main points:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked the Supreme Court today to set aside an Alabama injunction putting it out of business in the state and an Alabama contempt fine of $100,000.

OTTAWA, Jan. 15 -- Two men who have been friends and colleagues for years spoke as rivals tonight at the convention of the Liberal party of Canada, convened to choose a successor to former Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that two new lightweight torpedoes -- designed to seek out their targets by following sounds -- had been delivered to the fleet.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the United States "cannot afford the moral, economic and international cost" of racial prejudice in its labor force.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 15 -The Kenya Government has proscribed a secret society among the Kikuyu tribes with aims similar to those of the Mau Mau terrorist movement.
Seat tippers, purse snatchers and pickpockets gain because the American public is careless, a criminologist reported yesterday.
The Mayor's Commission on Intergroup Relations has begun an investigation into charges of racial and religious discrimination in the City Housing Authority.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 15 -- The Bergen County Board of Freeholders introduced its 1958 budget today. Appropriations total $14,109,712, an increase of $1,256,789 over last year. The amount to be raised by taxation is $10,822,352, an increase of $1,208,369.
Wallace Girling of Union College yesterday was elected president of the Touchdown Club of New York.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Bob Gutowski's pole vault of 15 feet 9 3/4 inches, not included in yesterday's International Amateur Athletic Federation list of accepted world records, may have been referred to the full rules and records committee meeting in Stockholm next August, it was indicated today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -- A lawsuit that may have important ramifications for the entertainment industry was filed today in Los Angeles Federal Court. It touched on the point of whether publicity has value as personal property.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Nonresidents working in New York would get equal treatment with residents in calculating their state income taxes under the terms of a bill introduced in the Legislature today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -President Eisenhower appealed today for as much publicity "in Soviet areas" for his reply to Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin as the Soviet leader's December letter received in the free world.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Administration, in drafting its new budget, substantially reduced the funds proposed by the National Science Foundation for basic research and research facilities.
PARIS, Jan. 15 -- After weeks of discussion the Cabinet decided today to send to Parliament a much disputed bill to reform the French Constitution.
Commodity futures closed generally lower on the New York exchanges yesterday. Sugar, cottonseed oil, zinc, copper, lead, rubber, hides and potatoes declined. Cocoa, coffee and wool rose.
The Greater New York Association, which conducts thoroughbred racing in this state, yesterday made public its 1958 stakes list comprising eightynine top races worth $2,800,000.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 15 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said tonight that the recent Bulganin letters were not a serious attempt to bring about an understanding but rather "a large-scale maneuver of distraction."

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 15 -- An authorized spokesman for the insurgent Algerian National Liberation Front declared tonight that it was "ready to receive representatives of the International Red Cross" to discuss the French prisoners.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Jon Konrads, a 15-year-old Latvian swimmer, bettered his fourth world record in four days in the New South Wales championships tonight.

A LETTER arrived from a man who took his 14year-old son hunting for the first time and seems to think there is something pretty good about it. This is not an unusual reaction, but this man, who prefers to be anonymous, is more articulate than most

PARIS, Jan. 15 (Reuters) -A British plan for promoting trade in European agricultural products was criticized as too vague today at a seventeennation meeting considering the proposed European free trade zone.
Yonkers Raceway revealed yesterday that it would sport a sparkling new appearance for its opening on Aug. 1.
A homemade burglar alarm trapped a theft suspect early yesterday in the parish hall of a church on the lower East Side.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -The House Committee on Un-American Activities voted today to recommend to the House contempt citations against two New York state men.
New mortgage bonds and preferred stock of the Pacific Power and Light Company with a market value of about $25,000,000 will be offered for public subscription today by investment banking syndicates.
GAUHATI, India, Jan. 15 -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party backed off a bit today from the official position that English must disappear as an official language by 1965.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers ousted their rookie coach, George Mikan, in the midst of a miserable season today. Mikan was succeeded by John Kundla.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 15 -A Jewish leader of wartime Hungary who had been branded a "Nazi collaborator" by an Israeli court, pilloried for twenty months and then murdered was cleared today of the stigma of "collaboration."
DETROIT, Jan. 15 -- Delegates to the special convention of the United Automobile Workers next week will consider the advisability of a special dues assessment to build a huge strike fund.

WEST NEW YORK, N. J., Jan. 15 -- Police Commissioner Ernest J. Modarelli tonight ended a self-imposed exile of several weeks by appearing at a meeting of the City Commission. The New Jersey Law Enforcement Council had tried unsuccessfully to locate the commissioner and subpoena him.

A drop of 8,672,000 barrels in the nation's light fuel oil stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 141,349,000 barrels, compared with 150,021,000 a week earlier and 122,983,000 a year earlier.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Premier Felix Gaillard decided today to send a personal message of protest and warning to President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia in the wake of last Saturday's military incident on the Tunisian-Algerian frontier.
The copper, industry's problems of lagging demand and surplus production were pointed up yesterday in the monthly report of the Copper Institute.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- The nation's colleges today urged Congress to grant tax cuts up to $450 a year for parents putting their children through college.

The five-story office building at 45 West Forty-seventh Street has been resold by a syndicate represented by Robert Netter of Netter Netter, attorneys. The structure formerly was owned and occupied for thirty-two years by the Actors Equity Association, which sold it to the syndicate about a year ago.

News stories on the Federal Budget for 1958-59 have emphasized the fact that the total bill for the nation's protection -- namely, $47.1 billion -- represents 64 per cent of all contemplated expenditures. But this does not include all categories of spending that had their origins in war -- past, present and potential future.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board yesterday completed representation elections for the crews of the eight vessels that form the Robin Line division of the Moore-McCormack Lines.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 15 -Hudson County's new acting prosecutor promised today that all indictments stemming from Samuel A. Larner's investigation of Jersey City's municipal affairs would be prosecuted, even though he himself might be involved in some of the cases.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Vince Martinez gained the National Boxing Association's sanction to fight Isaac Logart for the vacated welterweight title tonight when he out-punched Gil Turner in the final rounds to win a majority decision in their twelve-round elimination bout.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -- Julie London, singer-actress, has drawn the lead opposite Gary Cooper in "Man of the West." The Mirisch Company plans to put the film before the cameras on Feb. 3 for United Artists release.
Max Chester, a former union official and an intimate of Johnny Dio, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions Court to five to ten years in prison for attempted extortion.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
