WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A budget deficit would be preferable to a tax increase in current economic conditions, President Eisenhower said today.
Film production in France set a record last year, according to the French Film Office here. A total of 140 productions went before the cameras compared with 129 for the previous year.
Your editorial of Jan. 7 "Traffic Safety Lag" was interesting in that you showed surprise about something that is no mystery and should have been foreseen.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 15 -- The Opposition National party unexpectedly backed a taxpayers' revolt today.
The former 162-acre estate of the late Henry L. Stimson in the Mannetto Hills of Suffolk County has been acquired by the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- A bi-partisan plan to make it easier for war veterans to obtain mortgage loans from state banks was submitted to the Legislature today.

The Senate subcommittee hearing in Washington on problems of the railroads, held under the chairmanship of Senator Smathers of Florida, has produced some gloomy testimony from road presidents. The condition is "precarious"; "bankruptcy" is around the corner; the roads are being "nibbled to death" by overregulation.

Even by Soviet standards the Main Political Administration of the Soviet armed forces is a peculiar institution. Its job of assuring the loyalty of the Soviet armed forces is considered so important and so sensitive that it is officially and simultaneously part both of the Ministry of Defense and of the apparatus of the Communist party's Central Committee.

Conductors and brakemen on the New York Central Railroad called a strike for 6 o'clock this morning. The entire system between Buffalo and New York, including commuter service, was affected by the strike call.
The president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, George Alpert, has accepted an appointment as chairman of the national campaign of Junior Achievement, Inc.

Ski sketch: Robert (Bobo) Sheehan, the coach of Middlebury College's ski team, believes the American youngster has made great strides in the snowrunning sport. He predicts that some of them will cut a big figure internationally in a few years.

Dr. Bela Schick, chief pediatrics consultant to the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital at Denver, received the city's certificate for distinguished service from Mayor Wagner last night.

Lyndon Johnson, majority leader of the Senate, is a shrewd and expansive Texan. He is big, he thinks big and he talked big in his own personal "State of the Union" message that preceded by two days that of the President.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Selective buying of leading industrials brought widespread, although generally small, price advances on the stock market today. Gold mining shares were the exception.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -The Senate Democratic Policy Committee voted today to give legislative priority to a study of Presidential election, disability and succession.

The New York Yankees yesterday wrapped up a television package worth considerably more than a million dollars. The Bombers will telecast all of their seventy-seven home games and at least sixty-three road games this year on WPIX, Channel 11.

The rains that began Tuesday ended yesterday, leaving swollen streams, flooded cellars and a bounty of water in the city's watersheds. The Weather Bureau reported that a total of 1.74 inches of rain fell on the metropolitan area in the twenty-two-hour period ended at 7:15 o'clock yesterday morning.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- A British note reported to contain some veiled and cautious interest in a Soviet-Polish proposal for a zone in Central Europe from which nuclear weapons would be barred was cleared with the Atlantic alliance today.
Volkswagen of America, Inc., is about to hire an advertising agency. The move is likely to be greeted in the advertising business with a silent cheer.

The Great Teacher Awards of Columbia University's Society of Older Graduates were presented last night to Menelaos D. Hassialis, Professor of Mineral Engineering, and Charles W. Everett, Professor of English.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 15 -- A private cemetery nearly two centuries old is preventing a property owner here from building a twentieth century home.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 15 -- Navy's sophomore-dominated basketball team set a fast pace in the second half in rolling up its most impressive victory of the season today -- a surprisingly easy 90-60 decision over Manhattan.
There will be no special salary increases for the city's public school teachers this year, it was learned last night.

Mrs. Henriette Van Gelder, an investing client of Peter H. Miller of the Sherman Management Company, has purchased the garden apartment property at 2315-35 Barnes Avenue, corner of Wallace Avenue, in the Pelham Parkway area of the Bronx.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 16 (AP) -- The February oil allowable was increased today by the Texas Railroad Commission as the state's largest crude buyer threatened purchaser proration.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 16 -- The three principal Presidential candidates have promised to go along with the Provisional Government in discouraging violent post-election demonstrations.

The former manager of a branch of a stock brokerage company who, according to the District Attorney, increased his earnings from $30 a week to $30,000 a year and still was not satisfied, was charged yesterday with the theft of $192,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -President Eisenhower told Congress today that it must revise farm law sharply this year to cope with the farmer's unparalleled productive ability.

The Board of Education was sharply criticized yesterday for deleting a request for $30,000,000 for school salary increases from its proposed 1958-59 budget, and for modifying other items. Teacher groups and civic organizations accused the board, in effect, of taking orders from City Hall.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The United States plans to send a military mission to Spain to study an air defense problem raised by Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

A new electronic computer and auxiliary equipment that controls manufacturing processes in the oil refining and several other industries was introduced yesterday by ThompsonRamo-Wooldridge Products, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- President Eisenhower said today that he hoped Congress would pass legislation this year to regulate billboards along the nation's interstate highways.

Nobody knows how many families there are in this country that love to keep dogs which will bite any stranger, however noble his intentions, who ventures on their premises. It is hard to see why the possession of such a dog should make anybody any prouder or happier. Watchdogs are necessary under some circumstances, but a dog that cannot distinguish between a postman and a burglar is not a good watchdog.
There may be a lot of coffee in Brazil, but here at home coffee men are counting the number of beans that should be used to make the best cup of coffee.

The New York Central Railroad was authorized yesterday by the Public Service Commission in Albany to increase its coach fares in New York State by 5 per cent. The rise is expected to yield the railroad $600,000 a year in additional revenue.
BOSTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Larry Popein scored with less than three minutes remaining to give the third-place New York Rangers a 3-2 National Hockey League victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- There has been very little response around here as yet to the summons to "greatness" which so many have been issuing. So far general behavior in public affairs has been something less.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (UP) -Thomas E. Sunderland, vice president and general counsel of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, today attacked a proposed Congressional amendment to the Robinson-Patman Act as a price-raid dagger pointed at the throats of business men.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Ray Broussard gained his second victory of the program when he Booted High Authority to a one-and-one-half-length decision over Queensware today in the feature at the Fair Grounds.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The United States Court of Appeals here divided, 5 to 4, today in upholding the conviction of a former instructor at Vassar College for contempt of Congress.
NEWARK, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Elias Gilbert was called the "world's No. 1 hurdler" tonight as he received the Newark Athletic Club's annual collegiate award.
DETROIT, Jan. 16 -- A union local here and the United States Rubber Company have worked out a program of shorter hours that has averted the lay-off of 100 workers.
The Pennsylvania State Highway and Bridge Authority borrowed $20,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance construction of highways and bridges.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -When a visitor to the National Press Club can empty the bar at 12:30 P. M., and induce more than 500 reporters to pay $1.75 for a press club luncheon, it is a safe assumption (a) that he is controversial, or (b) a celebrity, or (c) both.

Irving Maidman, realty investor and builder, announced plans yesterday for a business building and pigeonhole garage for 320 cars at the southwest corner of Eighth Avenue and Forty-second Street. He said the project would represent an investment of almost $3,000,000.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 16 -The crisis in French-Tunisian relations became more acute today. President Habib Bourguiba declined to receive Brig. Gen. Georges Buchalet, one of two special envoys who arrived from Paris with a message from Premier Felix Gaillard.

The senior judge of the Court of General Sessions was called upon yesterday to decide whether the legislative watchdog committee has the right to confer immunity against criminal prosecution on witnesses who appear before it.
Stanley Ross, editor of the El Diario de Nueva York, repeated statements to the police yesterday that he made on television Wednesday night about the missing Dr. Jesus de Galindez.

S. C. Johnson Son, Inc., of Racine, Wis., maker of wax polishes and household products, announced yesterday the election of Howard M. Packard as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Packard, formerly executive vice president, succeeds Herbert F. Johnson, who has held the presidency since 1928 and who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer.

The Royal Dutch Petroleum Company announced yesterday that the price of the shares being offered stockholders would be 114 guilders, or $30 a share. The Shell Transport and Trading Company, Ltd., said its shares would be offered stockholders at 5 10s, or about $15.40 a share.

The decision of the Dodgers to transfer from Brooklyn to Los Angeles created a furor not only in the hearts of borough residents, but also in the design of a table accessory that went on sale this week.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Two areas of possible compromise in the legislative deadlock over unemployment insurance were reported under investigation today. One involves an increase in the maximum yearly pay on which employers are required to pay unemployment insurance taxes. This is now $3,000.
DETROIT, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports says 5,828,700 new automobiles were sold in 1957, compared with 5,850,900 in 1956.
Events today: Verdi's "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; New York Philharmonic, Jorge Bolet, pianist, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, 2:30; Michael Rabin, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

On Aug. 22, 1949, Hermann Field, an American architect and brother of Noel Field, who had disappeared behind the Iron Curtain, was abducted by the Polish Security Police and put into a cellar. It was to become his home for five years.

A Los Angeles physician, Dr. Lester C. Lowe, is the nominee to become national chief commander of the United States Power Squadrons at their annual conclave this week-end, timed always during the Motor Boat Show.

The city was populated yesterday by people who told themselves for the umpteenth time that they simply did not like snow. They talked to themselves as they squatted in it while trying to put chains on their cars or as they attempted to drive in the slippery, skiddy stuff.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 16 (AP) -- King Suramarit denied Eik Yioun the legal powers of Premier today -- and thus refused him authority to negotiate with Czechoslovakia's Communist Premier, Vilem Siroky.

WASHINGTON, Jan. l6 -- Six members of the Senate rackets committee introduced a bill today to permit the states to authorize wiretapping by their police. This would reverse a recent Supreme Court decision.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Justice William O. Douglas believes that some of his Supreme Court colleagues are raising dangerous bars against sex literature and otherwise restricting freedom of expression.
Industrial, utility and railroad debt securities valued at more than $61,000,000 are being offered to investors today. The offerings are:
A "massive attack" upon the "total problem" of traffic congestion in the midtown garment district was urged on the Board of Estimate yesterday by the Mayor's Interdepartmental Traffic Council.
The results of the first, comprehensive, nation-wide study of the motives and habits of the American moviegoer ever undertaken by the film industry were made public yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- The use of radar as a speed-detecting device received the endorsement of the state's highest court today.
PARIS, Jan. 16 -- A two-day negotiation by ministers of seventeen nations on a European free trade area ended here tonight in an atmosphere of uncertainty.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A mixture of influences pushed grain futures prices up and down on the Board of Trade today, leaving more losses than gains at the close.
New York Central Railroad conductors called a sudden strike on trains east of Buffalo yesterday, then postponed it ten minutes before the 6 A. M. deadline pending new negotiations.
Wide Federal support of engineering schools was called for last night by Columbia University's dean of engineering. Otherwise, he warned, new Federal scholarships alone may bankrupt the schools.

THE curiosity king of Second Avenue, has his site at 1145 1/2, near Sixty-third Street. Daily, television prop and stage prop hunters, decorators and collectors file into his shop in search of a totem pole, a pair of tin shoes, an illuminated sign from an old ice cream parlor or a mechanical bank, departing with brown parcels and a victorious look.

The letter you printed Jan. 13 from Dr. Edmund F. Kohl contains a major factual error which should be corrected in order to prevent the misconception from spreading and causing our 4,800,000 subscribers in this area to lose benefits they are entitled to receive.
As President Eisenhower has spoken to Congress, to this nation and to the listening world, his message is "bigger and better missiles."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Democrats proposed today that the United States vault into space with nuclear power. They suggested that the United States capitalize on its world supremacy in nuclear technology by undertaking a large-scale program to develop space vehicles propelled by atomic energy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that President Eisenhower's "goof" about his letter to Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin of Moscow was about the best thing that could have happened.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations officially acknowledged today the abolition of 100 organizers' jobs. The savings of the retrenchment program are about $1,000,000 a year.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 16 -- The executive members of the European Economic Community formally set to work today to administer an integrated economy for six nations.

A theatre party at Tuesday's performance of "The Dark at the Top of the Stairs" will be followed by a supper-dance in the ballroom of the Ambassador. The events will be a joint benefit for the American Institute of Decorators and the scholarship fund of the National Home Fashions League.

DEAN ECKERTSEN, young American conductor who made his debut here in 1951 leading an all-Corelli program, led the Chamber Orchestra of New York last night at Town Hall in a program of music from the same era. This one, though, ranged a little more widely.
A record high temperature of 5.5 degrees above zero, Fahrenheit, has been reported by the United States outpost at the South Pole.
HARTFORD, Jan. 16 -- A special session of the Connecticut General Assembly may be summoned by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff if the unemployment situation in the state worsens.

House of Holes There is nothing so porous as a house. A sieve has holes, as do swiss cheese and ancient piano rolls, but these are as nothing when compared to a house. The proof was fully exposed only the other day, when the mercury of the thermometer sought desperately to take up an irregular relationship with the figure zero.

The election of Edward Turner as president of the 9,000member Marine Cooks and Stewards Union, largest marine union on the West Coast, has been certified by a union election committee. The organization is an affiliate of The Seafarers International Union of North America.

Sales of electric motors and generators will rise by 30 per cent -- from $670,000,000 to $870,000,000 -- in the next three years, it was predicted yesterday by James M. Crawford, vice president and general manager of the General Electric Company's motor and generator division.
The Appellate Division refused yesterday to stop the city from taking possession of the site for the Lincoln Square redevelopment.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 16 -- A $2,500,000 plan to redevelop the center of South Orange was released today by the Village trustees.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A New Orleans physician reports that he has shattered a belief long held by law enforcement agencies and identification experts -- that fingerprints are permanent and unalterable.

President Eisenhower joined with the Poetry Society of America last night in honoring Robert Frost. The President hailed the craggy-faced poet of New England as one who could express "our innermost feelings and speak so clearly to us of our land and life."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission has accused National Dairy Products Corporation, the nation's largest distributor of dairy products of price discrimination.
MAXTON, N. C., Jan. 16 -- A threat of possible violence between the Ku Klux Klan and the Indian population of Robeson County hung over this farming area today.

President Eisenhower's appeal at his press conference on Wednesday that his reply to Premier Bulganin receive wide publicity in the Soviet world drew a swift reaction from Moscow. A few hours later the Soviet Union released a Tass dispatch which gave a distorted and hostile account of the President's reply.
Industrial Commissioner Isador Lubin said yesterday that unemployment insurance benefits had poured $3,200,000,000 into the state's economy in the last twenty years.
HAVANA, Jan. 16 -- A group of about 200 rebels attacked Veguita, on the south coast of Oriente Province, today, according to reports from that district.
WASHINGTON, Jan. I6 (UP) -House investigators denounced today the Defense Department's policy on discharging reservist. They called it "cruel and despotic'' and demanded an official explanation.

The American Institute of Men's and Boys' Wear has announced that Louis C. Pfeifle will be named president. This is the top management post of the institute, which is the national promotional arm of the industry.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 16 -West German opinion on the speech of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer last night was divided today.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 16 (UP) -- An explosion crumpled two sections of the eighteen-inchthick walls of a cold-storage plant today.
BELHAVEN, N. C., Jan. 16 -Things got turned around a little here yesterday and today, but they ought to straighten out tomorrow, if there is any justice or a law of averages.
New York City, corporately speaking, is learning how the other half -- the taxpaying public -- lives.
The New York Smith College Club will hold a theatre party at the Feb. 12 performance of "Oh Captain!" at the Alvin Theatre. Proceeds from the event will go to the club's scholarship fund.
MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- The No. 2 rink from the Country Club of Brookline, Mass., gained the final of the fourth Empire State women's bonspiel at the St. Andrew's Golf Club curling rink today.

THE interest at the Metropolitan Opera last night centered on Patrice Munsel, who sang her first Mimi at the house. Miss Munsel up to now has been associated mostly with coloratura or soubrette roles and this new role of hers in the Puccini "Boheme" gave the audience a chance to estimate a different facet of her art.

Carmen Basilio, the world middleweight champion, will defend his crown against Sugar Ray Robinson at the Chicago Stadium on Tuesday night, March 25. The agreement for the fight, scheduled for fifteen rounds, was disclosed yesterday by James Norris, the president of the International Boxing Club.
BERLIN, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Western Big Three officials demanded today that the Russians stop "harassing" allied military train traffic through East Germany between Berlin and the West.
Suat Hayri Urguplu, Turkish Ambassador to Washington, said yesterday that United States economic aid to Turkey had helped cause demand and prices to rise faster than production.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -The Secretary of the Treasury said today that he could "conceive of situations" in which he would recommend a tax cut as a cure for an economic slump.
OTTAWA, Jan. 16 -- Lester B. Pearson, the Nobel Peace Prize winner of last year, became the new leader of the Liberal party tonight. As such he placed himself in line to be Prime Minister of Canada.
Stone Webster, Inc., increased its consolidated net income last year by $3,154,000 to a record $10,125,000 from $6,971,000 in 1956, the previous peak year.
Television performers who go to Havana to appear on American programs originating there must be covered by a $300,000 life insurance policy to be purchased by their employers.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 16 -The courtroom battle to clear the late Dr. Rudolf Kastner of the stigma of collaboration with the Nazis will end tomorrow. Today the President of the Israeli Supreme Court concurred with the judgement given yesterday by Justice Shimon Agranat, one of a panel of five judges, that Dr. Kastner had not been a collaborator but had operated conscientiously to save Hungarian Jews from the gas chambers.
Consumers Union has charged Philip Morris, Inc., with a "breach of good ethics" in its advertisements for Parliament cigarettes.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Fred W. Hooper's Olymar sped to a two-and-onequarter length victory today in the $24,050 Hurricane Handicap, the closing feature at Tropical Park.
High excitement marked the first session of the New York Stock Exchange following the cut in the margin requirement from 70 to 50 per cent.
Membership in the Girl Scouts and facilities for them in New York have expanded steadily over the last five years, and now 64,789 girls are enrolled.
BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 16 -Dr. A. V. Astin, director of the National Bureau of Standards, urged today the standardization of the inch among friendly nations in an age of increasing weapon precision.
A special Brooklyn grand jury was directed yesterday to investigate the alleged granting of diplomas to unqualified public school graduates.

TORONTO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Government has started a doit-now winter employment campaign and is providing funds for public projects to cope with Canada's worst unemployment situation since the depression days of the Nineteen Thirties.

THE dearth of bargains at meat and vegetable counters is especially notable again this week-end. The situation will further test the mettle of thrifty shoppers when they discover that the scarcity and dearness of food is underscored by the very few special features in chain stores.
Wide-scale support for a bi-state transit district to develop a general plan for transit improvement between New York and New Jersey was urged last night by Charles H. Tuttle.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Arkansas National Guard troops on Federal duty were ordered to Central High School tonight as "a precautionary measure," a spokesman for the Arkansas Military district reported.

An extract of cancerous tissue that protects laboratory animals against transplanted cancer was described yesterday by Dr. Alex B. Novikoff of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Yeshiva University.
The following reports, provided by operators of the ski areas, were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses:

Manhattan College romped off with the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union Junior indoor track and field championship honors last night. The Jaspers finished with 63 1/2 points at the 102d Engineers Armory. St. John's was the runner-up with 25. New York University and Fordham tied at 19 each.

THOMAS EAKINS (18441916), the outstanding genre painter and portraitist of late nineteenth-century America, is the subject of a one-man exhibition, opening today, at the American Academy of Arts and Letters, Broadway and 155th Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The first White House social season to be devoted entirely to state dinners opened tonight with a more lavishly set table than ever before.
The Consolidated Electrodynamics Corporation, Pasadena, Calif., and Cenco Instruments Corporation, Chicago, are negotiating a merger of the diversified instrument companies.
The first five months of the International Geophysical Year have given man a clearer picture of the planet on which he lives.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The United States is willing to lend India $225,000,000 within the next few months.
Charles L. Patterson, chairman of the Transit Authority, told Rockaway residents yesterday that their only hope of a fare reduction would be an increased use of the IND division that serves them.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- A feature of a more cheerful stock market today was the wide interest shown in dollar stocks and leading industrials with an American content.
SOME impressive artistry saved "The Eighty-Yard Run," last night's drama on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2, from being a familiar and conventional story of a marital problem.

THE HAGUE, Netherlands, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The World Court today granted a time extension jointly requested by Switzerland and the United States in a Swiss suit seeking the $100,000,000 assets of the General Aniline and Film Corporation.
Winners of Sylvania television awards were announced last night at a dinner in the Plaza Hotel. The awards are presented annually under the auspices of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Jack Curtice, coach of the University of Utah football teams the past eight years, today was named head coach at Stanford.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 16 -Diplomats, economists and military leaders of the five nations adhering to the Baghdad Pact and of the United States will hold the first meeting of their conference tomorrow in Turkey's new partly completed Parliament building.

Loans to business outstanding at the larger New York banks declined $84,000,000 in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the comparable week of last year, business loans declined $26,000,000.

This country has just enjoyed a visit by a friend from the Far East who has been able to bring welcome reassurances regarding his country. He is Prince Souvanna Phouma, Premier of the kingdom of Laos, who has maintained the independence of his strategically situated nation against Communist Chinese pressure and has the additional distinction of having brought about the reunification of the first country which the Communists sought to partition.

Samuel Barber's "Vanessa," which received its world premiere Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera, will be made available on LP disks. Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan, announced yesterday that the opera would soon be recorded by RCA Victor through special arrangement with the Metropolitan Opera and the Book-of-the-Month Club, Inc.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 16 (UP) -- Five Negro students presented completed application blanks for admission to the University of South Carolina today, but the all-white institution refused to accept them.
Executives at a meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board yesterday discussed efforts to control labor costs despite a continued rise in hourly wage rates.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Twenty-nine legislators asked Congress today to prop up the sagging copper industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower designated J. Edgar Hoover, a Navy guided-missile expert and three other Federal employes today as the first recipients of the President's award for "exceptionally meritorious civilian service" to the Government.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower sent Congress today a report of the National Science Foundation cautioning that the United States could lose its lead in high energy physics

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Britain is ahead in the control of the thermonuclear reaction simply because of the size of the machine built for the purpose in the United States, according to an authoritative view.

IN his provocative and charming "From a Writer's Notebook," which was discussed in this space last week, Van Wyck Brooks referred to "the ever-increasing egotism of the writer's mind" and to "the subjectivity and isolation" that are the governing conditions of authorship. He did not mention any particular authors as examples, but he could have cited hordes, including most of the world's distinguished novelists.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 16 -- A Protestant mission official called today for farreaching changes in the traditional "Western" concept of Christian mission activity.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 16 -A New York State Supreme Court justice ruled today that a New Rochelle luxury apartment house must rent to a Negro.

Joseph P. McMurray, State Housing Commissioner, charged yesterday that urgently needed slum clearance, housing and urban renewal programs would be seriously hampered if President Eisenhower's budget recommendations were followed.

ALTHOUGH William Gibson has only two characters in "Two for the Seesaw" he has a tender style of writing and a beautiful little story to tell. And in the production that opened at the Booth last evening, he has two extraordinarily winning actors.

WARSAW, Jan. 16 -- The council of the faculty of mathematics and physics at the University of Warsaw today described Prof. Jerzy Leon Nowinski's action in seeking asylum in the United States as "unethical" and "groundless."
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 (AP) -- County Supervisor Kenneth Hahn today predicted that the Coliseum Commission would vote tomorrow to allow the Los Angeles Dodgers to use the big stadium for two years.
New York City took a fourinch snowstorm in stride yesterday.

In his budget message to Congress on Monday President Eisenhower pointed out that expenditures for agriculture and agricultural resources had accounted for more than 30 per cent of all Federal civilian benefits in the fiscal years 1956 and 1957 and would take almost as large a proportion in 1958.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz ruled today that the state could furnish funds for loans to college students.
A New York public relations man was advised by the Moscow radio that he had come close to winning a quiz contest held by the Soviet station.

LEONARD BERNSTEIN has brought imaginative program-making to his appearances with the New York Philharmonic this season, and with full authority as musical director next season he should be able to go further toward making the orchestra's concerts stimulating and coherent occasions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's farm message to Congress today:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 -- While theatre owners complained loudly last year about a shortage of movies, it could only have existed in terms of entertainment the public was interested in buying. The fact that there was no real quantitative lack of pictures became apparent today when the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences disclosed that a total of 411 features had been ruled eligible for its 1957 awards competition.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The State Commerce Commissioner tonight accused the Pen-Texas Corporation of showing a "ruthless disregard" for employes and the community in its plan to liquidate a plant at Farmingdale, L. I.
CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 16 -Two 105-foot fireboats built for the New York Fire Department were launched today at the John A. Mathis Company shipyard.

ONE cannot think of Robert Frost as a ruthless man. Yet he has said that he has one ruthless purpose, and that is poetry. It is better to accept that, and to rely on the evidence of his work. Otherwise the man, like relatively few of his poems, will be elusive.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 16 -- Harold J Gibbons, an international vice president-elect of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, maintained shaky control over St. Louis teamsters last night. He won by six votes in a contest for the presidency of Joint Council 13 of the union.

NEWARK, Jan. 16 -- Home owners and tenants in areas under the flight paths of airplanes using Newark Airport reported today that low-flying craft disrupted their daily routine and damaged their properties.
Katharine Cornell has selected Christopher Fry's verse drama, "The Firstborn," for her next Broadway appearance. She will be co-starred with Anthony Quayle in the Biblical play.
WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 16 -The Board of Education here has approved a rise of $400 for school teachers, bringing the minimum starting salary for new teachers with a bachelor's degree to $4,200.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The House Government Operations Committee suggested today that billions of dollars worth of United States military assistance had been wasted. It called for a "complete review" by Congress and the Executive branch.
TRENTON, Jan. 16 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey designated David C. Thompson of Glen Ridge today as this state's representative on the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -Secretary of State Dulles proposed today the formation of an international commission to insure the use of outer space exclusively for peaceful purposes.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 16 -- Students rioted on five occasions tonight to demonstrate against the Government of Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez. At the same time the police used tear gas to break up demonstrations by groups of women.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 16 (Reuters) -- The Central Banking Council decided today to lower the West German bank rate from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent, effective tomorrow.

MONTREAL, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Dickie Moore scored his twentysecond and twenty-third goals of the season tonight to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 5-2 National Hockey League victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.
The story by Sam Pope Brewer on Iran, published on Jan. 2, may well tend to be misleading in both its premises and its inferences.
An investigation of allegations of racial and religious discrimination within the New York City Housing Authority was voted yesterday by the city's Commission on Intergroup Relations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 -- Rod Serling, a leading exponent of live television, confirmed today he was preparing to coproduce and write a filmed television series in association with the Columbia Broadcasting System.

" The Dancing Heart," a film version of Norbert Schultze's Viennese musical, in color with English titles, will open today at the Seventy-second Street Playhouse. The Capitol-Film production was directed by Wolfgang Liebeneiner, from his own screenplay, which was based on a story by W. F. Fichelscher.

ST PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- A committee recommended today that a few top United States tennis players be allowed expenses while competing in the national championships at Forest Hills, Queens.

Shock at the Army's refusal to accept a Department of Justice legal view on discharges was expressed yesterday by Norman Thomas, honorary chairman, and Vera Rony, national secretary, of the Workers Defense League.
Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, yesterday warned against trying to match the Soviet Union, "stride for stride," in weapons, scientific achievements and diplomatic maneuvers.
Prince Souvanna Phouma, Premier of Laos, told a group of New York bankers and business men yesterday that his Government would welcome United States investments.

PRINCESS ALINE, wife of Prince Souvanna Phouma, who comes from a country where the temperature ranges between 70 and 102 degrees Fahrenheit all year, spent her almost negligible free time in New York yesterday looking for a fur coat.

Futures prices closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, copper, zinc, rubber and coffee rose; world sugar positions, lead, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides and wool declined, and price movements for potatoes were mixed.

Governor Meyner apparently caught some of his official family by surprise when, in his annual message, he urged that serious consideration be given to the adoption by New Jersey of compulsory liability insurance for automobiles. But, if he took the action on his personal initiative and conviction that the public wanted it, this was compatible with his sustained interest in highway and traffic problems.

It is evident from your editorial of Jan. 11 that there is a misunderstanding of the position of the League of Women Voters of New York on the most recent proposals of the Temporary Commission on the Courts.

Ivan C. McLeod, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, has recommended that the Federal agency certify the Steamship Office Workers Union as the official bargaining unit for the whitecollar personnel of the Italian Line here.
A possible mandatory safety code for the waterfront will be the main subject of the next executive conference of the New York State Board of Standards and Appeals.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 16 -- Arrangements have been concluded by the United States Government to deliver 2,700 tons of wheat, 378 tons of processed cheese and thirty tons of powdered milk to the Tunisian Government for distribution to about 50,000 Algerian refugees.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- The Harriman Administration was warned today that its plans to control chemical additives in food and soft drinks might result in chaos if they conflicted with future Federal regulations.

TULSA, Okla., Jan. 16 (AP) -The United States Junior Chamber of Commerce named ten "outstanding young men" of 1957 today. All are under 35 years of age. They are in medicine, government, industry, physics and aeronautical research.
A device similar to the heat exchanger used to cool transmission oil in automobiles has been used to improve open heart surgery at the Duke University Medical Center.

The East, which hasn't figured too prominently in these tables in the past, currently is monopolizing top honors in the National Collegiate Athletic Bureau's small-college basketball scoring statistics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -The Senate approved today a resolution establishing a joint Congressional committee to study all aspects of the election, disability and succession of the President and Vice President.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein upheld today the constitutionality of the state's Community College Law.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 16 -Official sources stated tonight that the Government of Premier Adnan Menderes had thwarted a plot to overthrow it and had arrested eight active army officers and one retired colonel as conspirators.

AT sundown next Thursday the sexton of St. Paul's Chapel, oldest religious edifice in the city (1764-1766 were the building years), will close the right-of-way through the churchyard from Fulton Street to Vesey Street.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Britain has challenged the Soviet Union to show its good faith by immediately beginning joint efforts with the West to work out essential controls for suspension of nuclear tests and for prevention of surprise attacks.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Ferenc Munnich, a First Deputy Premier, declared today that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty may stay in the United States legation as long as he likes -- "and then he can go to Heaven."

WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Jan. 16 -- About 3,500 acres near Traders Point, north of Indianapolis, have been given to Purdue University by Josiah K. Lilly, vice chairman of the board of Eli Lilly Co., pharmaceutical chemists.

For half a century (war years excepted) January has not been the impossible midwinter month that snow and ice have tried to make it. The compensating, consoling highlight has been the National Motor Boat Show.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The president of a labor union representing 30,000 engineers and scientists suggested today that this country had too many scientists, rather than too few.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Two professors said today that the way the tide was running the South and West would have more than half the nonagricultural jobs in the country by about 1975.

Yesterday seemed hardly a good day to go shopping for an island. Yet seven persons stomped through the blanket of snow that covered Ellis Island to try to decide whether they wanted to buy it.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 11 to 19 points yesterday, with late weakness in the near months. The drop equaled 55 to 95 cents a bale.

PITTSBURGH Jan. 16 (AP) -Aluminum Company of America the nation's biggest producer of aluminum, said today that as a result of lagging demand, its production of primary aluminum was being curtailed at plants at Alcoa, Tenn., and at Point Comfort, Tex.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP) -- An attorney said today that payment of $110,700 to Mrs. Maureen Connolly Brinker would end litigation over injuries she alleged ruined her tennis playing career.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Joseph C. Welman, president of the American Bankers Association, said today the Federal Reserve Board should quickly take a stand on "excessively high" reserve requirements.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- Premier Felix Gaillard's Cabinet was shaken but still standing tonight after a close victory in the National Assembly.

YOTVATA, Israel, Jan. 16 -One of Israel's fondest dreams was fulfilled today with the opening of a new highway linking Elath and Beersheba.

WHEN the first election was held for the Baseball Hall of Fame, 226 members of the Baseball Writers' Association cast ballots, with ten candidates nominated on each ballot. Triumphantly enrolled with the necessary 75 per cent of the votes were Ty Cobb, Babe Ruth, Honus Wagner, Christy Mathewson and Walter Johnson.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, disowned today some literature of the White Citizens Council sent out in official envelopes bearing his name.

Hungarian witnesses who testified before a U. N. committee investigating the outrages committed by the Russians during the 1956 revolt need not worry lest their identities be revealed. N. political officer who heard some of the evidence and then refused to let Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold have the names.

HONOLULU, Jan. 17 (AP) -The Liberian freighter Wanderer radioed today she lost her propeller in the North Pacific storm that disabled two grainladen Soviet freighters.

M.; Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera 8; Gounod's "Faust," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15; Mozart's "The Magic Flute," Lyric Players, Jan Hus Auditorium, 2:15; Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi" and "Suor Angelica," Opera Workshop, Greenwich House Music School, 8:30.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Wheat futures prices had their sharpest rally of the week on the Board of Trade today and finished the session still on the climb.
OTTAWA, Jan. 17 -- An offer to return to Canadian ownership the twenty - seven - story Canada House under construction in New York was renewed today by William Zeckendorf, a New York realty operator.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 17 -James H. Smith Jr., director of the International Cooperation Administration, completed tonight a two-day tour of United States aid projects for Lebanon. He visited Turkey before coming here and will leave for Libya tomorrow.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Left-wing Progressive People's party re-elected Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan as its leader today and named his Chicago-born wife, Janet, as general secretary.

Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregular yesterday in generally quiet trading. Potatoes, cocoa, tin, lead, rubber, wool and cottonseed oil rose; copper, zinc, hides, burlap and coffee declined, and price movements for sugar were mixed.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Sixty-one prominent citizens petitioned their Representatives today to abolish the twelve - year - old House Committee on Un-American Activities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Food and Drug Administration acted today to keep milk free of any possible contamination from chemicals used to combat insects.
Old Double X, as James Emory Foxx, the baseball Hall of Famer, was familiarly called by his team-mates, has been double crossed by time and fate.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Superior Court Judge Fletcher Bowron, former Mayor of Los Angeles, has filed a $1,000,000 damage suit as the result of a television interview Mike Wallace conducted with Mickey Cohen, former gambler, last May.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Up to now an insect has been able to curl up inside a grain of wheat with a sense of security and some assurance of privacy. But an invention patented this week should change all that.

For the final novelty of its engagement at the City Center, the New York City Ballet presented last night George Balanchine's fourth new work of the season. It is called "Stars and Stripes," with a score by Hershy Kay based on music of John Philip Sousa. After this, the theatre probably will have to be renamed the Radio City Center.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 17 -- Twenty-two traveling science teachers will be sent out from Oak Ridge next year -- more than twice the number traveling nationally this year.
"Showcase," a new program featuring entertainment personalities, will replace "The Wendy Barrie Show" on WABD (Channel 5) on Jan. 27.

How to select a container for a product depends on various functional and merchandising factors, as well as product protection, according to a sixteen-page illustrated booklet issued by the Stone Container Corporation of Chicago.

DENVER, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A district court injunction banning the use of the trademark Sohio by the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) in states in which the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) does business has been upheld by the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -A special investigating committee of airplane pilots said today that the nation's transport planes were carrying potentially dangerous cargoes. It blamed inadequate regulations, carelessness and ignorance of safety rules.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Ezra Taft Benson faced today a series of scathing challenges of his accuracy and honesty in presenting the Administration's new farm proposals to Congress.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Strong pressure for negotiations with the Soviet Union at the highest level continues to develop in Britain.

Washington has now given assurance that India can obtain a loan of $225,000,000 plus a grain-aid program of about $65,000,000. Presumably this will not require Congressional debate, since the funds are already available and the grain surplus is at hand.
MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- The Soviet press supported today the view that the Kremlin believes it has the West on the run. Western diplomats think that the Kremlin believes this.
A plan to relieve evening rush-hour congestion on the northbound platform of the Fourteenth Street station of the IRT Lexington Avenue line has been put into operation by the Transit Authority.

The integrity and effectiveness of the voluntary oil import controls program is being threatened by the Government itself by continued purchases of oil products in foreign markets, James E. Dyer, president of the Sinclair Refining Company, said yesterday.
GAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 17 -- The South African Parliament convened today in a mood of uncertainty over Government leadership in the face of a coming election.
The Police Department denied yesterday that mass transfers of patrolmen were contemplated, as charged by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

"My Arabian Days and Nights," by Dr. Eleanor T. Calverly, will be published by Crowell on Feb. 19. Dr. Calverly was the first woman physician in Kuwait, an Arabian town on the Persian Gulf. She tells of her experiencs and those of her husband during twenty years of medical pioneering and teaching in that community.
Rails boomed in the final hour of trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and produced a moderate gain for the market as a whole.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 17 -- Harold Macmillan, Prime Minister of Britain, said tonight that the question of whether foreign capital would be risked for development purposes was largely a matter that parliaments should determine.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 17 -- Venezuelan policemen swung unsheathed machetes last night at a group of women demonstrators.

A germanium rectifier cooling tube just introduced by the General Electric Company has a new cell arrangement that allows twelve fin assemblies to be stacked in series. This makes possible a 20 to 25 per cent higher cell rating for plating rectifier power supplies, the company said.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- Povl Bang-Jensen, suspended United Nations political officer, accused an investigating committee today of "serious errors of fact" in its report that he mishandled secret documents relating to Soviet repression in Hungary.

Gross volume of business of the International Business Machines Corporation last year exceeded one billion dollars for the first time in the company's history, Thomas J. Watson Jr., president, reported yesterday in the preliminary annual statement.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- The railroad industry's present hour may be a dark one, but sympathetic response to its problems may herald a bright dawn. James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, suggested today.

BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Philadelphia's Neil Johnston sank a fifteen-foot hook shot as the final buzzer sounded tonight, enabling the Warriors to nip the New York Knickerbockers, 117 -- 116, in a National Basketball Association game.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -The State Department promised Congress today to press for an international conference in the spring of 1959 to bring up to date the rules for safety at sea.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 -- The California liquor industry was set back today by a Superior Court ruling that voided a method used since 1935 to enforce "fair trade" price fixing on bottled alcoholic beverages.

MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- The official Soviet news agency Tass said today Mr. Khrushchev made his trip on the invitation of M. Gomulka and Premier Cyrankiewicz. Tass said Mr. Khrushchev had been taking a rest somewhere near the Soviet-Polish border when the invitation came from Warsaw.
John W. Roberts has been elected president of Albert Ramond Associates, Inc., management consulting concern, Chicago and New York.
The establishment of a Federal hospital on Ellis Island for the treatment of narcotic addicts from Atlantic seaboard states was suggested yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

The Matthews Company is building five models of its stock power cruiser this year. One of them, a forty-two-foot double cabin flying bridge craft, is displayed by Higgs Marine Service, Inc., the New York distributor.

EVERYBODY likes pancakes. Swedes like them small, thin and served with lingonberries. Russians dote on blinis smeared with caviar and sour cream and Americans feast mornings on flapjacks swimming in butter and maple syrup. Thank the French, however, for inventing the most sophisticated pancake of them -- all the crepe.

Critical of United States rule, 70,000 voters of Naha, the capital city, elected the more radical of two anti-American candidates for mayor. Both aspirants
GREENVILLE, Miss., Jan. 9 -- An area-wide program to transform the economic pattern of the State of Mississippi's Delta lands is chalking up initial successes.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The British and European attitude toward the exchange of letters between President Eisenhower and Premier Bulganin of the Soviet Union has been complicated by the development of a striking and perhaps dangerous difference between the governmental and the popular approach to the whole question of negotiation with the Soviet Union.

Records fell, tempers flared, players fought and the Knicker-bockers won last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. However, the 123-120 victory of the New Yorkers over the Syracuse National failed to lift the local quintet out of the Eastern Division cellar of the National Basketball Association. Philadelphia's upset of Boston kept the Knicks on the bottom.
Carnival amusements will be a feature of the eighth annual Animal Kingdom Ball at the Pierre on Thursday. A debutante committee has been selected to assist at the midway booths.
OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 16 -- The Strategic Air Command at Offut Air Force Base near here is probably the calmest and most confident outfit in the United States.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Paintings by Sir Winston Churchill will go on display here Wednesday in the world's first collective exhibit of his art.

"The heaviest, strongest, most ruggedly built 27-foot yacht available today" is what the Trojan Boat Company says of its new Sea Breeze cruiser. The boat is one of half a dozen cruisers and runabouts displayed.

CRANBURY, N. J., Jan. 18 -- A freakish dust storm here swirled across a ten-mile stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike shortly after noon today and caused fifteen vehicles to pile up in the southbound lane.
The city Department of Health is carefully checking all children in its well-baby clinics in an effort to detect early symptoms of lead poisoning.

WITH this morning, Doubleday is launching a new literary what-is-it, which for lack of better name is being called Headline Publications. Not hard cover books, but sort of books: not news magazines, but oh, call them Headline Publications and have done.

Chris-Craft, a giant of the pleasure boating industry, has more than eighty models this year ranging from kits to sixty-five-footers that cost as much as $166,700. The line includes runabouts, utilities, cruisers and motor yachts.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Jan. 15 -- A 500-foot hole in Antarctica's Marin Byrd Land has yielded ice that probably was formed three centuries ago.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 18 -- Jon Konrads, the young Latvian-born swimmer who now lives in Sydney, smashed two more world records tonight when he won the 220-yard freestyle event at the New South Wales championships in 2 minutes 4.8 seconds. He surpassed the 200-meter record en route.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sunday, Jan. 19 (AP) -- President Sukarno of Indonesia joined President Tito today in declaring neutralist nations "can considerably contribute to international cooperation and the strengthening of peace."

"When I was just a baby," Yvon Durelle says, "I was so soft and so sweet that everybody up home called me 'Doux.' In French doux means either soft or sweet."

BUFFALO, Jan. 18 -- After having experienced an unprecedented year of headaches during the 1956 unlimited Gold Cup racing season, the council and general membership of the American Power Boat Association finally acknowledged that the unlimited class was beset with "growing pains.
The proposal to establish Thirtieth Street as the route of the proposed $88,000,000 Mid-Manhattan Crosstown Expressway came under heavy civic attack yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 -- Educators profess to detect growing agitation among faculty members, especially in the West and Midwest, for abolition of examinations in colleges and universities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Navy is pressing ahead with development and construction of a large atomic-powered destroyer that would be able to go at full speed several times around the world without refueling.
HOW many times has it been argued that this country's best hope for a future in opera would be the development of regional companies to compare with the provincial troupes in Central Europe?

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- An investigation of voting records in the Seventh Congressional District special election was ordered today after five election judges were charged with vote frauds.
The nation's privately owned shipyards lost some ground last month. They completed only three vessels and obtained only one new contract.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 18 -- One of the most nervous men in Venezuela during the last two and a half weeks has been a former Argentine general, President and dictator named Juan Domingo Peron.

John H. Bremer, a 35-year-old writer and lecturer from Lake Zurich, Ill., and Kai Petersen, a 26-year-old neighbor, expect to leave tomorrow on a 10,000-mile voyage by outboard motorboat around the North American continent. The Motor Boat Show is the home base.

President Eisenhower's budget message to Congress disappointed many of the nation's top educational leaders. They were disturbed that less Federal funds are proposed for schools than were asked last year. In particular, they are concerned over the lack of any provision for school construction funds while it is becoming increasingly difficult to raise money on the local level.

New York University's experiment in giving a credit course over television was pronounced a success yesterday by the professor who taught it, the students who took it and the dean of the college under whose auspices it was given.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Samuel Devieux, a leading educator and newspaper editor in his country, has undertaken a mission to the United States to preach the gospel of a reborn Haiti.

WHEN painting walls or ceilings always try to begin near the windows and work back into the darker part of the room. Reflections on the wet paint will make it easier to see if the surface is being evenly coated.

The program of the Police Athletic League will be furthered as the result of a preview performance of the new musical, "The Body Beautiful", at the Broadway Theatre Wednesday evening.

The Palmer Engine Company, which never has missed a National Motor Boat Show, is featuring new "Spacemaker" gasoline marine engines. They have a profile height of only 12 3/4 inches from crankshaft to top for a third less height than conventional six-cylinder engines when installed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold accepted today the recommendation of a special committee that papers relating to the United Nations investigation of Soviet oppression in Hungary and retained by Povl Bang-Jensen, suspended United Nations political officer, should be burned.

THE panchromatic enlarging paper announced by Eastman Kodak Company last October at the annual convention of the Photographic Society of America will be available Feb. 1 under the name Kodak Panalure Paper E, a double-weight stock, with a grained, lustre, semi-matte, white surface, and in only one grade, normal contrast.

THE review by Justin O'Brien of my translation of "Albert Camus: The Invincible Summer," by Albert Maquet, has naturally caused me personal concern. I say review of my translation, rather than review of the book itself, because the heat of Mr. O'Brien's ire was, as printed, so witheringly directed against the translation and not the text.

THE late Justice Robert H. Jackson (1892-1954) was primarily a lawyer, and the profession no doubt regarded him as a "lawyer's judge." The country lawyer -- who did not attend college and spent but one year at law school -- achieved international renown as a consummate advocate and as a scholarly and urbane judge.

ALTHOUGH Jean Dalrymple is too practical an entrepreneur to have stars in her eyes, she is all for having stars on her stage. DINNER KEY, Miami, Jan. 18 -- Being the wife of an indefatigable yachting skipper has its problems as well as its fun. For some time now I have had a routine that works quite well if nothing unforeseen happens. Instead of writing out plans for all the meals we expect to eat on board for three or four days, as I did formerly, now I make an outline, and market accordingly.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls, the 1957 winner, moved into her familiar first-place spot today after three rounds of the $7,500 women's Tampa open golf tournament, shooting 74 for a 54-hole total of 228 and a two-stroke lead.
PATRICK AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Jan. 18 -- The nation's first strategic missile squadron, activated on Dec. 15, is rapidly building up to full strength here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 10 -- The equatorial electrojet, a magnetic current flowing through the earth's atmosphere above the equator, reacts almost instantly to sun spots, Brazilian observers have reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Senator Matthew M. Neely of West Virginia, an outspoken Democratic critic of the Eisenhower Administration and of fellow Democrats whom he considered too conservative, died today at the age of 83.

The fifty-five-boat fleet of sailing craft at the show places somewhat more emphasis on cruising boats this year. They include an English-built two-berth sloop that is 17 feet overall, smallest of its kind ever entered in the show; two familiar off-shore vessels in the 40-foot class and a scattering of others of 23 to 28 feet.
College students should flex their muscles with life's "real problems" instead of tackling examinations or scoring the team's winning point, an educator asserted here yesterday.
HAVANA, Jan. 18 -- Four youthful revolutionists who have been held incommunicado at Santiago in Oriente Province since their arrest several days ago, were tonight presented to the press in that city.

CORAL GABLES, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Tony Vincent of New York, who had a winning streak of eleven consecutive games, overwhelmed Iyo Pimental of Venezuela today in a semi-final match of the Coral Gables-University of Miami tennis championships. The scores were 10 -- 8, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- Six prominent Latin Americans from as many countries will open a ten-day meeting in Santiago, Chile, Feb. 1 to confer on ways of creating a common market in their region.
A collection of Georgian furniture and decorations will be auctioned Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis got a head start toward his fifth title in the Great Lakes speed skating championships today by winning two events and finishing second in a third.
Two policemen, acting quickly, managed to free a critically injured motorist from his badly damaged automobile yesterday on the Manhattan Bridge.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 18 -- Guatemala is preparing for one of her most important elections in an atmosphere of totally unlooked for but gratefully received calm.

THE happy turn furniture design has taken toward practical concepts, durable easy-to-maintain surfaces and good styling at a price were evident again at the wholesale furnishings markets in Chicago and Grand Rapids. Partly responsible for these welcome developments are the new young designers.

A WISTFUL - EYED, tense little man, clutching a zipper briefcase, is making a brand-new film name for himself in a way nobody, least of all George K. Arthur, ever expected. At the age of 57, one of the best-known silent screen comedians is back in business as a thumpingly successful movie distributor. Mr. Arthur, who should know, says "salesman."
DETROIT, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The auto industry is having inventory problems again.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 18 -- Venezuela's political-military crisis continued in full swing this week-end. President Marcos Perez Jimenez was reported to be facing new pressure by officers of the armed forces.

The Soviet armed forces have a new top political commissar, Col. Gen. F. I. Golikov, it became known last week. Military and diplomatic analysts in many capitals sought to fathom the meaning of the replacement of Col. Gen. A. S. Zheltov, who had held the post since shortly after Stalin's death in 1953.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- By the end of 1958 publication is expected of a regional geological map of Asia and the Far East, the only area in the world on which such reference material is lacking.
Rickie Ann Rendich, 18 years old, from Mamaroneck, N. Y., and Bruce Heiss, 14, of Ozone Park, Queens, shared honors yesterday in the Middle Atlantic figure skating championships.

IN this country Ramon Sender stands as the best-known Spanish novelist among the ill-fated "generation of 1936," so scattered and crushed by the Civil War which broke out in that year. Younger men, notably Jose Maria Gironella whose novel "The Cypresses Believe in God" dealt with that war, are beginning to bring another point of view to the tragedy, but the priority belongs to Sender.
HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Dartmouth staved off a last-ditch Holy Cross rally tonight to defeat the Crusaders, 84 -- 78, for its thirteenth basketball victory against one loss.

TRENTON, Jan. 18 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner will be inaugurated Tuesday for a second four-year term.

FOR THIS WEEK: White gnats and springtails on house plant soil are controlled by dusting lightly with 5 per cent chlordane or watering with lime water. . . . Always sweep off heavy snow from shrubbery to prevent branches and trunks from splitting. When ice covers plants, hose it off if day is mild. . . . Once flower buds and leaves show on amaryllis, move to a sunny spot; water freely. . . .

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Central to all discussions of East-West relations is the future of Germany. An East-West summit conference that did not put the problem of Germany in the center of the stage would be a mockery, Secretary Dulles said quite clearly at the National Press Club on Thursday.

THE excitement caused by the award of the Nobel Prize to Albert Camus having warmed everyone up, the balance sheet for the French literary year has been drawn with enthusiasm. An embarrassment of riches is the difficulty.

Each year sees a tremendous increase in boats and operators and a consequent need for extension and improvement of waterways, mooring facilities and safety controls.
