The forty-eighth annual National Motor Boat Show, holding forth for a ten-day run at New York's Coliseum on Columbus Circle, is already great by every standard and tradition.

CARDINAL WOLSEY (1471-1530) governed England for the first half of Henry VIII's reign, and was probably the most spectacular statesman the English have produced. In addition to wielding secular power, he possessed the advantage of being a Roman Cardinal who got the Pope to make him his legate for life.
A corporation executive with a six-figure salary who cuts his own firewood thinks our atomic navy will grow much larger.
NAZE, Amami-O-Shima, Japan, Jan. 18 -- Communism has established its firmest Japanese beachhead in this former United States administered territory, according to authorities here.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 18 -- Gov. Sir Raynor Arthur made a new move today to end the six-day general strike that has paralyzed this British resort colony and dried up the flow of tourist dollars.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The military strength of the North Atlantic alliance in Europe is endangered by the crisis that has developed out of the quarrel over West Germany's refusal to pay support costs, British officials said today.
AMES, Iowa, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Coach Jim Myers of Iowa State said today he had "forgotten all about" the Texas A. M. football coaching job, which Aggie students urged him to take in a lengthy telegram.

PALERMO, Sicily, Jan. 18 (Reuters) -- A psychiatrist indicated today that "nervous exhaustion" would prevent an opening-night opera performance here by Anita Cerquetti, Italian soprano. She had replaced Maria Callas after the latter walked out at the opening of the Rome Opera two weeks ago.

MIAMI, Jan. 18 -- The story goes that a United States Power Squadron's instructor giving out examination marks told one of his students that his wife had made 100 per cent on her paper. The instructor added, "I'm giving you 101 -- I'm a married man myself."

The Detroit Diesel Engine Division of General Motors is focusing attention on three engines developed during the last year. Shown for the first time, they are a 364 h. p. Diesel for large yachts, a 110 h. p. unit for small craft and a work-boat model with one of the highest power-to-weight ratios in the line.

A study made by the United States Public Health Service reveals that the cost of tuberculosis in the United States increased by $100,000,000 between 1952 and 1956, bringing the cost in 1956 to more than $725,000,000.

THERE was a time in the dimming past of the motion picture when a tree was a tree and a rock was a rock, but, like Keystone Kops, six-shooters that never have to be reloaded and Wampus baby stars, those days are gone forever.

The Chicago District and Southern California Golf Associations have advised officials in various parts of the country that they are not accepting the new handicap system adopted by the United States Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Administration is considering two ideas on the nature and scope of an international commission to carry out President Eisenhower's proposal that outer-space be used only for peaceful purposes.

THIS novel, which was awarded the Prix Goncourt for 1956 and has sold more than 300,000 copies in France, is one vast orchestral hymn in praise of the elephant. Romain Gary's elephants are of every kind: the elephant as a symbol, the metaphorical elephant, above all the great ivory-tusked pachyderm of French Equatorial Africa.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Clarence Meaux rallied W. Hal Bishop's Bernburgoo on the outside down the stretch today to take the $10,000 Marriage Handicap at the Fair Grounds with a three-length spread over the winner's stable-mate, Bryn.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 18 -- The names of forty-one persons voted into the National Cowboy Hall of Fame were released here today by trustees representing the seventeen Western states sponsoring the memorial.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 5 -- Argentines, long famed for pride in their personal dignity, which other Latins frequently dscribe as pomposity, are learning to laugh at themselves.
The stock market paid little heed to a rash of dramatic economic developments last week. Prices, in general, held within a narrow range and ended with moderate gains.

The United States budget defines in the most concrete terms the philosophy of the Administration that compiles it. The terms are dollars and cents. The budget answers the vital questions -- How much should be spent? For what? How will the cost be met? -- on the whole range of Government functions, from its most advanced missile development to the care of its most ancient monuments.

A silent participant in the debate last week over the budget, missiles, and other aspects of the program the Administration presented to Congress was Premier Nikolai Bulganin of Russia. A substantial easing of the Soviet threat could have a profound effect on the program that eventually emerges on Capitol Hill.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 18 -- Americans are buying larger outboard boats and putting a higher percentage of them on trailers than ever before. Data gathered by the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers, and the Outboard Boating Club of America, list 165,000 trailers and 320,000 outboard boats sold in 1957, an average of slightly better than one trailer for every two boats.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department today received the following reports on winter sports conditions:

FOR three decades, President Sukarno has been the focus and symbol of the Indonesian revolution. Today, with economic chaos and rebellion threatening the central government, status and future of this handsome, 56-year-old spellbinder, known affectionately as Bung (Brother or Comrade) Karno, are matters of speculation.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 18 -- The filing of a public school desegregation suit in the Federal District Court in Atlanta a week ago today poses the first serious assault on the scaffolding of resistance erected by the hard core of Southern states whose political leadership has steadfastly declared "it can't happen here."

CERTAINLY this is not a "nice" novel about Greece today. Nor is the protagonist, Spiro, a "nice" person. As Lord Russell says, "To be a nice person it is necessary to be protected from crude contact with reality." What Spiro has had all his life is crude contact -- and little else.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Yale and Army scored, a total of seven goals in the third period and played a 4-4 hockey tie in overtime before 1,500 fans tonight.

HONG KONG, Jan. 18 -- A protocol providing for Soviet scientific assistance to Communist China was signed in Moscow today. The protocol also covered joint Chinese-Soviet research in science and technology.

In his extremely successful remarks before the National Press Club in Washington on Thursday Secretary Dulles made a point that he might well have made before. This was, in brief, that all negotiations among governments are actually "at the summit." As he put it, "If negotiations are conducted through diplomacy, President Eisenhower has just as much a part in that as he would have if he were personally meeting with Chairman Bulganin."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- On the basis of past performances and present anticipation, the Democrats appear to have the votes needed to retake two seats vacated by members of the party in the eighty-fifth Congress.

A French transport plane, the Breguet 763, arrived yesterday on its first visit to this country. Described by its manufacturer, the Breguet Aircraft Corporation, as the only airplane with two full-length decks, it has come here on a sales and demonstration tour of the United States and South America.

AN old joke runs: "Who won the Civil War?" the correct answer of course being: "The American Booksellers Association." There appears to be no saturation point for Civil War fiction, historical surveys and biographies of Confederate and Federal leaders.

ROME, Jan. 18 -- A strengthening of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in the last year is reflected in the Pontifical Yearbook for 1958. A handsomely bound copy of the book was presented to Pope Pius XII today.

CHINCOTEAGUE, Va., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Four young rocketers watched their dream go up in smoke twice today. When the smoke cleared, their dream, a slim, shiny cylinder destined -- they hoped -- to swoosh through the air, was still there.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 18 -- The twenty-four-year tenure of this city's widely known Socialist Mayor, Jasper McLevy, was studded with many civic triumphs. But even his most ardent supporters were not likely to include snow removal among them.

THIRTY-FIVE years after his death, it is dazzlingly clear that Proust is the greatest French novelist of the century. Yet, up to the appearance of the Pleiade edition of his novel in 1954, we did not even have an accurate text in which to read him. "Jean Santeuil," that early fragmentary version of the Proustian saga, composed in 1896-99, was only lately discovered in an old trunk once relegated to the attic of Proust's apartment.

With a phenomenal growth during recent years in the pleasure boating population, which swelled to thirty-five million citizens this year, the United States Coast Guard has engaged in an intensified, all-out public education program -- that of informing the week-end skipper how to cruise in safety.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower's military budget for the next fiscal year has done more than underscore the increasing role of pushbutton weapons in the arsenal of the United States.
WARSAW, Jan. 18 -- Mao Tsetung made clear to Polish leaders in Moscow recently that the Communist bloc disapproved of Poland's taking economic aid from the United States.

Boats and engines built in ten foreign countries are displayed by American representatives at the show. England is most heavily represented, with products featured by five companies. They include the smallest cruising sailboats ever entered, a 17-footer offered by Ferrier Marine, and a 6 1/2-foot inboard powered water scooter by the Arnolt Corporation.

A new 3-cylinder 60 h.p. lightweight engine is featured in the Scott-Atwater line of outboard motors this year. It is of in-line construction and weighs 160 pounds. The powerhead measures 12 3/4 inches wide and 14 inches tall.

Fifteen of the country's outstanding power boat drivers elected yesterday to the 1957 Gulf Marine Racing Hall of Fame at an awards breakfast in the Belmont Plaza Hotel range in age from 11 to 45 and in occupation from schoolboy to airlines president.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The New York Rangers rallied twice today to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 -- 2, and preserve Goalie Gump Worsley's jinx over the Black Hawks, who haven't beaten him in their last seventeen tries.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight, in a startling setback, lost today in a bid to win endorsement by a Republican fact-finding group as the party's candidate for the United States Senate.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Gil Hodges, first baseman of the Dodgers, today signed his 1958 contract.
How to express a concept in a water color, rather than by photography, will be demonstrated by James A. Ernst at a free lecture at 6:15 P. M. Tuesday at the New York Public Library.
A vee-banked four-cylinder engine in a 50 horsepower model heads Evinrude's line of outboard motors for 1958. It is a new concept in outboard power plants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Sesquicentennial Year commemorated by the Coast and Geodetic Survey since last February afforded an opportunity to review the accomplishments of this bureau of the United States Department of Commerce in support of safe navigation.
BIRMINGHAM, England, Jan. 18 (Reuters) -- Lord Hailsham, chairman of the Conservative party, said here tonight that Britain would be "eliminated" in a third world war.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A lone business man has given Washington a case of frustration.

The greatest "uncommitted" region of the globe today is Africa. We see it now, taking the continent as a whole, on the eve of a crucial struggle. The portion south of the Sahara (excluding South Africa) has to move from a primitive life to the twentieth century in one bound.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A pair of Supreme Court orders this week focused attention on a Federal anti-obscenity statute lobbied through Congress in 1873 by Anthony Comstock. Among other things the law makes it a crime to send an "obscene" book, picture or other object through the mails.

VIENNA, Jan. 18 -- The ambition long entertained by President Tito of Yugoslavia to organize the neutrals and other uncommitted nations of the world into a third force has been finding definite expression recently, according to reports from Belgrade.

Five of the thirteen outboard motorboat models the Glasspar Company is manufacturing this year are at the show. They include a 19-foot cruiser, the Club Mariner, and a new 15-footer, the Trident, intended for the water-skiing family.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The chemistry faculty of Catholic University issued a warning today against the "extreme hazards" of amateur experiments in space rocketry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- One of the wire services, in speaking of the President's budget this week, referred to it as "balanced" -- in quotation marks.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 18 -- Edward Walsh, a 49-year-old St. Louis industrialist, took over the presidency of the Sports Car Club of America today.

The chief fault of the high schools in the United States is not that scientific subjects are neglected but that the curriculum contains little of substance. Subjects are seldom taught in a proper and serious manner. The most distressing consequence of a diluted high school program is that students acquire a disbelief in the reality of academic accomplishment and a contempt for learning.

WARSAW, Jan. 18 -- Polish Communist officials tried their best today to minimize the importance of last week's meeting between Nikita S. Khrushehev Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Soviet and Polish Communist leaders.
A boat show is never just a trade display. It is not a commonplace catch-all, like the shelves of a pharmacy.
SARANAC LAKE, N. Y. -- This prose-poem is being written by a year-round resident of the rugged Adirondacks who, quite frankly, loves it.
ROME, Jan. 18 -- In a firm reply to a message from Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin, Italy suggested today a conference on the foreign minister level to break the East-West deadlock.

YOUNG Harald Sigurdson, the Northman whose travels were chronicled in an earlier book, "Viking's Dawn," sets out about 785 A. D. on another venturesome voyage. In Ireland, he and his freebooting companions seize a giant's treasure, but lose it on their return trip when a storm drives the viking ship far southward.

Among the boats making debuts at the Coliseum is a new twenty-foot custom runabout that the Century Boat Company calls the XL 325. It is a high-powered futuristic boat with a 325 horsepower Cadillac Crusader Special engine.

Carnegie Hall was crawling with television technicians yesterday morning. The occasion was the first of four televised programs of the New York Philharmonic's Young People's Concerts conducted by Leonard Bernstein.

The Lone Star Boat Company's line for 1958 contains twenty-five models of aluminum and fiberglass outboard boats. They range from 12 feet to 23 and embrace engineering and styling advances for which the company has coined the word "Carefreedom."

QUEMOY, China, Jan. 10 -- A proposal aimed at enabling the Chinese Nationalists to withdraw about five divisions of trained troops from the offshore islands for use elsewhere was made by United States military leaders in this area yesterday. It was enthusiastically supported by Nationalist military figures.

Cheers to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey for clearing away much of the confusion and double-talk surrounding the problem of arms reduction negotiations. ("What Hope for Disarmament?" Jan. 5). His criticism of past policy regarding unilateral disarmament, lack of support for Mr. Stassen, making a test ban contingent upon a halt in production and our failure to call the Soviet bluff strikes me as justified and well-reasoned.
Johnson's line of outboard motors runs from 3 h. p. to a new 50 h. p. four-cylinder motor that applies the V principle to the two-cycle outboard.
In the feature entitled "Life as Seen By 'Mme. la Pipelette,'" (Jan. 5) the statement is made that the French word "concierge" has something to do with the words comte (count) and cierge (candle).

Oliver's line of 6, 16 and 35 horse power outboard motors are out in new colors this year. Also, the 6 h. p. model has been given completely new lines. The top of the motor thrusts forward, the lower portion juts to the rear.

IN its current show, "Nature in Abstraction," the Whitney Museum has taken a long step forward. Instead of merely presenting a cross section of what is being done, John I. H. Baur, curator, has assembled an exhibition of unusually high quality to demonstrate how and why modern artists are using new approaches to immemorial inspiration.

EXAMINATION weeks are drawing upon us again and, in isolated class rooms and schools across the country, episodes of cheating will be uncovered. This will set the tongues of the childless wagging and parental hearts sinking.

The New York Community Trust announced yesterday that last year it distributed $1,219,271. That was the second highest total since the trust was established thirty - four years ago. In 1950 it distributed $1,632,278.

The "New Chamber Music" program presented late yesterday afternoon in Norman J. Seaman's Twilight Concert series was a fresh demonstration that contemporary music is often invitingly melodious and thoroughly enjoyable at a first hearing.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah -- Dining car crews aboard the Rio Grande Railroad's trim and tidy Prospector are possibly the busiest entrepreneurs of comestibles on any of the nation's railroads nowadays. The reason ? Full course dinners and breakfasts are currently included with round-trip rail and Pullman fares on the overnight Salt Lake City-Denver streamliner.

In an effort to avoid duplications, seven of the nation's leading women's colleges have decided to accept applications from high school seniors in the fall if they are certified by their schools as having filed only one application. All others will be considered the following spring according to regular custom.

The resume of Soviet aid projects in underdeveloped lands, recently published in The New York Times, is a sober warning to Americans not to underestimate or belittle the achievements of the Russian bloc in this area, as we have so recently done in the missile field.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 18 -- John Russell and Richard Remsen of the University Club, the top-seeded tandem, led the way into the semi-finals of the annual Greenwich Country Club invitation squash racquets doubles tournament today.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Everett T. Winter, executive vice president of the Mississippi Valley Association, said this week that a new threat of tolls on inland waterways would be discussed at the association's meeting here Feb. 10 and 11.

NO matter where the New York Yankees finish in this year's pennant race, they are destined to set one new record at least. They will become the most televised baseball team in history. The Yankees staked their claim on such distinction by announcing last week that a minimum of 140 games would be televised here over station WPIX (Channel 11).

The electric storage battery, the familiar dry cell that powers a flashlight, has made possible many of the technological developments of modern science. The transis tor, miniaturization, new inventions, short-range broadcasting, powered toys, electric wrist watches, jet aircraft -- these and a host of other advances have drawn heavily on the battery industry.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 18 -- The man who paid Uncle Sam a penalty of $965,595 last year for growing 4,600 acres of cotton figures that he is just about going to break even on the deal.
AIR suspension, the new automotive development being offered widely for the first time this year, is undergoing the usual growing pains associated with such improvements.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- The Alfalfa Club held its annual frolic tonight and "nominated" Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican of Indiana, for President of the United States.

Announcing to the Chinese people the limited adoption of the Latin alphabet, Premier Chou En-lai adds that once it is adopted it is a Chinese alphabet and "no longer the ancient Latin alphabet and even less the alphabet of any other country." Thus the Western alphabet becomes another "first" for the Communist innovators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower will send housing legislation to Congress after mid-February with the expressed aim of reducing the Federal role and spurring the activity of state, local and private interests.

WITH the forty-first annual International Flower Show less than two months away, impatient flower lovers might like to have a preview of what is in store. "The World Is Your Garden" will be the theme of the 1958 exhibition which is slated 'March 9 to 15 at the New York Coliseum.

THE Postmaster General's Advisory Committee of illustrators and philatelists at a recent Washington meeting took under consideration the Post Office Department's program of special stamp issues in 1958.

EACH year the Berniers make a selection from their French magazine of art, L'Oeil, of articles and the accompanying reproductions and illustrations that have appeared during the twelve months preceding. Earlier volumes have included a wealth of miscellaneous material ranging from cave painting to the latest avant - garde manifestations.

FOR Sir Winston Churchill, painting has been a continuation of war by other means. Visitors to the touring American exhibition of his work may delude themselves that they are looking at a collection of peaceable, old-fashioned pictures in the manner of the impressionists and postimpressionists, but the fact is that "The Goldfish Pool at Chartwell," the beach or lake scenes from the Cote d'Azur or Italy are really items of battle.

Communist China has just initiated a new campaign to stamp out what it calls "regional nationalism" among some of the larger minority groups on the mainland. The most important of these ethnic, language and religious minority groups comprise less than 10 per cent of the population but occupy more than half of the territory.

LEONID KOGAN belongs with the elect. The Russian violinist, making his first New York appearance at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, gave a masterly account of the Brahms Concerto.
The Richadson Boat Company has put three inboard cruisers into the show. They are a 43-foot motor yacht, a 40-foot sedan cruiser and a 30-foot express cruiser.

STARTING tomorrow, Greer Garson, the cinematic epitome of the dignity, nobility and beauty of mature womanhood, will kick up her heels replacing Rosalind Russell as the cyclonic dame in the title role of "Auntie Mame."
CAIRO, Jan. 18 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser was reported today to have given a cool reception to Syria's eager demands for a hastily concluded Egyptian-Syrian federation.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 -- Complaining that they could not obtain steady employment in the shipping industry, eleven marine clerks filed suit this week in Superior Court to compel their admission to a union.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 13 -- A rabbinical ban on the use of Israeli-made paper for the publication of Jewish religious tracts was lifted today.
Changing competition is bringing commercial bankers together in support of reforming reserve requirements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The friends of foreign aid on Capitol Hill have an old grievance against the Administration. Secretary Dulles and his lieutenants, they say, are parade-ground soldiers who make a very fine presentation before the Senate Foreign Relations and House Foreign Affairs Committee, but melt away when the rough-house begins in the House Appropriations Committee.
Two notable events are being marked by Jewish groups in New York this week-end.

BOCA RATON, Fla. -- This middle section of the Florida Gold Coast, stretching a little more than twenty miles from Boynton Beach to Pompano Beach, has not yet attained the rate of tourist and residential development that has marked the Miami to Fort Lauderdale and the Palm Beach areas to the south and North.

THOSE people who reproached themselves for not getting to hear Paul Shyre's adaptation of Pictures in the Hallway, the second volume of Sean O'Casey's autobiography, can now lay their guilt feelings aside. Thanks to Riverside and to a hardworking group of actors that includes Muriel Kirkland, Rae Allen, Staats Cotsworth, Alvin Epstein, Robert Geiringer and Mr. Shyre himself, this version has now been fixed on two records.

Whereupon Mr. Keresey, a patient man with a quiet voice, a scholarly look and a thin figure, pulls out his score of the Mahler First.

Flagship Marine Engines, Inc., is manufacturing power plants of 220, 240 and 310 horsepower. The largest is called a "custom competition" engine and is intended strictly for speed. It does not operate smoothly at idling speed.

PETER GLENVILLE, young and talented English stage and screen director, will be able to look back on his first Hollywood movie assignment, "Me and the Colonel," and say without fear of exaggeration that it was unconventional.

Five new 17-foot runabouts for outboard or inboard power make up the 1958 "Royalty" line of the Carlisle Marine Manufacturing Company. They are built of wood, the sides of African mahogany, the keelson, keel and bow stem of Honduras. Decks are of five-ply marine plywood. All models powered by engines of over 100 h.p. have double-planked bottoms.

MILAN, Italy, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Raimondo Puccinelli, a sculptor of Brooklyn, New York, attended the opening of an exhibition of his works here today. Twenty bronze and marble sculptures and twelve drawings are being displayed in the twoweek exhibition at the Pater Gallery. Mr. Puccinelli has been a Professor of Sculpture at the University of California, the University of North Carolina and Queens College in New York.

NEW reduced night-coach fares to Miami and other Florida points are being introduced by the three big carriers linking north and south on the Atlantic seaboard. National Airlines last month requested Civil Aeronautics Board permission to run the directional reduced fares as a test until May 30.

KARAVSOSTASI, Cyprus, Jan. 10 -- No member of British "other ranks" in Cyprus enjoys the privileges of Pvt. Gwyllym Jenkins.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Paul Kletzki, noted European conductor, made his American debut yesterday with the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra and a usually reserved audience arose and cheered at the conclusion.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- Dr. Francisco Urrutia, personal representative of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, reported today that Jordan and Israel had agreed to steps to ease tension in the strategic Mount Scopus area at Jerusalem.

The Police Department is still overstressing arrests and court action for combating juvenile delinquency, the Juvenile Delinquency Evaluation Project reported yesterday.
Dr. Grayson Kirk will appoint committees soon to study the newly published Macmahon report on the future of Columbia University.

The Monthly Investment Plan of the New York Stock Exchange, which will be four years old this week, withstood the 1957 stock market break well. There were more plans in effect at the year-end than ever before.

HARTFORD, Conn. -- Connecticut's famous Old State House, the three-story, federal - style structure designed by Charles Bulfinch and long regarded as one of the finest examples of the noted architect's work, is to become a museum. The Hartford City Council, after lengthy consideration, has voted unanimously to assure the preservation of the landmark, by formally agreeing to lease the building for that purpose to the Connecticut Historical Society.
NEWARK, Jan. 18 -- A stateside survey to determine the need for programs of vocational studies is being conducted.

AN ARTHUR GRUMIAUX RECITAL: Arthur Grumiaux, violinist (Epic). Elegant interpretations and fine technical performances of Tartini's "Devil's Trill" Sonata. Corelli's "Le Follia," and other baroque staples of the violin repertory.
ORLANDO, Fla. -- All industries go through cycles and the pleasure boat industry is no exception.

HARTFORD, Jan. 18 -- Meade Alcorn, Republican National Chairman, told his home state Republicans this week to forget their long - standing factional feud and unite around the "strongest candidate" the party has for Governor.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- A permanent paper industry exhibit, including a 17-foot-long operating scale model of a Four-drinier paper making machine, will be dedicated at the Franklin Institute on Tuesday.
New York University has established a Graduate Institute of Book Publishing to train men and women for careers in the book publishing industry.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Forty-one persons died in a flash flood that swept away the hamlet of Pachacc last Monday night. The news from the isolated Andean mountain region did not reach Lima until today.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Cutter Laboratories challenged tonight the application of the law of implied warranty to impose absolute liability on a drug manufacturer. Company officials also prepared to appeal the loss of a $147,300 award to two polio patients.

The Home Lines passenger vessel Italia this week will reenter trans-Atlantic and cruise service after a major rebuilding of passenger accommodations on three of her seven decks. The work was done at Hamburg, Germany, from which port the vessel will leave on Thursday.
A Federal Court jury yesterday convicted R. Lawrence Siegel and Hadassah R. Shapiro, his law associate, of perjury and obstruction of justice.

The U. S. Department of Defense is one of the world's most colossal undertakings. On its payroll are 1,000,000 civilians and 2,800,000 men in uniforms. Its holdings in equipment and property are valued at $146 billion. Each of its three departments -- Army, Navy and Air Force -- is bigger than any other Federal agency.

EVERGLADES, Fla. -- This slumbering town of less than 700, county seat of Florida's largest county, lies surrounded by mangrove and water eighty-two miles west of Miami and seventy-three miles south of Fort Myers.
HONG KONG, Jan. 18 -- Observers here believe the session of the National People's Congress of Communist China, scheduled to start a week from today, will be especially significant and revealing.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 18 -- Justice William E. Powers of this state's Supreme Court, who was blinded at the age of 20, is today, at the age of 50, one of the most powerful men in Rhode Island politics.
GAUHATI, India, Jan. 18 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told India today that there would be "no retreat" from the goal of socialism.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 -- Oregon Republicans were suddenly confronted this week with a contest for Governor.

DETROIT, Jan. 17 -- Walter P. Reuther is preparing to present a persuasive case for his new profit-sharing contract proposal at next week's special convention of the United Automobile Workers. The meeting begins Wednesday.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Bob Pettit flipped in 40 points that included the winning goal with forty-one seconds left today as the St. Louis Hawks defeated the Detroit Pistons 105 -- 103, in a nationally televised National Basketball Association game.
Two builders have put houseboats into the show for those seeking living space afloat comparable to that found only in large, expensive cruisers.

KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Austria's Alpine ski team -- the pride of this small nation -- dominated the downhill races of the international Hahnenkamm event today although its top star, a triple Olympic champion. Toni Sailer, fell and finished twenty-second.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- Art Tokle, the only Easterner to make the Federation Internationale de Ski jumping team at the recent trials at Ishpeming, Mich., captured top honors in the Bear Mountain Sports Association ski-jumping tournament today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 18 -- Cornell found Princeton unable to find the range tonight and hung an 82 -- 56 defeat on the Tigers. It was the second basketball setback in Ivy League competition for Old Nassau, against three victories.

A set shot by Joe Saxenmeyer with only four seconds left gave an Ivy League basketball victory to Pennsylvania over Columbia at University Hall gymnasium last night. Saxenmeyer's shot enabled the visitors to win, 48 to 46.
PARIS, Jan. 18 -- France's economy made the turn into the new year like a fine, highly tuned sports car sputtering to a halt for lack of gasoline.

The trend to bigger outboard motors continued in 1957 as more American families took to the water for their leisure hours. The rise in horsepower requirements was reflected in statistics compiled by the Outboard Boating Club of America in the new 640-page Boating Industry, a trade paper published in St. Joseph, Mich.
WITH another record season apparently in the making for the Bahamas, tourist business there suffered a serious setback last week as a general strike went far to paralyze the resort colony.
WITH United States turbine-engine planes due on the airways within the year, safety specialists are urging that the new craft be equipped with what appears to be an effective fire-prevention system.
ONE of the more difficult technical television achievements of the season is required for Tuesday night's dramatization of Thornton Wilder's "The Bridge of San Luis Rey."

Forty years ago today, in the city then called Petrograd and now called Leningrad, the Bolsheviks used their superiority in armed force to disperse the Constituent Assembly, the most democratic parliament of Russian history. It is worth recalling that tragic event because long decades of Communist dictatorship have tended to obscure the historic fact that for many years striving for democratic rule has been a major thread in Russia's history.
Resident buying offices report a continuing stream of buyers arriving in New York for their second look at spring lines.

IN Onna White, Broadway has acquired a new choreographer of top talent. What she has done in "The Music Man" makes that perfectly clear. To be sure, she has had the luckiest of breaks in being able to do her first show under the direction of Morton Da Costa, who is both a craftsman and an artist.

BERLIN, Jan. 18 -- Mrs. Barksdale Hamlett, wife of Major Gen. Barksdale Hamlett, the United States commander in Berlin, was halted yesterday by the East German police while being driven in an American Army car from East Berlin to West Berlin.

IN his preface Blair Rouse suggests that his selection of the letters of Ellen Glasgow be read as "a complementary volume" to "A Certain Measure" and to Miss Glasgow's posthumously issued autobiography, "The Woman Within."

VIENNA, Jan. 18 -- The United States Government made three new offers of help to the International Atomic Energy Authority and its member states today. It offered the services of atomic experts to the agency and nuclear training to students from under-developed countries.

BELHAVEN, N. C., Jan. 18 -- A notable philosophical debate over cause and effect raged brilliantly here last night and probably will find its way later into the pages of thinkers' journals and little reviews.
There are two seasonal diversions that can ease the bite of any winter. One is the January thaw. The other is the seed catalogues.

Although off to a slow start, educational television is now gaining momentum. Twenty-eight stations devoted to education are now on the air. The Joint Council on Educational Television predicts that forty-two educational television stations will be in operation before the end of 1958.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 18 -- Political tensions in Westchester County are mounting early this year because of the possibility that the nominating primaries may be held in June instead of September.

THE authors of this novel, a native-born Israeli and her musician husband, an American who has lived in Israel for ten years, have set their theme of revenge and love against the grandeur, idealism, pageant and tragedy of life in the frontier settlements of Israel.
GAUHATI, Assam, India, Jan. 18 -- "These Russians," said an Indian politician. "I always tell them that any day they can get jobs in a public relations company in the United States."

COCONUT GROVE, Fla., Jan. 18 -- The 35-footer Osprey which checked into Dinner Key at Miami earlier this month after coming down the inland waterway from the Chesapeake was manned by a couple who considered it their happiest cruising.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Navy said today "it doesn't make very good sense" for the armed forces to be dismissing experienced officers even as pay rises are sought to keep trained men in service.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 -- During the early part of the century, when amateur boating became a recognized sport and harbors and rivers were being used more and more by private boats, there became a need for these boatmen to understand the nautical rules of the road, interpretation of the aids to navigation, and in general how to protect themselves from commercial shipping.

AS the nation's economy heads into its third post-war recession, after a long period in which inflation was the primary concern, one thing at least has not changed. The Government's main weapon for dealing with the situation remains a powerful, somewhat mysterious amalgam of people and money called the Federal Reserve System.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 18 (AP) -- With clear weather, observers in the northern half of the United States should be able to see the second Soviet satellite twice on tomorrow evening.

BEFORE putting a new finish on an old piece of furniture its surface must be properly prepared. In some cases this involves merely cleaning off old wax and polish and dulling down any remaining gloss. Sometimes a complete removal of the old finish is required.

BOSTON -- A tourist looking for a hotel room with a convention in town is inclined to view the milling delegates as time wasters using up space he would like for his own family. But if he had had a chance to look behind the scenes with a group of Boston hotel men here the other day, he would have learned how important both kinds of customers are to the bonifaces.
The country's greatest transportation bargain, a Staten Island ferry ride is going to stay unchanged, despite rising costs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- An effort to raise money for the expansion and improvements of its school by a Chicago suburb has been held illegal. The suburb had imposed a charge of $300 per city lot against subdivision builders.

Clayton Skiffs, Inc., is showing a 26-foot model of the five cruisers it is building at a new plant in Toms River, N. J. The firm specializes in Jersey sea skiffs. It includes in its line boats of 34 and 23 foot lengths as well as the 26.
Nine outstanding athletes will be hailed tonight by the Sports Lodge of B'nai B'rith at the Hotel Roosevelt.

FIVE specialists who have found in nature photography both hobby and profession offer their knowledge, experience and enthusiasm in "Hunting With the Camera" (New York: Harper Brothers. 215 pages. 40 illustrations. $4.50).
BOSTON, Jan. 18 -- Invincible Ron Delany sent the 1958 indoor track season off to a rousing start tonight by ripping off a meet record 4:05 mile.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- R. H. Macy Co. announced today "substantial agreement" on plans for a new department store in the Westchester Terminal Plaza development.

ASSIDUOUS publicity has never succeeded in making Nathaniel Bacon- -kinsman of the great Sir Francis -- a star of the first magnitude among our national heroes. Yet he was a provincial figure of primary importance, and his name stands, along with those of Capt. John Smith and John Rolfe, as one of the most prominent in the early history of Virginia.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Senator Walter J. Mahoney has two Republican county chairmen in his front office for the 1958 legislative session.
PEIPING, Jan. 18 (Reuters) -- Three mothers who had expected to be starting their return trip to the United States today instead saw their imprisoned sons for the fifth time.

There is a new product on the market, selling for under $3, that can be attached to any size or style of outboard motor and will produce the same kind of easy handling found in an automobile equipped with power-steering.
A polar air mass sent temperatures tumbling below freezing yesterday in the metropolitan area. The Weather Bureau said the cold would intensify today.

TIJUANA, Mexico, Jan. 18 -- Bo Wininger lost a small decision to a Mexican motorcycle policeman today but then took the undisputed lead at the halfway mark of the $15,000 Tijuana open golf tournament.
The largest of the Chrysler Corporation's marine engines at the show is the Imperial V-275. Its smallest is one rated at 95 h. p.

FOR some fifteen years, two philosophies have been clashing against each other in the decisions of the Supreme Court, and with this significant book they break into open warfare. Up to now, the struggle has resembled a more or less polite duel of ironies and sarcastic allusions, which may have entertained the initiate but certainly left the general public in a state of mystification.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 18 (UP) -- Willie Hartack has an offer to ride Promised Land next Saturday in the estimated $170,000 Santa Anita Maturity at Santa Anita Park.
"The quest for peace can never be successful as long as the quest for power continues to be the motivating force in the world," the Rev. Dr. Louis C. Gerstein said in a sermon here yesterday.
INBAL, Dance Theatre of Israel, has proved to be so great a success at the Martin Beck Theatre that its engagement has been extended for an extra week. It will now run through Feb. 1.
SEAFORD, L. I., Jan. 18 -- Quick action by neighbors saved a little girl and her brother from death in the icy waters of Verity River, a canal that separates this village from Massapequa.
Thirty-five student nurses of Skidmore College received their caps last night at ceremonies in Alumni Hall, New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, 550 First Avenue.

A visiting Japanese educator expressed concern here last week that the educational systems in the United States and Japan eventually would suffer because they had "no influential philosophy" to guide them.

The Liberal party of New York proposed a twenty-one-point state legislative program yesterday as an atomic-age blueprint to "show the way to the fuller and deeper life." The Liberals went far beyond the spending and social-welfare proposals of the Democratic Administration of Governor Harriman.
Exploration for oil in the free world is at its highest level.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 18 -- If anyone had asked my father, who founded Evinrude Motors in 1909, to define outboarding as it exists today, it would be like getting a definition of space ships from the Wright brothers.

The Soviet trails the United States in most branches of science, Dr. Donald J. Hughes, senior physicist at Brookhaven National Laboratory, Long Island, told a conference of 200 high school science teachers yesterday at Fordham University, the Bronx.
VIENNA, Jan. 18 -- Austria, a country devoted to neutrality, is learning that it is the object of espionage nevertheless.
THIS Japanese-American novel by Capt. George Campbell, U. S. N. (retired), has just about everything in it except a sputnik. It even has the United States Army and Air Force.

There are eight displays at the show devoted to marine education. They cover hints on how to organize a boat club, safety rules and regulations, state and Federal boating laws, and charts and tide tables.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Barry Mackay of Dayton, Ohio, and Mike Green of Miami won their opening matches today in the Australian tennis championships. Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn, the other United States Davis Cup player who entered the tournament, underwent an emergency appendectomy.
A revolutionary 7 1/2 horsepower Diesel outboard motor is shown for the first time by American M. A. R. C., Inc., a California manufacturer of lightweight Diesel engines.
WAUKEGAN, Ill., Jan. 18 -- When asked how much longer I expect an industry like ours to continue to grow year after year, I find myself replying with a question of my own.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 18 -- As pleasure boating grows up into a sport for new millions of Americans, the design and styling of cruisers is changing constantly to reflect the demands of today's new-style yachtsman.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Eugenio Monti and Renzo Alvera, 1957 world two-man bobsled champions, won the Italian crown today and served notice they are ready to defend their international title in Germany, Jan. 25-Feb. 2.

MAXTON, N. C., Jan. 19 -- Five hundred Indians, including many armed with squirrel guns and hunting knives, balked a rally of 100 Ku Klux Klansmen near here tonight. The rally followed a flare-up in tension between Indians and white racists in this intensely segregationist farming community.

IT should be fairly obvious that a movie set in France should give off a pretty rich aroma of genuine French atmosphere. All of the great French films have done it -- all of them set in France, that is -- and because of this flavorsome distinction, they have been the more viable films.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 18 -- Gen. Robert E. Lee opposed the idea of a national park on the site of the decisive battle fought here nearly 100 years ago.

Penn Yan Boats, Inc., a builder of outboard hulls and canoes, has added lapstreak construction to some of its small boats for 1958. One of the new clinker-built craft at the show is the 16-foot Caribbean. These are wide and deep boats with full-skirted transoms that rise almost vertically from the water line.
Among this week's many art events are two benefit exhibitions.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 18 -- Tom Brown Jr. of San Francisco, who won two big tournaments in December, was elevated today from fourteenth to seventh place in the 1957 United States Lawn Association rankings.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Yale used a fast break in the second half tonight to defeat the Army Basketball team, 78 -- 56. It was Yale's sixth victory of the season.

AN all-out campaign to eradicate the imported fire ant is getting under way in the South. The control program -- which includes quarantine regulations and ground and aerial spraying -- should be in full swing by April.

FOND DU LAC, Wis., Jan. 18 -- While there have been estimates of outboard motor purchases as high as 700,000 in 1958, we subscribe to a more conservative forecast that purchases should approach 1956 levels, estimated by one marine trade association to have been 647,000 units.

IN this progressively gripping and expertly handled novel of adventure, Garland Roark brings to life the clipper ship world of the Eighteen Fifties, when vessels of unique American design, driven by tier on tier of canvas, set long-distance sailing records never equaled before or since.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- Six of Army's winter sports teams competing on the home front scored a clean sweep in the victory column to give the corps of cadets something to cheer about this wintry afternoon at the Military Academy.
Twenty-nine years ago eighteen New York and Long Island dealers formed the Marine Trades Association of New York, the first organization of marine retailers in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- A move within the Eisenhower Administration to lower interest rates on United States foreign aid loans in the worldwide economic war with the Soviet Union has been side-tracked for fear of protests from Congress, it was revealed today.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 18 -- It is rather difficult to predict what John Q. Public is going to demand next summer in the line of outboard boats, but it is a cinch that they will continue to be larger and roomier and more of the combination fishing-cruising-family type rather than just fast outboard runabouts.

CHICAGO -- In the midst of anguished cries from railroad operators that paying passenger traffic is melting away, the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, better known as the Burlington Route, has been quietly turning a handsome profit with its Slumbercoach service between here and Colorado Springs.

YONKERS, Jan. 18 -- Corporation Council J. Raymond Hannon has been directed by City Manager Charles L. Curran to prepare a preliminary draft of a proposed new state law to be offered in Albany to permit Yonkers to tap the pari-mutuel betting proceeds at Yonkers Raceway, it was learned today.

FORT MYERS, Fla. -- Sanibel Island's twenty-first annual Shell Fair, an event which attracts casual shell collectors and serious conchologists from all over the world, is scheduled for March 6-8 this year and the dredging of near-by bays and beaches for interesting exhibits has been underway for some weeks.

WHEN the present Mary Craig Sinclair was a young woman, the late George Sterling greeted her at first sight with the word "Goddess!" and wrote her a poem a day for a month. However, Mary Craig Kimbrough, who was born in Mississippi "in the midst of vast cotton plantations," did not marry George Sterling.

The Mary Washington Colonial Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution will give a bridge party on Feb. 10 at 2 P. M. in the ballroom of the Colony Club.
Princeton University's fencing team yesterday defeated City College, 17 to 10, at the losers' strip.

ENSENADA, Mexico -- First-time visitors from the United States sometimes experience momentary panic as they glance over Mexican hotel and motel rate lists. Here in Ensenada, for example, one might gather from a hasty inspection of such a list that rates at the better places run from $62.50 to $125 a day, without meals.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Walter O'Malley, his big problem of finding a playing field for the Dodgers settled, today plunged into the task of making the Memorial Coliseum into a baseball park.

A report on the activities of the United States National Committee for the International Geophysical Year during the period July 1-Nov. 30, 1957, is published in the current issue of Science, official weekly of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DURING the filming of "The Bridge on the River Kwai" in Ceylon last year, William Holden, one of its stars, got a cable from Hollywood. He had just been voted by film exhibitors the world's top box-office draw.

A proposal that Southern New York State, including New York City and Long Island, and Northern New Jersey form a separate region in the American Power Boat Association framework developed at the organization's council meeting in the Belmont Plaza Hotel yesterday.
