PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The Soviet sputniks, as Secretary Dulles so wisely recognized, undoubtedly stimulated a spasm of new thinking in the West. Because of this we may regard Russia's scientific triumph as beneficial to ourselves. Ideas are beginning to sprout in what was for too long a fallow democratic field.
ROME, Jan. 19 -- Pope Pius XII today praised the social importance and dignity of housework.
BOSTON, Jan. 19 -- Plans for the construction of a $1,000,000 hotel on the waterfront adjacent to the Logan International Airport in East Boston have been announced.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 19 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Kuomintang was strongly favored to win local elections held today in Taiwan. The elections were held to fill 1,025 seats in six municipal and fifteen county councils.
Loew's, Inc., reported a loss of $455,000 for the fiscal year ended Aug. 31, 1957.
Nineteen families who embarked on a career of foster care twenty-five years ago were honored yesterday. In that time they have assisted in the bringing up of a total of 306 youngsters.

Joan Brainerd, soprano, returned to the stage of Town Hall late yesterday afternoon in an interestingly diversified program. She was a winner of the Young Artists Auditions of the National Federation of Music Clubs in 1947 and made her Town Hall debut three years later.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Ford C. Frick, the commissioner of baseball, ruled today that the trade sending Jack Harshman, a pitcher, to the Baltimore Orioles would stand, but the Chicago White Sox must add something to the deal.
ROME, Jan. 18 -- Youth had its day on the Italian fashion scene today and most could, as the saying goes, have stood in bed.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 19 -- Plans were made here this week-end for a school strike tomorrow and a general strike on Tuesday in a major effort to overthrow Venezuela's dictatorial regime. Reports of a general strike were circulated by leaflets and word of mouth in this rumor-swept capital. Workers in the oil fields were urged to join the walkout.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he believed that the Soviet Government was not ready for an all-out war.

The city's next superintendent of schools believes that the nation must step up its entire educational program. He is Dr. John J. Theobald, now Deputy Mayor on leave from the presidency of Queens College.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The Government has asked Parliament to renew the 250 billion franc ($595,000,000) advance that the Bank of France gave last Nov. 6 for three months.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 19 -- A model recreation center and clubhouse for elderly people of all backgrounds will be built here on Soundview Avenue.
BOSTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens exploded for five last-period goals to trounce the Boston Bruins, 6 -- 2, tonight in a National Hockey League game before 13,909.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay and Eric Nesterenko each scored twice tonight to pace the Chicago Black Hawks to a 5-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.
This city is less hard hit than the rest of the state by recession-born unemployment. Jobless lists in the five boroughs have gone up less than half as fast in recent weeks as those upstate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Miss Frances G. Knight, Director of the Passport Office, seems a fair bet to become the most revolutionary figure in Government.

The American Civil Liberties Union asked Congress yesterday to make a "full evaluation" of the broadcasting spectrum. It said it was concerned with how additional channels could be provided to meet the public's need for diversity of information and opinion in radio and television programming.
Don Kennedy Sr., basketball coach of St. Peter's of Jersey City, denied yesterday that he had called his team's 59 -- 54 defeat by Dayton last night "the worst jobbing" he'd ever seen.

Cotton prices in the domestic market weakened last week on selling stimulated by reports from Washington about proposed farm legislation. At the close of trading Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 89 to 54 points ($1.95 to $2.70 a bale) from those of a week earlier.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Government and business circles have begun to diverge in the emphasis of their views about the desirability of maintaining a high bank rate of 7 per cent.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Negotiations for a new contract covering actors in filmed television commercials will get under way tomorrow in New York.

The season's first Wagnerian opera, "Tristan und Isolde," will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday evening, Feb. 1, as a feature of the fourteenth week of the season. Ramon Vinay and Martha Moedl will sing the name roles.

ETHEL MERMAN and Dinah Shore teamed last night for a fine song medley on the latter's program over Channel 4. Their interpretation of "I Got Rhythm" in counterpoint was a particular treat, a fitting climax to a sequence that highlighted the contrast between Miss Merman's wonderful driving stridency and Miss Shore's softer, more intimate style.
New Yorkers have been rallying to save the life of their free Shakespeare Festival with contributions ranging from a nickel to a check for $100.
Budget Director Abraham D. Beame got an unexpected pat on the back yesterday. It came from Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission, the unofficial watchdog of the city treasury.
KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Austria's Anderl Molterer won the nineteenth international Hahnenkamm ski races today by taking the slalom after finishing first in the downhill yesterday.
QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 19 (UP) -- An earthquake rocked northern Ecuador today. With a tidal wave that followed, it caused considerable damage and casualties in the Pacific port of Esmeraldas.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Tony Vincent of New York outlasted Gardnar Mulloy of Denver in a hectic second set today and went on to win the Coral Gables-University of Miami tennis final, 6 -- 3, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

THE news that James Emory Foxx was destitute jolted every baseball man. It had to. Here was one of America's great sports heroes, a one-time idol of the multitudes, with nothing except memories and debts. Yet there was something heartwarming about the way so many folks rushed to help him as soon as his plight was made known.
BERLIN, Jan. 19 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano said tonight that West Germany was "certainly willing to make true concessions" on disarmament.
The Royal Dutch Petroleum Company's offering of $228,000,000 of new common stock to its shareholders is in effect for a subscription period that will end on Fed. 10. Sub
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- Art Devlin, the 35-Year-old motel owner from Lake Placid, gained his second Class A ski-jumping triumph of the season today in the Norsemen Ski Club's meet.
Two teen-age partners won the senior dance title in the Middle Atlantic figure skating championships at the Iceland rink atop Madison Square Garden yesterday.

It's only by coincidence that four backfield members of last season's undefeated Pomfret School gridiron squad now are playing varsity hockey. Dick Flood, the hockey mentor, also is the Red and Black's backfield coach but he firmly maintains there's no connection.
This is the season when the largest fleet of vessels plying the Hudson River goes into mothballs for the winter. The fleet is made up of the 215 scows owned by the New York Trap Rock Corporation.

At a cost of a dozen pack horses, swept away in mountain torrents or engulfed in glacier crevasses, Russian scientists have established an observation station at 16,000 feet in the Pamir mountains of the Soviet Union.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Except for two fairly strong pushes, grain futures traded in a sticky market last week. All closed within 2 cents of where they began and most within 1 cent.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 19 -- President Eisenhower's plan for reorganization of the Pentagon will be offered "in the near future," Sherman Adams, the assistant to the President, said today.

MAXTON, N. C., Jan. 19 -- Two members of the Ku Klux Klan today faced charges of inciting to riot as the result of a clash between armed Indians and Klansmen last night. The Indians prevented 100 Klansmen from holding a rally.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- Snow clung to the hemlocks, ice sheathed the hillsides, the mercury dipped to 8 degrees and Arctic gusts shook the slab lodge.
ROME, Jan. 19 -- Roman couturiers Baratta, Gattinoni and Garnett came off with stellar honors in today's spring-summer fashion presentations with a strong assist from Italian fabric manufacturers.
Failure to meet production goals in both industry and agriculture were behind last month's shakeup of the Communist leadership in the Soviet republic of Kazakhstan, the Soviet press has indicated.

MANILA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Celestino Tugot of the Philippines won his second consecutive Far East open golf championship today with a birdie 3 on the second hole of a sudden-death play-off with Ben Arda.

On Jan. 10 The New York Times published an editorial entitled "African Preview" concerning mainly the report by the United Nations Visiting Mission on Belgium's trusteeship of the Ruanda-Urundi Territories.
The Board of Estimate will be asked to approve a $55,000 survey intended to safeguard from pollution six new beaches planned by the Park Department.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Jan. 19 -- Israeli officials said today that the new Mount Scopus agreement offered gains to both Israel and Jordan and that for once both sides appeared to be satisfied.
A request by the nation's railroads for Federal permission to increase freight rates on export-import shipments will come under heavy fire today.

The America Fore Loyalty Group of insurance companies reported over the week-end an increase of $35,778,463 in consolidated net premiums written last year. This boosted the yearend total to $464,970,334. Aggregate assets of the ten member companies slipped to $1,283,016,533, down $51,047,531 from the total reported on Dec. 31, 1956.

The memoirs of Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein, K. G., titled "The Sparks Fly Upward," will be issued late this year by World Publishing Company. Bernard Law Montgomery entered the British Army in 1908 and has served fifty years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A sweeping legislative program to coordinate and centralize all civilian scientific functions of the Government has been prepared for introduction in the Senate on Tuesday.
The start of several private housing projects for middle-income families is being delayed by differences within the Board of Estimate over tax exemption and city loans at low interest.
Why all this criticism of John Foster Dulles' foreign policy, especially in regard to Russia?
WRIGHTSVILLE, Ga., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Three members of a New York orchestra were among five persons killed in an automobile collision near her today.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The career of Vivian Ernest Fuchs is summed up in the affectionate name he is called by scores of Arctic, Antarctic and East African explorers. The name is Poppa.
The streets of New York City now measure more than 6,000 miles -- twice the distance from New York to San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon will share the Republican limelight on coast-to-coast television tomorrow night as the party opens an uphill fight to win the 1958 Congressional elections.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 19 (UP) -- Thirty-six yachts, sails billowing with a spanking breeze under clear skies, today started the 1,500-mile San Diego-to-Acapulco race.

Arthur Decker has been named a senior vice president and general manager of the Chicago office of Donahue Coe, Inc., effective Feb. 1. He had been a senior vice president in charge of administration and creative planning for the Buchen Company, a Chicago agency, for fourteen years.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 19 -- French authorities described today how a band of 200 guerrillas tricked, trapped and killed twenty-eight French artillerymen and took five prisoners.

In your editorial of Jan. 13 you called again for a study of the New York social insurance laws with particular reference to the benefit structure of the New York Workmen's Compensation and Unemployment Insurance Laws.
The General Foods Corporation set new records in sales and earnings for the quarter and nine months ended Dec. 31, according to the report released today.
The steamship charter market is "heading nowhere," in the opinion of many of the industry's leaders.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan has asked the Board of Estimate to authorize a ten-foot widening of Ninth Avenue between Forty-second and Fifty - seventh Streets.
HONG KONG, Monday, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Peiping radio said today that two non-Communist Cabinet members who had been branded as Rightists for criticizing the Communist regime had admitted their guilt.
The State Charities Aid Association reiterated yesterday its support of the controversial Youth Court Act, with amendments proposed by the Tweed Commission.

NAZE, Amami-O-Shima, Japan, Jan. 18 -- The people of Amami-O-Shima, five islands in the Northern Ryukyus chain that the United States restored to Japanese rule five years ago, want passionately to be reunited with their Okinawan kin under the Japanese flag.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of. California, joined yesterday in sending radio messages to the people of the Soviet Union.
LONDON, Monday, Jan 20 -- Trans - Antarctic Expedition headquarters announced early today that the main part of the Fuchs party had arrived at the South Pole.

TULSA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A crude bomb exploded tonight in the front yard of a home occupied by a Negro family. There were no injuries, the police said. A 14-year-old girl was treated for hysteria then released.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 -- California Republicans awoke today to the fact of a bitter intra-party battle over the Senatorial nomination.
The Soviet Union is working feverishly these days to expand its pig iron and chemical production sharply within a short period.

TRENTON, Jan. 19 -- Robert Morris, former counsel for the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee, charged today that the Republican party lacks effective leadership both in New Jersey and in Washington.

"ELEPHANTS," said Morel, "are different but not inferior." He had lived among the elephants of the Chad region of French Equatorial Africa and now he was circulating a petition asking that all African Governments ban the hunting of elephants. "I'd give anything to become an elephant myself," said Morel. If elephants were exterminated, he argued, that would be the end of freedom, dignity and natural splendor.
"Der Rosenkavalier" was staged at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday evening. Nicolai Gedda made his first Metropolitan appearance in the role of the Italian tenor.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Mayor Wagner announced today his own program for reorganizing the New York City Housing Authority. He assailed a Republican bill to reorganize it.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 19 -- Concern for education as a whole instead of "a frenetic, concentrated effort" to produce large numbers of scientists and engineers was urged today by Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Britain has turned to the United States for uranium fuel to use in future atomic power plants.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The United States has been quietly counseling moderation to both sides in the French - Tunisian dispute over four French military prisoners held by the Algerian rebels.

In presenting its trade program the Administration continues its unfortunate policy of stressing the point that lower American tariff will benefit our friends abroad, that strengthening them against communism.
The price tag for court reform in the state was put yesterday at roughly $2,200,000 a year.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 19 -- A sharp decline in Puerto Rican migration to the mainland last year was attributed here today to effects of the economic recession in the con tinental United States. The Puerto Rican Labor Department reported that 37,704 more persons left this island for the continent last year than returned here.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Thomas E. Murray Sr. eliminated himself today as a possible Democratic candidate for the Senate.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Breaking out of a tie in the last three minutes, the Syracuse Nationals won a hectic National Basketball Association game from the New York Knickerbockers, 112 -- 108, today. The victory enabled the Nats to maintain their grip on second place in the Eastern Division.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Jan. 19 -- Concern has been created here by an increase in unemployment to more than 100,000, against 40,000 a year ago.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 19 -- Prompt establishment of a bi-state transit district for the New York and New Jersey metropolitan area is being urged by the Transit Committee of Bergen County.
The feverish marketing race in the dentifrice industry is continuing. The Colgate-Palmolive Company is the latest entrant to come up with something new -- toothpaste in an aerosol container.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 19 -- The negotiations for the liberation of four French prisoners held by insurgent Algerian nationalists have run into a tactical snag.

Two composers of the Americas who are now working in the United States shared the program of the Composers Forum Saturday night in the McMillin Theatre of Columbia University. One is from Canada and the other from Uruguay.

A WEIRD heritage has fallen to the New York Institute of Technology in the windowless Pythian Temple at 135 West Seventieth Street. Before the first institute classes assemble there next month, college heads will have to dispose of a lot of ritualistic paraphernalia left in the Temple.
WARSAW, Jan. 19 -- Bedeviled by the failure of persuasion, Poland's rulers have decided to use stronger measures to re-enlist the country's writers for the cause of communism.
Greater opportunity for union members to oust officers who have lost their confidence was urged in a study made public yesterday by the Fund for the Republic.
Proposals to help university trustees oversee the kind and quality of education without infringing upon academic freedom were made public yesterday by Columbia University.

MAIN ROUSSEAU BOCHER, a 67-year-old Middle Westerner with a Paris patina, was recently asked what he thought constituted a well-dressed woman. In the Fifty-seventh Street salon where some of the world's most discerning women buy their clothes, Mainbocher gave his answer.

Gene Barry, motion picture actor, stands on the threshold of becoming another television hero of the old West. He has been selected to portray the title role in "Bat Masterson," a film series about the gunfighter, Indian scout and United States marshal.

Nine top-flight athletes were honored for "high principle and achievement in sports" at the seventh annual dinner of Sports Lodge 840, B'nai B'rith, last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt.

A floor in the office building rising at 200 East Forty-second Street has been leased by the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company for occupancy by the Robert E. Clancy Agency, now at 347 Madison Avenue. Feist Foist were the brokers, Collins, Tuttle Co., agents for the building, represented Joseph Durst, the builder and owner.

The first feelers have been put out by taxicab interests in New York City for a fare increase. These come in a letter to Abe Stark, President of the City Council, from a group of owner-drivers, and suggest that the "first drop" be raised to 50 cents from 25.

The Security Bureau in 1957 continued its role as a vigorous and militant force in the campaign against waterfront theft, obtaining forty-one convictions against offenders, Lloyd H. Dalzell said yesterday.

The Indian war whoop still brings terror to a little band of settlers in Robeson County, North Carolina, not far from the South Carolina frontier, who have organized to keep the white race pure and supreme. These characters somewhat resemble the little band of youths whom the police gathered up in Queens last week, except that they do not call themselves the United Nordic Confederation -- they prefer that quaint old designation, Ku Klux Klan.
OMURA, Japan, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- Sixty-nine South Koreans released from a Japanese prison camp here told today of attempts by North Korean prisoners to force them to join the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Congress awaits President Eisenhower's annual Economic Message tomorrow in the wake of a warning from the chairman of its major tax-writing committee of a possible need to reduce taxes.
A former Governor of Washington asserted yesterday that the real strength of the United States lay in its spiritual wealth and not in monetary resources or military might.

RUSSELL STANGER, an intense and vibrant young man from Massachusetts, made his New York debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. He led twenty-five members of the Boston Symphony Orchestra who were organized for the occasion under the name of the Stanger Chamber Orchestra.

DUBLIN, Jan. 18 -- A highlight of the Dublin fashion collections shown here last week was the opening of the Sybil Connolly new salon in one of the capital's finest Georgian residences. The decor evoked much admiration from the distinguished gathering present.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 -- A 300-acre tract in near-by West Norristown Township, Montgomery County, has been acquired by a syndicate of business men for a $25,000,000 industrial park.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- Two 15-year-old home club riders, Wendy Wright of Bronxville and Marie Kadel of Mount Vernon, divided the blue ribbons in the open events in the Saddle Tree Farms winter horse show today.
The Prison Association of New York said yesterday that a high rate of criminal backsliding could be cut by using all modern social resources to rehabilitate felons.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 19 (AP) -- An explosion was set off today near a Negro school.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- A thirty-two-man Soviet Antarctic expedition has completed 519 miles of a 1,420-mile trek to the Pole of Inaccessibility, in loose snow that made the going "very difficult," Moscow radio reported today.
Adolph . Bleiler has been elected president of First California Company, San Francisco brokerage concern and subsidiary of Blair Holdings Corporation.

The United Negro College Fund received $1,934,407 for its thirty-one member institutions last year, Lee H. Bristol, national campaign chairman, announced yesterday. The figure compared with $2,084,841 in 1956.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Britain's Stirling Moss, who only a few moments before the race removed a bandage from his injured eye, roared to victory today in the sixth annual Argentine Republic Grand Prix at the wheel of a Cooper-Climax British car.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 19 -- British Navy Technicians were landed from a warship today to help man power stations of this strike-bound colony.
A diesel - powered tugboat with three persons aboard was reported missing yesterday in Long Island Sound.

Bankers' acceptances out standing in the United States increased $83,747,000 in December, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. 'This compared with a decrease of $1,189,000 in November, 1957, and an increase of $42,314,000 in December, 1956.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 19 -- Except for minor incidents, order prevailed today as Guatemalans queued in long lines to vote in one of the country's most important presidential elections.

Emil Gilels played three Beethoven Concertos last night at Carnegie Hall with all the excitement and drive of a virtuoso and master pianist. He was accompanied by the Symphony of the Air under the direction of Alfred Wallenstein.
MOSCOW, Jan. 19 -- The Soviet travel agency Intourist may have to open a new branch office.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls won her fourth Tampa open golf tournament in five years today. She defeated Mickey Wright and Patty Berg by one stroke.
Students on The New York Times Youth Forum sharply questioned India's chief representative to the United Nations yesterday on his country's policies in Kashmir and toward the Soviet Union.
The golden jubilee service of the annual Chair of Unity Octave was marked in the New York area yesterday by a solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
PASSAIC, N. J., Jan. 19 -- "They say things will be better in the spring. But what do we do until spring?"
CLAYTON, Ala., Jan. 19 (AP) -- A South Alabama judge declared today that records of his court would be closed to Federal civil rights investigators.

The recommendations of the Prison Association of New York, which go to the State Legislature today as part of its 113th annual report, are prefaced by some useful philosophy about correctional affairs. One point is not confined to that field alone: nothing stimulates reform like some horror or catastrophe.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The Republican legislative leaders proposed today a new leisurely look at the problem of simplifying the State Constitution.
The chairman of the general canvass committee in the New York area for A Program for Harvvard College is George G. Walker. He is president of the Electric Bond and Share Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 -- A marine engineer and two seamen, all with Coast Guard clearance, were ordered off an American President Lines ship here yesterday for security reasons by the Military Sea Transportation Service.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Don Carter of St. Louis, the defender, tonight defeated Buzz Fazio, also of St. Louis, to win the national all-star match-game bowling tournament for the fourth time.

Fresh reports of food shortage in Indonesia offer still another sorrowful and ironic side light on the present troubled situation. In East Borneo some 50,000 persons are facing a rice "crisis" and thousands are said to have sold their personal belongings to purchase rice at inflated prices.

DETROIT, Jan. 19 (UP) -- The New York Rangers fired five goals in the last period tonight to defeat the Detroit Red Wings, 6 -- 1, for their third straight victory. The triumphy strengthened the Blues' hold on second place in the National Hockey League.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 19 -- The first change in the Cabinet formed by Premier Adnan Menderes last November was announced tonight, as Shemi Ergin, Minister of National Defense, resigned. The resignation followed a report by the Defense Ministry last week of a plot by Army officers to overthrow the Administration.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19 -- Steel buying remained on a hand-to- mouth basis last week. Inventories were still being cut and steel production was being trimmed to meet the lower volume of incoming orders.

So many thousands have visited the boat show in the New York Coliseum that an unexpected new hazard has developed. It is lost children, not just an isolated one or two youngsters, but rather surprising aggregates of them.
The big population increases that have been predicted -- and well publicized -- are not simply mathematical abstractions. They cast their signs before them -- and very real signs they are.

Thomas H. Hawks, president of the Rochester (N. Y.) Savings Bank, has been elected chairman of the Savings Bank Life Insurance Fund of New York. He succeeds Earl Hark-ness, president of the Greenwich Savings Bank, Manhattan, who will complete on July 1 his eighth year as a trustee, the maximum period fixed by the banking law.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Contrary to popular mythology, the State Department is not entirely resident in John Foster Dulles's earth-circling vest pocket.
Production and consumption of newsprint in December continued to lag behind year-earlier levels, according to trade association reports issued over the week-end.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 19 -- Unseeded Charles Brinton and Edward W. Madeira of Philadelphia upset the two top-seeded teams today to win the twenty-third annual Greenwich Country Club invitation squash racquets doubles tournament. Both victories were in straight games.
Wilt Chamberlain got back into action for the University of Kansas last week and the Jayhawkers' basketball fortunes began to climb again.

SPARKS OFF MY ANVIL. By James R. Adams. 171 pp. Harper Brothers, New York. $3. Not many writers can produce a book of worthwhile epigrams. This one contains short paragraphs of the author's thoughts on a variety of subjects, mostly connected with advertising.
Modern writers were criticized as "prophets of disgust and despair'' in a sermon here yesterday by the Rev. Hugh McCandless.

ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 19 -- Many cocktail parties, dinners and dessert gatherings are being planned to precede the sixth annual Community Ball of the Junior League of the Oranges, to be held Saturday, at Graulich's here.

SINCE music written for the clavichord is usually performed on the piano nowadays, it was interesting to hear a clavichord piece in its original instrumentation yesterday afternoon at the Amor Musicae concert at Carnegie Recital Hall.

IN the most elegant French restaurants here a compote of one or more stewed fruits is considered a fitting finale for most any meal. This applies even to stewed prunes, a dessert most of us tend to dismiss as uninspired.
Six new films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Business and labor attacked President Eisenhower's $73,900,000,000 record peace-time budget today on different grounds.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- A 150-ton shipment of arms, which French officials said was destined for the Algerian rebellion, was seized aboard a Yugoslav ship that was stopped off Oran yesterday morning.
John J. McCloy, a member of the Advisory Panel on the Gaither Report, said yesterday that this country had placed "too great emphasis on secrecy for our own good."
The American Jewish Congress yesterday urged the newly created United States Commission on Civil Rights to start a "massive attack upon the illegal movements of resistance to law and order."
Houston, Tex., Independent School District is putting $15,000,000 of bonds up for sale on Feb. 26. The obligations will come due serially from 1960 to 1987.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 19 -- These are the days of reckoning for Bulgarian men of letters.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The visit to Washington by the Premier of a Southeast Asian nation has injected a new idea into the debate about what could be accomplished at a top-level conference.
Cold weather and snow-covered fields forced postponement of virtually all of the soccer contests listed for the metropolitan area and other sectors in the East.

The action of the Federal Reserve Board in reducing stock market margin requirements last Wednesday from the 70 per cent level that had prevailed up to then for nearly three years, to 50 per cent, came, apparently, as a distinct surprise.
Mayor Wagner has appealed to the automobile industry to help relieve traffic congestion by manufacturing shorter and narrower cars.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Movie producers and distributors were advised today that they have been short-changing themselves by scheduling the release of big attractions during the Christmas holidays in the hope of a box-office killing.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Billy Olson, a 27-year-old accountant from Eau Claire, Wis., won the Norge Ski Club jumping title today in suburban Fox River Grove.

The Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr said yesterday that Americans should get used to the idea that they were disliked because they were powerful, and that they would be imperfect no matter how virtuous they strove to be.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 19 -- State Senator Walter H. Jones, Republican of Bergen County, announced today that he had received assurances from three Governors that they would support his fight against state income taxes on nonresidents.
SOUTH POLE, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Sir Edmund and a group of Americans led by Rear Admiral George Dufek formed a welcoming committee at the South Pole today for Dr. Fuchs and his British expedition.

ZURICH, Jan. 19 -- Trading in German dollar bonds over the counter featured financial business here last week. Prices shot up after the Deutsche Bundesbank announced on Thursday that a cut in the bank rate, from 4 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent, would be effective Friday. The bond market in Zurich followed closely that in Frankfurt.
DANVILLE, Ill., Jan. 19 (AP) -- A wild west-type robbery thriller replete with gunplay ended early today with three men jailed and three hostages of one gunman freed unharmed.

The relations of Poland to the rest of the Communist bloc have suddenly come to the center of world attention as a result of recent developments. Of these the most dramatic, of course, is the news of Nikita S. Khrushchev's originally secret visit to Poland and his conference with the highest Polish leaders.

The Inland Waterways Common Carriers Association is slated to appear before the Senate Subcommittee on Surface Transportation to defend the importance of inland water transportation to the economy of the nation, A. M. Thompson, president of the organization said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- What can a lawyer do when a client rejects his advice and refuses to abandon some activity that the lawyer considers improper?

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis tied Andy Korenak Jr. of near-by West Allis for the senior men's title in the Great Lakes speed-skating championships today. A disqualification cost Bartholomew outright possession of his fifth crown.
Iced coffee flowed in Twenty-third Street yesterday -- hundreds of gallons of it, all of it free but none of it fit to drink.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- A British bank has challenged the widely held belief that when the United States sneezes economically the rest of the world gets pneumonia.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Monday, Jan. 20 -- Indonesia and Japan are signing a treaty of peace here today, sixteen years after invading Japanese forces brought World War II to these islands and opened the way for the end of three centuries of Dutch colonial rule.

MAX POLLIKOFF and his fellow enthusiasts for contemporary music got their third "Music in Our Time" series off to a lively start yesterday. And the opening program, besides having musical interest, had the features of informality and friendliness that have contributed to the success of the concerts in the past.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) -Mark Antony, an Irish-bred colt owned by Mrs. John Payson Adams, startled most of the 19,221 bettors today at Hialeah by winning the $5,000 Seagull Purse.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Bert Bell, the Commissioner of the National Football League, today said the use of Penn's Franklin Field by the Philadelphia Eagles had "saved pro football for Philadelphia."
SAN DIEGO, Jan. 20 (UP) -The eighty-one-foot sloop Windward tonight held the lead in actual distance covered in the 1,500-mile San Diego-Acapulco yacht race it was reported tonight.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 20 -- More than 500 foreign buyers, with Germans outnumbering Anglo-Americans four to 1, loosened their purse strings today as the fifteenth Florence Fashion Show opened its sportswear presentation at Pitti Palace.
A massive young man who has been pushing his weight around in New York these days is Henry Korn, a 17-Year-old senior from Archbishop Stepinac High who is a shot-putter extraordinaire.
VASTERAS, Sweden, Jan. 20 (AP)-- Sweden opened the tomb of King Erik XIV today after wondering for, 380 years whether he died from pea soup. A belated inquest will be held.

MOST of us do not need to be reminded of the good taste and high nutritive value of cheddar cheese. But one fact about this well-liked food has not received the prominence it deserves: While other edibles have been rising in cost, cheddar has been selling at the same price level for the last three years. Sharp cheddar is generally about 75 cents a pound; the mild and processed varieties, about 55 cents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UP) -- The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court today to make a broad general ruling in the Federal-state dispute over the ownership of submerged lands off the Gulf coast beyond the three-mile limit.
